HEADLINE: Japan Stocks Fall Sharply

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Tokyo stock prices tumbled more than 5 percent today on the widespread selling of long cash-index positions by futures arbitragers before regaining nearly a percentage point. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 1,153.12 points, or 4.22 percent, to close at 26,176.43. 
Selling fueled by concerns over the Persian Gulf sent the Japanese index plunging as much as 1,411.74 points, or 5.17 percent, to 25,917.81, in afternoon trading. The Nikkei finished the morning session down 763.12 points, or 2.79 percent, to 26,566.43 - the first time it had fallen below the 27,000 level in more than two years. On Friday, the gauge fell 286.18 points.
''The Nikkei has been dropping almost every day,'' said a trader at a foreign brokerage. ''There is a growing number of people who think it will fall to levels that were inconceivable only a year ago. They say it could fall as low as 23,000 or 22,000.''
In earlier trading, the dollar firmed on the Nikkei's drop and on the news that an Iraqi soldier killed a British business executive attempting to flee from Kuwait to Saudi Arabia.
The dealers expect the dollar's long-term trend to remain negative because of concerns over an economic slowdown in the United States. Some of the traders fear the cost to the United States deploying forces in the Middle East will make it harder to cut its budget deficit.
In trading in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was down further, at 3,067.73, compared with 3,078.97 on Friday. The index has fallen 11.23 percent since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
''The current tension in the Middle East makes it too risky for bargain-hunting on a grand scale,'' said Richardson Wong, a broker at Sun Hung Kai Securities here.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Iraqi Invasion Adds To Markets' Problems

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The world's stock markets have quickly declined since Iraq invaded Kuwait 12 days ago. But the invasion's dramatic impact merely exaggerated the problems already troubling the world markets.
Before the invasion early on Aug. 2, the markets were already being weighed down by worries about inflation, high interest rates worldwide, poor corporate earnings and slowing growth in several leading countries.
By driving up oil prices and raising the specter of higher inflation and slower economic growth, all the problems are now worse. Long-term interest rates around the world have already risen, depressing bond markets and drawing more investors away from the stock markets. 
 
Markets Likely to Head Lower
''The Middle East is keeping people very nervous and keeping people in cash,'' said David A. Robbins, head of the international securities department at UBS Securities in New York. Even without an escalation in the Persian Gulf, he said, world markets are likely to drift lower.
A rally will be difficult, he said, because investors will be unwilling to commit themselves even to bargains until some resolution to the crisis appears. ''And whenever you get a bad piece of news out of the gulf,'' he added, ''the markets will sell off again.''
Earlier this year, the Tokyo stock market had been troubled by high interest rates and a weak currency, and the Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell to 28,002.07 on April 2. The Nikkei then bounced back to above 33,000, but new concerns that the Bank of Japan would push interest rates higher to slow the economy and curb inflationary expectations started a new decline July 20. Before the invasion, the Nikkei had already fallen 7 percent from the 33,000 level. On Friday, the index closed at 27,329.55.
In Britain and the United States, high interest rates, economies near the brink of recession and disappointing earnings had already turned the markets sour after spring and early- summer rallies.
 
Consequences of Unification
In West Germany, despite the future potential of the development of Eastern and Central Euorpe, the near-term cost and inflationary consequences of the unification of the two Germanys were helping to keep the stock market from rising to a new high.
France, the darling to which investors fled in the spring when West Germany faltered after rising to record levels, was softening under high interest rates. Switzerland, like France, had taken a turn and rose to new highs in late May and early June but was falling back. And the attractive smaller markets, like Spain and Italy, were having trouble keeping up their momentum.
Only Mexico, Hong Kong and Austria, of the 24 markets in the Financial Times world indexes, were rallying before the invasion. And only Mexico, with its oil cushion, was resilient after Aug. 2.
 
Big Drop in the Markets
Since the invasion, world stock markets as a whole have fallen 6.7 percent and are down 16.22 percent in terms of local currencies for the year, according to The Financial Times world indexes.
The markets that have taken the worst beating are Singapore, down 12.59 percent in local currency; Hong Kong, off 12.10 percent; Malaysia, down 11.18 percent; Austria, off 10.87 percent, and Japan, down 8.51 percent.
The shock from oil prices, which jumped $8 a barrel after the invasion, sent Tokyo's weak market even further down. Japan imports almost all its oil, with about 70 percent coming from the Middle East.
Until the invasion, Hong Kong had been on a rally that took it up 18 percent since May and pushed the local Hang Seng Index far past the high before the market collapsed after the Tiananmen Square massacre June 4, 1989. Austria, which has been favord for its connections with Eastern Europe, especially Hungary, was inching back close to its high for the year. Both had probably overstreched themselves, which made the decline that followed a little steeper.
 
South Africa Is Flat
The country whose stocks fared the best, South Africa, is virtually unchanged when the index is measured in the local currency, the rand. Other countries that did relatively well included Mexico, down nine-tenths of 1 percent; Australia, off 1.63 percent; Canada, down 1.95 percent, and Norway, off 2.98 percent. Those countries benefited from having strong oil and gas interests.
The decline in Britain, which was 4.71 percent, was mitigated by the country's North Sea oil production. But oil plays a far less important role in the British economy now than it did 10 years ago.
The United States was just above the middle of the pack, falling 5.52 percent. Italy, down 9.26 percent, and Spain, off 9.65 percent, fell fairly sharply, partially because their earlier rallies had been so dependent on foreign investors, who moved out quickly after the Iraqi invasion.
The decline in markets since the beginning of August left the rankings for the year generally intact. Mexico, Austria and Norway are the top three performers and Japan is still at the bottom. The biggest moves were made by the countries whose markets were helped by oil or gold. South Africa jumped from 21st to 15th for the year and Britain moved from 12th to 7th. Malaysia fell from 11th to 17th, and France from 15th to 20th.
 
Gold Prices Rebound
Except for precious metals and minerals, to which many investors rushed as a safe haven, no sector of the world's economy was unscathed. And despite a 1.24 percent rise in gold and other precious metal stocks, the sector is still down 10.12 percent for the year because the price of gold had fallen sharply to around $360, from more than $420 in February. But the Iraqi invasion has given gold a boost. On Friday, gold was up more than $11 for the day, to $396.90 in New York, very close to the psychologically crucial $400 level.
Even the oil-company stocks, the best defense in an oil-shocked market, are down on average by four-tenths of 1 percent since the invasion. There were gains by some companies, like British Petroleum, up 7.12; Sasol, the South African refiner, up 15.37 percent, and Saga Petroleum of Norway, up 14 percent. But others, which have to buy much of the oil they process, will be hurt as the price increases.
The fear of a slowing economy as a result of higher oil prices and the possiblity of loss of contracts hurt the engineering and shipbuilding industry, whose stocks declined 12.48 percent. Slower growth, which would mean a weaker housing sector, also hurt construction, down 11.56 percent, and appliances, down 10.83 percent. And the higher price of oil knocked the automobile sector down 10.65 percent.

HEADLINE: Previous Exports to Iraq May Prove Costly for U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
President Bush's freeze on Iraqi assets and financial dealings may prove costly to the United States Government, which has guaranteed the payment of $1.7 billion that Iraq owes for the purchase of American farm products.
According to the Commodity Credit Corporation, an arm of the Agriculture Department that guarantees payment for agricultural exports, foreign and American banks have begun to file notices of Iraq's failure to make payments. Including interest, Iraq owes nearly $2 billion, of which about $1.8 billion would be covered by the commodity credit guarantees. 
Iraq imports about three-fourths of its food and was the 10th-largest foreign customer for American agricultural products in 1989, buying about $1 billion worth of products ranging from barley malt to yeast.
''Bank notices that they have not been paid according to schedule are starting to come in now,'' said Richard Godsey, chief of the credit sales registration branch of the Commodity Credit Corporation. Banks have 30 days after filing notices to assemble documents and make their claims. Such documents have not yet been submitted, ''but it seems to be a foregone conclusion they will be,'' Mr. Godsey added. Under the export-guarantee program, Iraq was not required to pay immediately. Instead, American banks and American branches of foreign banks would pay grain companies and other exporters, and then wait for repayment from an Iraqi bank that had issued a letter of credit. The Iraqi bank would usually be the Government-owned Rafidain Bank of Baghdad, the nation's largest, which does not have a good reputation in financial markets. But until recently it had met all payments on letters of credit for agricultural imports.
If Iraq does not pay the banks, the credit corporation is to pay for 98 percent of the exports' value, plus 4.5 percentage points, or roughly half of the interest being charged by the banks on the three-year credit agreements. A higher interest rate equal to that on one-year Treasury bills is covered for exports with a 10-year repayment period.
The export guarantee program was started in the early 1980's to stimulate purchases of American agricultural products. Iraq had been active in the program.

HEADLINE: Freeze on Iraqi Assets Expected to Cost U.S. Banks Little

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The freeze on Iraqi and Kuwaiti investments and bank deposits announced by President Bush and officials of other Western countries last week is not likely to be costly to American banks, according to Government data and bankers' estimates.
The intent of the freezes is to punish Iraq and reinforce the United Nations embargo on trade, while protecting Kuwaiti Government assets from seizure by Iraq. Bankers say their biggest problem has been deciding which Kuwaiti accounts are Government controlled and subject to the freeze.
''The background information about the accounts was available, but it was not all immediately at hand in a single place,'' one New York banker said. Several bankers said the close relationship between businesses owned by members of Kuwait's ruling family and state-owned activities had made it hard to distinguish between private and Government assets. 
 
Administrative Headaches
As bankers wait for the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control to provide more details by Aug. 18 about which Kuwaiti accounts are deemed to be Government controlled, they are applying for special licenses to handle transactions like payments of interest and dividends that do transfer Kuwaiti assets to Iraq.
Bankers have complained about the administrative headaches and have worried that some Kuwaiti clients would be angered by the freeze. They said the freeze had been far less disruptive than the 1979 freeze of Iranian assets, which affected more than $9 billion on deposit at American banks.
Because other countries joined the United States in freezing assets of Iraq and Kuwait, overseas branches of American banks have avoided the delicate and unclear issue of whether they are bound by policies of the United States or the country where they are situated.
 
Easing of Restrictions Begun
In recent days, governments have begun to ease restrictions on Kuwaiti accounts and allow ordinary business dealings. Swiss officials, for example, announced Friday that banks could allow transfers out of Kuwaiti Government accounts, so long as assets do not go to private hands, or to Iraqi controlled accounts.
Even before the attack on Kuwait, American banks had been wary about lending to Iraq because the country's finances are in precarious condition. The country's largest bank, Rafidain Bank in Baghdad, ''was not regarded as a reliable guarantor,'' one American banker said.
A Federal Reserve survey of American banks found loans to Iraq at the end of March totaled $575 million, of which $463 million was backed by guarantees from non-Iraqi sources, often agencies of European governments. Losses on the remaining $112 million of non-guaranteed loans could be reduced by banks' holdings of Iraqi deposits.
 
Effect on New York Banks
Big banks in New York declined to say exactly how much they could lose in their dealings with Iraq, but said their exposure was small. A spokesman for Citibank, the most active American bank in the Persian Gulf area, said the risk of loss to Iraq was ''zero.'' Officials at Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, J. P. Morgan and the Bank of New York said their exposure was minimal.
Sharif Ghalib, director of the Africa/Middle East department at the Institute for International Finance in Washington, estimated last week that institutions in other parts of the world were more vulnerable than United States banks to Iraqi loan losses.
Mr. Ghalib estimated that Iraq was in arrears on about $4 billion of debt, much of it loans from government agencies of France, Britain and Italy used to finance imports.
 
Estimate of $35 Billion Owed
By Mr. Ghalib's estimates, Iraq owes about $25 billion to banks, businesses and governments in Western nations and Arab countries besides Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Another $10 billion is owed to Eastern European counties, including $6 billion to the Soviet Union.
Little is known about Iraq's debts to Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, except that they are large and were mostly accumulated during Iraq's war with Iran. Mr. Ghalib estimated that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait had supplied a total of $47 billion to $64 billion since late 1980.
''Interest has never been paid on that money,'' he said, ''and I do not think it was regarded as a loan that would ever be repaid.''
 
Banks' Risk of Losses
Determining the risk of loss from loans to Iraq is difficult because there is no single source of complete information and there are many conflicts and inconsistencies. Data from the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland, for example, show Iraq's claims, or deposits, in 11 developed Western countries totaled $2.9 billion, while claims on Iraq, or loans from those countries, were nearly $8.3 billion.
Jonathan Crusoe, an editor at Middle East Economic Digest in London, estimated that loans by agencies of the Governments of Japan and France totaled $4.5 billion and $4 billion, respectively. Lenders in Italy have well over $2 billion in loans to Iraq, primarily through the Government-owned Banca Nazionale del Lavaro.
 
Bank Dealings With Kuwait
Bankers generally do not think they are exposed to losses on their dealings with Kuwait, which has long invested widely and wisely around the world. Mr. Ghalib of the Institute for International Finance estimated that Kuwaiti Government assets, excluding money lent to Iraq and other illiquid investments in Arab countries, probably total about $80 billion. Another $25 billion to $30 billion is held by individuals and corporations, he said.
Within the banking system, data of the Bank for International Settlements, covering banks in 11 developed countries, show the Kuwaiti Government and businesses holding about $16.3 billion of deposits at banks, with loans of only about $7.5 billion. The biggest risk from the invasion of Kuwait may be borne by Arab banks, many of them based in Bahrain, that have made big loans to Kuwaiti businesses, bankers said.
As a large investor whose intentions, if known, could cause big price changes, Kuwait has kept most of its financial dealings secret. But Kuwaitis are known to have invested heavily in the oil business. For example, the Kuwaiti Government acquired the Santa Fe International Corporation, based in Alhambra, Calif., for $2.5 billion in 1981.
Estimates of Kuwaiti investments range from about $4.2 billion, according to a Commerce Department count, to more than $40 billion. Mr. Ghalib said Kuwait's investment in the United States is $15 billion to $20 billion, including real estate and securities. Investments in Britain are about $28 billion to $37 billion, he said, with another $13.3 billion in Japan, $2.8 billion in Switzerland and $2.5 billion in Spain.

HEADLINE: SHIPS TURN AWAY FROM PORTS AS IRAQ EMBARGO TIGHTENS; U.S. MILITARY FORCE POURS IN;
U.S. Alliances Recast

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The Persian Gulf crisis is recasting the United States' relations with two of its oldest Middle East allies, Israel and Jordan.
 
Upset by the support
King Hussein of Jordan has been giving Iraq in the crisis, Administration officials said today that if the Jordanians allow Iraq to use the Red Sea port of Aqaba to break the United Nations trade embargo, then the United States Navy will blockade Iraqi shipping seeking to use the port.
Such news will make it clear to King Hussein, who often used to boast that he counted every American President since Dwight D. Eisenhower, especially George Bush, as a personal friend, how far Jordan and the United States are drifting apart. For his part, the King said the United States forces in the region had created an ''explosive situation.''
 
Israel Urged to Lie Low
While the Administration is seeking to induce King Hussein to drop his support for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and join in the anti-Baghdad boycott, the Bush team has been asking Israel to keep quiet and not to undertake any military actions in the gulf. It is no accident that virtually the only two Middle Eastern leaders whom President Bush has not telephoned since the gulf crisis began are the Iraqi President and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. 
The Israelis did get a call, but of a different nature. According to Administration officials, the first phone call made by the United States to any Middle East nation on the night Iraq invaded Kuwait went from Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, to Israel's Ambassador in Washington, Moshe Arad.
Mr. Kimmitt, officials said, told the Israeli Ambassador that Washington wanted Israel to keep its head down and its guns holstered. The more public the Israelis were, and the more active they were on the military front, the more difficult it would be for the United States to assemble and maintain an Arab coalition against Iraq. Since then Mr. Arad has met regularly with senior Administration officials, but always in private and without fanfare.
Israeli leaders have indicated that, for now at least, they understand and are prepared to cooperate by quietly sharing their intelligence on Iraq with Washington and to support American military moves in the gulf through a variety of means. What these might be the Pentagon and Israeli officials decline to disclose, but they are understood to be extensive. Officials said that Mr. Shamir sent Mr. Bush a private letter on Thursday assuring him that Israel was prepared to cooperate to deter ''Iraqi aggression'' in any way that Washington suggested.
 
A Meeting Is Postponed
For now, that way is for Israel to remain as unobtrusive as possible. Administration officials were relieved when it was decided that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would go to Turkey at the end of last week, precisely when he was scheduled to meet in Washington with Israel's new Foreign Minister, David Levy, to talk about Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.
American officials wanted the Baker-Levy meeting postponed so that no picture would be sent around the Middle East showing Mr. Baker and Mr. Levy standing together in the State Department lobby. The officials were also concerned by reports quoting leaders of Israel's governing right-wing Likud Party as saying that the Iraqi invasion proved that the real problem in the Middle East was not the Palestinian issue but rather the belligerent nature of certain Arab nations.
American officials said Ambassador Arad told his superiors in Jerusalem that for the sake of United States-Israel relations it would be best that they forgo making strident propaganda points at this time and to lie low. Mr. Arad is also understood to have told his superiors that while the crisis was underscoring Israeli arguments about the violent nature of Middle East politics and highlighting Israel's value as a loyal ally, it could in the long run rebound to Israel's disfavor.
In particular, Israeli officials are concerned that a ''bonding'' between the United States and the Arab world is now taking place at all levels, from the President down to the foot soldier stationed in Saudi Arabia. If the Iraq crisis is resolved, some Israeli analysts predict, the moderate Arab countries will say to Washington: ''We helped you turn back the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and we paid a high political price for that in our countries, now you have to help us roll back the Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza. How can you be opposed to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and not the Israeli occupation of the West Bank?''
 
What Washington Wants
Answering such a question could become all the more urgent for Washington if President Hussein succeeds in painting the leaders of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria and the gulf Arab nations as ''lackeys'' of the United States and Israel. Israel occupied the West Bank after King Hussein refused to heed an Israeli warning to stay out of the 1967 war in the Middle East and the Jordanian Army opened fire on Israeli troops.
For now, though, it is Jordan's cooperation that the Administration wants most to complete the encirclement of President Hussein. It will not be easy to enlist.
King Hussein has no illusions about the Iraqis. It was President Hussein's predecessors in the Iraqi Baath Party who, in 1958, burst into the Rihad Palace in Baghdad and pumped bullet after bullet into his Hashemite cousin, King Faisal, then the ruler of Iraq. In addition, Jordan, already $9 billion in debt, gets 95 percent of its oil from Iraq, as well as a large percentage of its foreign currency from Iraqi shipping through Aqaba. It receives just $50 million in aid from the United States, compared with $2 billion a year that goes to Egypt.
Finally, the King is a lonely man in a dangerous neighborhood. He has watched in recent years as his tacit allies in Israel's Labor Party, who moved troops to save him from Syria in 1970, have been replaced by a Likud Party that boasts it is prepared to allow Jordan to be turned into a Palestinian nation. For its part, Washington, having tired of the King's equivocations on peace with Israel, decided to bet its big money on President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. The King gradually found himself an orphan.
 
Between Two Worlds
King Hussein now stands torn between two worlds. On one side, he hears the economic grievances of his predominantly Palestinian refugee population, which has not shared in the wealth of the oil boom and which identifies with President Hussein's attack on the rich oil sheikdom of Kuwait. On the other side, he has always had more in common in terms of family and heritage with the ruling Sabah tribe in Kuwait and the Saud tribe in Arabia than with a gunman-turned-politician like President Hussein. Whatever their shortcomings as leaders, the Sauds and Sabahs were always men of limits, unlike President Hussein, who keeps taking the King across lines he has never before crossed.
''The King is now trapped between his Arab obligations, his international obligations and his desire to survive,'' said Marvin C. Feuerwerger, an expert on Jordan at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. ''He saw what happened to his cousin. He saw what happened to his fellow Arab kings, and he made a strategic choice to side with Iraq in hopes that this will put him at the bottom of Saddam Hussein's enemies' list. This is not a good time to be a traditional monarch on the border of Iraq.''

HEADLINE: Environmentalism vs. Jobs Troubles Taos

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QUESTA, N.M.

 BODY:
In isolated pockets of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, it is possible to gaze for miles and lose track of the century.
It might seem that this remote region still belongs to the Pueblo Indians, whose adobe buildings have stood for 800 years, or to the Spaniards who followed the conquistadors, or to the descendants of later settlers who rode the trail blazed by Kit Carson.
In fact, the land is home to all these cultures. Now another wave of newcomers is settling here in Taos County, as the pristine setting and slower pace of life draw affluent people from faraway urban centers. And once again, old practices are being challenged by new values and interests. 
The newcomers are among the most vocal elements in an environmental movement that is fighting a proposed disposal site for waste from a molybdenum mine, which has provided relatively high-paying jobs for several generations of Hispanic workers.
In Taos County, where the unemployment level exceeds 15 percent, and where the average household has an income of less than $10,000 a year, the dispute has uncovered bitter feelings about class, race and roots.
''The people I work with don't have trust funds, and they can't sell a painting for a few thousand bucks,'' said LeRoy Phillippi, a social worker whose Spanish ancestors settled here in the 1600's. ''We all want blue skies and clean ground water, but people shouldn't have to starve to death, either. You can't hear the birds and the streams when your stomach is grumbling with hunger.''
Environmentalists say the construction of disposal pits, which would be visible from some roads, would scar the mountainside and disrupt wildlife. The miners say they fear losing their jobs if the Bureau of Land Management, which is reviewing the mine's application, does not approve a new disposal site.
David Bates, president of the Taos Environmental Association, said a disposal pit would harm the region's worth as a recreational attraction.
''It's not in the region's best interest,'' said Mr. Bates, who designs adobe-style homes, chiefly for newcomers from California and the East.
Around the country, such disputes have become increasingly common since facsimile machines and computer modems have allowed many professionals to live amid the quiet beauty of rural regions while maintaining easy contact with urban centers.
Environmentalists say these people often serve as protectors of the natural splendor. But many longtime residents of these remote areas complain that their economies, which are already struggling, are being further hampered by newcomers with more empathy for wildlife than for wage earners.
The owner of the mine, Molycorp, says it is running out of room for disposal of tailings, the crushed rock that is the residue of molybdenum mining. Moly, as the miners call it, is a metallic element used to make alloys like stainless steel.
 
Plan for Disposal Site
''People come here and talk about retaining the culture,'' said LeRoy Apodaca, manager of administration at Molycorp. ''Well, mining has been part of the culture in these parts since the middle of the 1800's. We're willing to do all we can to show our commitment to the environment. But you can only go so far until you start looking somewhere else. And shutting down the mine here would severely disrupt the lives of a lot of people.''
Molycorp, a subsidiary of the Unocal Corporation of Los Angeles, asked permission to build the disposal pit in the saddle of Guadalupe Mountain, a few miles west of the mine. The dump would cover 568 acres that now are juniper and pinyon forest. The company said it had room for disposal for 8 to 10 more years but must make a decision much sooner about whether the mine would remain usable beyond that time.
Lee Keesling, a spokesman for the Bureau of Land Management, said alternatives were also being studied by the agency. Before making a ruling, it will assess effect a new pit would have on the environment and gauge the sentiments of people who live in the region, he said.
In the tiny town of Questa, virtually every family has a member who has worked for the mine. In 1985 nearly 900 workers were employed there. But the falling price of molybdenum - in part, a result of a slump in oil-exploration, which uses a lot of the element - has cut its employment here to fewer than 300 workers. Because there is so little other work, those who have been laid off must move or wait to be called back to jobs that pay $10 an hour and more.
Many of the unemployed workers fear that opposition to a disposal pit among ''Anglos with rich parents,'' as one idled miner put it, will doom their chances to return to work.
 
'I've Got to Feed My Family'
''I appreciate that these people like our scenery, but I've got to feed my family,'' said Steven Garcia, 41 years old, who has been out of work since 1986.
Writers and artists have been coming to Taos County since before the turn of the century, drawn by the natural beauty and the unusual culture here. Pueblo Indians have endured for 1,000 years here. And the Spaniards who followed Coronado have retained a distinctive culture, largely because of the mountain region's isolation. The language of the Spanish descendants, for example, derives from 17th-century Castilian.
In recent years, Taos has increasingly been a magnet for prosperous newcomers with a love for the environment. Some still work for companies in distant cities. Some are retired. Others have sold homes elsewhere, shed their business suits and started careers as crafts dealers or proprietors of bed-and-breakfast inns.
A few years ago, there were no such inns here; now there are about 30. Some of these people are known here as ''yoarpies,'' or, young almost-retired professionals.
 
Reasons for Migration
''A lot of us came because we have certain environmental concerns,'' said Randy Pelton, who quit his job as an advertising director in Santa Monica, Calif., and moved here with his wife, Carol, to open a bed-and-breakfast inn, the Hacienda del Sol.
Mr. Pelton said they chose Taos because they appreciated the ''cross-cultural experience'' here and because they liked to ski.
''We're trying to get away from what's already been ruined,'' he said. ''Many of the people here take things for granted. But then, given that we didn't do so well with the environments we came from, I suppose we should be more open-minded.''
Mr. Bates, who settled here 17 years ago after studying philosophy at Yale Graduate School, said the movement to places like Taos County is not entirely new.
''But it's different than the migration of the 60's, where you had a lot of young people coming out here to live in teepees and communes,'' he said. ''Now it's more middle-aged people who have become sensitized to what's going on in modern America. They're no longer seduced by the chase. They want clean air, natural beauty and a slower pace.''
Environmentalists concede that the mining issue has largely divided people by economic class, but they note that some natives share their opposition to the mine.
Joe Vigil has organized rallies and petition drives to fight the mine's plan. Mr. Vigil told the hearing sponsored by the Bureau of Land Management that the region's spiritual connection to the mountains was endangered. ''That mountain is like a mother to us,'' he said.
But Phil Rael, who began working at the mine 26 years ago, said the primary concern here ought to be ways to support families.
''What's a working man in Taos County supposed to do?'' he asked. ''I've got a house. I've raised my children. This is what I know how to do. What's wrong with that?'' Mr. Bates and others contend that mining does not provide a healthy source of support.
''My understanding of mining is that it creates a boom and bust cycle,'' he said. ''People get paid high wages one year, so they go out and buy expensive vehicles. Then they get laid off the next year, so they can't make the payments.''
The miners and their supporters consider such a view to be condescending. Moreover, they detect some hypocrisy among the more affluent environmentalists.
''They want to get back to nature, so they come out here and build the old wood-burning stoves,'' said Mr. Phillippi, the social worker. ''On some mornings, when they've all got their stoves going, you can't see the mountains because of the haze.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordan Denounces U.S. For 'Explosive' Tactics

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 13

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan, whose position in the gulf crisis has been equivocal, accused the United States in a speech published today of creating an ''explosive situation'' that threatens the entire Middle East.
The King appeared to be aligning his country with Iraq, although he did not formally take Baghdad's side in the angry speech to his country's Parliament. ''Foreign ambitions in this region serve the purposes of the enemies of the Arab nation and are designed to help achieve the enemy's objectives by depriving the Arabs of their wealth now and in the future,'' he said.
''The foreign powers aim to regain control of this Arab land and those who live on it,'' the King said. Although he did not mention the United States by name, or its decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia, Washington was clearly a target of his indignation. 
Taking note of the high tensions in the region, King Hussein ordered that first aid centers be opened and training stepped up for civil defense and military units. He cautioned the Jordanians, who have quickly emptied grocery store shelves, against hoarding, and he urged them to limit their use of water and electricity.
 
Fails to Block Goods
Although the United Nations Security Council has imposed trade sanctions on Iraq in response to its occupation of Kuwait, Jordan has not moved to block shipments through its territory to Iraq. Iraq, Jordan's main trading partner, is regarded here as a protector against Israeli attack.
Jordanian officials at the barren desert border with Iraq said this morning that 500 heavy trucks were entering Iraq daily with cargoes including fruit, vegetables, shoes, stone construction blocks and chemicals.
The King's brother, Crown Prince Hassan, who counsels the monarch on political strategy, told a televison interviewer today that Jordan considered the United Nations resolution imposing the trade sanctions to be mandatory. But he suggested that Jordan might appeal to the United Nations for compensation because of the country's dependence on trade with Iraq.
A senior Government official said advisers were reviewing the sanctions and that it was not clear when Jordan would begin to observe them.
 
Solarz Meets King
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a New York Democrat, said before meeting with the King today that he intended to tell him that ''his whole relationship with the United States hinges on making these sanctions effective.''
''Given the interests we have in the Gulf,'' Mr. Solarz said, ''it's inconceivable that we'd be prepared to maintain relations as we have in the past if he subverts the sanctions meant to bring this aggression to an end.''
The King, in his address to the joint session of his Parliament, complained that ''an Arab border problem'' had been ''transformed into a major and dangerous confrontation with international consequences'' as a result of ''the massing of foreign military forces on Arab soil.''
American combat troops began landing in Saudi Arabia last week, and hundreds more are arriving daily. President Bush said he ordered the troops to the Middle East in the hope of discouraging an advance by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who has been massing troops along the Saudi border since he occupied Kuwait 11 days ago. The two Husseins are not related. No Longer a Balance King Hussein's remarks were a sharp departure from the balance he seemed previously to have sought between his relationship with the United States, which gives Jordan millions of dollars in economic and military aid, and his ties with his powerful neighbor Iraq.
President Bush said last week he was disappointed that King Hussein, an old friend, had not joined other Arab League leaders in condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and its massing of combat troops at the Saudi border.
A few days later, the King called a news conference and objected to the forceful seizure of territory. He also said he continued to recognize Kuwait's royal family as the legitimate rulers.
But at a hastily called meeting of Arab leaders on Friday in Cairo, King Hussein hedged his approval of a resolution to condemn the Iraqi leader and to send Arab troops to defend Saudi Arabia, voting ''with reservations.''
Palace aides say the King has spoken several times by telephone with President Bush since the Iraqi invasion 11 days ago.
Taking questions from foreign reporters last week, King Hussein appeared to be trying to mollify the United States without offending President Hussein of Iraq. Aides say the two Husseins have become close friends. Another Turnabout? The Jordanian King's harsh address to Parliament suggested a turnabout, and possible annoyance at pressure from Washington.
A spokesman for the United States Embassy here declined to comment on the speech. A senior Jordanian Government official, apparently seeking to soften the impact of the speech in Washington, said the King's remarks were not ''particularly directed at the United States.''
The official also denied that King Hussein's speech was an attempt to increase his standing in his own country, which has been one of the region's most enthusiastic supporters of the Iraqi leader's actions.
But the spirit of the King's address apparently was not lost on Suleiman Arar, the speaker of the lower house, who praised the Jordanian leader for ''confronting the imperialist-Zionist plans and conspiracies.'' He applauded the King for challenging ''American arrogance and choosing to side by the struggle of the people.''
The Speaker of the Senate, Ahmad Lawzi, also referring specifically to the Americans, said, ''These troops and forces wove the conspiracy of Palestine and want now to keep the power of the Arab oil in their hands.''
King Hussein has said he will continue to seek an ''Arab solution'' to the crisis.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Policies Uncertain, Tokyo Leader Abruptly Puts Off a Mideast Visit

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Monday abruptly put off his plans to travel to the Middle East amid indications that his advisers were divided and uncertain about how to promote Japan's interests there.
The decision, announced two days before Mr. Kaifu's scheduled departure, was widely viewed here as a blow to Tokyo's efforts to play a more assertive diplomatic role on the world stage. He would have been the first leader of a leading Western ally to travel to the area since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. 
Japanese officials said Tokyo needed more time to come up with ''concrete measures'' to assist the international efforts to isolate Iraq militarily and economically.
 
Foreign Minister to Go Instead
But there was also some confusion as to what Japan had agreed or not agreed to do, aside from continuing to enforce its economic sanctions against Iraq, which were announced a few days after the invasion.
The Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, will travel to the Middle East instead of Mr. Kaifu. Mr. Nakayama said Japan would not supply any financial aid to military efforts by the United States and other countries to assist Saudi Arabia and enforce a blockade against Iraq.
His comment appeared to be a rebuff to informal suggestions in the United States that Japan, because of its overwhelming dependence on oil from the Middle East, should be prepared to help financially to make sure that its supplies are not interrupted.
But a Foreign Ministry spokesman emphasized Monday evening that Mr. Nakayama had ruled out financial assistance to the military efforts only for the time being.
President Bush telephoned Prime Minister Kaifu with a request that Japan increase its financial assistance to Middle East nations hit hard by the trade sanctions against Iraq, Japanese officials said this morning. It was unclear whether the United States was seeking aid to the military efforts in the gulf region.
 
Constitutional Restriction
The Foreign Ministry spokesman and others emphasized on Monday that Japan would have difficulties in assisting the military efforts because the Japanese Constitution, written by the United States after World War II, forbids the use of force by Japan.
The Constitution does not specifically forbid assisting armed forces fielded by others, and Tokyo in fact pays 40 percent of the $7 billion cost of stationing American troops in Japan. But the Constitution is often cited by those who oppose increasing military spending.
Mr. Kaifu was to have left Wednesday for Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Jordan and Egypt on a long-planned ''good will'' mission.
Officials said the cancellation was forced by mounting fears in both the Foreign Ministry and the ruling Liberal Democratic Party that the trip would turn into a debacle.
They were said to be worried that Japan would anger both Iraq and its enemies by seeming to appeal to other oil-producing countries to increase production. The concern that the trip would merely be seen as an ''oil-buying expedition'' caused Japanese diplomats to reassess it, officials said.
 
A Cautious Image
Nevertheless, for many the cancellation seemed to reinforce Japan's image as a country that hesitates to assert its political interests in a way commensurate with its status as an economic superpower.
''This shows that Japan simply isn't ready to forge an independent diplomacy,'' said Kent E. Calder, associate professor of politics and international relations at Princeton University, who was visiting Tokyo. ''Japan really doesn't want to move in uncharted waters where there's any kind of risk.''

HEADLINE: Bush Returning to Washington for Budget Session

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 13

 BODY:
President Bush is returning to Washington on Tuesday, a day earlier than scheduled, and plans to hold a budget meeting and a news conference where aides said he would prod the Democrats to come to a ''reasonable'' agreement on the budget.
The President will argue that the need for such an agreement is more urgent than before, they said, with the Persian Gulf confrontation following so closely on the costly savings and loan bailout.
No specific proposals are expected to come out of the meeting of Administration officials involved in budget negotiations with Congressional leaders. But White House officials said the negotiators would try to come up with a preliminary estimate of the impact of oil price increases and the American military presence in the gulf. 
 
Economy Called Sound
''We want to see what changes we might want to make in our proposals to reflect the impact'' of sending ships and troops to the Middle East, said one senior Administration official.
Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has left both Democratic and Republican lawmakers worried about the effect of rising oil prices on a faltering economy and skeptical that the budget talks between Congress and the White House can move forward.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady predicted last week that higher oil prices would cut the economy's growth rate in half but asserted that it was resilient enough to avert a recession. He said those who argued for delaying talks on reducing the deficit because of fears about the invasion of Kuwait and rising oil prices were ''dead wrong.''
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, took a similar position at a briefing here today, saying, ''There's no official change in our assumptions at this point'' that rising oil prices will not devastate the economy.
Last month negotiators for the White House and Congress tentatively agreed to cut the deficit by $50 billion. Asked whether that would be more difficult in light of the crisis in the gulf, Mr. Fitzwater replied: ''It's been so difficult to this point, it's hard to imagine it getting more difficult. It will be difficult, but on the other hand, we are hopeful that the Democrats are operating in good faith and that we'll be able to reach an agreement.''
At the budget meeting, Mr. Fitzwater said, Administration negotiators would also review their plans for cutting expenditures, overall budget figures and tax policy, in preparation for resuming budget talks with Congressional negotiators in September.
Mr. Bush has exempted some military personnel from the automatic spending cuts that will take effect on Oct. 15 under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law if there is no budget plan by then.
Mr. Fitzwater said today that the money for the Persian Gulf operation would come from ''existing budgetary resources.''
''The money is there,'' he said. ''Funding will not drive this operation.''
Mr. Fitzwater was asked if the cost of the Gulf crisis had changed the President's view that taxes would need to be raised as part of any budget agreement. ''We don't discuss the internal aspects of the budget,'' Mr. Fitzwater replied. But he said the President's view on taxes had not changed.

HEADLINE: Road Still Rough for Black Candidates

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Just a year after L. Douglas Wilder made history in Virginia by becoming the first black elected Governor of a state, national attention has been focused on the chances of new breakthroughs by black candidates for governor in Georgia and South Carolina and for the Senate in North Carolina.
 
But when Andrew
Young suffered a crushing defeat last Tuesday in the Democratic runoff in Georgia, it underscored that Mr. Wilder's success will be difficult to duplicate.
The candidacies of blacks in those three states are important signs of the remarkable political gains that blacks have made in the South only three decades after the end of segregation. According to a recent report by the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research group in Washington, 4,955 of the nation's 7,370 black elected officials are in 16 Southern and border states and the District of Columbia.
But some of the gains, as exemplified by Theo Mitchell's candidacy for governor of South Carolina, say as much about a Democratic Party weakened by the defection of white voters as they do about racial progress. 
And a Department of Justice challenge to Georgia's primary system two days after the runoff, accented the degree to which gains by blacks are bringing the Democrats risks as well as opportunities as they try to hold on to white voters.
 
Victory Was 'Extraordinary'
''Young's race points up again just how extraordinary the Wilder victory in Virginia was,'' said Larry J. Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia. ''While it is possible for a black to win now in the South, it is never likely a black will win.''
Even before Mr. Young's dismal showing, losing to Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller by 38 percent to 62 percent, many political analysts said that unique aspects of Virginia politics hid some of the problems black candidates still face and that it was a mistake to read too much into the three candidacies this year.
Mr. Mitchell won the nomination of perhaps the most demoralized state Democratic Party in the South and is given little chance of beating the Republican incumbent, Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. Mr. Young, despite his international reputation and moderate record as Mayor of Atlanta, attracted only minimal white support.
But in North Carolina, Harvey Gantt faces better prospect in his underdog race against Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican.
Despite the obvious echoes of last year's Virginia campaign, the differences between the three races and Mr. Wilder's outweigh the similarities, experts say.
Mr. Wilder was nominated by a party convention rather than having to face a primary battle, so he faced the voters only once, in the general election. He found an issue, support for abortion rights, that attracted a white constituency. His opponent ran what was considered a weak campaign, and his state, Virginia, includes the Washington suburbs with a white constituency more sympathetic than those in Georgia, North Carolina or South Carolina.
 
Lessons From Young
''Wilder only had to win one race,'' Mr. Sabato said. ''He had the silver bullet of abortion, which was the hot issue. He had a divided Republican Party. And he still won by only 6,800 votes.'' The defeat of Mr. Young, who had an impressive record of public service and a mainstream message, illustrates pitfalls black candidates still face.
Mr. Young tried to run a low-key race much like Mr. Wilder's, assiduously courting white voters and counting on solid black support. Instead, he made few inroads among whites and failed to generate great enthusiasm among blacks.
Many black candidates seem to face a choice of alienating whites with a campaign that excites blacks or failing to energize their black base with a low-key campaign aimed at courting whites.
Mr. Young faced other problems as well. Like many other black candidates with their bases in big cities, he had to overcome the historic antipathy of rural Georgia voters to candidates from Atlanta.
Polls showed that the most important factor in the election was not race, but Mr. Miller's support for a lottery to finance education. But polling also found that about a third of the white voters were highly unlikely to vote for a black, leaving Mr. Young with a difficult task with only two-thirds willing to hear his message.
 
Tough Battle in South Carolina
Mr. Mitchell, a veteran State Senator with close ties to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, sees a similar symbolism in all three races.
''I think it's a source of pride that Virginia, capital of the Confederacy, would see fit to end the hostility between the races,'' he said in a recent interview. ''And I also say that the state where the first shot was fired in the Civil War is going to fire the final shot. We're going to really end the Civil War with the election of yours truly as governor.'' Few think that is likely, however. Mr. Mitchell has one paid staff member and has raised $200,000 as against the $1.7 million that Mr. Campbell has raised toward a goal of $2.5 million.
Mr. Mitchell's nomination comes at a time when whites are continuing to desert or ignore the Democratic Party in South Carolina. In 1978, 455,000 people voted in the Democratic primary, with blacks making up 29 percent of the vote. In this year's primary, only 204,000 votes were cast, with blacks making up about 50 percent of the vote.
To many analysts, the real message of Mr. Mitchell's primary victory is that the Democratic Party in South Carolina is continuing to lose white support and is in danger of losing its ability to compete for major races.
 
Challenge to Runoffs
''For a lot of whites, particularly younger whites, the Democratic primary is not on their political radar screen anymore,'' said Earl Black, a professor of political science at the University of South Carolina.
The issue could be complicated by a United States Justice Department challenge to the election rules in Georgia, because other Southern states also mandate a runoff if no candidate wins 50 percent of the vote in the primary.
Some blacks say that the runoff rules dilute black voting strength and that the abolition of runoffs would make it easier for blacks to win statewide primaries. But many experts say that if runoffs are ended, the big winners would be Republicans, who would be more likely to face a candidate without broad-based support among Democrats. ''They will elect more Republicans if they succeed in abolishing the runoff,'' Mr. Sabato said.
Like Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Gantt won his nomination after the top Democratic contenders, like former Gov. James Hunt, declined to run in what would be a bruising race.
Unlike Mr. Mitchell, polls show Mr. Gantt is running strongly and is slightly ahead of Mr. Helms, though many voters remain undecided. But Mr. Helms trailed Mr. Hunt by large margins in early polls in 1984 only to mount a big-money, brass-knuckles campaign that won. And the polls were taken at a time when Mr. Gantt was campaigning heavily and Mr. Helms was not.
Mr. Gantt, a former Mayor of Charlotte who was defeated when he ran for re-election in 1987, gained 37 percent of the white vote in the Democratic runoff against District Attorney Mike Easley of Brunswick County. Mr. Gantt says the contrast with a dogged conservative like Mr. Helms helps his campaign. Analysts say that unlike Mr. Young's race against the moderate Mr. Miller, the presence of Mr. Helms on the ticket will insure a large black turnout no matter what kind of race Mr. Gantt runs. And running in a year with no Presidential race gives him an advantage over Mr. Hunt in 1984, who ran when Ronald Reagan's presence brought out Republican voters.
''I have always said in order for us to win, we felt we had to run against a guy like Jesse Helms who is so clearly defined and whose vision can be so sharply contrasted with mine,'' Mr. Gantt said in a telephone interview.
There is enough anti-Helms feeling in North Carolina that any serious challenger is believed to begin the race with at least 40 percent of the vote. Getting to 50 percent is the hard part. And some Democrats worry that Mr. Gantt has hurt himself by leaving open the possibility of tax increases and opposing the death penalty and will not have the financial resources to compete with a barrage of Helms television spending late in the race.
Still, if the races this year represent steps on a long journey rather than the full arrival of blacks in Southern politics, a win by Mr. Gantt over Mr. Helms would be at least as significant as Mr. Wilder's victory last year.
And some analysts say that if the trends are helping the Republicans as they continue to make gains in the South, in the long run they could help both the Democrats and the region as whites become more accustomed to blacks in politics.
''In the short run it could be a problem for the Democrats,'' said Hastings Wyman, publisher of the Southern Political Report, an independent newsletter.. ''In the long run, you have to say there are some trends going on that may be helpful to them - that is a lessening of hostility on the part of white voters to blacks in politics. That has been a burden to the Democrats and an asset to Republicans. To the extent that over time becomes less of a factor, it helps the Democrats.''

HEADLINE: Rinfret Proposes Towns Bid For Waste-Site Exemptions

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Pierre A Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial nominee, said today that he would solve the perennial problem of finding sites for landfills and garbage incinerators by forcing local governments to bid for the right not to build them.
Environmentalists and local government leaders were quick to criticize the plan as discriminatory against the poorest areas of the state, which could become dumping grounds for the rest of New York.
''It sounds like the worst case of toxic imperialism I've ever heard of,'' said Lee Wasserman, executive director of the Environmental Protection Lobby, a statewide advocacy group. 
''I think many of our officials would find that proposal objectionable, and it would get little support here,'' said Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties.
 
Payments to Accepting Town
Under Mr. Rinfret's plan, auctions would be held in which counties or municipal governments would bid against other governments in their areas for the right to keep solid-waste disposal center out of their towns.
Eventually, Mr. Rinfret said, one government would stop the bidding and accept the landfill or incinerator, either because it could not afford to bid higher or because it wanted the center in its area. The other governments would then pay the accepting government an annual fee equivalent to the amount of the winning bid, possibly hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Mr. Rinfret announced his proposal at three news conferences, including one here, in which he discussed an environmental program that he said was based on ''free-market ideas.'' He also appeared on Staten Island at the Fresh Kills Landfill and in Syracuse at the site of a solid-waste transfer station.
Mr. Rinfret, a New York City economist, has based his campaign on a series of unconventional proposals. Among other suggestions, Mr. Rinfret has proposed selling the New York City subways and eliminating plea bargaining.
Mr Rinfret said the auction idea could also be used to find sites for low-level radiation storage and prisons. He denied that the practice would put poorer counties or municipalities at a competitive disadvantage.
 
'An American System'
''They have a choice,'' he said. ''They just bid more to get out of it. That's called an American system. Why don't you drive a Rolls-Royce? Because you don't have the money, right?''
In other environmental proposals, Mr. Rinfret said he would favor mandatory recycling across the state. He said he opposed a recommendation by a gubernatorial commission to limit development in the Adirondacks, saying it would be unfair to residents there.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Player Sues N.C.A.A. Over Eligibility Rules

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
College football, already beset by whirlwind changes, is faced this week with a new legal challenge to its authority.
Braxston Banks, a fullback at Notre Dame who sat out the 1989-90 season, has filed suit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Notre Dame in an effort to regain the final year of eligibility that he lost as a result of becoming a candidate for the National Football League draft last April.
Banks was one of 38 players with remaining eligibility to declare and one of 20 not selected.
A hearing is scheduled in South Bend, Ind., on Thursday at which Banks will attempt to get an injunction enjoining the N.C.A.A. and Notre Dame from enforcing two key eligibility rules: one automatically prevents athletes who place their names in a professional sports draft from playing college sports again, even if they are not chosen; the other makes players ineligible if they agree to retain an agent, even if the agent is a friend or family member. 
 
One Person, One Institution
''The preliminary injunction principally affects one person in one institution and the teams they play against,'' said Allan Morrison, Banks's chief attorney in the case. ''The case as a whole, however, deals with how the N.C.A.A. and its member institutions are going to relate to college athletes who are being used by these institutions, in many cases to make enormous amounts of money for those institutions, and whether they're going to continue to treat them in a way that many people, including some high officials in the N.C.A.A., consider to be unfair.''
Richard Schultz, the N.C.A.A.'s executive director, has publicly advocated a rule change that would allow undergraduates to declare for the N.F.L. draft, testing the pro market, without losing their eligibility.
Banks sat out the 1989-90 season after undergoing knee surgery in February 1989. Because he was graduating in the spring with a degree in English, he had originally planned to use the year of eligibility and enroll in Notre Dame's business school, an expense the school would have carried had Banks remained on his football scholarship. But Banks changed his mind and declared for the draft.
 
Family Member Consulted
Once he declared, Banks became ineligible under the two N.C.A.A. regulations that are being challenged in the suit. Banks admits that while he was making up his mind on the draft, he consulted with a family member who happened to be a sports attorney, but he maintains that he did not sign a contract or accept money.
''Although the focus of the preliminary injunction is not on the agent rule, we think that the agent rule is perhaps even more important in the long run,'' Morrison explained. ''These kids need good advice from reputable people before they make up their minds, before they even test the waters. Part of the problem is that its hard to get good advice now.''
Attorneys for the N.C.A.A. say that they are operating under provisions of the current regulations, and that under those rules, Banks is ineligible to play this fall at Notre Dame.
''He made a wrong decision,'' said William C. Duncan, one of the attorneys representing the N.C.A.A. ''Not every wrong decision can be remedied by a court decision.
''Whether the rule is not fair, whether it is too broad is not the issue here. There is no antitrust issue here. Banks can try out for any team he pleases; what he cannot do is return to Notre Dame and play football for Notre Dame. There is no economic injury to anyone but him, because he guessed wrong. He made a conscious decision and he guessed wrong and now he wants another chance. If there was a law that said he could come back, then he would be able to return. Right now, there is no such law.'' Neutral at Notre Dame Notre Dame describes itself as a neutral party in the case.
''We're members of the N.C.A.A.,'' said Gerald Lutkus, one of Notre Dame's lawyers. ''We support the rule; we will follow those values, unless the court tells us otherwise.''
''If the court says yes, it is my understanding that he has been informed that he will be given a fourth year of eligibility,'' Lutkus added, alluding to the school's athletic department.

HEADLINE: Antarctica Sheds Ice and Scientists Wonder Why

BYLINE: By WALTER SULLIVAN

 BODY:
SATELLITE monitoring shows that Antarctica has shed more than 11,000 of its 5 million square miles of ice since the 1970's, and scientists say further study is needed to determine whether the findings indicate that global warming is melting polar ice.
The new findings and other reported indicators of warming have led researchers to devise elaborate plans to map Antarctica's ice. Only half its coastline has been repeatedly recorded in satellite pictures so far.
A meeting of experts organized early this year by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in College Park, Md., recommended that a multidisciplinary research initiative be established to involve universities and Federal agencies in the study of changes in marine ice sheets, ice resting on land that is now below sea level.
If global warming occurs, its effects will be most obvious at the poles, Dr. Richard S. Williams Jr. of the United States Geological Survey said in an interview. In the past, the comings and goings of polar ice have caused sea levels to fall and rise by hundreds of feet. A sea level rise of only a few feet could be catastrophic for coastal areas worldwide. 
Dr. Williams said the shedding of Antarctic ice might have begun ''hundreds of years ago.'' He said he doubted that it was part of a short-term cycle, but said he could not rule out global warming as the cause.
Jane G. Ferrigno, who works with Dr. Williams, said at an international conference on the subject at the University of Alaska in Fairbanks in June, that in 1986 alone, more than 8,800 square miles of ice had floated into the Weddell Sea from the Larsen and Filchner ice shelves, layers of continental ice about 1,000 feet thick, that flowed off onto ocean water.
''Recent apparent large-scale retreat or recession in several areas make it important to continue to monitor and evaluate the changes to determine if they are random, cyclic, or whether they are a signal of global climate change,'' she said.
This loss of ice from the shelves did not substantially raise sea levels, she said, but could clear the way for rapid and massive shedding of ice resting on land, which would cause water levels to rise.
Ms. Ferrigno said four other extensions of the continental ice had gone to sea in the last few years, as well. In 1987 more than 1,900 square miles from the Ross Ice Shelf ''calved,'' floating off to sea as a giant iceberg and disintegrated.
Researchers studying corals have concluded that two periods of polar ice melting after the last ice age brought about extremely rapid sea level rises - up to 14 feet in a century. Last month, French scientists reported that evidence from African lakes suggested that rapid climate change coincided with the polar melting and filled the previously arid lakes, perhaps within decades.
The Antarctic accounts for 91 percent of the earth's ice. Almost all the rest is over Greenland. Enough of this ice melted between the last two ice ages, 125,000 years ago, to raise global sea levels at least 20 feet above their present level. A study of sea-level rise published this month by the National Academy of Sciences, while noting that global sea levels have risen 300 feet in the last 18,000 years as ice sheets melted and taking into account the possibility of further polar ice melting, forecast a rise of roughly 1.5 to 3.5 feet in the next century.
Participants at the NASA meeting said much of West Antarctica's marine ice sheet is vulnerable to collapse and dispersal into the oceans when sea water penetrates it, causing it to break into icebergs. The proposed multidisciplinary project, called Searise, would monitor the grounding line, the place where ice flowing off the continent becomes waterborne and the spot where the penetration of ocean under the marine ice sheets would occur. Because the land slopes downward at the new grounding line, the ice ''would find itself in deeper water, where the ice needs to be thicker to maintain contact with the bed,'' the Searise report said. In such a situation, it explained, ''the grounding line retreats faster and faster as the entire ice mass is dispersed toward its margin and into the ocean.''
 
Possible Signs of Collapse
Like water flowing off a continent, five ''streams'' of ice renewed by snowfall, up to 50 miles wide and 300 miles long, flow across the slow-moving West Antarctic ice sheet into the floating Ross Ice Shelf. These streams, which move half a mile a year, ''may be manifestations of collapse already under way,'' the NASA panel said.
Specialists believe that if the Ross Shelf went to sea, no longer buttressing the inland ice, the ice might become ''unplugged'' and disperse. This might occur as well on the opposite side of West Antarctica if the Ronne and Filchner ice shelves went to sea, but only a small percentage of them has broken up in recent years.
A contrary view, that the Antarctic ice may be growing, has been advanced by Dr. Charles R. Bentley of the University of Wisconsin at Madison. From measurements of snow accumulation and ice that broke off into the water, he has sought to estimate how much ice is being added to the ice sheet by snowfall and compare it with the loss by flow into the sea around the entire continent. From this he estimates that input exceeds output by 5 to 15 percent. He said global warming would produce even greater accumulation, since that would increase the humidity of air blowing from the sea, causing still more snow to fall.
The accumulation that he estimates is already occurring would lower worldwide sea levels by one-tenth to four-tenths of an inch per year. But sea levels seem to be rising. This means the melting ice must be coming from elsewhere, possibly Greenland or mountain glaciers, he said in a telephone interview.
 
Melting Greenland Ice
Dr. Roy M. Koerner of the Geological Survey of Canada has argued that the rise in sea level at the end of the next-to-last ice age to 20 feet above the present level was almost all caused by shedding of ice from Greenland. Samples from the bottoms of two holes drilled through the Greenland ice cap, he argues, show that the ice formed on bare land at the start of the most recent ice age, after all ice from the previous ice age had already vanished.
He noted that so far, samples from the sea floor off Antarctica have not shown evidence that West Antarctica totally shed its ice after the next-to-last ice age.
Evidence that polar ice disintegrated after the last ice age far more rapidly than had been supposed has been derived from corals on the island of Barbados by Dr. Richard G. Fairbanks of the Columbia University Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory. He has reconstructed a record of sea levels over the past 18,000 years. This, he said in an interview, shows that 14,200 years ago, sea levels were rising at a rate of 14 feet per century.
In a subsequent surge, 11,300 years ago, seas rose 12 feet per century. Whether the melting came from Antarctica or elsewhere is uncertain, he said. The rapid filling of widely separated lake beds in the African desert was reported in a recent issue of the journal Nature by French researchers who studied lake sediment.
Participants in the NASA meeting acknowledged that ice is also flowing swiftly off Greenland. For example, Jakobshavn Glacier, the world's fastest, is flowing into the sea at the rate of 75 feet a day. They decided, however, that their first focus should be on the West Antarctic sheet because of its vulnerability. More offshore sampling could help determine its history, as well as drilling through it to see whether any ice from the previous ice age remains.
Participants also noted that shedding of the Antarctic ice would have many little-recognized effects, changing ocean and air circulation probably as far north as the tropics. Such circulation is now strongly influenced by the violent winds that pour off the South Polar ice.
 
Monitoring by Satellites
NASA officials believe that satellites carrying laser altimeters will be able to spot lowering of the surface, if a collapse is occurring. The program assumes that satellites, as well as surface expeditions, will monitor changing ice volume, including flow down the glaciers and ice streams. Scientists from several countries are building radio-observing stations in Antarctica to provide highly precise reference points for such observations.
By comparing radio signals from distant celestial objects like quasars, scientists at stations on land and on the ice can determine their locations to within a fraction of an inch. The Japanese have recently built such a station at Showa, their base in Enderby Land. The West Germans have started one near the Antarctic Peninsula. A Soviet station is projected, but the site is still uncertain.
Dr. James Garwin of NASA, who is working on plans for satellite mapping of Mars as well as the height of the Antarctic ice, said a challenge would be to determine the satellite's orbit precisely enough to identify where its radar or laser beam is looking.
Other efforts are already under way. Dr. Baerbel K. Lucchitta of the Geological Survey office in Flagstaff, Ariz., told the Fairbanks meeting of efforts to learn the extent to which Antarctica, through its many coastal glaciers, is dumping ice directly into the sea. The 25-nation Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research has begun a program to take duplicate photographs from space of glaciers recorded by satellite in the early 1970's.
So far, she said, such repeated images of 15 glaciers have been recorded, showing rates of annual motion ranging from 328 feet to 1.4 miles. Because the flowing glaciers carry with them crevasse patterns, splits in the ice that are easily recognized in the images, their motions can be followed from year to year. The fastest are the Pine Island and Land Glaciers, both draining Marie Byrd Land.
Robert A. Wharton Jr., of the Desert Research Institute in Reno, told of 10 years of observing ice thickness on Lake Hoare, a permanently ice-covered lake in southern Victoria Land, near McMurdo Sound. From 1979 to 1986, he said, it thinned from 18 feet to 11 feet, then stabilized.
 
Above-Freezing Temperatures
''An increase in mean annual temperature is the most plausible explanation,'' he said. He and his colleagues believe that peak summer temperatures have been above freezing ''for a progressively longer period of time each year since 1973.''
Another temperature measurement was reported by Gary D. Clow and colleagues at the Geological Survey branch in Menlo Park, Calif. They studied the manner in which heat has propagated downward in permanently frozen ground, concluding that during the past century much of northern Alaska has warmed about 4 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit.
Dr. Clow said a drill hole in the Taylor Dry Valley of Antarctica showed a rise of about two degrees in the past 15 years, but its link to warming was uncertain.
The June 28 issue of Nature discussed evidence for Arctic ice thinning obtained by upward-looking sonar on two British submarines cruising under the ice. Earlier expeditions have found average thicknesses to be highly variable, ranging from 10 to 15 feet. The thinning from 1976 to 1987 was found to be substantial, but subject to so many factors that it could not be taken as evidence for climate change.
There seems to be widespread, though not universal, agreement that the world has become warmer in recent decades. Philip D. Jones and Tom M. L. Wigley at the University of East Anglia in Britain have completed a 10-year analysis of available data. In the August issue of Scientific American they say: ''Our work shows conclusively that the world's climate, though highly variable over periods of a decade or less, has become generally warmer during the past century.''
The effect, they say, has been less than that predicted from carbon dioxide and other gases added to the atmosphere by human activity. There is no proof that such an effect is occurring, they say, but they argue that this should not be used as an excuse for inaction.
''The longer the world waits to act, the greater will be the climate change that future generations will have to endure,'' they warned.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rifts began to appear in the Filchner ice shelf in Antarctica, left, in 1973. By 1986, giant icebergs had formed on the seaward side of the rifts. (U.S. Geological Survey) (pg. C1); map of East Antarctica (source: United States Geological Survey) (pg. C8)
