HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Man's Fight for the Rain Forest

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:

The World Is Burning
By Alex Shoumatoff
377 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $19.95
 
The Burning Season
The Murder of Chico Mendes and the Fight for the Amazon Rain Forest
By Andrew Revkin
317 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95.
In Chico Mendes, a Brazilian rubber tapper who was murdered in December 1988, the developed world found a symbol of resistance to the destruction of the planet. Mr. Mendes, who had campaigned for the preservation of the Amazon rain forest that provided his livelihood, became a martyr to the environment and a posthumously fashionable figure. 
After a torrid summer in the United States in 1988, with its drought and fires in Yellowstone Park, the killing of Mr. Mendes by ranchers intent on setting the Brazilian forest ablaze caught the imagination and indignation of Americans. He became the symbol of the little man standing up to the big interests that were fueling global warming.
Now, two books - Andrew Revkin's ''Burning Season: The Murder of Chico Mendes and the Fight for the Amazon Rain Forest'' and Alex Shoumatoff's ''World is Burning'' - look back at the life and death of Mr. Mendes. Each, inevitably, covers much of the same ground, chronicling the gradual transformation of Mr. Mendes from a humble rubber tapper in Acre, an eastern Brazilian state, to a man whose courageous defense of the trees and workers he loved eventually made him a figure of such influence that the ranchers he opposed decided to kill him.
But the similarities between the books end there. While Mr. Revkin's book is a clear, informative account of the clash in the dark heart of the rain forest, Mr. Shoumatoff seems unable to decide whether he is writing a personal travelogue of his own meanderings in the Amazon and elsewhere or the story of Mr. Mendes. His hip language, which seems to owe much to Hunter S. Thompson without ever having Mr. Thompson's bite or humor, is too often a thin mask for an irritating sloppiness. Explaining the difficulty of getting statistics on the Amazon, for example, he writes that ''numbers are a temperate-zone precision trip.''
Born from a magazine piece on Mr. Mendes that appeared last year in Vanity Fair, Mr. Shoumatoff's book is flawed by its self-obsession and lack of structure. Chapters follow the writer in a circuitous route from his country cabin in New York State, to Rio de Janeiro, on through the Amazon and around again. It reads like a long unedited diary, awaiting distillation. In one of countless references to himself, he describes how he wrote a 714-page ''vomit draft'' of the book in the last three months of last year. Even at half that length in its final form, the book is a trifle emetic.
That is a pity because Mr. Shoumatoff, an old Brazil hand, has a sharper journalistic eye for the country than Mr. Revkin. He captures well the mounting sense of moral depravity that marked the country during the administration of President Jose Sarney and reached a culmination with the murder of Mr. Mendes.
Moreover, he understands the sometimes maddening meekness of the myriad Brazilian poor, some of whom Mr. Mendes unexpectedly organized into a resistance force, and their unusual generosity of spirit. He describes well the Brazilian conviction that American concern over the Amazon masks a quest to hold back the economic development of a country with lingering superpower pretensions. And he has a keen sense of the country's institutions, writing, for example, ''In the Brazilian system, the church is the moral check, and the military is the check against chaos.'' But if there are interesting insights scattered through Mr. Shoumatoff's pages, they are awash in a sea of trivia. Overall, Mr. Revkin does a better job of telling the rubber tapper's story.
Mr. Mendes emerges as a genuinely tragic figure, swept up in larger forces that ultimately destroy him. Born into the depressed fringes of western Brazil, he takes up his father's work, tapping the rubber trees of the rain forest to extract the syrupy latex that will become rubber. Through a series of chance encounters, he is thrust from this role into the defense of his livelihood against ranchers and others pouring into Acre, intent on burning the forest for pasture.
Finally, as the global environmental movement gathers force, he assumes a much wider role as a spokesman for the rain forest at international meetings in Miami and Washington, before his still primitive corner of Brazil reclaims him, with bullets.
In a telling passage on the roots of Mr. Mendes's dogged campaign, Mr. Revkin quotes the rubber tapper, shortly before his death, as he leaps up in anger while watching a documentary on the greenhouse effect and the carbon dioxide spewing from the burning forests of the Amazon.
''I'm not protecting the forest because I'm worried that in 20 years the world will be affected,'' he said. ''I'm worried about it because there are thousands of people living here who depend on the forest, and their lives are in danger every day.''
While waving the Mendes banner is now de rigueur for those who are attracted by rain-forest chic, this is a useful reminder that the rubber tapper was no starry-eyed environmentalist.
On the contrary, his struggle to create ''extractive reserves'' in the forest was directly born of the violent reality of Brazil. It is a reality well captured by Mr. Revkin when he evokes the strangeness of Amazonia: ''The look, feel and smell of the hunks of smoked latex seemed antiquated, anachronistic. It was a material from another time, but in the Amazon all times overlap. Here, rubber tappers still live as they did in the 19th century while ranchers hop to their properties in sleek twin-engine planes and watch television via satellite.''
Amid the media's discovery of the rain forest and Hollywood's fascination with it, the complexity of Brazilian society and the forces driving settlers into the Amazon has often been forgotten. Mr. Revkin does a good job of presenting all the issues. And although those charged with killing Mr. Mendes have not yet been brought to trial, he sounds a cautiously optimistic note.
Large extractive reserves for rubber and nuts have been created since Mr. Mendes's death. Killings in Amazonia have fallen off in an apparent sign that the ranchers' sense of impunity has diminished. And the new Brazilian President, Fernando Collor de Mello, has committed himself to environmental defense amid a growing realization that the development of the Amazon has been hopelessly mismanaged.
This is testimony to Mr. Mendes's achievement. The Amazon, 15 percent of the total mass of plant life, is still little known, and he stood up, almost alone, to preserve its treasures. As Mr. Revkin writes, in an image that is bound to encourage those continuing the struggle Mr. Mendes began, ''Where one tree has fallen to crumble and rot, dozens of green seedlings and saplngs suddenly spring up to vie for the blast of sunlight entering the hole in the canopy.''

The Oil Jolt
 Iraq has transferred $3 billion to $4 billion worth of gold bullion, foreign currencies and goods seized from Kuwaiti financial and commercial institutions, including the Central Bank, to Baghdad, considerably increasing its financial reserves, Arab bankers in London and the Gulf region say. [Page A1.]
Kuwait's marketing and refining company is negotiating with Saudi Arabia to supply some of the 400,000 barrels of crude oil and refined products that it received daily from Kuwait before the Iraqi invasion. [D1.] 
Higher crude oil prices are starting to affect prices in the chemical industry. Consumers may soon feel the pinch. [D7.]
Oil prices moved more than $1 a barrel on world markets. In a shortened session on the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate oil for September delivery ended at $26.77, up 54 cents. [D7.]
 
 
 
The Economy
A four-alarm fire in an electrical substation knocked out power to the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan. [A1.] The fire brought some of Wall Street's business to halt, closing several exchanges and slowing trading all around. [B4.]
Events in the Middle East have revived concern on Wall Street about the prospect of a securities transfer tax - something the financial community is dead set against. [D9.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Prices of precious metals continued to advance, fueled by the Middle East crisis. Gold jumped to more than $400 an ounce for the first time in five months. [D1.]
The stock market recouped earlier losses and the Dow industrials gained 30.20 points, to 2,746.78. Volume was light at 122.8 million shares, and trading was hampered by a fire near Wall Street. [D10.]
The dollar fell against primary foreign currencies on concern about interest rates. [D17.]
Treasury securities prices were narrowly mixed in a shortened session. [D16.]
 
 
 
Companies
 A strike against United Parcel Service was averted when the drivers and handlers rejected the recommendation of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' leadership and narrowly ratified a new three-year contract. [D1.]
G.M. and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative agreement that could end a parts plant strike, a G.M. spokesman said. [A16.]
A Federal judge in Brooklyn appointed Marvin E. Frankel, a former Federal judge, as a special master to conduct hearings on a national plan for resolving asbestos personal injury cases. [D1.]
American Express is aggressively challenging Western Union at the business of wiring money. [D1.]
Donald J. Trump will use First Boston, not Merrill Lynch, to reorganize some of his casino debt. [D2.]
A.T.&T. said that in the last 62 days it has opened 1.7 million new accounts for its Universal card, a combination calling card and general-purpose credit card. [D5.]

The fire at the Con Ed plant shows just how fragile - and resilient - the nation's financial trading systems are. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]

HEADLINE: 2 Giants Battle in Wiring Money

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The American Express Company, the nation's largest financial-services concern, is aggressively challenging the Western Union Corporation at a business it pioneered and has long dominated: wiring money.
The objective of the American Express campaign, which started in earnest this summer, is to capture an unlikely market - primarily poor and working-class black and Hispanic consumers, many of them immigrants - who are the most loyal customers of the money-wiring business. It is an unusual campaign for a company that honed its marketing skills on appealing to the affluent and those who want to be.
Wired money is transferred electronically from one city to another through a network of agents. While higher-income Americans usually prefer to send money by check or money order, many poor people either are unaccustomed to banks and checking accounts or cannot afford the fees that banks attach to low-balance accounts. 
John J. Oliviera, a wire agent for American Express who co-owns E.& J. Milk Farms, a combination grocery store/bus depot/used-car lot in Queens, said his customers were often unemployed or working class people. ''They don't exactly have a cellular phone in their car,'' said Mr. Oliviera, who recently switched from Western Union.
Poor black and Hispanic customers are among the biggest users of wired money, sending funds to family members in places like the South, Mexico and Puerto Rico. But they pay high fees for doing so. The American Express charge to wire up to $100 is $12, at least 12 times the cost of traveler's checks.
At least $3.3 billion was wired last year by Western Union and American Express alone. (An unknown number of small ethnic companies, mainly serving the Hispanic market, also wire money, but the amount is not known.) What is known is that the vast majority of the money transfers - about $3 billion - was handled by Western Union. It is a market that is now one of the few reliable sources of profit for the heavily indebted telecommunications company, which narrowly avoided bankruptcy earlier this year and has labor problems. And Western Union's brand name is so powerful that Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, withdrew from the money-transfer business in frustration in 1988.
As if Western Union does not have enough problems, American Express appears to be gaining ground. After months of building a large agent network but doing little advertising, American Express has already gained about $300 million in money transfers.
 
An Upbeat Attitude
American Express executives are upbeat about the prospects of their money-wiring service, called MoneyGram, against Western Union's Money Transfer service.
''We're going to provide faster, better, less expensive service and get a good piece of the money-transfer business,'' said Robbin L. Ayers, head of the American Express wire-transfer unit in Englewood, Colo. ''But it's going to be a challenge because Western Union is the dominant player.''
Another, and perhaps larger, challenge for American Express may be that it is out of its element in trying to appeal to lower-income groups. The working class and poor - ''habitual users'' in American Express parlance - account for half or more of all wire transfers. Because both American Express and Western Union get their revenue from the per-transaction service fee, they are the most desirable customers. Upper- or middle-class consumers tend to be only ''emergency users,'' wiring money, for example, to cash-short children on vacation or at school.
 
A Large Lead
At least 13 million money transfers occurred last year, most originating in the United States. Twelve million of them were Western Union's, and about one million were American Express's. The busiest months are July, August and just before Christmas.
Western Union, which had total sales of $629 million last year, has seen its revenue from money transfers grow more than 80 percent since 1984, to about $236 million last year. American Express does not disclose financial figures for its wire business, but analysts doubt that it is profitable at this stage.
''American Express is using their size and their skill to come into this market in a big way,'' said Edward J. Fuhrman, head of Western Union's money-transfer division in Upper Saddle River, N.J. ''They're no David and we're not Goliath.''
In a departure from American Express's usual marketing approach of placing a major emphasis on newspaper and magazine ads, the company is devoting most of its money-transfer advertising to radio and television commercials to try to reach people less prone to read. Some of the ads are broadcast on Spanish-language radio and television and on radio stations with large black audiences. $10 Million Budget American Express will not say how much it is spending on advertising, but acknowledges the amount is more than $10 million, compared with Western Union's $20 million budget.
In one general-market radio spot, a wife tells her husband that their son the musician is calling long distance to tell them he ''finally got a gig.'' Trouble is, she says, his group needs money for new outfits within the hour. The husband grumbles, ''I don't believe it.'' The mother sighs and says, ''Well, I guess they can come back here and rehearse in the garage.'' Says the father, ''I believe it . . . Let's send them money right now.''
In one Spanish-language television ad for American Express, a construction worker says, ''Because I work hard for what I earn, I need to know that my money gets there.'' Another man is shown entering a wire agent's office, saying, ''I send money to my family because I want to, and with American Express MoneyGram every time I send money . . . it gets there.''
 
Opportunity in Mexico
Money sent to Mexico is an especially attractive opportunity for both American Express and Western Union. The estimated 22 million Americans of Hispanic descent send abroad, by various means, about $7 billion annually, American Express said. About $5 billion is sent to Mexico alone, but only a small fraction of this money is sent by wire transfer.
American Express has introduced in Mexico a new product called Lightning Service, or El Servicio Relampago. The company claims a processing time of less than 10 minutes for money sent in the form of dollar-denominated traveler's checks that can be exchanged for pesos. Western Union, which claims greater geographical reach than American Express, acknowledges that its service can take as long as two days, but notes that the money is provided directly in pesos.
For New York-based American Express, which had a profit last year of $1.2 billion on revenue of $25 billion, the wire-transfer business is a relatively small but attractive opportunity, analysts say. ''This is very close to their core business; they're good at this,'' said Michael L. Goldstein of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. ''If anyone can do it, they can do it.''
American Express gets about 3.5 cents every time someone uses any of its charge cards, Mr. Goldstein estimates. Western Union, long establshed in the business, averages $19.60 in revenue for each wire transfer.
 
Few Sources of Profit
For Western Union, the wire-transfer business is one of the few sources of profit. The company's telex and other businesses have been hurt by the rise of new technology, such as facsimile machines. Last year the company lost $32 million.
Over the weekend, Western Union replaced most of its 2,500 unionized workers who are negotiating a new labor accord. The company said the lockout would not affect money transfers or other services, but said the action was prompted by the ''ever present threat'' of a strike.
So far, Western Union is planning no major marketing countermoves against American Express in the money-wiring business. And, given Western Union's financial troubles, it may not be able to afford any expensive new marketing campaigns soon. ''We're just sticking to our game plan,'' Mr. Fuhrman said.
 
Network of Agents
If American Express is to make headway against Western Union, it will have to put together a global network of agents. In the money-transfer business, customers pay a fee to an agent, such as a supermarket, convenience store or bus station, to have the money wired to another city or town. The party receiving the money picks it up at a particular receiving agent, or in the case of ''will call'' service, anywhere in the network.
Unlike money orders - where a company makes most of its money from the ''float,'' investing the money in the interval between the order's issuance and actual cashing - a wire-transfer company and its agents make money from the fee itself.
American Express said it had learned lessons from Citicorp's unhappy experience. It has already built up a large agent base - more than 9,000 agents in 35 countries, mainly the United States. Unlike Citicorp, which announced it was going national with its service and then attempted to build an agent network, American Express has been quietly putting together a network since January 1988, but did not start its national advertising campaign until May.
Citicorp, when it withdrew from the business, had only 2,100 agents. Western Union has more than 15,000 agents.

LENGTH: 1650 words

HEADLINE: Unequal Pay Widespread in U.S.

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
People who work in the same field and are of similar age and education are finding that their wages, once very close, now extend across a much wider range, new studies of Labor Department data show.
Such findings contribute a new explanation for the growing gap between the incomes of the wealthiest and poorest Americans, which is now the widest since World War II, even after adjusting for inflation. The gap can no longer be explained simply by noting that the college-educated earn much more than those with only a high school degree, that blacks do not fare so well as whites or that men earn more than women.
Among the theories explaining the change is that the wage spread reflects a decline in the power of unions, which act to keep wages more uniform. Another is the stiff competition wrought by deregulation in some industries, which forced some struggling employers to impose lower wage scales than their more successful rivals. 
Some economists also think the wage gap has grown as employers increasingly short of skilled labor bid up wages for the best workers, using criteria that go beyond education and job experience. Finally, some economists say that social mores that once kept wages within limits even on Wall Street eroded in the 1980's.
Although wage spreads are increasing among all workers, what is most striking about the trend is its appearance among men who hold full-time jobs, economists say. They constitute more than 50 percent of the labor force, and their wage scales had historically been the most uniform. Results from the recent studies suggest to many economists that the increasing wage gap in this group is perhaps the chief reason for the growing number of wealthy and poor Americans.
''The college/high school thing is important and so are the other differences, but most of the action is among people of the same age and education,'' said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard labor economist, who is studying the wage-spread phenomenon. ''Inequality is going up in nearly every occupation.''
Ten years ago, for example, young lawyers of similar age and education who were seeking to specialize in pension law could expect to land jobs in New York that paid similar salaries. Today, wage surveys show, the top salary is $110,000 and the bottom $42,000, a spread of $68,000. Electrical engineers in their early 30's, holding jobs in Silicon Valley, in California, earned within $12,000 of each other in 1980. The spread has grown to $25,000, greatly outstripping the increase in inflation, with the high end now $65,000. And until 13 years ago, mechanics at any of the nation's big airlines with the same seniority earned virtually the same wage. Today, a top-scale mechanic's hourly wage ranges from $16 at Pan American World Airways to $21 at American Airlines.
Economists who say that the wider wage gap has been caused mainly by employers bidding up wages for the most skilled workers add that this situation makes United States companies more competitive.
But paying sharply different wages to people with essentially the same job credentials is divisive for American society, some economists and sociologists argue. ''I'm not overly concerned about one lawyer who makes $35,000 and another who makes $100,000,'' said Richard Freeman, a Harvard economist. ''But for many others, the wage spread means they no longer make it into the middle class. And they are working just as hard as people did 30 years ago.''
 
Uniformity Exists Abroad
The wage spread means, in effect, the disappearance of a sort of insurance policy that assured people they would receive roughly the same pay if they switched jobs, even if one shoe salesman, mechanic, secretary or engineer was not so skilled as another, Mr. Freeman said. Such uniformity exists today in other industrial nations, among them West Germany and Sweden, where government agencies or unions set pay guidelines.
Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University, sees another dark side in the wage spread. More workers, finding themselves earning less than their peers, seem to be growing discouraged and leaving the labor force, Census Bureau data indicate. ''People get a set of wage expectations that become harder to fulfill,'' he said.
Many theories are being offered to help understand a process that the studies show is 20 years in the making and that is only now getting the attention of many economists. Mr. Freeman and others think that union contracts had tended to keep wage scales uniform within many industries and that the decline in union membership and influence at the bargaining table has undermined this check on wage inequality.
 
Skewing Follows Deregulation
That change took place, for example, in the airline industry, where mechanics' wages were ''in lockstep with each other'' in the 1970's, kept that way by the International Association of Machinists union until deregulation, said Jerry Glass, head of J. Glass & Associates, a labor-relations consultant to the industry. Stiff competition, wage givebacks and bankruptcies forced some workers to give ground, disrupting the scales. Now, senior mechanics at Northwest Airlines or American Airlines are paid 30 percent more than those at Pan Am, a less healthy carrier.
Other economists argue that employers are hungrier than in the past for highly skilled workers and are bidding up wages for the best people in every occupation. Because job skills are not necessarily related to schooling, many of the college-educated are falling behind their former classmates, said Marvin Kosters of the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research organization.
Mr. Kosters's analysis might help to explain the wage spread for pension-rights lawyers that blossomed in the mid-1980's, when the financial health of corporate pension plans became an issue. ''Pension lawyers became hot in the mid-1980's, and companies and consulting firms began to bid for them,'' said Carole R. Schwartz, chairman of the executive search firm McCabe & Schwartz. ''That disrupted the established salary structure.''
 
Other Explanations
Some economists speculate that the spreads might also be the result of changes in the American economy that cannot be easily reversed. Small companies, for example, proliferated in the 1980's. While established companies in Silicon Valley tend to pay electrical engineers with 10 years' experience about $65,000, the small new companies offer only $40,000 but lure skilled people with stock options that promise big payoffs if the venture succeeds, surveys show.
Some economists go beyond economics to explain the wage gap. One hunch of Frank Levy of the University of Maryland is that workplace mores have eroded. From a purely free-market point of view, Michael R. Milken, who created and dominated the market in high-yield ''junk bonds,'' might have been worth to Drexel Burnham Lambert 20 years ago the inflation-adjusted equivalent of his 1987 income of $550 million, Mr. Levy explained. But in those days, Mr. Milken would not have dared to ask for so much money. And paying such an amount was beyond Wall Street's imagination.
''Then, as custom eroded in the 1980's, the free market came into full play and inhibitions on paying such big sums disappeared,'' Mr. Levy said.
 
The Latest Studies
Kevin M. Murphy of the University of Chicago and Finis Welch of the University of California at Los Angeles produced several of the new studies, which cull from Labor Department data the education, age and experience levels for the nation's full-time male workers, going back nearly 30 years. Until the early 1970's, wage spreads did not change much; after that they widened rapidly. Through 1987, the latest year covered in the recently published studies, the spreads within the various age and education groups were, on average, 30 percent broader than they had been in the early 1970's.
The studies involved men working full time. Separate studies of black and white men produced comparable results. Although the wage gap phenomenon also exists among women working full time, economists say, they were not included in the studies because their tendency to leave the labor force for long periods to rear children can skew the results.
The studies show that people at the top of their salary scales frequently improved their standards of living in the 1980's, or held their own. This improvement took place most often among occupations that employed the college-educated. But in occupations served mostly by high school graduates the top earners also brought home enough in wage increases to maintain their living standard. The wages of nearly all the others, whatever their education, did not rise so fast as the inflation rate.
 
Gains for the Best Paid Only
One of Mr. Murphy's studies shows how men out of school for 11 to 20 years have been affected. Near the high end of the scale, those with college degrees earned $1,076 a week in inflation-adjusted dollars in 1970. The wage near the low end was $377, and the median for this group was $663. Seventeen years later, only the people at the high end had improved their standard of living, which rose 5.2 percent, to $1,132 a week. At the low end wages fell 14.3 percent, to $323, while median wages fell 9.8 percent, to $598 a week.
Similarly, only the best-paid high school graduates were keeping their heads above water 11 to 20 years after completing school. The high-end wage was $650 a week for this group in 1970, adjusted for inflation, and it fell only six-tenths of 1 percent, to $646 in 1987. The median and the low-end wages lost much more ground in those years, with the median falling 10 percent, from $431 to $388, and the low plunging 29.2 percent, from $274 to $194.
The wage gap expanded in those 17 years by 21 percent for the high school graduates and 16 percent for those with college degrees.

HEADLINE: Chip Indicator Continues Slide

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Chip orders declined in July as the American semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued the downward slide it began in June, a trade group said today.
 
The Semiconductor Industry
Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1 for the three-month period that ended in July, down from 1.06 in June and down significantly from a revised figure of 1.15 in May. 
The ratio compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry. A ratio of 1 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $100 was ordered, indicating demand is no longer growing but has not yet declined.
At $1.19 billion, three-month orders for July were down 6.4 percent from $1.27 billion for the period that ended in June.

HEADLINE: Costs Rising for Chemical Industry

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Higher crude oil prices are starting to affect prices in the chemical industry, a leading consumer of petroleum products, executives of chemical companies say. And because products derived from crude oil are used to make many of the basic materials that go into a host of other products, notably plastics, consumers will soon feel the pinch.
Some chemical companies say they have already seen slightly higher prices on the spot market. For example, the price of naphtha, a product that comes out of refineries and is used in making propylene, ethylene and benzene, has soared from $160 a metric ton three weeks ago, to $240 a metric ton. And last week the spot price for benzene, a key ingredient of plastic packaging, increased 17 percent, while xylene, a chemical used as an octane enhancer and an important ingredient in making plastic bottles, was up 12 percent. 'Higher Consumer Prices' 
''Downstream products have not yet responded,'' said Carolyn Koss Kasten, director of chemical services with Data Resources Inc. in Boston. ''But if there is a protracted period of higher oil prices, the effect on downstream products - plastics, synthetic rubber and synthetic fibers - could easily be higher consumer prices.'' Products as diverse as clothing and airplane parts would be affected. Despite increases in the cost of raw materials, many chemical manufacturers said they were reluctant to pass them along to consumers and that the impact would be negligible on most manufactured goods. As a result, many analysts expect that profits in the industry will be lower than previously thought.
''While it is difficult and premature to assess the scope of the likely negative impact higher crude oil prices may have on chemical company earnings, it is clear to us that for most hydrocarbon-dependent chemical makers, feedstock and energy costs will be rising,'' said Leonard Bogner, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities. ''And they probably won't be able to offset them via high selling prices.'' Mr. Bogner said that pricing for petrochemicals would be based more on supply and demand trends, rather than raw material costs.
But if crude oil prices continue to increase, the result will be higher prices for consumer products, chemical industry executives maintain. ''There aren't many manufactured products that don't have a chemical ingredient in them,'' said Allen Lenz, chief economist with the Chemical Manufacturers Association in Washington. ''And consumers will see those increases if chemical companies see significantly higher crude oil prices.'' Higher oil prices affect all of American industry by raising the cost of energy for manufacturers. The chemical industry is particularly vulnerable not only because of its high consumption of energy, but also because products derived from crude oil are important components in making chemical products.
Robert W. Gallant, vice president of hydrocarbons and energy for the Dow Chemical Company, said higher crude oil prices had begun to affect the price of raw materials. But Mr. Gallant said the higher prices had not changed the company's long-term strategy because supplies were ample.
''We are not in a shortage situation,'' he said. ''In fact, we're carrying a higher inventory than usual.''
 
'Perceived Shortages'
A. Nicholas Filippello, chief economist with the Monsanto Corporation, said even though prices for some raw materials had risen slightly, it was unlikely that prices would remain elevated. ''There is a fundamental excess capacity in the world petrochemical market,'' Mr. Filippello said. ''It's more a function of supply and demand, and perceived shortages can make prices volatile. But when things settle down, I think we will find that not all of that will flow through.''
Many American companies said they expected to be less affected by higher prices than their European rivals because they were larger users of natural gas. A spokesman for the Union Carbide Corporation said natural gas spot prices had increased by 25 to 45 percent, while the spot prices of naphtha had risen 60 percent.
Still, many in the chemical industry are expecting prices of raw materials to increase. ''Although it hasn't affected our raw material costs yet, we definitely expect that it will,'' said William G. Mays, president of the Mays Chemical Company, a commodity chemical distributor based in Indianapolis.

HEADLINE: A New Interest in Taxing Trades

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Events in the Middle East have revived concern on Wall Street about the prospect of a securities transfer tax - something the financial community is dead set against.
The Iraqi conflict has caused Congressional leaders, who will recovene in September, to rethink ways to cut the budget deficit. Rising oil prices have virtually ended any chance of higher energy taxes, and American troop movements to the region mean that cuts in military spending are less likely.
As a result, alternative plans to generate revenue, like a tax on the trades of all stocks, bonds and commodities, have become more viable, almost by default.
 
'A Complicated Equation'
Of course, the same events may also cut the other way. That the Middle East crisis increases the prospect of a recession raises serious questions about the wisdom of imposing any new taxes on a fragile economy, whether on securities or beer. 
And, a tax that could eat into profits on securities trades and undermine confidence in jittery stock and bond markets might be unwise right now - so Wall Street hopes.
''No one wants to cause the stock market to crash right now,'' said Stuart Kaswell, a lawyer with Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts in Washington. ''But, at the same time, the choices are narrowed, and that seems to push more in favor of the tax. It's a complicated equation.'' Mr. Kaswell is a former staff lawyer for the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which reviews securities laws.
Arthur Levitt Jr., the former chairman of the American Stock Exchange who now heads the Levitt Media Company, said he gave the measure ''60 to 70 percent odds of passage.''
 
Wall Street's Position
Wall Street, already buffeted by layoffs, declining business and sharpened global competition, contends that the tax will only hurt. It says the surcharge will drive up transaction costs, drive down securities prices and send business to tax-free markets overseas.
''The Street is unified on this as anything I've seen in my years,'' said Edward I. O'Brien, the president of the Securities Industry Association, a trade organization based in New York. ''The proposed tax is really a slap at the heart of our business.''
And Wall Street has not been shy about lobbying. The nation's stock and commodities exchanges, pension funds and insurance companies have written leading Congressional officials. Even Wall Street's biggest guns have been pulled into the fray.
For instance, just before Iraq invaded Kuwait, John H. Gutfruend, the chairman of Salomon Inc., and William A. Schreyer, the chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, called on Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, a former chairman of Dillon, Read & Company, to voice opposition to the tax.
 
Tax in Discussion Phase
But this lobbying is taking place even though no formal proposal for transfer tax has been made. The tax, which was first suggested by House Speaker Jim Wright, a Texas Democrat, in 1987, is only being discussed. But it is being considered by the highest levels in the Bush Administration and is on the ''short list'' of the bipartisan group scheduled to resume talks on reducing the deficit after Labor Day.
Initially, it appeared that the proposed tax would be 50 basis points levied on all securities upon sale. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. According to the Congressional Research Service, a branch of the Library of Congress, this would have generated $12 billion a year.
Now, discussion is centered on a tax of 15 basis points, or fifteen-hundredths of a percentage point, which would raise an estimated $3 billion annually. The tax would be imposed on all stock, bond, commodities, futures and options trades. Only Treasury securities would be exempted -something opponents contend is an open admission by the Government that the tax would only increase borrowing costs.
 
The Street's Problem
Yet, even before the Middle East crisis, Wall Street faced a tough challenge. Republicans have insisted that income tax rates not be touched to cut the deficit. Meanwhile, Democrats say any final tax package must be progressive - weighing more heavily on the rich than on the middle class or on those with low incomes.
On their face, few of the new taxes proposed, like higher ones on beer or gasoline, met both political requirements - except for the securities transfer tax.
''The securities industry has a tough battle,'' said Mr. Kaswell, the Washington lawyer. ''There are no investment-banker poster children. And there are a lot more blue-collar workers than investment bankers. It comes down to taxing rich people or taxing six cool ones at the end of a day.''
Still, opponents are gathering volumes of information to argue that the surcharge could cripple United States securities markets. They say the tax is likely to cause big investors to flee the American markets, which would cause trading volume to drop and cut the revenues generated by this tax. Some Trades 'Won't Get Done'
A study from the Congressional Research Service shows that a tax of one-half of a percent would decrease the volume of equity trades by about 8 percent.
''We are talking about something that is reasonably significant here,'' said Donald W. Kiefer, a senior economic policy specialist who wrote the study. ''This will dramatically increase the cost of trading, particularly for institutional investors. So a lot of trades just won't get done.''
Pension funds and insurance companies contend that if the tax is imposed, they could end up paying more in taxes than in commissions for stock trades. For instance, the tax on the sale of a share of stock at $20 could be as much as 10 cents, compared with the 3 cents to 5 cents a share in commissions that institutionals pay.
This, the institutions say, will come out of the money available for benefits to retirees - very often, the middle class that some in Congress want to protect from regressive taxes. It could also force local governments to raise taxes to cover these shortfalls, again hurting the middle class.
''This will have an impact on the average working person who will receive a retirement benefit,'' said Roger C. Bransford, a consultant in the Atlanta office of TPF&C, a benefits consulting firm. ''You are talking about the retirement security of Americans.'' $9.5 Million Estimate James D. Mosman, the chief executive of the California State Teachers Retirement System with about $31 billion in assets, said that a 50-basis-point tax would cost the fund about $9.5 million a year.
''That's money that's not available for benefits,'' Mr. Mosman said. ''And with public funds, that cost gets passed back to the employer, whether it is the state or county. They will then shift it to the local taxpayers.''
The traders of bonds, options, futures, money market and other fixed-income instruments, are particularly concerned. In these markets, profits are often made by betting large sums on small and quickly changing price anomalies. The tax could be larger than the discrepancy in prices, eliminating any reason to trade.
''A transaction tax would have an extremely significant structural impact on fixed-income markets,'' said John Brookmeyer, a senior managing director at the Prudential Capital Managment Group. ''A lot of bond trading is based on anomolies, when relative prices are out of line. This means the markets would become less active, less liquid and a lot of the trading would go offshore.''
 
Sending Business Abroad
Opponents say the tax will drive business from the United States to markets where trading rates are cheaper. They say that some foreign countries have reduced, eliminated or have pledged to end transactions taxes after finding that the tax reduced trading volume.
West Germany, for instance, is eliminating a transactions tax that pushed trading in German securities to London, where foreigners are exempted from its transfer tax. London is planning to abolish its tax, and the Netherlands just ended its surcharge, as did Sweden after trading in Swedish companies moved abroad.
''Everyone has been talking about the globalization of financial markets for years,'' said Sarah A. B. Teslik, the executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, a pension fund trade group. ''But only now is it beginning to be true. International competition is more cut-throat, and institutional investors do shop around.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Ends Soviet Curb

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Maine, Aug. 13

 BODY:
In a bid to bolster United States-Soviet trade, President Bush today raised a longstanding ceiling on the number of Soviet business people permitted to live and work in the United States.
Until now, only 69 Russians were allowed to reside in America while pursuing business deals. Now there will be no limit.
Mr. Bush called upon President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to match his move with ''reciprocal improvements in the climate for American business in the U.S.S.R.'' He also cautioned the Soviets against trying to slip in spies on the pretext of doing business.
''This action is taken as an expression of our policy to build a more normal economic relationship with the Soviets,'' Mr. Bush said in a statement issued from his vacation home here.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 30.20 in Late Rally; Trading Light

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market recovered from an opening slump to finish sharply higher yesterday, showing resiliency in the face of uncertainty over Middle East developments.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.20 points, to 2,746.78, but declining stocks outnumbered those that gained by 766 to 726.
Volume was light at 122.8 million shares, with trading hampered by a fire in the Wall Street area that cut off power and telephone service at many brokerage houses in the downtown area. The New York Stock Exchange still had electrical power, but suffered some telephone problems. 
But trading on the American Stock Exchange and the five New York futures exchanges was halted soon after 1 P.M. The power outage shut down all systems and darkened trading floors on the Amex and the five exchanges - the Commodity Exchange, the New York Mercantile Exchange, the New York Futures Exchange, the New York Cotton Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
Trading in the Nasdaq over-the-counter stock system was also disrupted when about 500 Nasdaq computer terminals in brokerage houses were cut off.
The Amex composite index finished the shortened day at 338.14, down 1.18 points. The Nasdaq composite closed at 408.30, up 0.27. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 3.32 points, to 338.84.
 
'Better Prepared' on Oil
Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company, said that the market rise, which included blue chips like Eastman Kodak, which was up 2 1/2, to 43 1/2, and I.B.M., up 1 3/4, to 103 3/4, might have given a technical buy signal to the market. ''This market is much better prepared for an oil problem than it was in 1978,'' he added.
The market's rally from an opening plunge - the Dow fell as much as 32 points in the first half-hour - began with investors entering the market to bargain-hunt and was supported by a stabilized bond market. Declines in other overseas markets yesterday -the Tokyo market had ended down sharply and London was having an off day - were less important than the Treasury's 30-year bond, which closed unchanged at a price to yield 8.79 percent.
In Tokyo, the stock market rose today after a series of setbacks. The Nikkei 225-stock index gained 496.10 points, or 1.90 percent, to close at 26,672.53. The index fell 1,153.12 yesterday.
The low volume in New York trading was responsible for the large jump in the Dow, traders said, noting that light trading often made share prices extremely sensitive to spurts in buying or selling.
Birinyi Associates Inc., which keeps tabs on program trading by large institutions and brokers through certain fluctuations in trading activity, said there were six sell programs yesterday, four between 2:50 P.M. and 3:56 P.M., when the Dow rose 31.19 points.
Oil stocks were generally higher, and among the big gainers were ARCO, up 2 1/4, to close at 137 1/4; Royal Dutch/Shell, up 1 3/8, to 83 5/8, and Mobil, up 1 1/4, to 67 1/8.
Among airlines stocks, Midway Airlines was up 2, to 9 5/8. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, retained Goldman, Sachs & Company, to weigh a possible acquisition of part or all of Midway. AMR was up 1/8, to 51 1/8.
UAL rose 2 5/8, to 110 1/8. According to a report in Crain's Chicago Business, three unidentified banks and possibly four unidentified financial institutions may be interested in lending to the employee-led group seeking to buy out UAL.
Gold stocks were up, and several analysts recommended gold-mining companies, suggesting that the sector will continue to benefit from the uncertainty in the Middle East. Gold is often sought as a safe haven for investments in times of tension. Amax Gold Inc. was up 1, to 19, and Homestake Mining was up 1 1/8, to 23.
In over-the-counter trading, Survival Technology, whose business is medical injection technology, rose 1 1/4, to 14 1/2. The company said its shares gained on speculation that the United States military buildup in Saudi Arabia could increase demand for its nerve gas antidotes. It added that it was the only American-based supplier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in a session that effectively ended shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday, after a fire in lower Manhattan led to a widespread loss of electrical power.
The fire at the Consolidated Edison power plant just moments after the Treasury had conducted its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills darkened trading screens and computers.
Had the fire not broken out, the auction would likely have been the highlight of an otherwise quiet summer Monday trading session.
''The market was lucky that the power outage happened on a day when not much was going on,'' said David R. Duerson, manager of government securities trading operations at the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles. 
At the auction, bids on the three-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.41 percent, up from the average rate of 7.23 percent at the sale a week ago.
 
Six-Month Bill Rates Up
Six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.31 percent, up from an average rate of 7.19 percent a week ago.
Trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities continued on a very limited basis after the fire. It all but ended at 3 P.M., Eastern time, when trading in bond futures contracts close on the Chicago Board of Trade.
''We tried to stay open in some limited capacity until the Board of Trade closed,'' said Bruce R. Lakefield, an executive vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 17/32, down 1/32 point, to yield 8.79 percent, unchanged from late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 17/ 32, down 6/32, to yield 8.66 percent. And the 8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 6/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.89 percent.
The prices are quotes from a sampling of dealers by a New Jersey office of Telerate Inc., a subsidiary of Dow Jones & Company that provides price information electronically to market participants. The Telerate office was not affected by the power outage.
 
Pricing Extremely difficult
However, pricing securities was extremely difficult yesterday because three major interdealer brokers, the RMJ Securities Corporation, Fundamental Brokers Inc. and Cantor Fitzgerald & Company, were affected.
''The long end of the market is still very worried about oil prices and the Middle East,'' one government bond trader said. ''But the short end is likely to stay firm or do better because people are optimistic that the Fed will have to ease credit conditions to cope with a weaker economy.''
At the Chicago Board of Trade, the nearby September bond futures contract closed at 90 23/32, down 5/32 on the day.
''Developments in the Middle East will remain the key theme for some time,'' said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
''But this week all eyes are on the economic data that will be released, beginning with the retail sales report this morning.'' On Thursday reports are due on the Consumer Price Index, industrial production, capacity utilization, housing starts and real earnings.
Mr. Stone and other analysts are projecting that retail sales rose by half a percentage point last month.
A more accurate barometer of consumer sentiment may be announced later in the day, however, when major auto makers are expected to report on how auto sales fared during the first 10 days of August.
''Those numbers will be the first piece of information we will have that bridges the oil price shock,'' Mr. Stone said.
''The sharp rise in prices had to do something to consumer confidence, and the numbers may show that consumers may be a little hesitant to purchase a car right now because with gasoline prices going up, they don't know what kind to buy.''
Although the severity of the fire's damage was unknown as market participants went home, many traders said they did not expect that activity would return to normal today. That could create difficulties if unexpected news develops.
''If we come in on Tuesday and the systems are still down, we could have a problem,'' Mr. Duerson said.

HEADLINE: Breeden Sees Industry Glut

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The United States securities industry has ''substantial overcapacity'' that is similar to the overcapacity in the banking industry, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said here today.
In a speech before the Atlanta Rotary Club, Richard C. Breeden noted that American banks had suffered loan losses of $80 billion in the last five years. 
''We see a situation as we look forward to the 1990's in which we have substantial overcapacity in banking, and, indeed, I think the same situation is generally shared in securities - at least if the pattern of trading volumes since the 1987 crash continues to be the case,'' Mr. Breeden said. ''We have all too many very large financial firms, but with extremely weak balance sheets.''
Mr. Breeden rated the performance of American financial markets during the Persian Gulf crisis as ''orderly.''
He said securities markets had already begun to react negatively to overall economic fundamentals before Iraq invaded Kuwait. ''Then when you have a specific event, you have an overlay over what is already an underlying economic assessment,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Amid Prospects Of Higher Rates Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against primary foreign currencies, which are expected to strengthen as interest rates rise overseas while those in the United States fall as monetary authorities try to avert the threat of a recession.
In New York, the dollar fell to 150.25 Japanese yen, from 150.40 yen late Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 150.65 yen, from 149.75 yen at Friday's close. In London, it fell to 150.35 yen. 
The dollar lost ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8825, from $1.8735 late Friday. In London, sterling rose to $1.8842, from $1.8730 late Friday. The dollar fell to 1.5780 German marks, down from 1.5895 on Friday The dollar has been under pressure in recent weeks because of weakness in the American economy, and many traders expect the Federal Reserve eventually to move to lower interest rates to try to stimulate the economy.
But traders also expect rates to rise in Germany and Japan, as central banks there try to head off inflation because of rising oil prices.
The net effect would be to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
''The only thing supporting the dollar is the flight to quality'' that is traditionally involved when international events are in turmoil, said Karen Gibbs, a senior financial analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago.
''The dollar is no longer perceived as quality - it's the Swiss franc, the Deutsche mark and the Australian dollar,'' she said.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Friday, included: 1.3165 Swiss francs, down from 1.3375; 5.2925 French francs, down from 5.3325; 1,156.25 Italian lire, down from 1,165.00, and 1.14625 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14705.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.5762 West German marks, down from 1.5895; 1.3160 Swiss francs, down from 1.3400; 5.2915 French francs, down from 5.3360; 1.7753 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7925; 1,156.00 Italian lire, down from 1,166.50, and 1.1475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1476.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Executives Cautiously Optimistic

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
A survey on the views of American business leaders was released last week, and the findings indicated a ''guarded optimism'' about the economy. Because of the Middle East crisis, an update was quickly made to get the executives' reaction. They supported President Bush's stand.
The survey is the Chivas Regal Report on American Business Leaders: Executive Attitudes in a Time of Upheaval. Chivas Regal, a leading Scotch whisky brand, is a unit of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons. Last year it commissioned a similar study on American workers. 
Nicholas J. Tortorello, chairman of Research and Forecasts Inc. of New York, conducted this year's survey.
Mentioning the ''large dose of uncertainty'' that the managers find surrounding them, Mr. Tortorello pointed out that many were nonetheless reasonably optimistic. Even in the face of international turmoil and the possibility of a recession, many said they were not ready to alter earnings predictions for their companies.
More than half of the respondents are vice presidents, 20 percent are directors and another 20 percent are senior corporate officers. The survey found that their average household income was $186,000 and their average age slightly over 47 years. They had spent about 13 years with their companies.
Mr. Tortorello said he had little difficulty reaching the business leaders by telephone. ''Most people like to talk, if the questions are interesting and if they think they can learn something from organizing their thinking,'' he said. About 300 responded to the long questionnaire, which took an average of 24 minutes to complete.
The survey found that following years of mergers and downsizings, ''executives say they are working harder, have less job security and face more stress.'' Most are married, and the younger ones in particular said that at times of stress they talked to their spouses about business problems. Also, they believe exercise and participating in sports help at such times.
The day before announcing the results, the research firm telephoned 100 of the same respondents to get their views on the American reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. About 78 percent approved of President Bush's stand. They even had some suggestions about what might be done if Iraq invaded Saudi Arabia - air strikes against Iraq, seizure of the Strait of Hormuz, and mining of Iraqi-controlled harbors.
As for the budget deficit and the savings and loan bailout, most of the executives said they thought Federal tax increases were likely, and a majority said they would be willing to pay higher taxes if the money went for special needs and was spent responsibly. At the same time, they gave ''a strong negative assessment of the Internal Revenue Service,'' contending that it operates ''abusively and inefficiently.'' Some 92 percent of those surveyed think tax laws are ''overly complicated and confusing.''
Looking ahead, most of the business leaders found ''disheartening'' the ''shortage of adequate candidates for the United States Presidency in the future.''
Many respondents had some military training and said the discipline helped them in their careers. In fact, the survey found ''a strong correlation between service as a commissioned officer and achievement of senior-level management positions.''
About 92 percent of those polled are college graduates, and more than half of these had some postgraduate study. In fact, top-level management increasingly shows more education credentials because college study became more available and important after World War II.
While the Chivas Regal questionnaire did not go into the professional backgrounds of the executives, a recent survey by Korn/Ferry International, the management recruiting firm, did make such a study.
As the nation's largest recruiting firm, it can tap into the thinking of many of its corporate clients, so it looked into the backgrounds of the executives now filling top jobs in this country.
''In 1979 when we conducted a similar study, finance and accounting were the fastest routes to the top,'' said Lester Korn, head of the recruiting firm.
Now, the firm found that marketing and sales were ''the quickest routes to the executive suites,'' with finance and accounting second and a general management background holding third place.
The respondents to the Korn/Ferry survey also took a look ahead and predicted that managers with marketing and sales skills would still be the leading source tapped for top management jobs in the year 2000. The primary reason is the growing acknowledgment of the importance of the consumer to business.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1179 words

HEADLINE: BANKS' PAYMENTS TO INSURE DEPOSITS MAY JUMP BY 30%

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation moved today to raise the premiums banks pay for deposit insurance by $1.1 billion, or 30 percent, next year. The action reflects increased concerns about the safety of the deposit insurance system and about the effects of depressed real estate prices on commercial banks and the overall economy.
Although considered stronger than the sister fund that insures deposits at savings and loan associations, the reserves of the F.D.I.C.'s Bank Insurance Fund, as a percent of insured deposits, have reached the lowest level since the agency was created in the early 1930's. The fund is now at half the level Congress mandated last year in the savings and loan bailout legislation, and 1990 is expected to produce a third consecutive year of losses. 
''What we are trying to do is to assure that our fund moves back to the required level and that the burden not fall on taxpayers for any payment,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the F.D.I.C. ''We have a considerable way to go.'' #30-Day Comment Period The action today, a call for a 30-day period of public comment before a final vote by the agency's five-member board in late September, was the first step in a regulatory process that is all but certain to require banks to pay 19.5 cents in insurance premiums for every $100 of insured deposits. That would be up 30 percent from a scheduled 15 cents per $100.
The savings and loan bailout legislation signed a year ago had scheduled a premium increase for 1991 of 3 cents for each $100 of insured bank deposits, raising the premium as of next January to 15 cents, from the current 12 cents. The F.D.I.C. action today would add another 4.5 cents to that scheduled increase.
The move did not surprise bankers. During the last three months, Mr. Seidman has repeatedly warned that the bank fund is ''under considerable stress.'' Earlier this month, he predicted that the fund's reserves, now at $13 billion, could fall to $11 billion by the end of the year.
The increase is certain to squeeze the profits of banks in 1991. The industry's earnings are declining, and bankers are casting about both to sell unprofitable assets and find new, profitable businesses.
For consumers, the increase is likely to mean that the costs of many bank services, like charges for overdrafts and monthly fees on checking accounts, will be raised to cover the higher insurance premiums. The costs were likely to have risen in any case, to cover the original premium increase mandated by the savings and loan bailout legislation, but the move today may result in a bigger jump in customer charges.
Taken together, the 3-cent scheduled increase and the additional 4.5-cent proposed rise for each $100 of insured deposits would amount to a total of $1.9 billion more in insurance premiums in 1991.
 
'Fund Is Under Stress'
Many bankers called the increase in their premiums a necessary evil.
''It will certainly narrow profitability,'' said John F. Betar, legislative counsel for the Association of Bank Holding Companies. ''On the other hand, we have always advocated a strong deposit insurance fund. The fund is under stress.''
Janet Pavliska, chairman of the National Council of Savings Institutions, said, ''The Bank Insurance Fund has been under serious pressure in recent months and we understand the need for an increase in the premiums.''
She added: ''There are negatives. The higher costs add to already overburdened operating costs at a time when it is difficult to recoup the full amount of the increase.''
Mr. Seidman said the agency had considered an even larger premium increase, but decided on the advice of its lawyers that the 4.5 cents, on top of the scheduled 3-cent increase for 1991, was the most it could impose under provisions of the bailout legislation.
 
Savings Industry Had Complained
The action heartened some lobbyists for the savings and loan industry, who have complained for months that savings institutions must pay considerably higher premiums on deposit insurance than banks, giving banks a competitive advantage.
Savings and loans now pay 23 cents for each $100 of deposits - the most currently allowed by law.
Mr. Seidman said the aim of the agency was to begin rebuilding the reserves of the bank fund, to avoid the need for a taxpayer bailout like the hugely expensive rescue of the savings industry.
Under the bailout law passed last year, Congress set a goal for the bank fund of $1.25 of reserves for each $100 of insured deposits - a level that is considered adequate.
As recently as 1987, the fund's reserves were $1.10, but they fell to 80 cents in 1988 and 70 cents in 1989, and are projected to fall below 60 cents by the end of the year. Mr. Seidman said it would take at least five years to reach the $1.25 level, assuming the 19.5-cent premium.
''The level of reserves is historically low,'' Mr. Seidman said today, ''and the unfortunate trend in recent years'' has been downward.
''Clearly, this is unacceptable,'' he added, ''and a change in direction is needed.''
Mr. Seidman said that while the proposed increase would eat into the industry's profitability, the agency's staff had calculated that it would reduce overall bank earnings by only 4 percent.
 
Growing Real Estate Concerns
The action today was the latest indication that banking regulators are growing increasingly concerned about the toll that weak real estate markets are taking on banks.
Earlier this year, Mr. Seidman had predicted that the bank fund could break even in 1990, but in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee two weeks ago, he radically changed that projection to a loss of $2 billion. He also said then that this year, for the third year in a row, almost 200 banks would fail.
Analysts have said that the prediction of a $2 billion drop in the fund means the Government will spend $6 billion on failures this year. The agency will bring in $3 billion in income from premiums this year and another $1 billion in interest income.
Although Mr. Seidman has said he does not foresee the failure of a very large bank this year, many analysts say a $6 billion deficit would have to include the failure of a big bank, possibly one in New England, where a slumping real estate market has increased defaults on loans.
 
Problems Are Spreading
One indication that the agency is gearing up for greater real estate losses, particularly from bank failures in New England, is that it plans to open a liquidation office in Boston with a staff of more than 400.
The projected loss in the Bank Insurance Fund is also a sign of the breadth of the downturn in commercial real estate markets across the country. Mr. Seidman has warned that what began as regional weakness in the Northeast has spread to most parts of the country and that it will be a while before the markets turn up.
This is particularly alarming to regulators, because banks have plunged heavily into real estate lending in recent years. More than half of all new bank loans in the late 1980's were for real estate.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
BUSH THREATENS A BLOCKADE OF JORDAN PORT AIDING IRAQ; KING COMES TO U.S. FOR TALKS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 15

 BODY:
As truckloads of cargo rolled from the Jordanian port of Aqaba toward Baghdad today, King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Washington for a meeting with President Bush in an apparent attempt to mediate the worsening crisis in the Middle East.
Mr. Bush said at a news conference in Washington on Tuesday that if Aqaba was ''a hole through which commerce flows,'' the United States would blockade the port, which seems to be the only gap remaining in the international quarantine of Iraq. But the President also hinted that if Jordan cooperated with the embargo, the United States would help compensate it for the economic suffering that sanctions would cause.
 
Seeking Aid for Jordan
American officials said Tuesday that the United States was also pressing West Germany, Japan and Saudi Arabia to help offset financial losses by Jordan and by Syria.
The stated purpose of the Presidential news conference was to talk about the Federal budget, and Mr. Bush lambasted Democrats on Capitol Hill for their attitude in negotiations on the Federal deficit. [Page A21.] But the focus shifted to the Middle East. King Hussein is under domestic pressure to keep Aqaba open. Amman imports 90 percent of its oil from Iraq and sends 40 percent of its total exports to Iraq. In addition, Jordan's large Palestinian population is sympathetic to the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, whom they see as a champion of the have-nots. 
 
Doubts on Workable Formula
Reports in several Middle Eastern capitals said the King was carrying a letter to Mr. Bush from President Hussein, whom he met in Baghdad on Monday.
ABC News, in a report from Baghdad, said that Foreign Ministry officials said the letter conveyed that President Hussein would like direct contact with United States officials and a sign that negotiation remains a possibilty. CBS News, citing unnamed Jordanian sources, said the message called for an international conference to discuss terms for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait in exchange for a freeze on the buildup of United States forces in Saudi Arabia, which has passed the 20,000 mark.
But two ranking Administration officials said they had no reason to believe that a workable peace formula would be produced by Mr. Bush's meeting with King Hussein, scheduled for Thursday at the President's vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me. The King arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington early today.
Mr. Bush himself, speaking to reporters at the White House on Tuesday as he took a brief hiatus from his 25-day holiday, said he saw no prospects for a diplomatic solution to the crisis until sanctions had bitten deeply enough to convince the Iraqis ''that they've got to get out of Kuwait, and they've got to let the rightful rulers return to Kuwait.'' Iraq annexed Kuwait last week.
Although the President deflected questions on the subject, aides said he had agreed to try to work out a plan under which American warships and those of other nations, some already committed to the blockade and others not, could operate under United Nations auspices.
 
Idea Discussed at Meeting
The idea, first broached several days ago by the Soviet Union, was discussed at a meeting at the State Department among officials of the five nations with permanent seats on the Security Council - the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France.
Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d were said to see the plan, which could involve a joint command or ships under separate commands all flying the United Nations flag, as an opportunity to involve Moscow in concerted international action, if complex problems of coordination could be resolved.
With American paratroopers moving into joint positions with Saudi soldiers to defend crucial oilfields, Pentagon officials said the Administration was considering a partial mobilization of the reserves. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told a veterans' group in Atlanta that the President had the authority to call up as many as 200,000 members of the National Guard or reserve forces.
Mr. Bush is to meet with the Joint Chiefs of Staff and other officers at the Pentagon today before returning to Maine, and the question of the reserves could come up then.
 
U.S. Focuses on Aqaba
Although rules of engagement have not been issued for the blockade of Iraqi commerce, which the Administration prefers to call an interdiction, Mr. Cheney said that ''we are watching all traffic that may be headed for Iraqi ports or may have cargo intended for Iraq.'' Among a handful of ships under surveillance, officials said, is the Iraqi-flag Balqees, believed to be carrying a cargo of tanks, engines and other military equipment from Gdynia in Poland to an unknown port in the Middle East.
The biggest worry for those trying to complete the economic encirclement of Iraq is the port of Aqaba, which lies at the head of an arm of the Red Sea. It is linked to Baghdad by a highway and a small pipeline, the last functioning outlet for Iraqi oil.
During the Iran-Iraq war, much of Iraq's war materiel and food flowed through Aqaba. It is easily accessible to the Mediterranean Sea through the Gulf of Suez and the Suez Canal, which Egypt declined today to close to Iraqi shipping, although Cairo is the leader of the group of Arab nations that have sent troops to Saudi Arabia to deter an Iraqi invasion.
A dozen ships were berthed at Aqaba on Tuesday or anchored offshore. While it was impossible to establish the destination of all the cargoes, John Prescott, a London shipping specialist, said he had been told that at least three of the ships carried goods bound for Baghdad.
The Associated Press reported from the Ruweishid border post, on the main highway linking Baghdad and Aqaba, that an unusually large number of heavy trucks and tankers were crossing from Jordan into Iraq. Military officials in Washington confirmed that Iraqi trade through Aqaba appeared to be proceeding at a brisk pace.
Mutasem Belbeisi, an under secretary at the Jordanian Foreign Ministry, said that although the United Nations sanctions voted on Aug. 6 were binding on all member states, ''every country whose economy can be severely affected can consult with the Security Council to see what measures could be adopted and what sanctions could be imposed, if any.'' He said such consultations were under way in New York.
 
Israel to Take No Action
Israel, whose port of Eilat also lies at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba, just a few miles down the coast from Aqaba, said it would take no action to interefere with Iraqi shipping through Aqaba. Only if Iraqi troops move into Jordan, officials said, will Israel become involved in the crisis.
So far, the blockade, to which American, British and Australian vessels have been committed, has not had a significant test. Arab harbormasters in the Persian Gulf turned away two Iraqi freighters, and a British warship stopped a third merchant ship but released it when an inspection showed it to have no cargo.
The buildup of forces in Saudi Arabia accelerated further with the arrival of the vanguard of Syrian troops. The Syrians joined about 5,000 Egyptians, and contingents from Morocco and possibly Pakistan are expected within a week or so.
A total of at least 100,000 American ground troops is expected to reach Saudi Arabia in the next month or two, and Mr. Cheney said today that an Iraqi force of 200,000 was now deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq.
In Kuwait and Iraq, at least 3,000 Americans, by the State Department's estimate, remained trapped.
Iraqi officials made conflicting statements about the status of the Americans and thousands of other foreigners. ABC News reported that a senior Foreign Ministry official in Baghdad called the Americans in Iraq ''restrictees'' who would have to remain until the crisis was over. And Iraq's Ambassador to Greece said in Athens that they could leave only when ''the threats from the United States and its allies have been eliminated.'' But the Iraqi Ambassador in Washington indicated that the release could come much earlier than that.
