HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
U.S. Remains at a Loss Trying to Predict Saddam Hussein's Next Move

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Nearly two weeks after the Iraqi Army seized the desert sheikdom of Kuwait, the United States has little sense of what Saddam Hussein will do next.
Bush Administration officials are united in their assessment - even in their adjectives - that the Iraqi President is not a mad Arab warrior, but a tough-minded, ruthless opportunist who is more vulnerable now than at any time in his 22 years in power. But American intelligence on him is poor, and officials differ on whether or when he will strike next.
So far, the Iraqi President has shown no sign of abandoning his stranglehold on Kuwait or pulling his troops from the Saudi border. And in private conversations with Administration officials, two different theories of Mr. Hussein's intentions emerge. 
The more conventional theory is that he is an unpredictable figure who invaded Kuwait with no warning and that he might be just as willing to move against Saudi Arabia or provoke a conflict that would involve Israel.
 
'He Could Sit It Out'
According to that analysis, Mr. Hussein's overwhelming vulnerability in the face of American troops digging into the Saudi desert and the economic quarantine on Iraqi trade does not necessarily mean that he will turn pragmatic, conclude that he miscalculated badly when he invaded and annexed his neighbor and look for a face-saving exit. Mr. Hussein might just stay put and hope that the international resolve on sanctions weakens or that the Arab world might not keep its commitment of unity with Saudi Arabia.
''He's isolated in a way he never has been before and he's facing extraordinarily massive American military force,'' said a senior Administration official who has followed events in the Middle East for years. ''But that doesn't mean he will get out of it and not attack Saudi Arabia or turn his attention to Israel. No one knows that. Or he could sit it out, and hope the whole sanctions thing against him falls apart.''
The theory continues that Mr. Hussein is likely to continue to play to the streets of the Arab world to push Arab leaders into a compromise attractive to Iraq.
Mr. Hussein could try to provoke riots in Amman or in Cairo, perhaps with the help of Iraqi cash and agents posing as workers returning home from Iraq. On Monday, he opened up a radio station that beams messages to Egyptians to rise up against their Government. Or he could resort to terrorist acts intended to break down Arab resolve.
There is a second, less-popular theory within the Administration about Mr. Hussein's intentions, less popular because it would ultimately involve negotiations and could give the impression of rewarding the aggressor at a time when the United States is trying to act tough. Asked about negotiations in his news conference today, President Bush said that he saw no hope for a diplomatic solution, at least until economic sanctions force Mr. Hussein to pull back his army.
According to that theory, Mr. Hussein is a bully who invaded Kuwait because he calculated - wrongly it turned out - that it would be a quick, low-risk way of seizing the skeikdom's oil and wealth. Now, that argument goes, Mr. Hussein realizes he cannot move across the Saudi border.
''With each passing day the probability of an attack on Saudi Arabia lessens,'' said a senior Administration official who is watching events closely.
Mr. Hussein, the theory continues, is a man capable of compromise. His various justifications for invading Kuwait and his ''peace proposal'' on Sunday listing conditions for withdrawal from Kuwait may indicate that he is looking for a face-saving resolution.
 
About-Faces by Hussein
Experts on Iraq inside the Administration liken his situation today to that in 1975, when he did a dramatic about-face and recognized Iran's territorial claims to the Shatt al Arab waterway in return for Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's promise to stop aiding Iraqi Kurdish rebels. Again, in 1982, when Iranian troops set foot on Iraqi soil, he abandoned his claim on Iran's Arab-speaking province of Khuzistan and desperately tried to end the border war he had started.
Despite public statements that the United States will not negotiate a settlement that would include concessions to Iraq, privately senior officials say a negotiated settlement might include free elections in Kuwait, and Arab financial support and some territorial concessions for Iraq.
If Iraq were to withdraw from Kuwait, that argument goes, the United States could settle for an Iraq confined to its borders, with Mr. Hussein still in power but with a long-term American military presence in the gulf.
The overthrow of Mr. Hussein is unlikely, and the destruction of his governing Baath Party impossible.
 
Ideas From Jordan's Leader
The Bush Administration may receive its first clear-cut indication of Mr. Hussein's intentions on Thursday, if King Hussein of Jordan delivers a message from the Iraqi President when he meets with President Bush. Senior policymakers privately have expressed the hope that the King, who has supported Iraq in the crisis, will provide some ideas for an eventual framework for a face-saving resolution.
But the King may not be able to offer any more insight into Mr. Hussein or his motives. Even officials who have followed his moves for years are mystified. ''He's clearly a tough, extraordinarily determined man,'' said a senior American diplomat with expertise on the Middle East. ''He's not in any way a maniac or out of his wits.''
But then, the official said, ''There are severe limitations in my own understanding of the man.''

PUB-DATE: August 15, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: Taking Budget Offensive, Bush Accuses Democrats of Imperiling Economy

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Saying the budget impasse at home deserved the same urgent attention as the crisis in the Persian Gulf, President Bush today dropped his gentleman's agreement with the Democratic leaders in Congress and accused them of endangering the economy by playing politics with the Federal deficit.
Accusing Congress of ''an abdication of responsibility that endangers our economic vitality and the jobs that go with it,'' the President termed the lack of a budget ''a real threat to the economic well-being of this country.''
Mr. Bush spoke at a news conference at the White House after a meeting with advisers who gave him an assessment of how the confrontation in the Middle East would affect budget negotiations between the Administration and Congress.
Trying to shift part of the nation's attention away from the the Persian Gulf, Mr. Bush began his news conference with a statement intended to satisfy the demands of his fellow Republicans that he take the offensive on the budget before the resumption of the talks early next month. 
 
'Process Has Broken Down'
''We're getting right down to the crunch,'' Mr. Bush said. He added, ''It is no secret to the American people that the Congressional budget process has broken down.''
The President has been saying he feels ''liberated'' to criticize the Democrats since a confidential Administration plan on taxes appeared in news reports last month. He blames Democrats for the disclosure and said the breach of the agreement to keep details of the budget negotiations secret allows him to take the offensive.
Presidential aides say Mr. Bush hesitated to do so last week because he did not want to strain the bipartisan support for his decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia.
The President has been smarting because the Democrats have managed to get an Administration proposal for taxes into the public debate without responding with any politically unpleasant proposals of their own.
 
Democrats Taken Aback
Democrats seemed taken aback by the tartness and timing of Mr. Bush's attack today.
''Frankly, we are flabbergasted at the President's remarks,'' said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. ''At a time when all Democrats are hoping and praying for the success of the Administration's Persian Gulf policy, we do not understand why the President wants to divide Americans along partisan lines.''
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said: ''If there has been an 'abdication of responsibilities' on the budget, it has been on the part of the President.''
''Just a few months ago,'' Mr. Mitchell said, ''in his State of the Union address the President claimed that his proposed budget would reduce the deficit, meet the Gramm-Rudman target, and balance the budget by 1993, all with no new taxes. Every one of those statements was inaccurate, as he himself has now admitted.''
 
Threat of Vetos
The President warned that if there is still no budget agreement by Oct. 1, there would be a ''painful'' $100 billion cut in non-military spending programs, as required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit-reduction law. He also threatened to veto ''any and every spending bill'' that he believed would stretch the budget beyond the limits imposed by the law.
''While they have the power of the purse,'' the President said of Congress, he has ''the power of the veto pen.''
''I'm still here in a nice tranquil mood, wanting to discuss it with them,'' Mr. Bush said, with a grin. ''But you see, we had this kind of a truce on this abiding by the Marquis of Queensberry's 'no comment' rules. And so, during this period of truce I'm going to put the focus where it belongs and where the American people year after year know it belongs, and that is on the party that controls the United States Congress.''
Mr. Bush renewed his attack on the Congressional budget process, calling it a ''procedural monstrosity,'' and arguing that ''nobody cares'' about Congress getting bogged down ''in the jurisdiction of this committee or another.''
Using a tried and true political technique, the President managed to blame the Democratic leadership of the House, including Speaker Thomas S. Foley and Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader, by saying he was not going to do so.
''I'm not going to accuse Tom Foley of this or Dick Gephardt of this,'' he said, ''but I think there were some saying, 'Hey, we think we got the President over a barrel here. We've made him back away and give and give and give and get nothing.' And my view is, 'Well, fine, if that's the game that some up there want to play.' ''
 
Careful Selection of Facts
Both sides are carefully selecting their facts and emphasis to present the budget negotiations in the most favorable light for their side.
While the President asserted that Administration officials had refrained from ''divisive rhetoric'' on the budget, he was correct only in that they had not done so for public quotation. There have been several instances in which senior Bush Administration officials attacked Democrats in private sessions in which reporters had agreed not to quote them by name.
At the same time, the Democrats have yet to offer a specific alternative to the White House proposals.
Mr. Bush, who especially dislikes unauthorized policy disclosures, referred derisively today to the way an Administration plan that included some tax increases had ''oozed'' into news reports last month.
Senator Mitchell responded today by contending that it was a Republican negotiator who provided the information to reporters and noted that many Republicans as well as Democrats had criticized the plan.
''The President's anger at the leak of the Republican plan to the press by a Republican should not serve as justification for unfair and inaccurate criticisms of the Democrats,'' said Mr. Mitchell.
 
Top Budget Aides Absent
White House officials said Mr. Bush had returned to Washington from his vacation to discuss the budget with top advisers. But no new numbers or proposals were discussed at the meeting and the President could not answer afterward how much the deployment of American military forces to the Persian Gulf would cost.
Two of the pivotal figures on budget matters did not attend the meeting. Richard G. Darman, the budget director, was not at the White House and Nicholas F. Brady, the Treasury Secretary, did not come back from a Midwest campaign swing for Republican candidates.

PUB-DATE: August 15, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2567 words

HEADLINE: Excerpts of News Conference By Bush on Budget and Gulf

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
I know that the focus of the media attention today, and understandably, is on a crisis 6,000 miles away. But there's another important well-known longstanding crisis at home, and that's the failure of the budget process to produce a solution to this nation's deficit, terrible deficit.
And even while we address our critical international obligations, we must address that persistent, real need. And therefore, I want to just take a few minutes to talk about that.
Our current budget or lack thereof constitutes a real threat to the economic well-being of this country. And in this case the problem is a lack of action on the part of the Congress, and abdication of responsibility that endangers our economic vitality and the jobs that go with it. 
It is no secret to the American people that the Congressional budget process has broken down. Over the last couple of decades, we've seen the real problems of overspending. And we've seen the stalemate in budgeting, which is the result of internal Congressional conflicts and a committee system that is so complex that not only have the hard decisions been postponed or avoided, but today nearly all budget decisions are being finessed.
Previous Presidents have urged fundamental reform, fundamental budget reform. And we can all remember President Reagan slamming down that massive continuing resolution, and yet Congress has failed to straighten out this procedural monstrosity. As a result the deficit continues to grow. And with the growing threat such deficit spending poses, I took the initiative in May in calling on the Democratic Congressional leaders to join me in a bipartisan summit on the budget.
And the success of this summit is essential to insure the economic health of the nation, to resolve once and for all the deficit dilemma and in doing so to avoid the painful sequester cuts which will occur without an agreement.
 
Move to Jump-Start Budget Talks
As the talks flagged, I acted to jump-start them. And you're all familiar with that. When the Democrats sought to hold the talks hostage over new revenues, I made a very difficult decision to put everything, including taxes, on the table to make those budget talks succeed.
And to keep those budget talks going, the Administration kept - I feel I kept my share of the bargain - the Administration refrained from divisive rhetoric. We worked in earnest. We held meeting after meeting without any preconditions, and emphasized the need above all for progress to put a budget package together.
We offered billions in additional spending cuts even as Congressional committees were voting out spending bills that would bust the budget. Only July 26, both sides agreed to put budget plans on the table. We again had a complete proposal ready for negotiation. And after weeks of good-faith negotiating, we expected, we honestly believed there would be a specific Democratic plan in exchange.
And while the summit failed to move forward with specific solutions, the Congress continued with counterproductive legislation. For example, the House has already passed 10 appropriations bills, eight of which exceed my request for discretionary spending by $14 billion, and are $25 billion higher than the budget for last year.
And the Senate is asking the taxpayers now put up another $150 million to finance election campaigns of Congress. And let me be clear on that one: I oppose adding this kind of taxpayer financing of Congressional elections, and I'm going to veto any such bill that appears on my desk.
Now Congress is now on recess. And 100 days after I called on Democrats and Republicans in the Congress to work with me toward a bipartisan solution, I note, frankly in sadness, that after three full months the Democrats have yet to offer one single proposal at the budget summit.
 
Focus on Democrats in Congress
And I've been reluctant to go public in this matter. We've dealt in good faith with the leaders. We have played by the rules. And now it is up to the Democrats who control Congress. It is up to the Democrats in Congress.
And I stand ready to work on this process as long as it takes to get a five-year package which solves the problem. And I have postponed what I think was a very important September trip to Latin America so as to focus on this issue. And there are, however, a number of specific realities to be noted.
First, it's the Congress that has the responsibility to pass a budget. And while they have the power of the purse, like any power -President, I've got the power of the veto pen. And I will use that pen to veto any and every spending bill that busts the budget.
And second, if no budget is agreed - no agreement is reached, that means a sequester on Oct. 1 of about $100 billion. And painful as such deep cuts would be, I must uphold the law, I'm determined to manage them as best I can, knowing that I've done all in my power to avoid them.
And so, the Democrats in Congress should know that if it comes to sequester, they'll will bear a heavy responsibility for the consequences.
And third, if the Congress really wants economic growth and increased Government revenues, the place to start is not with tax increases, but with incentives for growth, investment in jobs. And again I cite the capital gains area as one that would stimulate and be investment oriented.
And fourthly, the Congress must recognize the utter failure of their budget process to control spending. It's got to be reformed. The process has to be reformed.
And fifth, our budget must maintain a defense posture consistent with the demands on American leadership in the world and in the dangers we face.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Blockade and Annexation
Q. Mr. President, I have a two-part question. After successfully internationalizing opposition to the Iraqi aggression through the U.N., why did you jump the gun and unilaterally order a blockade, upsetting other members? And two, is the U.S. policy against the annexation of captured lands in the Middle East an across-the-board policy with the U.S.?
A. Upsetting? I don't think we've upset members on our policy of interdiction. We are acting within our legal rights, and I don't think - I think the world wants to see these Chapter 51 sanctions carried out. And that's the role that the United States is trying to do.
Q. But you didn't go through the step-by-step with Chapter 7.
A. Well, we're doing it the way our attorneys and others around the world recommend. And I think we're doing it properly. And I hope we're doing it to the degree that all ships will turn back if they're - if they're in contravention of the U.N. action.
Q. How about the last --
A. The last, what was that?
Q. Opposition to annexation of conquered lands.
A. Well, I can only address myself in the current - currently. I don't know whether there are any exceptions or not. But I know that annexation, if this is what one calls this invasion of Kuwait, is unacceptable. And that is - it won't stand.
 
Jordan and Iraqi Sanctions
Q. Mr. President, Jordan says that it's abiding by the U.N. sanctions, yet truckloads of goods are rolling through Jordan into Iraq coming from the port of Aqaba. Do you think that Jordan is subverting the sanctions, and what will you do about it?
A. Well, before I answer your question, I ought to let King Hussein tell me whether -you know what is happening - and if a country is not, is permitting a flow of commerce, it would be in violation of the sanctions. But I -you know he's coming here and I'll have a chance to talk to him and explain the U.S. view, though I'm pretty sure he understands it clearly.
Q. Let me ask you, what do you think about King Hussein's charges that the American forces in the Persian Gulf have created an explosive situation.
A. I don't know what he means by that, but I don't agree with that. I think we are there not to have the situation explosive but to supplement fully what the United Nations has done in condemning this outrageous aggression, so we'll discuss that one, too. It's going to be an interesting conversation, I'd say, if you're writing his agenda for him.
 
Reason for King Hussein's Visit
Q. Why is King Hussein coming when he called to ask you that he'd like to come? His brother has told reporters in Jordan that one of Jordan's problems is it would suffer so, economically, if it abided by the sanctions. They complained that they had no guarantees or assurances from the West. What can you offer?
A. Maybe that's what he wants to talk about. I hope it is. Because clearly we've always been a friend of Jordan. We've helped them in the past. We'd help them in the future, if they fulfill their obligations here. But I, Anne, I can just tell you what he told me on the telephone yesterday when he called. He said I'd like to come over and talk about the whole situation. There was no agenda; there was no discussion of any support for action of that kind.
Q. But you are willing to support him economically or have other countries in the region help him?
A. I think we would, provided Jordan joined these other countries in fulfilling these sanctions, obligations under the sanctions.
 
Outlook on Diplomatic Solution
Q. Mr. President, is there any hope at all of a diplomatic solution to this crisis?
A. I don't see it right now. But as the sanctions begin to take effect, and it's going to take a while, I would hope there would be a diplomatic solution to this crisis.
Q. But, sir, like the other day when Saddam Hussein offered his proposal, which I realize was totally unacceptable to you, I mean, could that serve as a basis for perhaps some type of negotiation?
A. I don't think just any proposal serves as a basis for negotiation. No, I couldn't, I don't see enough positive elements there to think that that would be a basis for a negotiation at all. It was bringing all extraneous problems and it did not address itself to the fundamental problem, which is that they took over Kuwait and that they've got to get out of Kuwait. And they've got to let their rightful rulers return to Kuwait. So I don't see that as a, you know, possibility to negotiate from that, those proposals at all.
 
U.N. Command in Action on Iraq
Q. Mr. President, you have ambassadors coming to the State Department presumably to discuss a U.N. multinational quarantine or interdiction, whatever word you want.Is it now the policy of the United States to potentially submit to a joint U.N. command or to reflag U.S. ships under a U.N. command?
A. That is not the plan right now, but we are talking to see how we can make this naval presence most effective. But that, what you said there, is not the policy of the United States.
Q. Well, sir, may I ask do you consider in any way - there are reports out of the U.N. that there is some criticism that you have acted unilaterally and perhaps outside your legal authority in this de facto blockade that's going on. Do you consider that you've had your hand slapped, or do you think --
A. No, I don't think so at all.
 
Sharing Costs of Operation
Q. Mr. President, given the staggering, given the staggering number in the deficit and the cost of the military operation in the gulf and in Saudi Arabia, doesn't it make sense that some of the countries that are relying on us will pay some of the cost? I'm thinking, of course, of Japan, Germany, France, Italy. Shouldn't they pay some of the cost of our troops over there?
A. I think that we will find a very cooperative spirit in that regard from countries. I'm convinced, from a good talk I had - I think it was yesterday - with Prime Minister Kaifu - that the Japanese are more than ready to entertain proposals along those lines. I've not talked to Kohl about that recently. France, of course, has vessels and are spending funds on their own right now, but I think you'll find - I think we'll have a cooperative - cooperative effort here, some on the financial side, some on the military and shipping side.
Q. What about the Saudis themselves? They're the most direct beneficiaries?
A. Yes, I think the Saudis will do their part in helping out along the way. I'm confident of that. And I also would say - the question hasn't yet been asked - that I am also confident that other countries will make up the shortfall in production that comes about from Iraqi oil, and Kuwaiti oil, not going to market. I can't give you the details on that, but I've had enough conversations with people around the world. Jim Baker has as well -General Scowcroft - to feel that things are moving in the right direction there. Yeah, John?
 
Americans Held by Iraqis
Q. Mr. President, the Iraqis have now held Americans for 12 to 13 days. Are you willing to sacrifice those Americans should it come to direct military action?
A. I'm never willing to sacrifice the life of any American. Sacrifice? No.
Q. Do you believe the Iraqis are using those Americans as a shield against potential American --
A. I don't have that feeling now, and I hope I never come to that because you see difficulty of others getting out and so it's a - but it's a troubling situation when people are held against their will or delayed from leaving. It troubles me.
Q. What's their status in your view?
A. Status is inconvenienced people who want to get out and it's not only them but a lot of others. And I hope that it doesn't become more than that. I have no reason to think at this juncture that it will. But the more we talk about it and the more we speculate about it, the less helpful it is, I think. But I'd like to feel that all foreigners who want to leave Kuwait or want to leave Iraq would be free to do so. And there have been some encouraging statements - you heard from their Ambassador this morning - that make me say, well, let's see, let's wait and see on that one.
 
U.S. Presence in Saudi Arabia
Q. Mr. President, should the American people look forward to an ongoing American presence in Saudi Arabia over a period of years?
A. I don't know about a period of years, but certainly we're going to be there long enough to get the job done.But I can't, I'd like to give you a time frame. I can't.
 
Iraqi Withdrawal From Kuwait
Q. Mr. President, just very briefly, you have called repeatedly for the Iraqis to be out of Kuwait, to withdraw unconditionally and completely. You've helped put sanctions in place to try and force them to do that.How important is that withdrawal? Is it important enough that if the sanctions don't seem to work after a short period that you will promise to use military force to force Saddam Hussein out.
A. That is too hypothetical a question. We have a plan, and the plan is to implement fully the United Nations's sanction and also a part of our plan is to - arrangement with King Fahd is to help protect Saudi Arabia in a part of a multinational force now of quite a few countries against aggression from Saddam Hussein, the same kind of aggression that took over Kuwait. So that's where we are. That's the plan, and I just can't help you by going in a hypothetical sense any further.
Listen, I hate to run, but I do have an appointment in here, and thank you very much.

HEADLINE: Congress Acts to Admit More Skilled Immigrants

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
In a step long favored by free-market economists, Congress is moving to admit more skilled immigrants - scientists, engineers, medical technicians - to compensate for expected labor shortages in the 1990's.
The number of immigrants selected on the basis of their job skills, now about 23,000 a year, would rise to more than 85,000 under a bill passed by the Senate. The number would be 75,000 under a companion bill moving through the House of Representatives.
Congress, the Labor Department and many researchers see the admission of permanent immigrants, not temporary workers, as a way to correct the mismatch between labor supply and demand. 
The notion has aligned free-market economists with immigrant-rights advocates in support of increased immigration, giving more weight to job skills in selecting newcomers. But it may also revive an old debate over the role of immigrants in the economy, including their effects on the job prospects of members of minorities already here.
 
New View on Immigrants
For decades, it was assumed that immigrants took jobs from Americans and depressed wages and working conditions in industries where they were concentrated. But increasingly, research suggests that immigrants create jobs and pay much more in taxes than they get in social welfare benefits.
''The debate has definitely shifted,'' said Representative Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of Connecticut, who, with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is leading the campaign for immigration legislation designed to tap needed job skills. ''In the past, few people focused on legal immigration as an economic issue. But a growing body of evidence shows that immigration creates jobs and stimulates demand. You need a growing economy to produce jobs for unemployed workers, and labor shortages can be a barrier to economic growth.''
The Senate has passed a bill revamping the system for choosing immigrants. Mr. Kennedy, who is chairman of both the Committee on Labor and Human Resources and the Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, said his bill ''recognizes future U.S. labor needs, especially for skilled professionals.''
The House Judiciary Committee approved Mr. Morrison's similar bill on Aug. 1, just before the Congressional recess, and the measure is likely to win approval from the full House. Its fate may depend on whether the Bush Administration works actively for or against it.
 
Administration's Position
The Administration says it supports ''a modest increase in the number of legal immigrants'' and prefers the Senate bill over the House version.
The Senate bill includes a point system for assessing would-be immigrants. Points would be awarded for education, occupational training, work experience and age, with credit going to those in 21 to 44 years old. Under current law, most immigrants qualify for visas because of their family connections. While not diminishing preferences for relatives of United States citizens and permanent resident aliens, the Senate and House bills would increase the number of immigrants chosen for their job skills.
The United States has been admitting about 500,000 immigrants a year, not counting refugees. Under the Senate bill, the number would rise to 630,000 a year. The House bill would permit an increase to 775,000. The additional visas would be made available to workers, their spouses and children and the relatives of United States citizens and permanent resident aliens.
The number of skilled workers wishing to migrate to the United States far exceeds the number of available visas, so there is a waiting list of several years in some countries.
 
Labor Backs House Version
The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations supports Mr. Morrison's bill, in part because it would establish stricter criteria for admission of temporary foreign workers.
A report for the Labor Department by the Hudson Institute, ''Work Force 2000,'' has popularized the idea that labor shortages threaten the United States' ability to compete in world markets. The study said the United States population and work force would grow more slowly in the 1990's than at any time since the 1930's. ''The fastest-growing jobs will be in professional, technical and sales fields requiring the highest education and skill levels,'' it said.
Under current law, the United States annually admits about 23,000 immigrants chosen on the basis of their job skills. Demetrios G. Papademetriou, director of immigration policy and research at the Labor Department, said that 44 percent of those foreign workers obtained their visas for jobs requiring ''low skills and education.'' Many are domestic workers, cooks and hotel and restaurant workers.
Under the Kennedy bill, such unskilled workers would have much more difficulty obtaining visas, Mr. Papademetriou said. Under the Senate bill, the United States would still admit many immigrants from the third world, but those chosen on the basis of their job skills would, in general, have more formal education and training than those who now get such visas.
 
Concern About Unskilled
Many businesses say it is cheaper and easier to import foreign-born professionals than to invest in the education and training of unskilled, poorly educated Americans. Some blacks, like Milton D. Morris, research director at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research institute, express concern that ''if we turn too quickly to immigrants to meet labor-market needs, we might be sidestepping our responsibility to develop the human resources of people already here.''
Under the House bill, companies with 50 or more employees would have to pay a fee of $500 to $1,000 for each foreign worker they hire. The proceeds would be used to educate and train American workers.
Economists as diverse as Milton Friedman and John Kenneth Galbraith subscribe to the emerging consensus that ''the long-run benefits of immigration greatly exceed any short-run costs,'' as President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers said this year.
With the birth rate relatively low, immigration now accounts for 27 percent of population growth in the United States, and the Census Bureau says it will account for a steadily growing share in the next two decades. Even with no increase in admission quotas, immigration would have a major impact on the composition of the American labor force.
At the same time, the politics of immigration is changing. Rick Swartz, an immigraton lawyer here, said: ''The pro-immigration coalition is expanding. In 1980, it involved churches, Hispanic and Asian groups and civil rights lawyers. Today it also includes major corporations, industry associations and conservative think tanks like the Heritage Foundation and the Hudson Institute.''

HEADLINE: Use the United United Nations

 BODY:
The first sour note has sounded in President Bush's exemplary management of the Persian Gulf crisis. He is faulted for unilaterally ordering naval interdiction of Iraqi ports without waiting for United Nations support. Though Mr. Bush acted legally, the criticism is valid. He can best respond by working with the Security Council to create a joint U.N. command to enforce mandatory economic sanctions against Iraq. 
The chief reason Mr. Bush has not gone that route is Pentagon skittishness about practical difficulties, like winning rapid agreement on rules of engagement for a multinational force. But the benefits so obviously outweigh the difficulties that a prompt course correction is in order. Indeed, Secretary of State Baker is making that case, evidently with some success.
The U.N. has surprised even itself with the unanimity and vigor of its response to Iraq's lawless grab of Kuwait. The Security Council has voted tough mandatory sanctions and refused to countenance Baghdad's annexation of a tiny neighbor. Crucial to this consensus has been the support of the Soviet Union, which also favors a multinational force.
The President had ample legal grounds to move on his own. Kuwait's deposed rulers asked the U.S. to help enforce a U.N. embargo. As Mr. Bush noted yesterday, his response was consistent with the U.N. Charter. But as a matter of policy, the better course would have been to strive for Security Council approval first. It is far from clear that moving so fast has won him advantages that outweigh the cost of bypassing the Security Council and its permanent members.
The political case for joint action is compelling. A multinational fleet in the gulf, flying a U.N. flag, can blunt Saddam Hussein's most powerful propaganda weapon: anti-Americanism. It can offer a protective umbrella to Arab rulers now being assailed as foreign accomplices and Israeli stooges. And success in the gulf would serve powerfully to deter future transgressions.
Indeed, the United States has now decided to support a Soviet suggestion for reactivating the U.N.'s moribund Military Staff Committee. This was the instrument envisioned by the charter for carrying out military operations under the command of the Security Council's permament members. Superpower rivalry neutralized this useful entity after the bitter Soviet experience in the Korean War. Taking advantage of a Soviet walkout, America won a U.N. mandate for the forces in Korea.
President Bush deserves credit for his energy and skill in mobilizing the collective global response to Iraq's aggression. And the U.S. buildup in Saudi Arabia has been swift and efficient. But it is the truly united United Nations that has emboldened Arab states to add their troops to a multinational army. Americans have every reason to press for a similar collective effort at sea.

HEADLINE: Mr. Rinfret on Garbage

 BODY:
Pierre Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, believes that one way to give plausibility to his quixotic campaign against Gov. Mario Cuomo is to offer dramatically unconventional solutions to New York State's problems. He now proposes to resolve the struggle over landfills and incinerator sites by allowing local communities to bid for the right not to have them. That's certainly an original idea. It's also nonsense.
The winners in any such auction would assuredly be the wealthier counties and municipal governments. Poorer upstate communities would stand little chance against the resources of, say, Scarsdale, Bronxville, Rye and other well-heeled communities in Westchester County. What Mr. Rinfret proposes is to give the destructive principle of Nimby - Not in My Backyard - the imprimatur of market economics.
The plan also oversimplifies a hugely complex problem. To the dismay of many other states, New York already exports 11 percent of its trash, in part because existing landfills are closing for environmental reasons. Any plausible solution to the solid waste crisis requires a larger strategy combining recycling, waste-to-energy plants and equitable siting of landfills.
Mr. Rinfret is quite right to suggest that Albany has no such strategy now; but putting trash up for auction is hardly the answer. One environmentalist calls his proposal ''the worst case of toxic imperialism I've ever heard of.''
It also contradicts other aspects of his environmental program. In the same speech, Mr. Rinfret criticized proposals to limit development in the Adirondacks because they would be unfair to local residents. But those same cash-poor residents would almost certainly wind up as the reluctant recipients of other people's garbage.

HEADLINE: Immigrants Help Others Lost in Maze

BYLINE: By KAREN De WITT

 BODY:
Sung Soo Kim, a native of South Korea, does not know Esther Cartagena, formerly of Puerto Rico, or Philippe Wilson Desir, formerly of Haiti. But in their adopted city, they each serve a similar role: helping to guide compatriots recently arrived from their homelands through the bureaucratic maze that governs social services, the education of their children and how they do business.
Immigration experts say those guides and others like them are in greater demand than ever before, as New York City adjusts to its third great wave of immigration since the middle of the 19th century.
The latest influx, which began in the 1960's, approaches 100,000 immigrants a year. About 2.6 million people, or one-third of the city's population, are estimated to be foreign-born. 
''The new immigrant needs a broker to help navigate the public bureaucracies,'' said Lido Tomasi of the Center for Migration Studies on Staten Island. ''Today the Federal and state governments play a direct fiscal role where 100 years ago they weren't players. The 1986 amnesty situation, outreach to the undocumented, direct involvement of state agencies to provide English language classes, that kind of involvement is relatively new.''
 
'Parties Are Less Important'
Years ago political parties were an important source of and conduit to jobs for new immigrants.
''That's changed now so that parties are less important, and what you have is publically funded social service agencies,'' said Josh De Wind, a professor of anthropology at Hunter College. ''People who are representative of immigrant groups try to become social service providers by making application for reading programs, health programs and things like that or just knowing about them.'' Mr. Kim is one such person. Five years ago, Mr. Kim, a former political science professor at the University of Seoul, formed the Korean American Small Business Service Center of New York Inc. Since then he has sponsored more than 30 seminars on the ins and outs of doing business in the United States.
Out of his tiny second-floor office in Flushing, Queens, packed with books on New York City and state business codes, Mr. Kim tries to clarify, amend and decode for his fellow countrymen the labyrinth of laws that govern how they and other small merchants do business. Below is his constituency: Korean-American greengrocers, dry cleaners, nail parlor operators and deli owners.
Mr. Kim said that Korean shopkeepers, often touted as model immigrants because of their business acumen, often end up handing out much of their profit in fines, often because they know neither the rules nor their rights of appeal. Spilling off Mr. Kim's desk and out of folders are pamphlets he produced in Korean on everything from how to read a water meter to how to make a profit.
Though much of his day is spent wielding phones and searching documents, the 50-year-old Mr. Kim is just as likely to find his work out on the streets during a luncheon break. Recently on Roosevelt Avenue, he had just such a situation.
'' 'The usual problems. The usual reasons.' Do you hear him? 'The usual.' What is this 'usual'?'' Mr. Kim repeated like a litany Environmental Control Board Superintendant J. G. Kennelly's explanation for checking the dimensions of two fruit and vegetable stands at the Big Apple greengrocer on Roosevelt Avenue for the second time in two weeks.
 
Government's Tape Measures
Sun Yong Back, 35, who works in the shop his family owns, stood mute while Mr. Kim argued.
Mr. Kennelly knew Mr. Kim from seeing him at hearings, but he and Inspector Frank Merlo had their work to do and their tape measures out. Each stand should take up no more than 10 by 4 feet of space. The stands were a foot or so larger than the limit.
Mr. Kim told Mr. Back that he would go down to appeal. Maybe it would work, maybe it wouldn't, but he had been effective in the past.
Last November, after eight months of negotiating, Mr. Kim saved the greengrocers $1.5 million when he persuaded the city's Environmental Control Board to halve $3 million in fines for dirty sidewalks and sanitary violations. Some storekeepers owed as much as $70,000 because they hadn't appealed the fines. ''These people work 12 and 14 hours six days a week,'' said Mr. Kim. ''They cannot shut their stores to go down and appeal this overenforcement.''
Mr. Kim wants the city to institute night appeals court for such violations. He also wants to change the standards. ''These stand regulations were established in the 1930's. What hasn't changed since then? Everything but these laws.''
Mr. Kim sees political action as the best way to solve the group's problems. ''It's not just the A B C's that we need, but teeth and muscle. That comes through political involvement.'' But Mr. Kim isn't hopeful that his community will assert itself in the political arena any time soon.
''People say they don't have time or they don't want to make trouble. They're too busy making a living, trying to get an economic foothold in this country. Leave it to the next generation, they say, but I say that we should be doing both now,'' said Mr. Kim.
Mr. Kim's counterpart in Brooklyn is Mr. Desir, a former lieutenant in Haiti's coast guard.
 
Radio Voice for Haitians
Earlier immigrants depended on fliers or newspapers in their native languages to keep up with affairs at home. More often today it is radio and television that link ethnic communities.
Thousands of Haitian immigrants know Mr. Desir through the nine and a half hours of community affairs programming he broadcasts each week on New York City radio stations.
As a result, dozens of people go to his small storefront on Eastern Parkway in the Crown Heights section each week looking for everything from news about the latest political shifts in Haiti to a translation of a French document into English.
The walls of the triangular shop are covered with Haitian paintings and awards from Haitian emigre associations. On a recent day, several people sat on metal folding chairs waiting for Mr. Desir, who was late because he had to see his family off at the airport.
The air was filled with the quiet murmur of French and Creole, but the office came alive with the arrival of Mr. Desir, a compact man with a sleepy-eyed, dour expression.
 
An Assurance in Creole
Before he could get into the door, a man politely accosted him on the street, gesturing to a woman who was standing a few feet away.
In Creole, Mr. Desir assured the man that he would help the woman with her immigration problem.
''This is my neighborhood. This is my territory,'' said Mr. Desir, who is president of the Alliance of Haitian Emigres in Brooklyn. ''Anything I can do to help, I do.''
Mr. Desir fled to the United States with his family in 1970. After Haiti's first elections in 30 years were canceled amid terrorism at the polls in 1987, it was to Mr. Desir's office that many immigrants retreated to find out the fate of relatives still in Haiti.
On the Lower East Side of Manhattan, recent arrivals from Puerto Rico, a commonwealth of the United States, soon hear about Esther Cartagena, the woman who can help them find ''little jobs.''
''I think of myself as an example of what anybody can do,'' said Mrs. Cartagena, 44, who recently took a job as director of the Department of Puerto Rican Community Affairs, an agency of Puerto Rico. ''Look around. What are the needs? What can people do.''
Mrs. Cartagena worked for several years for the Lower East Side Housing Coalition and began her informal job-referral service there.
 
'Looking for Esther'
''I had so many meetings to go to and other women at the meetings were like me. They'd run in and say, 'I had to leave my kids by themselves, so I'll be getting up to call them a lot during this meeting.' We had so much guilt. Then one day I realized that one of the people who came to my office, a woman who had only a welfare check and a Social Security check, she could do a bit of babysitting.
''Or many of the landlords would tell me that they had to raise the rent because they had to paint. And I'd say 'Hey, if I can get you some people to paint who won't cost so much, maybe you won't have to raise the rent so much.' So I'd say to some unemployed men, listen guys, here you can make some money painting. They would do the work for less money than a regular contractor.
''This wasn't my job, but people started looking for Esther.''
Mrs. Cartagena says she believes in immigrants' getting jobs in their neighborhoods because it eliminates traveling costs, provides needed service to the community and frequently does not require knowledge of English.
''It doesn't have to be a big job, or a full-time job, just a job,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Once a Hotel Desert, Times Square Blooms

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
Times Square, which has been a near-wasteland for hotels since the Beaux-Arts splendor of the Astor met the wrecker's ball in the 1960's, is now at the center of a virtual tide of new hotels. Coming in the wake of a wave of high-rise construction on the West Side, two brand-new skyscraper hotels, the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza on Broadway at 49th Street and the Hotel Macklowe on West 44th Street just east of Broadway, have opened in the last few months. A third new high-rise hotel, the Embassy Suites at the corner of 47th Street and Seventh Avenue, will open in September.
Together with the Marriott Marquis, which opened in 1985 on Broadway between 45th and 46th Streets, they hold the potential to make Times Square a locus for visitors to New York in a way that it has not been for a generation.
Joining with those new buildings is the renovated Paramount on West 46th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. The hotel, once the Century Paramount, has been redone by the French designer Philippe Starck for the hotelier Ian Schraeger as a budget version of Morgans and the Royalton, the innovative hotels Mr. Schraeger created with his late partner, Steve Rubell. The Paramount has remained open throughout its renovation, and the Starck-designed guest rooms are now all complete; the new lobby, restaurants and public rooms were completed yesterday. 
Though it is the one Times Square project that is not a completely new building, the Paramount, which is part of Mr. Schraeger's Morgans Hotel Group, is the one that holds out the most promise as a work of design and architecture: Mr. Starck's rooms, which begin at $90 a night, have a kind of sensual chic to them. The low price has meant that the rooms are small and tight (the configuration of the original rooms at the Paramount, built as a middle-class hotel, was left intact to keep renovation costs down) but they have the same aura of crispness and sensuality that marked Mr. Starck's rooms at the much more expensive Royalton a few blocks to the east.
The lobby is shaping up to be a handsome, wonderfully proportioned space of richly colored marble and cool gray plaster, its rear marked by a canted wall of silver against which a staircase slices its way up. The work of Mr. Starck, who was aided here by the architect Anda Andrei, has always had a curious mix of theatrical flamboyance and modernist discipline, playing on the swoops and curves and colors of 1950's modernism and integrating those things into a kind of 1980's sensibility.
This lobby manages to be sumptuous yet restrained, and with its brand-name concessionaires - a restaurant by Brian McNally, a take-out gourmet shop by Dean & DeLuca - it may feel to many visitors as if SoHo has drifted three miles uptown.
 
Better From the Inside
No more characteristic of the seedy, faded elegance that is the traditional image of Times Square is the lobby of the Hotel Macklowe on West 44th Street. This lobby is a spectacular interior set within a mediocre new tower of dark green glass on a stone base that appears to have been designed for another building altogether. If ever there was a building in Manhattan where it is better to be inside looking out than outside looking in, it is the Hotel Macklowe. Here, one of Manhattan's most banal outsides hides one of its most appealing new insides.
The building was designed by the firm of Perkins & Will along with the architect William Derman, the head of the design staff of the hotel's developer, Harry Macklowe, who gained some notoriety five years ago when a contractor hired by one of his companies illegally demolished a single-room-occupancy hotel on this new building's site.
Mr. Derman himself did the interiors, and they are among the city's most impressive and sophisticated new public spaces. The lobby, a mix of marble, metal and mahogany, comes closer than any space since the renovated Rainbow Room to evoking the spirit of New York City in the 1930's - not literally as it was in the 30's, but how it would have been had the image of the city from the movies existed in real life.
 
Homage to the City
There are hints of Viennese turn-of-the-century modernism in this space, echoes of Rockefeller Center in the gray and black carpeting and columns and stairs, and even, in the handsomely matched mahogany of the hotel's conference center lobbies, allusions to the grill room at the Four Seasons.
In a sense this hotel is a kind of homage to the best of New York, or at least to the best of New York's 20th-century architecture: it manages to feel the way a New York hotel ought to feel, to emit a sense of belonging in New York and not, like so many other hotels, of having been dropped onto Manhattan from another planet. The Marriott across Broadway from the Hotel Macklowe, for example, always felt like an oversize UFO from Atlanta; it seems made for swarms of visiting conventioneers who like the fact that its massive size means they can spend their days going up and down the glass elevators and will never have to march onto the city's streets.
The lobby of the Macklowe, by contrast, looks like the sort of place where you would expect to find other New Yorkers, as the Algonquin was in its heyday, or as the Royalton has to some extent become. There are surely no tourists gawking at the glass elevators here; the elevators at the Macklowe are splendid cabs of mahagony and metal, crafted to evoke the same sense of idealized Manhattan elegance that the lobby does. They may well be the best wooden elevator cabs of any Manhattan tower since the Chrysler Building.
The second and third floors of the hotel contain a large conference center with meeting rooms that look more like sleek corporate boardrooms than anything usually found in a hotel. Joined to this area will be the old Hudson Theater next door to the Macklowe, which is being restored and will reopen this fall as the hotel's main auditorium and meeting space.
It is only in the guest rooms, unfortunately, that the dreary quality of the building itself reasserts itself, if only partially. The level of taste here is still high - this is the only new high-rise hotel that could be said to be the equal in sophistication of something like the Paramount - but the solid, weighty feeling of the public rooms is gone. The guest rooms feel both tight and light, like the rooms in any cheap new high-rise tower, even if they have been improved by better furniture and more serious art (in the form of very au courant architectural prints) on the walls.
 
Behind the Signs
If the Hotel Macklowe feels like New York on the inside and like anywhere on the outside, the reverse is true of the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, designed by Alan Lapidus. This tall tower of salmon-colored brick and pinkish-brown glass was designed in accordance with the city's new Times Square zoning district, which requires elaborate signs on the facades of new tall buildings.
Mr. Lapidus chose not to struggle to make his building's signs disappear, as some architects in the area have done, but to do the reverse, to make the building itself disappear behind the signs. The Holiday Inn is essentially a container for signs, and as such, it looks vastly better at night, when it is ablaze with neon, than it does during the day, when it seems only like a failed effort at elegance, with a particularly feeble marble arch over the entrance.
 
Small, Cramped Rooms
The building as of now lacks a full complement of signs; the city's zoning laws did not take into account the possibility that an economic downturn would make it impossible for developers to rent all of the large and expensive signs that are required to decorate the facades. The Holiday Inn is still waiting for tenants for some of its sign spaces, and much of the facade is covered by temporary metal framing awaiting the erection of signs over it.
Inside, the best thing are the views back outside - the opposite completely from the Hotel Macklowe. Some of the restaurant and bar areas offer sweeping views down Broadway toward the lights of Times Square, as do many of the guest rooms. The rooms themselves, unfortunately, are small and cramped.
The Embassy Suites Hotel, which is rising atop the old Palace Theater, was designed by the architects Fox & Fowle, and its exterior is perhaps the best of the three new hotels. This building will also have signs around its base, but the tower itself makes a stronger effort architecturally: It's a kind of jazzed-up International Style building in gray masonry, with red stripes and blue accents, all meeting the sky with a crisp 1930's spire-like sign. If all this seems to be old-style modernism made sleek and trendy, it feels energetic and zestful, and is just right for Times Square.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Asserts Federal Courts Shift Obligation

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 14

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told the country's leading state court judges today that the Federal courts had increasingly ceded the task of protecting basic liberties to the state courts and in the process had abandoned their obligation to address a number of national problems.
Speaking to the annual Conference of Chief Justices at a resort hotel on Lake George, Mr. Cuomo said there was a ''judicial new federalism'' that was similar to the political new federalism practiced by Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bush. The policies of those Administrations, Mr. Cuomo said, have forced the states to accept the fiscal and policy-making responsibilities for solving national problems like drug abuse, homelessness, education and the decaying infrastructure. 
Mr. Cuomo said those policies had failed because they had placed neighboring states in economic competition. He also said the recent behavior of the Federal courts had built an unwieldy and unbalanced judicial confederation.
''Our national values, national resolve and national capacity are strengthened when we have a firm set of overarching standards that apply to every American, no matter where he or she lives,'' said Mr. Cuomo. ''I do not believe that the fundamental liberties and rights of members of our national community should vary, depending on what side of the state line one happens to be on at the moment.''
 
No Great Detail
The message conveyed by Mr. Cuomo was not particularly novel, but several justices said the speech was significant because of the Governor's national stature, both as a politician and as a legal thinker.
Mr. Cuomo did not support his contention with great detail. He referred in passing to cases involving government financing of abortion, the economic disparity between school districts and a patient's right to die as areas where the states had set precedents with little direction from the United States Supreme Court. In a news conference after his speech, the Governor declined to list other examples.
Most of the justices in the audience agreed with Mr. Cuomo's assertion that the Federal courts had pushed more responsibility onto the state bench, particularly in areas of criminal law, like the proper conduct of searches and seizures. But not all the listeners thought it was bad for legal standards to be set by the courts closest to the people.
''I think criticism of the Federal courts is going to come from partisan sources,'' said Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who also spoke at the conference. ''But the American people, I think, look to our courts as a major protector of their rights and liberties.''

HEADLINE: Suspect Arrested in Rabbi's Slaying

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
A 35-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested on Monday and charged with the slaying of a leader of the Satmar Hasidim in February in the Williamsburg section of the borough, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday.
He made the announcement at a news conference at the 90th Precinct station house, where relatives and friends of the victim, Rabbi Chaskel Werzberger, crowded in a room. Most of them wore the black hats and fringed prayer shawls of the 25,000-member sect.
Mr. Brown said the suspect, David Ranta, an unemployed house painter, was the gunman in the killing. The police said another man might have also been involved. Mr. Ranta, a former convict with a long criminal record, was arrested on 73d Street, near his house on 81st Street, in the Bensonhurst section, Mr. Brown said. 
After the conference, some residents of the area said they were relieved that there was a suspect. ''It makes me feel good,'' the owner of a store on Lee Avenue said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ''They should hang him up in the middle of the street. They should build a pole. Everybody will give money to build the pole. Even if the person is a Jew, that is our feeling toward him.''
 
Accounts From Witnesses
Rabbi Werzberger, 58 years old, a survivor of the Auschwitz death camp. is still widely mourned. ''He was so well loved around here that you miss him, even if you were not part of that congregation,'' said a woman managing a candy store on Lee Avenue.
Rabbi Werzberger was the sexton, an assistant to the grand rabbi, at Congregation Yetev Lev D'Satmar.
The arrest was made after more than six months of old-fashioned detective work, Mr. Brown said. The accounts of witnesses to the shooting, at 5:45 A.M. on Feb. 8, helped the police track the suspect, other officials said.
Rabbi Werzberger had just left his apartment in a public housing complex at 130 Clymer Street and was opening his car door when he was attacked, the police said. He managed to close the door and enter the car, but the gunman, who had apparently tried to rob another man in the apartment building, shot him through the window, the police added. A bullet struck Rabbi Werzberger above the right eye. The assailant pushed the rabbi out of the car and sped away, the police said.
His car, a 1985 Oldsmobile Cutlass, was found in another neighborhood. Paint was splattered on the front seat and windshield, apparently in an effort to conceal fingerprints, the police said in Februrary.
Rabbi Werzberger, a native of Hungary, died three days after the attack. His funeral at Kiryas Joel, a community he helped found in the 70's near Monroe, N.Y., drew several thousand mourners.
Mr. Ranta faces charges of second-degree murder and criminal possession of a deadly weapon, said a spokesman for the police, Capt. Stephen P. Davis. Mr. Ranta's criminal record includes 15 or 16 arrests on various charges and prison time for robbery, Mr. Brown said.
No weapon was recovered. Captain Davis said the police believed a .44- or .45-caliber gun had been used. Mr. Ranta, a thin blond mustachioed man who was wearing a football T-shirt and ripped jeans as he was whisked from the station house to a police car, made no statements ''of any substance,'' Captain Davis said. Hasidim shouted at the suspect and pounded on the car as it passed.
A neighborhood resident, Shulem Landau, said the man who had almost been robbed before the rabbi had fled by hurling himself and his cart with diamonds into his car and driving off. ''The rabbi was just in the wrong place at the wrong time,'' Mr. Landau said.

HEADLINE: Nowhere Vacations: Beyond TV and Fax

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
AH, to get away from it all: the faxes, the phones, the FedExes, the Filofaxes, the people. You remember what vacations used to be, before advanced technology made it easier to reach out and touch someone, wherever they may be. When the average workweek was 40 hours or less and employers wouldn't dream of interrupting your personal or private time, let alone a vacation, unless it were an emergency.
While many Americans, fearing a recession, are taking shorter vacations or sticking close to home, others are finding ways to escape totally from life's daily routines and petty annoyances. More than a few resort to keeping vacation destinations under wraps or otherwise limiting their accessibility, and some choose a remote vacation spot and go native.
That's what Neale S. Godfrey did last March when she left her son and daughter at home with her mother, and along with her sister took a boat with an Indian guide up the Amazon River, and camped in the jungle. 
''I wanted a vacation that was really an escape,'' said Ms. Godfrey, chairman of the Children's Financial Network, a Manhattan-based company that teaches children about money, banking and finance. ''No phones, no electricity.'' No American Express card, even. Ms. Godfrey used her cosmetics to barter with the Indians, though she said few seemed to like her shade of nail polish.
Social scientists say the pressure-filled 1980's, which ushered in desk-top personal computers, cellular telephones and hotel business centers, and a corporate culture that often measured loyalty, dedication, ambition and drive by the sacrifices one was willing to make, changed the meaning of work ethic and the way society viewed leisure time.
''Employers feel more entitled to imposing on your time,'' said Howard J. Kogan, a psychotherapist and director of training at the Training Institute for Mental Health in New York City. ''It's almost become universal that the most important thing about a person is what they do, and people themselves and their employers think that.''
But more and more people are beginning to resent this kind of intrusion and will stop at nothing to keep the office from going on vacation with them. Take Dale W., for example.
Dale, a newspaper reporter, asked that his full name not be used because his editors believe that the nearest telephone to the cabin he rents each year in the Rocky Mountains is a half-mile down the road.
''There's a phone in the cabin,'' Dale said with a chuckle. ''I just never bothered to have it turned on.''
People like Ms. Godfrey and Dale W. appear to be the exception, rather than the rule. Most people still wouldn't dream of taking a vacation without leaving a forwarding address, telephone number or a detailed itinerary.
''It's amazing how many executives are afraid to go somewhere and be unreachable,'' said C. C. Smiley, senior vice president of Inverness Travel in Manhattan, which has a large professional clientele. ''I've been an agent for a long time and I've never had anyone call me who said, 'Send me someplace where I can't be reached.' ''
People 50 years and older, who have achieved success and are still active in business but who are less afraid they would lose something by being out of contact, are more likely to go on vacations and not worry about being incommunicado, said Francis Goranin, owner of Vega International, a travel agency in Chicago.
''The younger crowd is more concerned about appearances,'' he said. ''They want to know what's going on, so they won't lose out on anything.''
The truth is, there is hardly any place in the world where a person couldn't be reached sooner or later. Even the Bora Bora Hotel in French Polynesia has a fax number.
Ms. Smiley remembers tracking down a client who was on a barge in France and relaying a message for her to call her office. ''It meant getting in touch with the company that ran the barge trip,'' she said, ''but we got a message through in time.''
To cut down on what many view as unnecessary interruptions, vacationers will leave their whereabouts with an intermediary like a travel agent, who is usually too busy to come right to the telephone, or a neighbor who is usually not at home. And if that doesn't work, try a cruise or a train trip. For reasons unknown, many people believe it's extremely difficult to reach someone on a moving vessel, so they seldom bother.
''It's a tried and proven principle: If people have to go through someone else to get to you, they're less likely to try, unless it's a real emergency,'' said Arlene Reeves, a substitute teacher in Washington, who has taken a cruise every summer for the last five years for that reason alone - she doesn't want to be bothered. ''I remember after one cruise, I returned home and found that my basement was flooded. My sister said she tried to reach me on the ship to let me know, but wasn't sure how to go about it. Thank goodness.''
Although many people may still look askance at someone running off for days or weeks at a time without leaving a forwarding number or address, a growing cottage industry is helping travelers to do just that.
Some of these are businesses like Andrew Harper's Hideaway Report, a monthly newsletter described as a ''connoisseur's guide to peaceful and unspoiled places''; Ocean Escapes Inc., a yachts-for-charter business billed as an ''escape to a timeless paradise from which you may never want to return''; and Wilderness Inquiry, which organizes outdoor adventures and whose itineraries read more like Lewis and Clark expeditions than fun in the sun.
Places appreciated for the amenities not included, like a television or daily newspaper delivery; secluded little hideaways; and sparsely populated islands are becoming increasingly chic. Some resorts are still fairly well-kept secrets, like Culebra, an island 12 miles from Puerto Rico whose beaches are so devoid of people that visitors are greeted with suspicion by the island's 2,000 residents. Or try Keeper's House on Isle au Haut, Me., where there is no electricity, so dinner is by candlelight and bedtime is early.
Those are the kinds of places Mr. Harper likes. A man who says he ''disdains crowds, flash, pomposity, plastic, name-dropping hotels and copycat motels,'' Mr. Harper started his magazine, based in Sun Valley, Idaho, for like-minded people. Apparently, he's found plenty. Since its first issue in 1979, the Hideaway Report has grown in circulation from 87 readers in 11 states to 15,000 subscribers in 50 states and 71 countries.
''The premise I had for the newsletter was to seek out peaceful and unspoiled sanctuaries,'' Mr. Harper said. Total-escape vacations can have a sobering effect, say some who have tried them. ''You come to realize that you aren't indispensable,'' said Ms. Godfrey, who is 39 and divorced. ''That you can go off for two or four weeks and the world continues to function without you.'' And you without it. Just ask Nancy Kesselof Charleston, W. Va. A registered nurse married to a surgeon, Mrs. Kessel said she and her husband, James, are always tied to the telephones.
''We have a phone in every room of the house,'' she said, ''a pager and an answering service.'' Mrs. Kessel is also an insulin-dependent diabetic.
Which is why she thought twice about going on the Wilderness Inquiry's 10-day kayaking trip around British Columbia's Queen Charlotte Islands last September. Not only was she worried about not being near any doctors, but ''there's no call-forwarding to the wilderness,'' she said.
''I didn't have any problems,'' Mrs. Kessel said recently. ''I was able to adjust my dosage of insulin and was more stable in the wilderness than I am at home, where stress often comes into play. I came back and I really think my family expected to find me pale and exhausted. Instead, I had this beautiful tan and looked healthier than I had in 10 years.''

HEADLINE: In New Book, Trump Is on the Attack

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Two months ahead of schedule, ''Trump: Surviving at the Top'' goes on sale today in bookstores across the United States. In his new book, Mr. Trump says that his financial and personal troubles have been compounded by his own mistakes, by a softening economy and by unfair and sensationalized news reports.
The book's publication has generated anxiety within Random House, some of whose executives are known to fear that the public may have become satiated with reading about Mr. Trump's triumphs, and more recently, his travails. But to justify the large advance, reported to be almost $2 million dollars, and as a sign of confidence in the book, the publishing house has printed 500,000 copies, a number usually reserved for sure best sellers by authors like Robert Ludlum and James Michener. 
Mr. Trump's first book was a best seller for 51 weeks in hard cover and paperback. His new book is written with Charles Leerhsen, a senior writer at Newsweek.
In the book, Mr. Trump describes himself as a changed man as a result of his personal and business troubles. And he expresses confidence in his future.
Individual chapters are devoted to Mr. Trump's purchase of the Plaza Hotel, his ownership of the yacht Trump Princess and his acquisition of the Eastern Shuttle, since renamed the Trump Shuttle. He writes that he made a tactical mistake in telling The Wall Street Journal that he would sell the shuttle for the right price, because it made the public lose confidence in the shuttle. ''The shuttle is now profitable,'' he writes. ''Frankly, I'm glad I saved it.''
 
Chapter on Mrs. Trump
Mr. Trump also devotes an entire chapter to his wife, Ivana, saying that personality and life-style differences were responsible for the breakup of his marriage, and not, despite numerous press accounts, another woman. His wife, he wrote ''aspires to the aristocracy,'' and loves gala society events and expensive clothes. Mrs. Trump did not return a telephone call to her office. Her husband describes himself, by contrast, as ''a man of very simple tastes.'' He said he did not know what would result from their separation.
There are few revelations about his financial difficulties. Of his protracted negotiations with bankers to restructure his almost $2 billion in debt, Mr. Trump says only that he ''worked out a terrific deal that allows me the time, the money and the leeway to come out stronger than ever.''
Mr. Trump and his publisher appear to be betting that this book, unlike his first, ''Trump: The Art of the Deal,'' with Tony Schwartz, will sell not merely because of his tips about business, but also because of his caustic opinions of public figures.
He charges, for example, that Malcolm Forbes, the late publisher of Forbes Magazine, ''favored those who advertised in his magazine and tried, with surprising viciousness, to punish those who didn't.''
Malcolm Forbes Jr., president and editor and chief of the magazine, said, ''His allegations are as truthful as his estimates of his wealth.''
 
'Pendulum Has Swung'
Mr. Trump's book also criticizes coverage of his troubles by Liz Smith, the syndicated gossip columnist for The Daily News, the tabloid press, Time and Newsweek, and television talk show hosts Geraldo Rivera and Phil Donahue. A telephone call to Ms. Smith was not returned.
''I've also been in the public eye long enough so that the pendulum has swung,'' he writes, ''and many of the same media people who once put me on a pedestal now can't wait for me to fall off.''
Because of Mr. Trump's separation from his wife and his deteriorating financial condition, the book's publication was moved up from October and it was published in relative secrecy. Finishing touches were still being added last month and the editing was not completed until July 16, said Peter Osnos, the book's editor.

HEADLINE: Eastern Can Trim Pilots' Pay

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
In a ruling that gives Eastern Airlines some financial relief, a Federal Bankruptcy Court said yesterday that the beleaguered carrier could impose temporary wage and benefits cuts on pilots. At the same time, the airline reported a $35.6 million loss for the second quarter, an improvement from the period a year earlier.
The ruling by Judge Burton R. Lifland paves the way for Eastern to cut the pilots' wages 20 percent, a move that could save the airline $7 million to $9 million a month, said a lawyer familiar with the case.
Although most of the 1,900 pilots now flying for Eastern are not union members, they had been represented by the pilots' union in court proceedings. 
The ruling grants Eastern ''emergency relief'' from its obligation to abide by the pilots' contract, giving the airline a bit more financial breathing room. ''It's clear that prompt cost reductions, including pilot labor-cost reductions, are essential if an imminent liquidation is to be avoided,'' Judge Lifland said in his ruling.
 
Negotiated Settlement Sought
The ruling ''gives us the economic relief we need on an interim basis,'' said Karen Ceremsak, an Eastern spokeswoman. ''The long-term solution is a negotiated settlement with the pilots.'' Ms. Ceremsak would not specify how much the pilots' wages would be cut.
The bankruptcy court also gave the airline permission to remove another $50 million from its escrow account yesterday.
Lawyers for Eastern had argued that if the airline was not allowed to impose the wage cuts it would not meet its financial projections and might shut down. Lawyers for the pilots' union argued that Eastern was using its dire financial condition as an excuse to break the union contract.
''They were using the bankruptcy court as a convenient tool'' to break the contract, said James L. Linsey, a lawyer for the pilots' union.
 
Elimination of Dispute Boards
Mr. Linsey said he was especially disturbed by Judge Lifland's decision to allow the airline to eliminate its arbritration and pension dispute boards, which were used to settle retirement and disability claims. Earlier this month a Federal District Court in Miami ruled that Eastern was obligated to allow 178 union pilots to return to work. Most of Eastern's pilots had honored striking machinists' picket lines.
The $35.6 million loss for the second quarter compares with a $130 million loss in the period last year. The Miami-based airline said revenue totaled $545.2 million in the second quarter, compared with $89.6 million in 1989. Eastern, which lost $170 million in the first half of this year, has been operating under bankruptcy protection since March 9, 1989. a few days after the machinists began their strike.
Martin R. Shugrue Jr., Eastern's court-appointed trustee, has projected that the airline will lose $510 million this year - much more than earlier projections of a $330 million loss. But Eastern's outlook may be even bleaker, because the business plan does not take into account the sharply higher fuel prices that have resulted from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
On Monday, Eastern announced a new marketing plan that includes fares that are 15 percent to 40 percent lower this fall. The fares, which range from $69 to $139 each way and must be booked by Aug. 29, are in stark contrast to the fare increases announced by most airlines as a result of higher fuel costs.
Still, many analysts are doubtful that Eastern will survive in the long term, and avoid a liquidation. ''Today's action is a diversion from the true questions facing Eastern, which is when are the parts going to be dismantled and who will they go to,'' said a lawyer working with Eastern's bankruptcy proceedings.
 
 LORENZO FAREWELL
 HOUSTON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. may be losing Frank Lorenzo, but it will be gaining a new image, Mr. Lorenzo said during an emotional goodbye ceremony today. Mr. Lorenzo, who choked back tears as he addressed 3,000 Continental employees, said the airline would introduce changes after his departure as chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Lorenzo said that as Continental moved into the fall it ''will be coming out with some really dramatic changes in the whole perception of Continental, the whole look, the visual image of Continental: colors, paint jobs, so forth.''
