HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar In Plunge Vs. Mark

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday to its lowest level against the West German mark in that currency's 42-year history, breaking through a significant barrier on a decline that economists said should bring it even lower against the mark and other currencies before the end of the year.
With interest rates expected to rise abroad while they decline in the United States, the downward pressure on the dollar has been mounting because Americans and foreigners are being attracted to non-dollar investments.
Reports that the American economy is in or near a recession, combined with the negative impact on growth of higher oil prices, have heightened the expectation of lower United States interest rates. And this has been enough to overcome the lift the dollar would have been expected to get as a traditional safe haven in the Persian Gulf crisis. 
 
Little Possibility of Action
For the United States, faced with a recession and prospects of rising inflation because of the Iraqi-induced jump in oil prices, the lower dollar is not good news. But there appears to be little that American policy makers can do about the decline now.
''Net, net it should be seen as a negative, especially because it will make the job of the Federal Reserve more difficult,'' said Geoffrey Dennis, chief international economist for James Capel Inc. in London.
In late trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5635 West German marks, from 1.5780 on Monday. That was its lowest close in New York since the German currency was created in 1948. Its previous New York low of 1.5700 was reached on Dec. 31, 1987. That came at the end of a two-and-a-half-year effort by the United States and its economic allies to bring the dollar down from peaks that had helped push the American trade deficit to record levels.
 
New Lows for the Year
The dollar also fell against other currencies yesterday, including the British pound, the Swiss franc, the French franc, the Italian lira and the Canadian dollar. It hit new lows for the year against all these currencies and was at its lowest level in a decade against the Canadian dollar. The British pound rose against the dollar to $1.8980, from $1.8825 on Monday.
The only exception to the dollar's slide has been the Japanese yen. Although the dollar fell to 148.80 yen yesterday, from 150.25 on Monday, it is still stronger than it was at the beginning of the year and is far above its record low of 120.90 in November 1988. The yen has remained weak because of uncertainity about the economic outlook in Japan and the declines of its bond and stock markets, which have sent Japanese abroad looking for investments.
The lower dollar will worsen American inflationary pressures by making imports more expensive. And the added pressure comes with inflation already in the 5 percent range, a level the Federal Reserve believes is too high.
The expectation of a further dollar decline and a recession could also make foreigners even more hesitant to invest in the already weakened stock and bond markets because of the loss they would face when sales are translated back into their stronger currencies. In addition, it could be more difficult to attract the foreign investment needed to cover the Federal budget deficit.
 
Higher Deficit Seen
David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, said the combination of a recession and the cost of the military buildup in the Persian Gulf could push the Federal budget deficit to more than $300 billion. This, he said, ''is a new twist'' in the economic outlook, and a declining dollar now ''is going to make it harder to finance'' this deficit.
Despite the consequences, both the United States and its allies in the Group of Seven, which includes Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, are confronting economic problems to which solutions are generally negative for the dollar.
For the Federal Reserve, a recession is just as troubling a problem now as inflation. Many economists still expect the Fed to lower interest rates, as an anti-recession move, rather than raising them to fight inflation and support the dollar.
''Sometime in the next month, the Fed has to move to lower interest rates,'' said Victor M. Polce, manager of foreign exchange sales at the Algemene Bank Nederland in New York, who believes a recession has already begun.
 
Not Worried About Drop
West Germany and Japan, meanwhile, are no longer worried about a dollar decline, as they were in the past.
A stronger mark will help the Germans fight any inflationary surge from the unification of the two Germanys and the recent rise in oil prices, which are set in dollars. And while the Japanese have been unsuccessful so far, the Government and the Bank of Japan want a stronger yen to help bring some stability back to the country's financial markets.
The Germans are expected to raise interest rates soon to slow growth and inflation, which should add support to the mark, weakening the dollar further. The Bank of Japan has been hinting strongly that it will raise interest rates, which are already about as high as they are in the United States. But both may delay the moves until they see how the Middle East situation is working out and how high oil prices are likely to go.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
What Price Cleaner Air?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
Like purer hearts or thinner thighs, cleaner air is an unalloyed virtue. But like other virtues, cleaner air can only be attained through sacrifice. And according to Paul R. Portney, an environmental economist at Resources for the Future in Washington, Americans may be on the verge of giving up too much for too little: They are not likely to get their money's worth from the sweeping amendments to the Clean Air Act now being cobbled together by Congress.
According to Mr. Portney's startling analysis, to be published in the next issue of the American Economic Association's Journal of Economic Perspectives, the amendments will double the current $30 billion cost of the air quality regulation. But the benefits will probably be worth just $14 billion, Mr. Portney concluded. His analysis is all the more depressing because the legislation is the first to draw on the expertise of efficiency-minded economists. 
The first of the three big-ticket items in the clean air package would require coal- and oil-fired power plants to slash emissions of sulfur and nitrogen oxides. The likely bill for antipollution equipment and more expensive fuel: about $4 billion annually. But the benefits should exceed the costs. Mr. Portney reckons that the value in better health and reduced damage to forests, lakes and farms will run about $5 billion.
Thereafter, however, the economics of the clean air amendments is all downhill. Tougher regulation of urban polluters will cost $19 billion to $22 billion annually. But the benefits, everything from reduced incidence of asthma to increased crop yields downwind, will probably fall in the $4 billion to $12 billion range, Mr. Portney says. The third expensive item, reductions in emissions of 190 cancer-causing industrial chemicals, Mr. Portney estimates, will probably run $6 billion to $10 billion annually. But by Government analysis, the risks from these toxic effluents is much smaller than commonly supposed; lives saved will probably not exceed 500 annually. Valuing these lives at $3 million each, the total benefits will fall short of $2 billion.
These estimates, Mr. Portney readily acknowledges, are educated guesses. But the guesses, from a variety of sources ranging from the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment to studies commissioned by the Environmental Protection Agency, do apparently represent the state of the scientific art.
Some environmental advocates - perhaps a majority - deny the relevance of such analysis. Cleaner is better, they insist, no matter what the green-eyeshade types say. But for economists (and those who think like economists), comparisons of costs and benefits must matter in a world of limited resources. An extra billion spent sanitizing the air around oil refineries is a billion less to spend on, say, safer tankers or tastier tomatoes. And if regulation itself breeds inefficiency - if less money spent elsewhere could accomplish the same task -the approach is even more problematic.
That raises a troubling question. Never have so many smart, free-market-oriented economists been so involved in drafting new environmental rules. If resulting legislation is such a bad deal, why are they now silent?
One reason is that the free-market enthusiasts within the clean air lobby did win one big victory: Utilities will be allowed to buy and sell rights to pollute, insuring that the polluters who can cut emissions most cheaply will do the cutting.
This will reduce the acid rain cleanup cost by $2 billion to $3 billion annually, Mr. Portney says. Moreover, ''emissions trading'' on acid rain could serve as the precedent for a least-cost solution for the big kahuna of environmental problems, containment of the ''greenhouse effect'' gases that cause atmospheric warming. But the price of this victory was acquiescence on air toxics regulation, which many environmental economists privately concede will be about as cost-effective as the Pentagon's $600 toilet seats.
The other bargain for silence cannot be rationalized so high-mindedly. President Bush's economic advisers have long been unhappy with the urban air quality amendments as well as the air toxics provisions; the former, it is argued, would effectively force the whole country to use expensive emission controls that make sense only for the dozen most heavily polluted cities.
But the self-proclaimed environmental President seems readier to settle for a wasteful bill than to share the blame for a legislative deadlock. And the pinchpennies in the budget office, who might have been expected to stiffen Mr. Bush's spine, seem unconcerned because Washington won't foot the bill. Consumers will.

HEADLINE: Sales of U.S. Vehicles Down in Early August

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell 18.8 percent in early August and analysts attributed the decline to the weakness in the United States economy and unusually strong sales a year earlier.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.6 million units for the 10 days ended Aug. 10, compared with 7.9 million in the same period a year earlier. During the 30 days ended Aug. 10, cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.9 million, while the seasonally adjusted selling rate for the first half of the year was 6.9 million.
Over all, sales of passenger cars fell 20.7 percent in early August, to 150,897 units. Sales of light trucks, including mini-vans, declined 15.6 percent, to 95,895 units. Rise in Japanese Models While the Big Three domestic auto makers reported a collective decline in sales, the Japanese manufacturers reported a 5.3 percent increase in sales of vehicles produced in their factories in the United States. 
Auto makers said they detected no movement of buyers to smaller, more fuel-efficient models in the wake of sudden increases in the price of gasoline resulting from the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Some dealers, however, said sales of small cars had picked up, while larger cars were selling more slowly.
''Customers are talking more about fuel economy, but they are not switching to different, more fuel-efficient cars,'' said Joel Pitcoff, the Ford Motor Company's manager of research and analysis.
Analysts predicted that a prolonged conflict in the Persian Gulf, resulting in still higher gasoline prices or greater disruption in oil supplies, could begin to affect retail auto sales by September.
Gasoline would have to rise by 25 cents to 50 cents a gallon before customers would begin switching to smaller, more fuel-efficient cars, said Maryann N. Keller, an automotive analyst and vice president at Furman Selz in New York.
''If the hostilities keep up, the truck market is much more vulnerable than the car market, because that is where the inefficient product is located today,'' said Ms. Keller.
Vehicle sales in the 10-day period last year were especially strong as customers rushed to take advantage of clearance sales at the end of the model year that included generous cash rebates and discount financing.
The cash rebates offered by manufacturers are smaller this year than last, and with inventories significantly lower than last year, dealers and analysts predicted that further price discounts on 1990 models were unlikely.
General Motors reported sales of its cars fell 22.2 percent in early August, to 65,611 units. G.M.'s light truck sales were down 18.1 percent, to 41,818 units.
Ford's car sales declined 21.3 percent, to 48,369 units, while sales of Ford's light trucks fell 4 percent, to 34,250. #38.6% Drop for Chrysler The Chrysler Corporation posted a 38.6 percent decline in sales of its cars, to 15,667 units. The company said in a statement that the big drop in car sales was a result of ''extremely high sales of the Shadow and Sundance in the 1989 period,'' when the company was offering some of the biggest rebates in the industry's history. Sales of Chysler's light trucks and mini-vans were down 25.8 percent, to 17,339.
The Toyota Motor Corporation posted an increase of 64.3 percent in sales of its cars, manufactured in Georgetown, Ky., to 8,573 units.
Sales of cars made by the Honda Motor Company at its plant in Marysville, Ohio, declined 15.4 percent in early August, to 7,617 units. The Nissan Motor Company posted a decline of 32.4 percent in sales of cars made in Smyrna, Tenn., to 1,988 units. Sales of Nissan's domestically made light trucks fell 34.5 percent, to 2,296 units.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up in July, But Outlook Is Negative

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Retail sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July from the month before, the Commerce Department said today.
The gain would normally have been seen as an indication that consumers were spending enough to keep the economy moving sluggishly higher. But with the recent oil crisis created by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, analysts focused more on future conditions, which they expect to be unfavorable. 
''There are two big negatives overhanging the economy now,'' said Lynn Reiser, senior economist with First Interstate Bancorp, a bank-holding company in Los Angeles: ''the Middle East crisis and its impact on oil prices and the deteriorating outlook for new jobs.''
 
Earlier Decline in Jobs
The Government had already reported that the unemployment rate climbed in July to 5.5 percent from 5.2 percent in June, and that new-job growth slowed sharply. And since the Iraqi action earlier this month, retail gasoline prices have risen about 15 cents a gallon.
''Consumers will spend more on petroleum products, leaving them with less money to spend on other products,'' said Richard Rahn, chief economist with the United States Chamber of Commerce.
The Government had reported previously that growth in the nation's total output of goods and services, or the gross national product, had slowed to an anemic 1.2 percent annual rate between April and June, before the onset of higher oil prices.
 
Upward Revision for June
The July sales gain followed a 1.1 percent increase in June, which the Commerce Department revised upward today from the previously reported five-tenths of 1 percent gain. Sales had declined in May, April and March, and were flat in February.
Before June, the last significant monthly rise was a 2.8 percent increase in January. The department also revised the May decline to one-tenth of 1 percent from a six-tenths of 1 percent drop reported previously.
The two revisions suggested that inventories of unsold goods were smaller than had been believed, a potential benefit in times of slow economic activity.
''It does not look as though inventories will be a major overhang, which, if we do go into a recession, would mitigate the impact of it,'' Ms. Reiser said. She said that low inventories would give manufacturers a reason to keep production lines going even in a sluggish economy.
 
Building Materials Strong
Total sales in July were a seasonally adjusted $149.5 billion. The increase from June was led by sales of building materials, which rose 3.9 percent after a 3.2 percent rise the month before.
Sales at auto dealerships, which account for about 20 percent of the monthly retail sales measure, fell six-tenths of 1 percent after rising by six-tenths of 1 percent in June. Excluding that volatile category, retail sales were up by three-tenths of 1 percent last month after increasing 1.2 percent on a similar basis in June, the department said.
Sales of gasoline at service stations fell three-tenths of 1 percent in July after a 1 percent June rise.
Sales of durable goods, meant to last three or more years, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July after increasing four-tenths of 1 percent in June. Sales of nondurable goods, like food and disposable items, were unchanged in July after a rise of 1.5 percent in June.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bank in Brooklyn Sets Fall Opening

 BODY:
The Community Capital Bank, Brooklyn, said yesterday that it had met its goal of raising $6 million of shareholder capital, and it planned to open for business in November. The bank, which attracted about a third of its shareholder funds from 41 religious organizations and another third from institutions like the American Express Company and J. P. Morgan & Company, promised to concentrate on lending to small businesses in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods of New York City.
From an office on Livingston Street, Brooklyn, the bank will also offer consumer services, with federally insured deposits at market interest rates.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
New Fiber-Optic Cable Will Expand Calls Abroad, and Defy Sharks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
Like Brobdingnagian spools of thread, three giant steel cones in the hold of an unusual ship here are wrapped with up to 3,000 miles of cable no thicker than a garden hose. The cable, composed of six hair-thin strands of glass covered by steel and plastic, can carry 40,000 telephone calls across the ocean floor at a time.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which owns the ship, hopes to lay 20,000 miles of such cable within several years. The effort is but one of many by the world's major telephone companies to keep up with international telephone traffic, which is doubling every four years and is expected to grow faster if a recently proposed United States rate-cutting effort succeeds.
The telephone companies are not only speeding up the laying of fiber-optic cables to supplement copper ones, but also making the first large round of orders for cable-laying ships in a generation. At the same time, research into better electronics is producing cables that can carry even more calls, while new techniques are providing more protection for cables against hazards ranging from shark bites to equipment used by fishing boats to harvest clams on the sea floor. 
The next trans-Atlantic telephone cable, scheduled for deployment in 1992, will use sophisticated electronics to carry 80,000 lines - compared with 48 lines on the first telephone cable, laid in 1956. The latest cables are armored against shark bites with two layers of steel tape and buried deeper than before under the sea bed in shallow waters to prevent damage from fishing boats.
International traffic has soared largely because of increasing facsimile and computer communications, together with a trend by manufacturing and service companies to set up offices and factories in many countries, said Gregory C. Staple, a Washington consultant who has written two studies on the trend.
 
Caught by Surprise
A.T.&T. says the sustained growth in traffic during the 1980's has caught it by surprise and forced it to lease extra call-transmission capacity aboard satellites and cables laid by other companies. But satellite capacity is limited, and many corporations demand undersea links from their long-distance telephone companies because fiber-optic cables provide connections with less static and echo.
While A.T.&T. says existing and planned cable capacity will be sufficient for its needs, the MCI Communications Corporation, the second-largest long-distance company, says it needs more capacity. MCI wants the Federal Communications Commission to give it some of A.T.&T.'s lines in cables built by consortiums that included A.T.&T. and MCI. A.T.&T. owns almost all of the existing outbound American telephone cable lines and most of the planned capacity, while MCI owns little of either.
Traffic could grow even faster if the F.C.C. succeeds in its effort to force foreign governments to reduce the rates their phone companies charge for receiving international calls. Reducing these charges could halve the price of an international call from the United States within three years, the F.C.C. says. Some economists think this could cause traffic to double, on top of the current annual growth of 20 percent.
 
Heavy Demand
All the capacity on a $430 million trans-Atlantic cable planned for 1992 by a consortium of major telephone companies has already been sold to consortium members, while spare telephone circuits in previously laid cables are also in short supply.
Installing a new cable requires several years of negotiations to assemble a consortium and arrange financing, while actually laying a trans-oceanic cable can be done in a month. ''If we had the cables right now, we'd put them in,'' said James M. Barrett, the head of submarine cable operations at A.T.&T.
A shortage of cable-laying ships is crimping the telephone industry's response. Few such ships have been built in recent years. A.T.&T.'s Long Lines, the ship based here, began laying its first cable in 1963 and is not well suited to lay fiber-optic cable because it is not very maneuverable.
A new generation of cable-laying ships is under construction, mostly in East Asian shipyards. A.T.&T. is spending $100 million to build two vessels in Singapore that are better suited for laying fiber-optic cables, which transmit telephone calls by laser through their fibers.
 
Strange Ships
British Telecommunications P.L.C., Teleglobe Canada Inc. and the Kokusai Denshin Denwa Company of Japan have each ordered a new cable-laying ship.
These ships are among the oddest vessels afloat. In the holds are not only the 25-foot-high steel cones but also buoys twice the height of a person, refrigerator-size grapples for dredging up damaged cables and even one or more small laboratories for splicing cable and testing its electronic properties.
On the deck stands a remote-controlled submarine, used to inspect cables after they have been laid, and an undersea sled, used to bury cables under the sea floor in shallow waters near shore where fishing boats troll for shellfish. A turret typically protrudes from the bow to haul submerged cables aboard for splicing or repair.
The new ships share these features with older vessels like the Long Lines. But they also have design improvements.
 
Limit on Maneuvering
One weakness of the Long Lines is that while a propeller in the bow allows the front of the ship to be maneuvered laterally, its single propeller in the stern simply drives the ship forward, giving the captain little ability to maneuver the stern. ''We can control the bow very easily, but we really have no control over the stern except the rudder,'' said Leonard J. Becicka, the captain of the Long Lines.
That is a problem because unlike copper cable, fiber-optic cable must be fed out straight from the stern. Severe twisting, such as when wind, waves and currents toss the stern about, can stress the glass and reduce its ability to carry phone calls. ''You don't want to bend it, you don't want to drag it around,'' Captain Becicka said.
To remedy the problem, each of the new A.T.&T. ships will have two lateral propellers in the bow and two propulsion propellers in the stern that can rotate the boat from side to side.
The extra maneuverability is also needed so vessels can continue to lay fiber-optic cable during bad weather. Because this cable is lighter and finer than copper cable, a vessel can carry enough of it for a month's work at sea, and over that period at least one storm is likely. In the past, cable-laying ships scurried out of harbors after storms to lay a few hundred miles of copper cable, then headed back to port before rough weather returned.
 
Renewing the Signal
Another technological leap that could help relieve the shortages of capacity would be the development of a way to dispense with so-called repeaters. These are $800,000 torpedo-shaped blocks of electronic circuitry encased in steel that are now placed every 35 to 45 miles along a fiber-optic cable to renew the signal, which tends to fade as it travels.
A.T.&T. and other companies are working to lengthen the distance between repeaters, and the next trans-Atlantic cable is scheduled to have one every 70 to 85 miles. The goal is to develop cables that need no repeaters, so that the electronics on land at either end of the cable could be upgraded periodically to increase the number of calls a cable can handle. This cannot be done now because the repeaters cannot be reprogrammed once they are laid. Dredging up and replacing every repeater on a submerged cable is prohibitively expensive, so new cables are laid instead.
But the development of a repeaterless cable remains in the distant future. ''We've got a long way to go there,'' Mr. Barrett said. ''That's not on our horizon. It's in the laboratory.''

HEADLINE: 2 Nicaragua Currencies

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Two official currencies were in circulation today in Nicaragua, one on par with the United States dollar and the other devalued almost into oblivion. The central bank announced today that it had devalued the old cordoba 7.2 percent, to 690,000 to the dollar from 640,000. Black market dealers offered 740,000 old cordobas for $1. On Monday the first bills of the new currency, the gold cordoba, began circulating when state workers cashed paychecks in the new money. The Government of President Violeta Chamorro has vowed to maintain the new cordoba on par with the dollar as part of a strategy to cut inflation, which was 62 percent in July.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices in a Slight Advance

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Bond prices rose slightly and long-term interest rates dipped yesterday, as credit market participants reacted favorably to a more stable oil market, rumors of institutional purchases of long-term securities and hopes that the meeting tomorrow between President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan may help to defuse tensions in the Middle East.
Price gains were concentrated among long-term securities, even though a number of analysts said they are convinced that economic weakness will force the Federal Reserve Board to ease short-term interest rates soon, perhaps as early as next week.
Indeed, market participants suggested that yesterday's small gains in bond prices were likely to prove ephemeral until and unless the warlike atmosphere that prevails in the Middle East evaporates.
''It is hard to imagine the market going higher without a solution in the region,'' one government bond trader said. 
''Last week. the long end got killed because of oil prices, and if the situtation over there gets resolved, presumably oil prices will come down and the long end will take off.''
 
Kennebunkport Meeting
Word that King Hussein would be traveling to Kennebunkport, Maine, bearing a letter from Iraq's President Saddam Hussein to President Bush at his vacation home flashed across trading screens in advance of the President's 4 P.M. news conference and led to some speculation that a deal that would end the conflict might already have been struck.
That notion was quickly dispelled when Mr. Bush began his meeting with reporters by talking tough on the Federal budget.
The President's remarks, in which he re-emphasized the need to cut $50 billion from the budget in the coming fiscal year, did not provoke much of a reaction from traders.
Nevertheless, ''his remarks were somewhat positive for the market,'' said Lawrence N. Leuzzi, a managing director at S.G. Warburg & Company.
''Given everything that has happened in the Middle East and its likely impact on the economy, he could have used this opportunity to backslide on what was needed and to reset the budget negotiations in a framework where smaller cuts would be sought,'' Mr. Leuzzi said.
Activity in the secondary market for Treasury securities was light yesterday, due in part to the lingering effects of the widespread power failures in lower Manhattan.
Although most dealers were fully operational yesterday, two major interdealer brokers, the RMJ Securities Corporation and Fundamental Brokers Inc., were still without power.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 22/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.78 percent, down slightly from 8.79 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 21/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.31 percent. And the 8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, down 2/32, to yield 7.92 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.43 percent late yesterday, up four basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.32 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.17 percent, up three basis points.
 
Note and Bill Rates
Even though the view that the Fed will move soon to lower short-term interest rates was not reflected in note and bill rates yesterday, some market participants said that such a move was very likely.
''I don't think the Fed has any choice'' but to lower rates after its policy-making Open Market Committee meets on Aug. 21, said William M. Brachfeld, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
While such a move would do little to help cool inflation, ''we don't want to have a recession in this country,'' Mr. Brachfeld said.
Elsewhere, activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was very light, dealers said.
Prices of most widely quoted corporate bonds were unchanged on the day. Meanwhile, prices of most municipal bonds rose by about 1/4 point.
New issues priced yesterday included a competitive offering of $115 million worth of insured tax-exempt serial bonds from the Ohio Public Facility for Higher Education.
The bonds, which are insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, were won by a syndicate led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
The serial bonds were reoffered to investors with coupons from 5.90 percent in 1992 to 7 percent in 2005.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Decline Slightly As Investors Take Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices fell slightly yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, after profit taking erased gains that had brought the market to its highest level in nearly six months.
Trading resumed yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, which were shut down Monday afternoon by an electrical blackout. 
On the Commodity Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange, where oil futures are traded, exchange officials combined Monday's incomplete trading day with yesterday's session for price-quoting purposes. Therefore, the quoted changes yesterday in settlement prices for those commodities were relative to Friday's settlement prices, not to the prices at which the markets stopped trading Monday.
On the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $7.90 to $8.20 above Friday's settlement, with the contract for delivery in August at $404.80 an ounce, which was 40 cents below Monday's last price.
Silver futures ended 22.1 cents to 25.3 cents above Friday's settlement, with August at $5.191 an ounce, which was 4.6 cents above Monday's last price.
August gold traded as high as $413.50, the highest spot gold price since Feb. 23.
Analysts attributed the early run-up to fears of inflation and political unrest stemming from the Persian Gulf conflict.
The late profit taking was prompted by news that King Hussein of Jordan was carrying a message from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to President Bush, and by a decline in buying interest as the December gold contract neared $425 an ounce.
''Some people who were running profits from last week tended to ring up the cash register, so to speak,'' said Don Tierney, an analyst with Stanley Bell & Company, a New York-based commodities brokerage.

HEADLINE: Mexico Debt Deal Is Denied

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
A senior Treasury official vigorously denied a Congressman's charge today that the Bush Administration had spent $192 million to subsidize Mexico's debt-reduction agreement with commercial banks.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, said such a Mexican transaction, completed in January, was just one of a number of ''back-door financing schemes'' put together ''behind closed doors'' to finance the Treasury's international operations. 
David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said: ''We do not believe in producing subsidies for foreign governments. The entire debt strategy is an indication that our efforts have been devoted to curing this problem without recourse to taxpayers' money.''
The Mexican agreement was the first and most important struck under the so-called Brady plan. Named after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, it seeks to induce banks to forgive part of the $1.3 trillion debt burden on third-world countries in exchange for economic reforms.
At issue is whether the United States gave Mexico a favorable price when it sold $2.99 billion in zero-coupon Treasury bonds.

HEADLINE: IRAQ SEEKS PEACE WITH IRAN, TURNING BACK SPOILS OF WAR IN MOVE TO END ITS ISOLATION;
Teheran is Pleased

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Iraq took a dramatic step today to counter its growing international isolation over the invasion of Kuwait, offering to meet almost all of Iran's conditions for settling key issues persisting from their eight-year war.
President Saddam Hussein's apparent decision to give up his longstanding goals against Iran seemed intended to free military units deployed along the Iranian border for use if a conflict develops with forces in Saudi Arabia.
The decision may also reflect a calculated hope by Baghdad that Iran, in return for the concessions, might help Iraq evade international economic sanctions.
 
A Hint of Approval
Iran immediately implied that it would be amenable to Iraq's offer of peace, saying that it would be reviewed ''with optimism.''
But Iran, which initially condemned the invasion of Kuwait and later expressed concern at the decision of the United States and other Western powers to send troops to the region, has not indicated whether it will help Iraq in its economic plight. 
The initiative by the Iraqi President, made in a letter to President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, represented one of the most significant moves since Washington's decision to throw its full weight behind an effort to protect Saudi Arabia and to compel Iraq to pull out of Kuwait.
 
'Fishing in Muddy Waters'
The Iraqi leader's letter held out a possibility of a ''new life in which cooperation prevails under the shadow of Islamic principles and that each of us respects the rights of the other and keeps away those fishing in muddy waters on our shores.''
It came as the two sides were nearing the 10th anniversary of the outbreak of the war, on Sept. 19, when Iraq invaded Iran, which was then holding American hostages and was in the throes of the Islamic revolution that toppled the Shah in 1979.
Ostensibly, Iraq invaded because of a dispute over Shatt al Arab, the strategic border waterway at the head of the Persian Gulf used by both countries.
President Hussein is bound to be faced by questions from his military about why Baghdad waged such a high-cost war with Iran, only to offer to return to the pre-war borders with Iran, something that Mr. Hussein had repeatedly said he would never accept.
There are estimates that more than a million people died in the war, in which a cease-fire was declared in 1988, with heavy casualties, air and missile attacks, human-wave assaults by Iran and the use of poison gas by Iraq. Millions of people were wounded or driven from their homes.
Iranian officials said secret and direct talks were held between the two nations over the last few weeks.
They added that they viewed the Iraqi concessions as a direct result of the economic and military pressures on Baghdad after the invasion of Kuwait, including trade sanctions decreed by the United Nations Security Council, naval interdictions by American and other warships and a buildup of an multi-national force in Saudi Arabia.
The Iraqi leader's conciliatory gesture to Teheran was announced over Iraqi radio and television. It promised the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from about 700 square miles of Iranian territory. It also called for the exchange of nearly 100,000 prisoners of war and an equal division of the Shatt al Arab estuary.
 
Iraq Canceled Waterway Pact
When the war broke out in 1980, Mr. Hussein canceled a 1975 agreement between the two countries to divide the waterway, which is Iraq's only outlet to the Persian Gulf.
Since then, Iraq had insisted that it would ''never'' allow Iran sovereignty over any part of the waterway. Iraq also insisted that it would not allow an exchange of prisoners nor pull back from Iranian territory until Iran had conceded this point.
The Iraqi leader said today that his troops would begin to withdraw from Iran on Friday and might start releasing prisoners of war even before reciprocal action by Iran.
Iranian officials said the first high-level contact between the two countries started in April with a letter from President Hussein to President Rafsanjani. It was followed by several unannounced meetings and one public meeting between foreign ministers in Geneva in July.
Shortly after that, Iran and Iraq cooperated in pressing other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices, just before the invasion of Kuwait.
These events seemed to confirm suggestions by many Persian Gulf experts that the two countries have many common interests in areas like oil policy and opposition to the United States military presence in the gulf area.
It was not clear whether Iran would be willing to take the kind of actions that could alleviate the growing international pressure on Iraq. Given the long border between Iran and Iraq, the worldwide embargo against Iraq could be thwarted if Teheran allowed its territory to become a transit route for Iraqi imports.
The announcement by Iraq underlined Baghdad's eagerness to ease the pressure on its frontier with Iran so it could concentrate strength in response to the military buildup in Saudi Arabia.
In announcing his offer today, President Hussein noted the Islamic heritage of both nations, even though his secular Baathist Government has harshly repressed the Islamic fundamentalist movement, Al Dawa al-Islamiya, which was allied with Iran, and executed scores of the movement's leaders.
 
'Dear Brother'
In his letter to President Rafsanjani, the Iraqi leader referred to the Iranian as ''Dear Brother.'' The letter said, in part: ''Everything has become clear and everthing you wanted and concentrated upon has been realized.''
The tone was a sharp change in Baghdad's attitude toward the Iranian Government. Over the last decade, the Iraqi press and broadcasting have repeatedly described the Iranian leaders, including Mr. Rafsanjani, as ''princes of darkness,'' ''Persian inferiors'' and ''imposters.''
In his message, President Hussein said he was looking forward to a peace treaty between the countries ''from an honorable position toward a new life in which cooperation prevails under the shadow of Islamic principles.''
In a move related to the gulf crisis, foreign embassies in Kuwait were ordered today to move to Baghdad. All Kuwaitis who served in the diplomatic service and their families have been taken to Baghdad and jailed.
Many of the newest refugees from Kuwait in Saudi Arabia say the situation in Kuwait is deteriorating and that food is scarce. Nine Britons who arrived in Bahrain last night said that shooting was heard every night as Kuwaitis continued to wage hit-and-run raids on Iraqi positions.
One of Syria's three vice presidents was reported today to be on his way to Teheran for consultations with the Iranian leadership. Syria, long a rival of Iraq, will probably try to persuade Teheran not to ease its pressure on Iraq.
In the Iranian capital, Morteza Sarmadi, spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, seemed pleased with the Iraqi offer to settle all remaining disputes, stressing that it represented significant concessions to Iran.
 
Iran Hails Iraqi Offer
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 (Reuters) - Iran hailed Iraq's acceptance of its terms for peace as the biggest victory since the 1979 Islamic revolution.
It predicted a new era of ''lasting and just peace'' with Iraq after President Hussein announced that he was ready to accept a 1975 border treaty that he had renounced in 1980.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1082 words

HEADLINE: IRAQ SEEKS PEACE WITH IRAN, TURNING BACK SPOILS OF WAR IN MOVE TO END ITS ISOLATION;
New Headache for U.S.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
If it lasts, the peace settlement shaping up today between Iraq and Iran, once its arch-enemy, could significantly prolong the stay of American troops in the Persian Gulf.
Iran is the natural counterweight to Iraq in the region and if Teheran is not willing to play that role, it means that the United States may have to - at least for the near future.
If Iran is not only removed as a threat to Iraq, but decides that it is ready to serve as an avenue for the Iraqis to break United Nations economic sanctions, then even a temporary accommodation between these two longtime foes could have even more serious implications for Washington.
''Saddam Hussein's main fear now isn't war, but sanctions,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, referring to the Iraqi President. ''Iran has a huge coastline, not to mention sieve-like borders. This is potentially the most serious threat yet to our ability to squeeze Saddam. Like a nightmare that just won't go away, Iran could yet again trip up another American President.'' 
 
A History of Rivalry
It is far too early, however, to say that Iran is actually aligning itself with Iraq. The two countries have long been adversaries, a rivalry spurred by geography and religion. Iraq is a secular state led by minority Sunni Muslims, while Iran is an Islamic republic run by Shiite Muslim clerics. Any rapprochement between them may well be temporary.
For now, Iran stands to gain in many respects: peace with Iraq on its terms, higher oil prices induced by the Iraqi occupation and the subsequent worldwide embargo, from which Iran will profit as an exporter, and greater danger for Saudi Arabia, another bitter foe of Teheran.
The one disadvantage for Iran is the huge buildup of American forces in the Persian Gulf, from which Teheran has long worked to exclude United States influence.
Temporary or not, any lessening of enmity between Baghdad and Teheran has potentially far-reaching consequences. Iran and Iraq have been the only two nations in the Persian Gulf region in the postwar period with the size, population, wealth and military strength to strive for supremacy.
When Iran was economically strong, politically united and heavily armed under the Shah in the 1970's, it called the shots in the region. When Iran and Iraq were at war and neutralizing each other, as they were from 1980 to 1988, the small states around them could breathe easier.
When Iran found itself exhausted after eight years of war with Iraq, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq discovered that he had a virtually free hand in the gulf and that there was nothing restraining him from devouring Kuwait. Saudi Arabia, with its limited population and cautious leadership, could not project enough power to hold him back, and the small gulf oil sheikdoms, like Bahrain, Qatar or the United Arab Emirates were nearly helpless.
As a result, the United States sent forces to the region to counterbalance Iraq's strength by building up Saudi Arabia.
 
U.S. Overtures to Iranians
Some analysts had already begun to suggest that unless the United States could restore the balance of power in the region in the long term by also gradually building up Iran, American troops, or at least naval forces, would have to remain for an indefinite period.
The Bush Administration, through the Swiss and others, began sending out feelers to Teheran to see if a new relationship was possible. American officials were hoping, at a minimum, that the Iranians might be induced to reinforce their troops on their border with Iraq to force Baghdad to divert some of its troops from the Kuwait front.
But, it appears that President Hussein may have beaten the United States to the punch, at least for now.
''If this deal comes off, and if it effectively neutralizes Iran, it is going to be that much more difficult for the United States to withdraw its forces,'' said Robert W. Tucker, an expert on the Persian Gulf at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''It would mean that Saddam does not have to fear the one force in the gulf that can really cause him trouble.''
The political reality in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Tucker added, ''is that you have only two powers that can contest for primacy there, Iran and Iraq. That, of course, dooms them to rivalry. On the other hand, anything that produces a temporary peace between them, and even indirect cooperative behavior, puts additional pressure on America to stay. Saudi Arabia does not have the wherewithal to constitute a vibrant presence in the gulf. The Arab gulf states each add up to zero. So zero plus zero is zero.''
 
Comparison to 1939
President Hussein's move has a historical analogy in the 1939 Nazi-Soviet pact, in which the Germans agreed not to attack their strongest opponent on the European continent, the Soviet Union, in return for which the Soviets gave them a free hand in Central Europe.
The Soviets also enabled the Nazis to break the British blockade when World War II erupted by allowing the Germans to import war materiel through Soviet territory.
It is not clear that Iran will provide a similar vehicle for Iraq to violate United Nations sanctions. But the temptation for Iran to profit from Iraq's isolation will be great.
For Washington, however, there may be some good news from the proposed Iranian-Iraqi rapprochement, in that it might be a sign of Baghdad's desperation. Respite for Iraqi Leadership? A senior Administration policymaker said that militarily, today's diplomatic move will not mean much for Iraq, since its top fighting units, the divisions of the Republican Guard, had all already been transferred to the Kuwait front. All that were left manning the Iran-Iraq cease-fire were low-grade infantry units.
Domestically, though, the official said, a settlement of the war with Iran could give President Hussein a little more running room with his population. The war with Iran was unpopular and exhausting. Bringing it to a close could make the Iraqi people slightly more willing to sustain some of the sacrifices that will be required on the Kuwait front.
The official added that the Administration had understood from the start that its forces might have to be in the gulf for a while, in order to maintain the power balance. Even if Iran had been open to a new relationship with Washington, he added, building it up to be an effective counterweight to Iraq would take years.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bush Says Iraqi Aggression Threatens 'Our Way of Life'

BYLINE: By R W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
President Bush told Pentagon employees today that American freedom and ''our way of life'' would suffer if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq ever gained control of Saudi Arabia.
On a day when a senior Baghdad official was quoted as describing the 3,000 or more Americans still trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait as ''restrictees'' who would not be released until the crisis in the Middle East was resolved, the President warned President Hussein, ''No one should doubt our staying power or determination.''
Stepping up the military pressure, the Pentagon announced that it would send an undisclosed number of its swallow-tailed, technologically sophisticated F-117 Stealth fighters, designed to evade enemy radar, to join American forces in the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Bush spoke in a strikingly martial setting, with generals and admirals in front of him, rows of brightly colored ribbons glinting on their uniforms. Seeking to picture the American deployment of tens of thousands of troops in the defense of Saudi Arabia as an act of democratic commitment, not economic self-interest, he said that ''we are striking a blow for the principle that might does not make right.'' 
 
'The Moment to Stand Firm'
Officials in the White House inner circle said Mr. Bush was willing to listen to, but unlikely to negotiate on, a peace proposal from the Iraqi President that King Hussein of Jordan is reportedly taking with him to a meeting with the President at his house in Kennebunkport, Me., probably for lunch Thursday. Mr. Bush is also scheduled to meet Thursday with Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi Foreign Minister, and with Prince Bandar, the Ambassador to Washington.
The officials said the Iraqi leader's decision to pull his troops out of Iranian territory and settle remaining issues between Iran and Iraq on Teheran's terms, which was announced this morning, demonstrated that the Iraqi leader was highly vulnerable.
''This is not the moment for us to be making deals,'' one official said. ''It's the moment to stand firm. And besides, if this proposal was really so hot, the King would have pushed hard to deliver it the minute he arrived last night instead of waiting almost 36 hours to hand it over.''
Another official said of King Hussein's peace mission: ''There are a lot of overbuilt expectations. I think that this is a nothing-burger.''
Although the international embargo seemed otherwise intact, and no Iraqi ships challenged the naval blockade set up by the United States and Britain, goods bound for Baghdad continued to be landed at the Jordanian port of Aqaba for onward transport by truck. More than 100 trucks, most laden with grain, were counted rumbling across the border from Jordan into Iraq in just a few hours this morning.
 
President Threatens a Blockade
President Bush threatened on Tuesday to blockade Aqaba if it continued to provide an outlet for Iraqi commerce, and the issue was expected to be an important part of the talks in Kennebunkport.
But Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, suggested that it was Teheran that might provide Baghdad with a ''gigantic breach'' in the United Nations sanctions, and experts on the Middle East agreed.
''Saddam wouldn't have done it if he didn't have hopes of getting something out of it,'' said Philip Sabin of King's College, London. ''Otherwise, pulling back like this just weakens his position.''
President Bush spoke at the Pentagon of ''Saddam's ruinous policies of war against other Muslims'' and condemned what he called his ''raw territorial ambition.'' It was the Iraqis, Mr. Bush said, who had made necessary what the President called ''one of the most important deployments of allied military power since World War II.''
''Our jobs, our way of life, our own freedom and the freedom of friendly countries around the world would all suffer if control of the world's great oil reserves fell into the hands of Saddam Hussein,'' the President said. ''A half century ago, our nation and the world paid dearly for appeasing an aggressor who should, and could, have been stopped,'' he added, referring to Hitler.''We are not going to make the same mistake again.''
Vowing once more to force the Iraqis from Kuwait and to restore the Kuwaiti Government, Mr. Bush said he would not allow the ''law of the jungle'' to prevail in the Middle East and pledged, in connection with sanctions, to ''insure that no goods get in and that not one drop of oil gets out.''
An effort to put the naval element of the international military operation under United Nations auspices, which was discussed at the State Department by the five permanent members of the Security Council, each of which has a veto, appeared to hit a snag when China, one of the five, expressed serious doubts about the idea.
In addition, the United States was said to favor a loose arrangement while Moscow, which first broached the idea of international cooperation, was said to want something formal.
With the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy sailing today from Norfolk, Va., and thousands of ground troops arriving daily at Saudi airfields, American and allied military might in the region was building rapidly. But the situation of American civilians in Iraq and Kuwait appeared to take a turn for the worse when the Iraqi Foreign Ministry said that the ''restrictees'' would remain for the duration of the conflict.
Iraq's Ambassador in Washington, Mohammed al-Mashat, contradicted Baghdad's statement. He said of the foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait, ''They are not restricted at all, and will be allowed to leave in good time.''
 
'Something Is Different'
Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said that even American diplomats and their families had been unable to procure exit visas when their seven-day waiting period expired today. The Iraqis had said a week ago that while others might be held back, those with diplomatic passports could go after paperwork had been processed.
''Something is different,'' Miss Tutwiler conceded. ''Frankly, they are finally admitting behavior contrary to all international norms.''
In Baghdad, Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, today called the detention of Americans in Iraq and Kuwait ''temporary precautionary measures'' and pledged that no foreigners would be harmed.
Speaking on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' Mr. Aziz also said his Government would consider allowing some persons, like those who are ill, to leave more quickly out of ''humanitarian'' concerns.
Nearly 9,000 Soviet citizens were among the hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped, and the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Yuri Gremitskikh, said in Moscow that Baghdad has agreed to allow all 880 Russians in Kuwait to leave. Also free to go if they wish, he said, are all the Soviet women, children and invalids in Iraq, but not the men, who are about two-thirds of the group.
At the same time, Moscow announced that it was sending a special ambassador, Mikhail Sytenko, a former Deputy Secretary General of the United Nations, on a peacemaking mission to Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Iraq.
Officials at the Ruweishid border station on the Jordanian frontier with Iraq said more than 4,000 foreigners fleeing from the tensions of the region had flooded through in the last 12 hours, but others died crossing the desert in the 120-degree heat. Among those who made it into Jordan were 2,000 Egyptians and 360 Jordanians as well as groups of Syrians, Lebanese, Pakistanis, Indians, Filipinos, Yemenis, Tunisians, Poles and others.
 
Iraqis 'Stealing Everything'
Said Salman, a 40-year-old Egyptian driver, said after arriving from Kuwait, ''The Iraqis stole my video, typewriter and color television.'' Another Egyptian, Saadeddine Hassan, a 36-year-old civil engineer, commented: ''Things are very bad in Kuwait. There is no money in the banks and the Iraqis are stealing everything.''
The Foreign Office in London said that there had been wholesale looting in Kuwait but reported that food and gasoline were still available. Miss Tutwiler said telephone service was sporadic, with only two lines at the American Embassy still working.
Bangladesh joined Pakistan, which made an announcement on Tuesday, in agreeing to send small contingents to join the Syrian, Egyptian and Moroccan soldiers who have already arrived in Saudi Arabia as a result of an Arab League decision to aid the Saudis.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Kuwaiti in U.S. Speaks Of an Exile Leadership

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON Aug. 15

 BODY:
The Kuwaiti government-in-exile is directing an underground armed resistance and a wide assortment of public services inside its country, from garbage removal to emergency medical care, senior Kuwaiti officials said today.
''When the Iraqis invaded, we were in shock,'' said Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, the Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, in an interview in Washington. ''Then we got organized. The people need us.'' 
In a matter of days, Saudi Arabia donated to the exiled Government a building in the mountain resort of Al Taif for various ministries to set up offices, a base near the border at Dhahran for a 5,000-man reconstituted army, and a radio station by which the royal Sabah family communicates with its people. Using Bedouin couriers, officials send letters of instruction and money every day to key bureaucrats who continue to run vital ministries at the behest of exiled ministers.
 
Military Resistance Predicted
The officials say the couriers have sent orders to the underground, which includes Kuwaiti military units and civilians, to begin open military resistance next week. ''They will begin to feel us,'' said Mr. Sabah, the 61-year-old brother of the Emir, adding, ''Ours is like the French exile Government'' during World War II.
The Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, has said he intends to merge his country and Kuwait into one. His occupation forces have fired the country's top ministers and ambassadors, and he has vowed that the Emir and his family will never return to power. But Kuwaiti officials say the Iraqis are effectively condoning the continued operations of the exiled Government to keep basic services such as health care and garbage removal functioning.
''We are coordinating all health services inside Kuwait,'' said Health Minister Abdulwahab Alfouzan. ''I'm getting good information on what is going on in our hospitals, medical centers - all we need to know. All the ministries are functioning the same, through indirect contacts.'' He said such services were a form of resistance.
''The people who pick up the garbage won't listen to the Iraqis,'' said Mr. Sabah, who is here to meet with President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ''They only listen to us.''
The exiled Government and its agents in the field have set up neighborhood committees to take care of police services, garbage collection and emergency health services to supplement the Government.
 
Complicating a Settlement
Should the Emir's Government continue to be able to resist, not only would it make Iraq's occupation more costly, but it might also limit the kind of negotiated settlement that could be arranged for ending the Persian Gulf crisis. The Kuwaiti officials make it clear that they will never accept a compromise in which Iraqi troops leave their country on the condition that a new government is formed.
The Kuwaitis are organizing inside and outside their country. More than 100 Kuwaiti embassies continue to function, coordinating by telephone, telex and fax with the Government office in Al Taif, working to persuade governments to enforce an economic blockade against Iraq. They have also established committees of Kuwaiti students, tourists and residents to take care of the personal problems of Kuwaitis living abroad. They counsel the emotionally distressed, ease communication among family members and even give financial help to people who wish to travel to Arab countries closer to home.
The Kuwait Investment Office, the London-based bureau that handles Kuwaiti investments abroad, still operates, and it serves as the exiled Government's treasury. The office is working with foreign governments to release some frozen Kuwaiti assets in foreign banks to finance the exiled Government's operations. Mr. Sabah said the office was obtaining good cooperation from foreign governments, although it faced much legal red tape.
 
Sadness and Composure
There was deep sadness in Mr. Sabah's eyes, but he remained composed. As he sat among his advisers in a Washington hotel room protected by American Secret Service agents, he gazed from time to time at a television set tuned to CNN. He watched with special interest an interview with the wives of American servicemen on their way to the Saudi desert.
''My brother, five in my family, died in the invasion,'' he said, but quickly added that what made him most sad was ''that one Arab country would invade another.''
Mr. Sabah's escape from his country, along with the escape of his brother, the Emir, was chilling.
''We weren't ready,'' he recalled. ''President Mubarak, King Fahd and King Hussein said there would be no military strike. They told us not to mobilize our forces so not to aggravate Iraq.''
But in the middle of the night, while Mr. Sabah was sleeping, 100,000 Iraqi troops began to pour over the Kuwaiti border.
Mr. Sabah and several Cabinet ministers rushed to army headquarters to monitor the fighting. When it became apparent that Iraqi forces were rushing to take Kuwait City, they called the Emir to wake him for their escape. Not five minutes after they picked him up from the palace, Iraqi helicopters and ground troops attacked the building.
The Emir and his Cabinet fled in a caravan of limousines to the Emir's seaside home at Jelaiah. Shortly afterward, they crossed the Saudi border into exile.
Mr. Sabah said all was not lost. The entire Kuwaiti air force and most of the country's armed forces managed to escape, he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
With Loyalty Split, Arab-Americans Fault Hussein, but Question U.S. Too

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Since the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis two weeks ago, most prominent Arab-Americans have joined the chorus of denunciation against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for his invasion and annexation of Kuwait. Yet at the end of the chorus, Arab-American voices add one word: but.
* But why are the American Government and American news organizations so ready to go beyond condemnation and demonize an Arab leader, evoking images of barbarism that Arab-Americans fear may be rooted as much in ethnic stereotypes as in Mr. Hussein's own history?
* But why does Iraq's crossing of Kuwait's border lead to a rapid deployment of American troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia, when Israel's crossing into Lebanon in 1982 provoked no such action? 
* And always there, though often muted: But what will happen to us?
''It's a serious emotional and political burden when your country is fighting your people,'' said Khalil Jahshan, a Palestinian who handles public relations for the National Association of Arab-Americans.
 
A Concept of Nationhood
Mr. Jahshan was one of a number of prominent Arab-Americans, interviewed in recent days, who responded to the crisis with both dispassionate analysis and emotional reflection on the history that unites and divides their people.
Among Arab-Americans, as in the Arab world, the concept of Arab nationhood - of respect, power and influence for an entire people - exerts a powerful pull, Mr. Jahshan said. ''It's not a movement, not a political party,'' he went on. ''It's basically an emotional desire for Arabs to be one. It's based on the notion of a glorious Arab past, and it's reinforced by the failures of recent history.''
The drawing and redrawing of national boundaries in the Middle East over the last century have left the two and a half million Arab-Americans with emotional ties to both present and former lands - Jordan, Syria, Palestine, Lebanon, Yemen, Iraq - and to a larger concept of kinship.
''When I was growing up in a Lebanese Maronite home in Utica, N.Y., and an Egyptian would come and visit, we kids would be in the kitchen wanting to get a peek at him because he was one of our guys,'' said James Zogby, the 44-year-old president of the Arab American Institute, a Washington lobbying group. ''There is a sense of commonness in culture, tradition and language.''
The ''serious emotional and political burden'' cited by Mr. Jahshan can result from a clash between that sense of unity and Arab-Americans' sense of loyalty to the United States. ''For Arab-Americans, this is their first country,'' said Osama Siblani, a native of Lebanon who is publisher of Sada al-Watan, a Detroit newspaper whose circulation of 20,000 makes it the largest Arab-American paper in the United States. ''America is where they chose to live. They fled persecution, oppression and poverty. And now they will try to prevent a catastrophe on both ends.''
 
Focus of Dialogue Changes
The crisis in the Persian Gulf has wrenched the Arab-American dialogue away from its usual focus on Israel and the Palestinian question and into equally complex terrain involving the Arab states' relations with one another and the resentment of the impoverished Arab countries toward the sheikdoms enriched by oil. But Israel and the perceived inequities of American policy in the Middle East are never far beneath the surface.
Mr. Zogby, Mr. Jahshan and others repeatedly invoke the comparison with Israel's 1982 invasion, although the comparison does not take into account a crucial difference: that Kuwait had not attacked Iraq, while southern Lebanon was home to Palestinian bases that had repeatedly shelled Israeli territory. Still, the distinction does little to eliminate the perception of Arab-Americans that United States policy in the Middle East has not been evenhanded.
''Kuwait must be restored,'' said Mr. Zogby. ''Saudi Arabia must be defended. But it is incumbent on America, if we want to win the hearts and minds of the Arab people, to be consistent to principle.'' He said Arab-Americans were ''looking to see that this is more than just a defense of oil.''
Many Arab-Americans share another concern: that an American campaign against an Arab state, in this case Iraq, could lead to a backlash against Arabs at home. James G. Abourezk, a Lebanese-American who is a former Senator from South Dakota and now heads the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, said a violent anti-Arab telephone message had recently been left on an answering machine at the group's Western regional headquarters. In 1985, at the time of the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro by a group of Palestinians, the Anti-Discrimination Committee's Western regional director, Alex Odeh, was killed by a bomb in his office. No one has been convicted or even indicted for the attack.
 
Borders Are Colonial
''By and large the Arab community supports the economic sanctions'' imposed against Iraq by the United Nations, Mr. Abourezk said, ''but I think they are very much opposed to U.S. troop intervention.'' If war breaks out between Arabs and Americans, he said, ''it's not going to be comfortable for people of Arab descent.''
Hisham Melhem, a Lebanese who was the Washington correspondent for al-Qabas, the leading Kuwaiti newspaper, said: ''Most Arabs, emotionally and intellectually, when they look at the map and see the borders among the gulf states or among Lebanon and Syria, Jordan and Iraq, they know that these were not historic national boundaries but boundaries drawn by colonial powers.''
People do not want to live in a country controlled by Mr. Hussein, Mr. Melhem went on, ''because they know how repressive he is.'' But he indicated that he was troubled by the reaction of Americans to the Iraqi President. Mr. Hussein has ''taken over Khomeini's position,'' he said.
''It seems now, beyond Communism, you like to look for someone who is the embodiment of evil,'' he said. ''If it's not Arafat, it's Qaddafi. If not Qaddafi, Noriega. If not Noriega, then it's Saddam. Saddam obviously is a dictator and has his place in the hierarchy of dictatorship. But he is not Hitler.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 705 words

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Again, a U.S. Surprise Leaves Nations Upset

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d got a cat-that-swallowed-the-canary look during a Sunday morning talk show and announced an American ''interdiction'' of Iraqi commerce at sea, he set off alarm bells among startled world leaders.
By Monday, just days after Washington had galvanized global opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, members of the Security Council were charging in a closed meeting at the United Nations that an impatient American President was imposing a blockade, calling it something else, using a questionable legal formula to justify it and doing it without telling anybody.
Those events reinforce two plain truths: how difficult it is in general for the United States to consult, even with its friends, and how quickly this image-obsessed Administration in particular can reverse itself in the face of a public outcry.
For all George Bush's personal diplomacy - his middle-of-the-night telephone calls to heads of state, his insistence that he has to know someone personally before he can do business with him and the constant talk of the need for collective action - people who know him well say he basically prefers to go it alone. 
In his news conference on Tuesday, Mr. Bush dismissed the criticism of the blockade as nitpicking, saying ''it doesn't disturb me in the least.'' A State Department official testily added, ''We're not going to tell everybody everything.''
But in the background, as the voices grew louder, there was a frantic effort to quiet things down. Mr. Baker got on the telephone with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, saying, yes, perhaps the United States should have consulted more and assuring them that the United States wanted their help to enforce the embargo. Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, called in the ambassadors of France, Britain, China and the Soviet Union to propose putting warships in the Persian Gulf under United Nations auspices.
''The White House was clearly surprised by our reaction,'' said one Western official familiar with the Security Council meeting. ''It was a clumsy move because the sanctions in place were working beautifully. The Americans are not going to say it, but they gave us the impression they made a mistake. But why were the Americans in so much of a rush?''
One answer is that the American way of doing things is to do them fast, particularly when force is involved. Privately, American officials will say that consultations and consensus sometimes gum up the works.
The Reagan Administration repeatedly took unilateral actions that disturbed America's closest allies. In 1984, for example, the United States began withdrawing marines from Lebanon with only an hour's notice to the French and Italians, who suddenly had to scramble to get their own soldiers out. And at one point during the reflagging of Kuwaiti ships in 1988 the United States decided - alone and with scant warning - to attack Iranian oil rigs, leaving other nations' ships in the Persian Gulf unprepared.
This Administration has tried to do better, but Mr. Bush has not kicked the secrecy habit. He says over and over that he does not need to tell everybody everything he is doing. Since assuming office his standard response to tough questions about his intentions is ''Stay tuned.''
Latin Americans were furious when the United States invaded Panama last December without telling them, European allies were peeved when the Administration closed its embassy in Afghanistan with no notice last year and Asians were stunned when Washington withdrew its support for the opposition coalition in Cambodia last month.
For the moment, the behind-the-scenes smoothing of ruffled feathers is working. The Soviets are pleased that the Americans have seized the idea of a gulf force sponsored by the United Nations. Other countries are satisfied that the Administration is not ignoring them.
''Fundamentally the Americans have not changed their position, but they are now trying to accommodate our sensitivities,'' said a European official. ''Still, there's this American tendency to work by itself. But George Bush knows the importance of public relations.''

HEADLINE: False Arguments for Fancy Weapons

 BODY:
In the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, some siren voices are inviting Congress to quit cutting the defense budget and restore money for threatened programs like the B-2 bomber and the Osprey transport plane. That's the way, they say, to maintain an indisputable military edge over third world dictators. The briefest reflection shows this to be pernicious advice. 
It's probably true that the B-2 bomber would be less vulnerable to Iraqi air defenses than the B-52's now available. And a plane like the tilt-rotor Osprey, a novel aircraft with many advantages over the helicopter, would also be nice to have.
But these weapons were designed during the Reagan defense buildup to be used in the context of the cold war. Their utility against countries like Iraq is marginal - and far outweighed by their enormous costs. At least $37 billion could now be saved by canceling the B-2 program and $24 billion by giving up the Osprey.
In confronting Saddam Hussein, the Pentagon does indeed find itself short of equipment - not glamorous weapons like B-2's or Ospreys but mundane items that it disdained to buy during the buildup years. The Navy always prefers to spend for warships than for mere transports to ferry the Army around. Former Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger let the services buy whatever they wanted - and now the Navy finds it has so few fast transports that it can move only one division at a time to the Middle East.
Minesweepers are another type of humble craft that ranks far down on the Navy's priority list, even though mines are a Soviet specialty and an obvious defense for third world countries. When an Iraqi tanker was suspected of laying mines in the Persian Gulf on Tuesday, the Navy had three aircraft carriers in the region but no minesweepers.
If Iraq should attack American forces, the Air Force's most useful aircraft will be not its beloved B-2 but the A-10, a dedicated tank-busting plane but so slow, cheap and unglamorous that the Air Force has closed down its production line.
America's military capability against countries like Iraq depends on tactics, training and workhorse equipment. The stealth technologies in the B-2, and the valuable tilt-rotor technology of the Osprey, warrant development. But the chief value of these gilded weapons now lies in the fortune that can be saved by not building them.
Those savings are all the more urgent given the other pressures on the Federal budget. Pentagon spending needs to be reshaped, and the first step is to curb systems designed to meet the now-shrinking threat from the Soviet Union. Congress and the services find all reductions painful, but the first retrenchments have been made.
Secretary Cheney made another on Monday in deciding to stretch out purchases of the Seawolf nuclear attack submarine and the Aegis cruiser. Since these decisions are based on the diminishing Soviet threat, the crisis in the Middle East is no reason for reversing them.
Congress should no more listen to the special interests urging a slower cut in the Pentagon's budget than Odysseus's men should have heeded the enchantress Circe, who turned them into pigs. With serious turbulence both abroad and in the economy, this is an occasion when the national interest transcends mere pork.

HEADLINE: Kill the Fresh Kills Plan

 BODY:
New York City's Board of Estimate is likely to reject a Dinkins administration proposal today that would help short-term revenues but hurt long-term garbage disposal capacity. The board is on the right track; the plan is flawed and the city would be unwise to try to revive it later. 
City Hall hoped to raise money by reducing the dumping fees that commercial carters pay to use the city's only landfill - Fresh Kills, on Staten Island. The relatively high fees at Fresh Kills now send carters in search of less expensive landfills outside the city; lower fees would encourage them to return.
Reducing the fee from $40 to $25 a cubic yard would add an estimated $18 million to the city treasury - a most attractive thought, given the city's faltering economy. But Fresh Kills would fill up with garbage more quickly.
That wouldn't be a problem if the city had developed a coherent, long-range program for disposing of solid waste. It hasn't. Present recycling efforts will help, but not enough, and Mayor David Dinkins has yet to approve former Mayor Edward Koch's proposal for huge incinerators. For now, that leaves only Fresh Kills, and it is rapidly running out of space.
The board has ample cause to reject the idea. And City Hall would do well to drop it and get on with the business of developing a comprehensive plan for disposing of solid waste.
