HEADLINE: As New England Goes, So May Go the Nation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I take no issue with the findings of your July 23 front-page article that the worst recession in the United States has taken hold in New England, nor with the bleak opinions offered by the professional economists. But as a native New Englander and a noneconomist, I would like to offer my own analysis.
The problems of New England (and indeed other areas of the country) stretch far beyond the ups and downs of the last 25 years of the ''technological revolution.'' They are American problems anchored in industrial and investment patterns of at least a century and a half. 
In talking to remaining and transplanted New Englanders over the last decade, I find the consensus is that the region's economic turnaround, while dramatic and obviously good for many professionals, was not founded on bedrock.
For longtime residents, the ''miracle'' was elusive and illusory. Yes, there was no limit to service jobs at moderate-to-good wages, but many offered minimal benefits. Better jobs with leading companies offering a full range of benefits were restricted to those with specialized skills and, often, advanced education. Many higher paid workers were young newcomers recruited from other parts of the country. For those with only average education, there was always the feeling that the phenomenal growth of the 1980's was fragile.
Although mill towns such as Lowell, Mass., did benefit from high technology and Government grants, many former manufacturing centers simply languished, beset by urban ills, such as drugs and unemployment. To say that New England's economic resurgence never existed is to fly in the face of reliable figures. But the turnaround was spotty; some benefited, some did not.
One of the crazy-quilt elements in American life is that populations continually change. This was the story of New England in the 1960's and 70's, with its once prominent textile mills dead or dying and its light industry facing regional and foreign competition. Many of the best, the brightest and the youngest left New England in these years - and this continues today. Contemporaneous with this outmigration was inmigration. What is more significant is the polarized composition of this inmigration.
In the late 1960's and 70's, with the economy booming, people in many parts of the country (including many New Yorkers) began to cast longing glances toward New England. The region is blessed with beauty, including both seashore and mountains, and as the oldest section of the country, enjoys arguably the most cohesive, settled and ultimately human culture in the United States. In the 70's, a trickle of newcomers seeking to start businesses or perhaps to retire began to penetrate the more picturesque sections of Vermont and New Hampshire. Soon they would be joined by hordes of the equally well off and well educated, eager to settle and puzzle out the sayings of the natives.
Other portions of New England would experience an entirely different influx. In Bridgeport, Stonington, Providence, Boston, Ludlow, Lowell and other industrial cities - once bustling and now neglected - hundreds and then thousands of polyglot immigrants would arrive throughout the 70's and 80's. The impetus would be the economic and social promise of America weighed against the political and economic difficulties of their own countries. This latest migration consisted of Azoreans and Cape Verdeans, Puerto Ricans, Central and South Americans, and even a few Eastern Europeans.
As a population, these newcomers remain among the most marginal. Many are ill housed, most work in low-paying, uncertain jobs. Their families require extensive social services, yet because of language and cultural differences, many have already found it difficult, often impossible, to join the mainstream. In many respects their prospects are narrower than immigrants arriving before World War II. Industrial jobs are shrinking, and an uncertain technological revolution requires increasing education and technical skills.
One feels that if Dickens were to walk through the back streets of Lowell or New Bedford in 1990, he would instantly recognize the urban poor and a choking wave of despair. As the 21st century approaches, New England as an economic entity must answer this question: Can the oldest section of the nation overcome the burden of an aging infrastructure and a disparate working population, while demonstrating that a highly technical service economy can work? There is a lot riding on the answer, and it is of concern to all Americans.
New Englanders new and old have no lack of fortitude in their rocky, sometimes quirky corner of the nation. One hopes that the latest flattening of the economic curve is just a deviation. Still, there are no guarantees that a service and technical economy can be secure. If there is any bright side, it might well be that East Germans and Poles now struggling with the vagaries of market economies and nascent democracies can take heart from the New England experience: there are no easy answers.
 
EDWARD D. SCULLEN
 Silver Spring, Md., July 31, 1990

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Iraq and Atom Bombs

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
In 1981, a small country recognized a deadly danger to its existence. In a courageous act of self-preservation the country struck out militarily to save itself. In doing so, that country benefited not only itself but the world.
Nine years later, the danger has risen again - and again it is to all the nations. The challenge and opportunity to end it now fall to a great power. 
On June 7, 1981, Israeli planes bombed the Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad. It thus prevented the Iraqi dictatorship from developing atomic bombs that were supposed to be its crucial instruments of blackmail, fear and death.
Much of the world screeched at Israel, a classic demonstration of global hypocrisy. But in truth every nation understood that Israel had moved the world one step back from self-destruction.
Then, blind with greed and suicidally stupid with self-delusion, the Arabs, the West and the Soviet Union stuffed Saddam Hussein with money, weapons and the material that allowed him to rebuild his nuclear weapon potential. He built a new plant near Turkey and every day moves closer to the bomb.
Saddam has used other weapons from which the world thought it was safe - chemicals that burn and choke before killing. He used them in Iran and against his people at home.
Who will now guarantee that this killer, once armed with nuclear bombs for the delivery missiles he already has, will never carry out or threaten a nuclear strike?
Shall we ask the State Department experts who said Saddam would never invade Kuwait? And while they are at it, can they also guarantee that Saddam will never slip a few of the bombs in his nuclear arsenal to his gangs of roving terrorists to stash away in some Middle Eastern warren - or in a Western city?
We are even now afraid to try to rescue our hostages, including the new thousands Saddam has taken in Kuwait and Iraq. Who will dare act against terrorists when they are armed with nuclear weapons?
We are at war with Iraq. When Iraq struck at vital U.S. economic interests and President Bush properly responded with blockade, that was war.
The questions now are how it will be fought and how it will be ended.
Saddam and assorted vassals, such as King Hussein of Jordan, did not expect Mr. Bush to react with such courage and force. Even some of Saddam's Arab ''brothers'' find themselves forced to stand up to him for awhile, to save their necks.
But the West would be even more foolish than usual to forget that some of our new Arab allies gave him billions of dollars before he threatened them directly. The biggest contributors to the Iraqi war chest were Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.
They would be slaveringly happy to give Saddam money and weapons again as long as he went after somebody else - say, Israel.
So Saddam shrewdly sends word that he is ready for a deal, some arrangement allowing him to get ready for the next move. Maybe he would even be willing to save the bank accounts of the Kuwaiti Emir and his oil-fat family - for a cut, of course.
Saddam would keep his job and army and build his nuclear threat. In a couple of years, he will be ready again to grab for international domination. This time he will be armed with nuclear weapons stockpiled at home and scattered in his various terrorist bases abroad.
Rest easy, we will be told by our experts, he will never dare to use or threaten the use of nuclear weapons. Maybe they will be right at last. But suppose they are wrong, just one more time?
If Saddam wants peace to regroup, the minimum price must be the destruction of his nuclear plants, missile factories and launching pads.
After the embargo is tight enough to hurt Saddam, the United States should give him a short time - a few days - to permit the entry of an international team to supervise the destruction. If he does not accept, the United States should do it from the air, with its allies or without.
Yes, Israel will still have nuclear capacity. That will be a danger to the West - provided Israel surrenders democracy for despotism, cries Holy War against the West, takes our hostages and threatens our economic independence.
Pretending democratic friends and tyrannical enemies are the same helped bring us Hitler, Stalin and Saddam Hussein.
A peace that leaves Saddam Hussein ever able to lift a nuclear bomb in threat would be a betrayal of all American forces that are sent now to put him down - or that will face him in the future.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
To Borough Chief, Ballroom Issue Is No Waltz

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
For more than a decade as a City Council member with little power and a staff that never exceeded six, Ruth W. Messinger was a thorn in the side of some of the most important people in New York City.
Now, as Manhattan borough president with a staff of more than 100, Ms. Messinger is still needling the establishment of which she has become a bigger part. But she also has some unaccustomed arrowheads in her own hide, more than a few of them fired by her friends.
''I don't know why she has gone that way,'' said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch. 
''I was somewhat incensed,'' said State Senator Franz S. Leichter.
The fuss is over Ms. Messinger's challenge to Columbia University's plan to build a commercial biomedical center - intended to draw new businesses - on the site of the historic but crumbling Audubon Ballroom in Washington Heights.
The plan is backed by the community board and elected officials from the area, and by Mayor David N. Dinkins, whose administration crafted a compromise to save part of the ballroom, where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965. But some preservationists and civil rights advocates want more, and Ms. Messinger, out-Dinkinsing Dinkins, has sided with them.
''I've got 15 major development items and 1,000 contracts to vote on,'' she said, a bit surprised at the stir. ''This was not where I planned to stake my claim.''
Whether Ms. Messinger will have to vote on the Audubon plan is unclear. It remains on the agenda for the last meeting of the Board of Estimate, which begins today. But using her powers under an obscure state law, she has already vetoed $8.1 million in funds from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that had been earmarked for the $34 million project, unless her conditions are met. She wants to preserve the whole ballroom, make space for community groups and get guarantees on jobs for local residents.
Her old ally, Senator Leichter, whose district includes the neighborhood and who has sought to block a few development deals in his time, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell and Councilman Stanley E. Michels think that's too much.
''The likely result of your action is a continued deterioration of the Audubon Ballroom with a consequent negative effect on the community, no memorial to Malcolm X and no economic development for northern Manhattan,'' they wrote her last week.
''When you reach the level that she's on,'' Mr. Leichter said, ''and you're asked to really produce something and do it in a climate that's quite different from the homogeneous hothouse climate of her political viewpoint, you just can't state all the ideal positions.''
Richard D. Emery, who represents a preservation group, the Sugar Hill Historical Society, called Ms. Messinger's decision ''courageous and wise.'' State Senator David Paterson of Harlem supports her, too. But she remains more alone than usual, or than any politician likes to be.
In her campaign last year, Ms. Messinger, a former social worker, tried hard to persuade people that for all her liberal crusading, she was not the anti-business, anti-development bomb thrower some feared. Now some of the old labels are back. Last week, a Daily News editorial called her Lady Macbeth.
''I don't think people should make a judgment on this one case,'' said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, ''although it is very troubling that she has taken such a position on a project that may now not be able to proceed, and with Columbia, an institution that is really sticking its neck out in trying to bring some new industries to New York.''
Ms. Messinger has raised objections to a number of other projects, but her stand on the Audubon may have as much to do with demanding clout and respect from her old friend the Mayor as anything else, especially with the Estimate Board on its deathbed and the borough presidents left trying to make something of untested roles under the new City Charter.
''If anybody can do that, Ruth can,'' Mr. Spinola said. ''She's exceptionally shrewd.''
''I think generally people have felt she's done an excellent job and not adhered to any rigid anti-development policy at all,'' said Nathan Leventhal, a former deputy mayor and now the president of Lincoln Center. ''I don't think this indicates anything other than a disagreement on this point.''
In fact, Ms. Messinger and the city are still talking, and senior mayoral aides said there might be a glimmer of progress. ''The notion is to negotiate a favorable agreement on that site,'' Ms. Messinger said. ''It will not, to be sure, satisfy every constituency that we've heard from.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 920 words

HEADLINE: Jail for Crime That Shocked Even the Jaded

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
After a trial that shocked even veteran Bronx prosecutors yet drew scant public attention, a young Bronx man received the maximum prison sentence yesterday for the 1988 murder of an Israeli immigrant who had employed one of his friends.
After strangling the man with a shoelace and stabbing him, 19-year-old Angel Diaz and four other youths took the subway from the Bronx to Brooklyn. There, after snacking on doughnuts, they donned Halloween masks to rob, beat and gang-rape the man's wife and 16-year-old daughter. The women were then sexually tortured while the man's 3-year-old daughter watched from her crib. 
''You have committed some of the most heinous crimes in recent memory,'' Justice Antonio I. Brandveen of State Supreme Court told Mr. Diaz, who rolled his eyes toward the courtroom's brass chandeliers. ''Yet you have no remorse.'' Then he sentenced Mr. Diaz to 38Y years to life for his conviction last month on 13 counts of murder, robbery, burglary and conspiracy.
 
Grew Up Together
Mr. Diaz was acquitted on four counts of rape even though the man's wife and daughter flew back from Israel to testify that all five of the youths who broke into their Starrett City apartment had sexually assaulted them.
Victor Sanchez, a 21-year-old man who had worked for the Israeli man on small construction jobs and driving a livery limousine, admitted he planned the murder and recruited friends to help him. He was sentenced late last year to 15 years to life. Dutvall Guzman, now 17, who strangled the man and then tortured his wife and daughter with a bedpost, curling iron and umbrella, also pleaded guilty. Late last year he was sentenced as a juvenile to eight years to life in jail.
Two other youths, Brando Campos, 16, and Luis Gonzalez, 17, have pleaded not guilty and are to go on trial next week.
Friends said some of the youths grew up together, and all of them lived in the same apartment building at 1420 Grand Concourse in the Highbridge section.
Like the judge, assistant district attorneys who have for years moved criminals through the Bronx county courthouse and even homicide detectives at the 41st Precinct, said they had difficulty recalling a crime more lurid.
Many pointedly insisted that in the elaborate planning, the case was more horrific than even that of the jogger who was attacked in Central Park last year. And some took it as a measure of the volume of local violence that by contrast, the Bronx killing has received relatively little notice, either in the borough or by the press.
''It's really a horror story,'' said Mr. Diaz's lawyer, Paul I. Auerbach, who has handled many sex cases for years. ''But nobody was there to hear it. It was like a tree in the forest.''
As Justice Brandveen vowed to send a message with his sentence that the city would not tolerate wanton brutality, the courtroom was nearly filled with spectators. But when Mr. Diaz was led away in handcuffs, only his mother, aunt, and 16-year-old girlfriend left with him. Most of the others, defendants and their relatives, stayed behind to wait their turn.
 
'We Believe in the System'
Mr. Diaz, dressed in baggy white shorts, a loose-fitting polka dot shirt and green leather sneakers, said nothing in his defense. He showed concern only when his mother, Norma Diaz, and his 16-year-old girlfriend broke down in loud, uncontrollable sobs.
In her appeal for a harsh sentence, Cindy Zamzok, an assistant district attorney, noted that Mr. Diaz had been arrested four times for burgularies, robberies and assault before he turned 16. And she recalled that in speaking to the murdered man's wife and daughter, whose names have been withheld because of the sexual assaults, she had told them that probably nothing could expunge their nightmares or compensate their loss.
''No,'' Ms. Zamzok quoted the women as responding. ''We believe in the system. That's why we came back from Israel to New York to testify.''
In the courtroom gallery, Mr. Diaz's girlfriend, Diane Colon, loudly dismissed the system with an expletive.
Mr. Diaz was arrested after his mother and stepfather, suspicious of the money and new clothes he suddenly appeared with, went to tell detectives about a crime in which they thought his friends might have been involved. Mr. Diaz, who was unemployed, had told them he earned the money by beating up a crack addict for a friend. It was not known whether the clothes he wore in court yesterday were among those he bought with his share of the more than $5,000 stolen from the victims. Just Like Jean Valjean? Detectives found Mr. Diaz on Oct. 21, four days after the killing, in a delivery room at Bronx Lebanon Hospital. Miss Colon, then 14, was giving birth to the couple's daughter, Crystal.
Yesterday, Mr. Auerbach began the hearing by requesting an adjournment until after Sept. 5, which he said would be Mr. Diaz's next opportunity to marry Miss Colon on Rikers Island. The judge refused. In Mr. Diaz's defense, Mr. Auerbach likened him to Jean Valjean, the honest peasant in Victor Hugo's ''Les Miserables.'' Valjean begins by stealing a loaf of bread and hardens as a criminal in an unforgiving system of justice until he is belatedly given a chance at redemption.
''My client intended to steal to feed his family,'' Mr. Auerbach said. Justice Brandveen ignored the plea. ''These crimes are beyond anyone's worst nightmares,'' he said. ''It is the recommendation of this court that you should serve all of your sentence without the possibility of parole.''

HEADLINE: METRO DATELINES;
Man Held in Robbing Of 31 Elderly People

DATELINE: PARKCHESTER

 BODY:
An unemployed man was charged yesterday with robbing 31 elderly people during a crime spree that began in January in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, the police said.
The suspect, Ramiro Serita, 33 years old, of 2264 Waterbury Avenue in the Schuylerville section of the Bronx, was identified yesterday by several of the victims at a lineup in the 43d Precinct station house, the police said. 
Mr. Serita was arrested at 1:15 P.M. on Tuesday after a resident of a building at 1480 Parkchester Road who had just been robbed pointed him out on the street to the police, said a police spokeswoman, Officer Janice Swinney. ''He would follow senior citizens into the lobby of their buildings, then into the elevator, where he would rob them at knifepoint,'' she said.
The robbery Tuesday fit that pattern, she said, adding that the police had recovered a 5-inch kitchen knife.
None of the victims - who lost a total of about $1,000 - was injured, Officer Swinney said. Mr. Serita was charged with first-degree robbery, possession of stolen property and possession of a weapon.

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Eli Lilly Facing Million-Dollar Suits On Its Antidepressant Drug Prozac

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
As reports mount that the nation's most widely prescribed antidepressant drug may spark violent or suicidal behavior in a fraction of patients, lawyers and former users of the medication are banding together to file multimillion-dollar lawsuits against the drug's maker.
In the last three weeks, six lawsuits have been lodged against Eli Lilly & Company of Indianapolis, who manufactures Prozac, seeking a total of more than $300 million in punitive and compensatory damages. Lawyers working on the cases say that they and other lawyers are planning to file dozens of suits in the next few weeks.
Although the specifics vary from case to case, the plaintiffs of all six suits generally charge the maker of Prozac with failure to have tested the drug properly before introducing it on the market in 1987. The suits also contend that Eli Lilly was ''grossly negligent'' for not warning doctors strongly and clearly enough that the antidepressant may sometimes set off aggressive, violent or suicidal behavior. 
The lawyers maintain that while their clients were taking Prozac, they became far more hostile, despairing and uncontrollable than they had ever been before, committing extreme acts of self-mutilation, attempting suicide and endangering their families. The lawyers attribute the violence to the psychiatric medication. They say that by presenting its product as relatively safe and free of significant side effects, Eli Lilly has made claims that are ''shocking, absurd and totally misleading,'' said Leonard L. Finz, who heads a New York firm specializing in product liability cases.
 
Lawyers Relying on Report
All lawyers are relying on a report published in the American Journal of Psychiatry in February by Dr. Martin H. Teicher and his colleagues at Harvard Medical School and McLean Hospital. In that paper, Dr. Teicher described six patients who were free of suicidal tendencies until they started on Prozac. His findings led him to predict that from 1.9 to 7.7 percent of Prozac users may be at risk for mania, obsession with suicide and dangerously violent behavior.
Spokesmen for Eli Lilly, while refusing to discuss the details of any cases under litigation, insist that Prozac was well tested before being marketed, and that it is remarkably safe.
''Certainly our product was adequately tested,'' said Edward West, director of corporate communications. ''Laboratory testing began in 1976. More than 11,000 people participated in clinical trials. To date, more than 2 million patients worldwide have been treated with Prozac. Our experience with Prozac does not show a cause-and-effect relationship between it and suicidal thoughts or acts. Our safety track record has been well established.''
In the last few months, the Food and Drug Administration has received about 10,000 reports from doctors, pharmacists and others of adverse reactions to Prozac. But Dr. Paul Leber, director of the division of neuropharmacological drug products at the agency, said that the vast majority of reported side effects, like agitation or insomnia, are relatively mild and are included on the list of warnings that accompany the drug's packaging.
 
Caution by F.D.A. Official
Of more severe reactions, he said it was hard to prove a cause-and-effect relationship.
''The trouble is that most of the symptoms described, like violence or suicidal tendencies, are symptoms well known to accompany depression,'' Dr. Leber said. ''To date, we don't see anything about this drug that is associated with an increased risk'' of violence or suicidal tendencies.
Dr. Leber and other experts note that, Prozac notwithstanding, depressed patients are at strong suicide risks. They said that no single treatment for depression was completely effective, and that a certain fraction of patients receiving Prozac or any other medication would be expected to fail to respond to the treatment and thus to continue being at risk for suicide. ''Ten percent of people with a lifelong depressive illnesses probably will kill themselves,'' said Dr. Leber.
Medical experts are mixed in their response to the recent lawsuits against Prozac. On one hand, psychiatrists and other doctors say that many of the latest complaints are exaggerated and misleading.
They insist that Prozac is an extremely valuable drug for treating depression, and say that it has far fewer side effects than do the older generation of antidepressant drugs. The lack of unpleasant side effects like weight gain, sluggishness, dry mouth and hypertension has lofted Prozac to its current position as the best-selling antidepressant.
But a growing number of experts worry that the ease of using Prozac, along with early hyperbolic reports that described Prozac as ''miracle drug,'' has led to its being overprescribed.
 
Hopes on Future Drug Use
''My main concern about Prozac is that, given the low incidence of side effects, the likelihood has increased that people would use it more casually, and that doctors would monitor its use less intensely,'' said Dr. Frederick K. Goodwin, director of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration and the government's top psychiatrist. ''But this is a powerful drug, and any powerful drug will have powerful side effects. The backlash effect of all this adverse publicity probably will lead to a correction that won't hurt.''
Other doctors agree that if the publicity spurs doctors to be more judicious in prescribing Prozac and more vigilant in monitoring patients taking the drug, the new caution is for the best. But they said they would hate to see Prozac go the way of Bendectin, a drug marketed by Merrill-Dow to treat nausea associated with pregnancy.
In the early 1980's, several lawsuits were brought against the company, contending that the medication caused birth defects. Experts say that there was little or no scientific support for the claims, but as a result of the cost of the litigation, Merrill-Dow took Bendectin off the market.
Mr. West of Lilly said that while the company never comments on specific dollar figures for any particular product, sales for Prozac remain strong. ''There is no basis for even considering'' discontinuing the drug, he said.
Despite the difficulty of proving that Prozac causes violence, lawyers seem eager to pursue litigation. ''There's been a deluge of people coming to us,'' said Terry Hawkins, a lawyer with Morris, Hawkins & Dutton, in Louisville, Ky. ''Right now we're investigating eight or nine cases.''
 
Suits After Shooting Spree
Mr. Hawkins's firm represents three widows who are charging the pharmaceutical giant with partial responsibility for the deaths of their husbands. The men were among the eight people murdered and 12 others who were wounded when Joseph Wesbecker, an unemployed printer, went on a shooting spree last year at a printing plant in Louisville where he had worked. Mr. Wesbecker then turned the gun on himself.
An autopsy revealed that Mr. Wesbecker had ''therapeutic'' doses of Prozac in his blood at the time. He also had traces of other medications in his blood, as well as a history of mental disorders, but the lawyers in the case contend that Prozac transformed Mr. Wesbecker from a relatively innocuous if disturbed man into a homicidal maniac.
''We're looking at a man with a history of psychiatric problems, but he had never before done anything to carry them out,'' said Mr. Hawkins. ''He was never violent until he started on Prozac.''
The suits, filed on July 25, seek $50 million each in punitive damages from Lilly and unspecified amounts in compensatory damages.
The three other suits that have been filed involve former Prozac users who came close to committing suicide. In early August, Mr. Finz filed a suit seeking $150 million from Lilly on behalf of Rhonda Hala, a Long Island woman who was given Prozac to treat depression, which he said she had developed after a back injury left her slightly disabled.
While taking the drug, he said, ''she started to exhibit extreme and bizarre behavior. She attacked her doctor and herself, mutilating her chest, legs, stomach, anything to cut into the flesh.'' Mr. Finz said that when she was taken off the drug, her violent behavior ended. But he said ''there is no part of her body left that isn't scarred and mutilated.''
 
Other Suits Against Lilly
On Aug. 8, lawyers in Chicago filed a suit for a salesman in his early 50's, who had been treated for depression since 1985, but who never did anything violent until receiving Prozac in September 1989. Two months later, said his lawyer, Aron D. Robinson of Chicago, ''he attempted suicide by driving his car into the rear of a tractor-trailer.''
Another suit was filed on Aug. 7 in Indianapolis on behalf of Janet Sims, who says she was given Prozac to help her through her marital difficulties, but that she ended up being manic and obsessively suicidal. ''I ended up needing 15 electroshock treatments, just because I'd become suicidal from the Prozac,'' she said.
Dr. Teicher of Harvard says it is unclear why Prozac seems to occasionally spark violence or mania in patients. He says that all antidepressants can cause people to carry out their violent or suicidal fantasies. ''If patients were suicidal before taking antidepressants, their energy level may have been so low that they couldn't act on the impulse,'' he said. ''Sometimes antidepressants can energize them to go ahead and commit suicide before the drugs have a chance to relieve the depression itself.''
But Dr. Teicher believes Prozac is different than the older generation of antidepressants. ''In a small percentage of cases it will take people who aren't suicidal to become preoccupied with suicide,'' he said.
 
Speculation on Effects
He speculates that Prozac may on rare occasions have that effect because it influences the balance of serotonin, a chemical signal in the brain that is involved in emotion and aggressive behavior. The older antidepressants work largely through other signaling pathways in the brain, he said, affecting the neurotransmitters dopamine and norepinephrine, which do not seem to be as directly involved in modulating aggressive impulses.
''It's possible that the neurochemistry of people who do badly on Prozac is more sensitive, or out of balance in a very particular way,'' he said. ''But it's amazing how little we really do know about the serotonin system.'' But Dr. Teicher said many of his fellow psychiatrists have seen excellent results from Prozac.
''I hear mostly the bad news, and I have to keep on reminding myself that most people are doing tremendously well on the medication,'' he said. ''You have to put this in the perspective of 650,000 prescriptions being written every month.''
 
 PROZAC' SIDE EFFECTS: 2 VIEWS
 
Lawsuits agaisnt Eli Lilly & Company allege that its antidepressant drug Prozac causes severe side effects, including suicidal and homicidal tendencies. The manufacturer says the drug has relatively few side effects. The Food and Drug Adminsitration says that violence or suicidal tendencies are not unknown among people with serious depression but are not among the adverse effects of the drug seen in clinical trials.
 
COMMON SIDE EFFECTS LISTED BY MANUFACTURER
 
* Nervous system complaints: anxiety, nervousness, insomnia.
 
* Drowsiness, fatigue; asthenia, the loss of strength or energy.
 
* Tremor.
 
* Sweating.
 
* Gastrointestinal complaints; anorexia, nausea and diarrhea.
 
* Dizziness and lightheadedness.
 
SEVERE SIDE EFFECTS ALLEGED IN LAWSUITS
 
* Suicidal tendencies, ideas and obsessions.
 
* Self-mutilation, attempted and actual suicide.
 
* Violent behavior; homicidal thoughts, behavior and actual homicide.
 
Sources: Eli Lilly & Company; Leonard L. Finz, Vernon Petri and Terry Howkins, plantiff's attorneys.

HEADLINE: Baby Trail Is Leading Couples To Peru

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
THEY attract attention on the sidewalks of the Miraflores and San Isidro neighborhoods of Lima - foreign men and women in jeans and jogging outfits, pushing newborn infants in strollers as passers-by stop to ooh and aah.
Thousands of miles from home in the United States, Canada or Europe, these people have come to fulfill dreams of parenthood. They get their first taste of it in temporary housing in a city suffering political terrorism and economic chaos, where electricity is unpredictable and water is not potable.
''We really have to scramble to make formula and sterilize bottles when the electricity comes on,'' said Rodney H. Mykle, a judge from the Canadian province of Manitoba, who with his wife, Lori McBeth, adopted twin boys during a six-week stay here.
Those who come to Peru to adopt infants have been on adoption lists at home for years and explored possibilities in Asia or elsewhere in Latin America, only to discover that Peru usually has babies readily available. Adoptive parents also say it is the only Latin American country that allows single women to adopt children, although most prospective parents seem to be couples. 
The Peruvian system is not without its critics. Here babies are given to couples right after proceedings are begun, leaving open the possibility that they will not get the child after a bond has formed between them and the baby. Red tape can be interminable. No centralized system or organization oversees adoptions by foreigners. Rather, the would-be parents make their way here through a combination of referrals from adoption agencies at home and word of mouth.
Some find lawyers recommended by previous adopting parents, like from the list kept by Millie de Sacio, an American who owns the La Gringa handicrafts shop in Miraflores.
''Traveling down here seemed awesome at the outset,'' said Terry Cannon, a mental-health counselor from Delaware who, with her husband, J. Roy Cannon, adopted a newborn girl they have named Katy. ''But, as a result, I feel I'll be able to tell Katy about Peru someday.''
''When I met the birth mother in court, we both cried, and I asked her what she would like for us to tell Katy when she grows up,'' Mrs. Cannon continued. ''She said to explain that she was a woman alone with two other children to support and no family around to help her and that she had to work.''
Of those seeking to adopt children here, few have been to South America before; the trip tests their willingness to confront bureaucratic obstacles and judicial proceedings in a foreign country and tongue. Corruption is widely reported in the Peruvian judicial system. Foreigners are often uncertain whether a judicial delay is legitimate or a maneuver by someone looking for a payoff. In addition, a State Department advisory warns, ''both terrorism and crime are serious problems throughout Peru,'' including Lima.
For the Peruvians, national pride raises doubts about sending babies abroad and raises concerns about the motives of the applicants; those feelings can result from different attitudes toward adoption in Latin America and the applicants' countries.
Adoption by nationals of Latin American countries is rare. Most of those who are financially able to adopt children are whites of European descent; most of the babies up for adoption are of mixed Indian and European blood.
''Some people in Peru are suspicious about why blond people want to adopt Indian babies,'' said a Washington woman who spent six weeks in Peru this year in an adoption effort that went awry when the natural mother changed her mind.
The American, who requested that her name not be used because of concerns for her career, said in a telephone interview that the doctor who delivered the baby girl had told her he had heard that some Americans adopted children in Peru to bring them up to become servants.
Partly because of such rumors, the natural mother was shown photographs of Mrs. Cannon's home life in Newark, Del., with her husband and Andy, a 3-year-old they adopted from Korea. Mrs. Cannon said photographs of Andy playing with his American cousins demonstrated that he was an equal part of the family.
About 30 to 40 foreign adoptions a month are said to be processed by courts here. Legal fees mentioned by various adopting parents ranged from $4,000 to $16,000, with most in the $6,000 to $9,000 range - on top of any fees paid to referral agencies outside Peru.
Ms. McBeth of Manitoba, a schoolteacher, and Mr. Mykle, a justice of the Court of Queen's Bench in the city of Brandon, said that after waiting five years to adopt a newborn baby at home, they heard of friends who were successful in Peru.
The Manitoba couple got in touch with the lawyers in Lima who had represented their friends. With the legal help, the Manitobans put together the documents required, had a home study commissioned, and sent the results to Peru by courier mail.
Knowing the adoption proceeding would take 6 to 12 weeks, Mr. Mykle planned to spend only his three-week vacation period in Peru and then to go home and let his wife complete their mission.
''But as soon as my colleagues heard what we were planning,'' he said in an interview, ''they said, 'Your place is there,' and started signing up to take my case load. So we decided, why not adopt two?''
On June 23, advised that twin boys were available, the couple flew to Lima with five suitcases filled with formula and disposable diapers. They moved into a large house converted into small apartments, complete with cribs, across the street from the Anglo-American Clinic. The next day, the lawyers brought them the two boys, who were then about 3 months old. The process took exactly six weeks, during which the couple visited with the natural parents and also visited Lima's museums. They flew home with the boys on Aug. 3.
Terry Cannon said she and her husband were aware of possible complications because they had an acquaintance whose effort to adopt a child here failed at the end of the proceedings.
For that reason, she said, before they set out on their journey, they asked a social worker in Peru who worked with their lawyer if the mother was sure of her decision and were told she was, although they knew she could change her mind. ''I knew we were taking the risk,'' she said.
Indeed, some adoptions do not go smoothly. Kate Ramsey, 36, a nurse from Macon, Ga., who is single, has put her life on hold since coming to Peru in June 1989. Her house and leased car in Macon are unused, but they still have to be paid for every month; her house has been burglarized; the neighbors water the lawn; she arranged for a tax extension, and a friend has her dogs. The hospital paid her salary through the end of last year, and now her parents are paying her expenses.
''My guess is I'm spending my inheritance,'' she said as she watched the 14-month-old boy, Thomas Seth, run around the lobby of the hotel where they live.
Ms. Ramsey said her first lawyer brought the baby to her two weeks after she arrived and said the mother was giving him up. But after months of delays, the mother did not appear in court to swear to her decision. At the end of 1989, the court ruled against the adoption, saying the baby might be stolen.
With a new lawyer, Ms. Ramsey appealed and won a ruling that she had done nothing wrong. She is now going through the adoption proceeding again, asserting that the baby was abandoned. No one has ever appeared to claim him.
''I also have the sense the judge doesn't like single mothers,'' she said. ''He's always saying, 'Let's find a nice Peruvian couple to take the baby,' but I haven't noticed them lined up in the street waiting.''
''I made a decision a long time ago to take this one day at a time,'' she said. ''There have been days when I've cried a lot.''

The Oil Jolt
Iraq took a dramatic step to counter the growing international isolation stemming from its invasion of Kuwait by offering to meet almost all of Iran's conditions for settling the key issues persisting from their eight-year war. [Page A1.]
Oil prices were little changed as the market confronted a lull in news from the Middle East and awaited OPEC's decision whether it would authorize members to pump more oil. [D1.] A renewed taste for cars with muscle is devouring gains for fuel economy. [D1.] 
 
Companies
Donald J. Trump's empire is worth far less than he claimed late last year, his accountants and bankers have concluded, saying that if he had been forced to sell his assets this spring he might not have realized enough money to get out of debt. [D1.]

HEADLINE: In Cars, Muscle vs. Mileage

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Experts on automobiles say technologies are readily available to make cars go much farther on a gallon of gasoline, reducing the demand for oil and therefore lessening the impact of events like the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But a renewed taste for cars with muscle is devouring gains in fuel economy.
In the last two years, Americans have shown little interest. Instead they have been choosing new cars that are heavier, faster and on average less fuel-efficient than those bought in earlier years, for the first time since the oil shock of 1973.
Auto makers have already made substantial gains in cutting fuel consumption by making cars lighter and smaller and developing more efficient engines, and they argue that Americans can best reduce energy consumption by switching to smaller cars with less performance. 
 
'All the Low-Hanging Fruit'
''We've picked all the low-hanging fruit when it comes to fuel efficiency,'' said Albert J. Slechter, the technical director of Federal affairs at the Chrysler Corporation.
But experts outside the auto makers point to innovations that are already in use on some models that if more widely applied could improve the picture even if Americans do not move to smaller cars.
A recent study concluded that applying 17 existing technologies more broadly would raise average mileage to 43.8 miles per gallon from 28.3 in 1987 if size and performance of cars were unchanged.
While this would also raise the cost of the car, the efficiency savings would more than offset this; for every 53 cents invested, one gallon of gasoline, which costs considerably more, would be saved.
The analysis, by Marc. R. Ledbetter, an automotive expert at the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a nonprofit group in Washington, and Marc Ross, of the University of Michigan Department of Physics, assumes that the mix of cars, including size and acceleration, will be the same as in 1987.
Among the improvements suggested by the study were these:
* Using engines with four valves per cylinder instead of the standard two. Having two valves to let in the fuel-air mixture and two for exhaust reduces friction in the gases passing through the cylinder, adding horsepower at high speed and enabling the use of a smaller engine. The fuel savings: about 6.8 percent.
* Electronically controlled shifting in an automatic transmission. This would pick a gear to maximize fuel economy rather than power, in most cases lowering engine speed. Savings: 8 percent.
* Intake valve control. The timing of the opening and closing of intake valves can be varied depending on engine speed. Savings: 6 percent.
* Overhead cam. The cam is a rotating shaft that controls valve opening and closing, and in most cars it is located under the parts it controls. An overhead cam has less mass and takes less energy to turn, reducing energy requirements, among other advantages. Savings: 6 percent.
* Front-wheel drive. Eliminating the drive shaft and rear axles allows a redesign to save space and cut weight. Savings: 10 percent.
* Aerodynamic changes to cut wind resistance. Savings: 4.6 percent. Limited Prospects? Car company executives say many of these technologies are already being used on most new cars, so the prospects for further savings are limited. And some innovations, they say, will hurt performance and could interfere with another goal for new cars, reducing air pollution.
Mr. Ledbetter responded that some gains from the new technologies have been offset by the increased popularity of more powerful engines.
The nation could also improve fuel economy without sacrificing car size if auto makers used lighter - but costlier - materials. A 10 percent weight reduction in a 3,000-pound car will save 6.6 percent in fuel, experts say. Floyd E. Allen, executive engineer of power-train engineering at Chrysler, said cars could be lighter if aluminum, magnesium and plastic were used to replace steel.
''But frequently the cost-benefit ratio is difficult to satisfy,'' with gasoline relatively cheap, he said. The average car uses 500 gallons a year, so a 10 percent savings at the current gasoline price would come to about $60 a year. Over the life of the car, saving that amount would justify hundreds of dollars in extra expense.
 
Reaction in the Showroom
But ''it doesn't necessarily make sense to the guy in the showroom, at a dollar a gallon and there's no threat of oil shortages on the horizon,'' Mr. Allen said. ''The reaction is going to be, 'My God, the price went up several hundred dollars.' ''
Indeed, gasoline is still so inexpensive that fuel economy is not a major goal for most drivers or car companies. ''If you tell me that gasoline will be at $2 a gallon in three years, I would say we'd all be searching for ways for better fuel efficiency, and spending money to find tenths of a mile per gallon,'' Mr. Slechter said. ''But that kind of mentality doesn't exist right now.''
In the months before the Iraqi invasion two weeks ago, ''gasoline was at the lowest price in recorded history,'' said James D. Johnston, the chief lobbyist in Washington for the General Motors Corporation, referring to the inflation-adjusted cost of gasoline needed to travel a mile. ''That's not a lot of incentive to conserve.''
With average fuel economy up by about 50 percent since the first oil shock in 1973, the cost of the gasoline needed to drive a mile is the lowest in at least 40 years, experts say.
 
Better Acceleration
The recent increase in gasoline prices is not expected to make much difference, unless it rekindles fear in consumers about future increases.
With gasoline so inexpensive, buyers have turned their attention to other characteristics, like better acceleration, and the car companies have responded.
The Environmental Protection Agency found that 1983 midsized models took about 14.5 seconds to go from zero to 60 miles an hour; the 1990's models take under 12 seconds. Some of the better performance comes from better engineering, but the auto makers have also added power by building bigger engines, which burn more fuel.
Another factor is the changing mix of vehicles. Small pickups and small vans, which represented only a tiny fragment of sales in 1978, now have nearly 20 percent of the market, the agency said. As a group, they are far less efficient than the passenger cars that many of them replace.
 
Declining Fuel Efficiency
Not surprisingly, then, Government figures show the 1990 model-year cars with an average efficiency of 27.8 miles per gallon, compared with 28.6 in 1988. (The calculations take into account how many of each model are sold.) The actual decline in mileage is probably even larger than the figures suggest, experts say, because of traffic congestion. The agency's ''combined'' figure assumes 55 percent of the miles are on the highway and 45 percent are in the city, but as roads get more crowded, experts say, the formula probably overstates the amount of driving done in highway conditions.
But if fuel efficiency in automobiles is still a low priority for most drivers, it remains a top priority for those concerned about energy conservation at times of uncertain supplies. The American vehicle fleet, a 32 billion-horsepower herd, is by far the biggest user of oil in this country, consuming about 7.2 million barrels a day - coincidentally, about the amount that the United States imports.
 
Environmentalists' Concern
The decline in average mileage also worries environmentalists. ''If this backslide continues, problems with nationwide fuel consumption will increase and global warming trends will worsen at a pace faster than is generally being assumed,'' according to an E.P.A. report in January. Carbon dioxide and other gases in car exhaust are thought to trap heat in the earth's atmosphere, contributing to climate change; the more fuel consumed, the worse the problem.
After the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo, the Government sought to mandate that by 1985 each manufacturer's product line would have an average performance of 27.5 miles per gallon. General Motors and the Ford Motor Company did not meet the standard, and they successfully petitioned the Department of Transportation to delay implementation of the standard. Chrysler met the standard by making heavy investments in plants to build smaller cars, but today the company does not count its compliance as shrewd.
''The market demand continued to go more and more toward luxury, power and what have you,'' said Mr. Slechter of Chrysler. Now, the three American manufacturers' fuel efficiency is nearly equal.
 
Less-Efficient Imports
Even the efficiency of Asian cars sold in this country is declining, from about 35 miles per gallon in 1988 to about 31 miles per gallon now, as consumer tastes move toward more powerful models. European imports show an even steeper decline, beginning in 1982.
Many energy experts would like to have the Government respond by setting higher energy efficiency standards for cars, as it has for such consumer equipment as refrigerators.
The auto companies vigorously dissent. At Ford, David L. Kulp, the manager of fuel economy planning and compliance, called for ''a cohesive policy,'' including giving consumers information on the importance of fuel efficiency and helping municipalities take steps to reduce congestion.
But Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, has proposed legislation raising average fuel economy 20 percent by 1995. By 2001, the average for new cars would have to be 40 miles per gallon. The bill would also set a statutory standard for light trucks for the first time.
 
Gradual Savings
The measure was approved by the Senate Commerce Committee earlier this year by a vote of 14-4, and is on the Senate calendar.
Even without mileage improvements, Americans could save oil merely by buying the most efficient model in its class. The Environmental Protection Agency reports that if every buyer of a 1990-model car of a given size - say, compact, or midsized - had instead bought the most fuel-efficient model of that class, average fuel efficiency would have been 32.5 miles per gallon, instead of the 27.5 miles per gallon actually achieved.

HEADLINE: Watch Urged On U.S. Loan Agencies

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Federal auditors said today that the Government should sharply increase the regulation and supervision of Government-sponsored enterprises that lend money to home buyers and college students or else taxpayers might have to foot the bill in the future.
In a report to Congress, the General Accounting Office said the ''ambiguous status'' of such lenders - ''neither fully private nor clearly public'' - exposed the Government to potentially large financial risks, as in the savings and loan industry.
The report said the Department of Housing and Urban Development had been passive in monitoring two such lenders, the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac.
In addition, it said, the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, ''has no Federal regulator to oversee the safety and soundness of its financial activities.'' 
The G.A.O., a Congressional investigative agency, said the Government should treat such hybrid entities more like commercial banks and insist that they increase their capital with the risks they take.
Leland C. Brendsel, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, responded that the report ''understates both the financial strength of Freddie Mac and the importance'' of its mission to provide credit for home buyers. ''We have a 20-year unbroken string of profits,'' he said, and Freddie Mac will not become a liability to the Government unless there is ''a nationwide economic catastrophe worse than the Great Depression.''
 
Other Agencies Respond
Similarly, David O. Maxwell, Fannie Mae's chairman, said his Congressionally chartered corporation had ''never cost taxpayers a penny.'' In fact, he said, ''over the last three years, we paid some $908 million in Federal income taxes.''
Mr. Maxwell added that he welcomed ''close scrutiny,'' but he denied that the special status of a Government-sponsored enterprise created ''incentives for management to take excessive risks.''
Edward A. Fox, the president of the Student Loan Marketing Association, said the report unfairly reinforced the ''perception among investors that the Federal Government will act as a credit backstop for all Government-sponsored enterprises.'' He said he saw no need to impose ''an outside regulator to monitor and evaluate the adequacy of Sallie Mae's capital.''
The General Accounting Office acknowledged that ''Sallie Mae's credit standing is quite high, and that there is no evidence to suggest that Sallie Mae represents an imminent risk of failure to the Government.'' But the agency said Federal supervision was needed because the Government would probably step in to provide assistance if Sallie Mae experienced financial trouble.
In general, the G.A.O. said, Government-sponsored enterprises enjoy certain privileges and benefits not available to an ordinary business. For example, it said, some can borrow money from the Treasury, and several are exempt from state and local income taxes.
Thus, the report said, ''the Government could face losses if an enterprise failed,'' so it is prudent for the Government to supervise their operations more closely.
 
No Discipline From Investors
The report said investors in the private market did not adequately discipline such lenders but assumed the Government would aid the institutions in times of financial difficulty, preventing default and protecting investors, even though the Government was not legally required to do so.
The study was required by the 1989 law that rescued hundreds of insolvent savings associations. The G.A.O. examined eight Government-sponsored enterprises with debts and other financial obligations totaling $800 billion. The obligations include bonds and other securities through which investors' money is ultimately made available for loans to home buyers, college students and farmers.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development ''has never used its authority to audit Fannie Mae,'' even though it has had the authority to do so since 1968, the G.A.O. said. ''Taxpayers deserve greater protection,'' the report said.
The Treasury Department ''has audit authority over Sallie Mae, but like H.U.D. has not exercised this authority,'' the report said.
 
'Inherent Conflicts'
The General Accounting Office did not assert that any particular Government-sponsored enterprise had inadequate capital. Rather, the auditors said they were dissatisfied because the Government had not established, through statute or regulation, minimal standards for the capital that such institutions must have to operate safely.
The agency also said the Housing Department was not in a good position to supervise Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac. ''Inherent conflicts could exist between the department's short-term housing policy goals and its goals as a financial regulator,'' it said.
The recent history of the savings industry ''illustrated the disastrous effects of having regulators responsible for both promoting an industry and overseeing it,'' the report said.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Loral's Fast Move Wins a Ford Unit

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
WHEN the Loral Corporation beat out giant competitors like Westinghouse Electric and Hughes Aircraft last month in bidding for the aerospace unit of Ford Motor, the victory had the air of David triumphing over Goliath.
But it now appears that Loral had something more than just a slingshot in its back pocket: about $85 million to $150 million from the aerospace division's overfunded pension fund. Loral agreed to let Ford keep a portion of the overfunded pension fund. At the same time the other two bidders said they thought the money was untouchable. 
So while Loral and Ford Aerospace announced that the deal was worth $715 million - less than another bid Ford received of $730 million - it is actually worth $800 million to $865 million.
The use of the pension fund, which was not publicly disclosed when the deal was signed, has prompted an inquiry by the Pentagon and left some on Wall Street wondering whether Loral and its equity partner, Shearson Lehman Brothers, outmaneuvered their competitors or overstepped the bounds of propriety.
Dipping into pension funds for a corporate buyout has generated storms of criticism in Washington in the last decade, but restrictions were few in coming. Now in the case of Ford Aerospace the issue takes on new dimensions.
The division depends in large part on Government contracts, meaning that the Pentagon pays for everything from the cost of materials to pensions for employees who work on the contracted business. So in the weapons industry, the cash in an overfunded pension fund, which companies might claim as their own, could be claimed by the Government.
Although the Ford Aerospace pension fund has assets of $300 to $400 million in excess of liabilities, the Government could say that the money was not Ford's to keep, said people who have examined internal company documents.
''A portion of that pension belongs to the Government,'' a senior Pentagon official said yesterday. The official said that the Pentagon had heard allegations about the use of excess pension assets in the Ford Aerospace deal and that it planned to examine the situation. ''We intend to do a complete and detailed review,'' the Pentagon official said.
Bankers involved in the deal said that they expected the Government to examine the deal closely and that there was nothing improper in it. ''No one is going to slide one by,'' one banker said.
Ford and Loral confirmed that the automobile company was keeping part of the pension fund, but stressed that more than enough money was being moved to Loral to cover the fund's liabilities.
''It seems to me the issue is not the amount of the surplus, but that more than sufficent funds are being transferred,'' said Tom Rhoades, a Ford spokesman.
Bernard L. Schwartz, the chairman and chief executive of Loral, indicated yesterday that the money from the pension fund being kept by Ford was not related to any of its Government contracts. ''Nobody has ever established that the Government has a claim on activities not involving the Defense Department,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''We made sure that funds that were transferred in the pension was more than enough to take care of the requirements of the individual Ford employees.''
One adviser to a losing bidder said the pension money would come out of the division's satellite business, which has a large proportion of commercial and foreign contracts. ''I thought it was very clever on Loral's part,'' he said. ''Make no mistake about it, they found some real money.''
Excess money from the pension fund, unrelated to Government contracts would presumably belong to Ford. Essentially, some of the losers say, they may well have been outthought by the smaller competitor.
But those answers do not assuage some losers in the bidding contest, some of whom contend that they were told not to touch the overfunded pension fund.
An investment banker who represented a losing bidder also said that the information he had been given about Ford's position on the pension fund was different than the results.
But executives involved in running the deal said all bidders were provided with the same financial details. ''We do know that everybody got same information, the same instructions, and were told that each bid would be evaluated in terms of which bid would provide the greatest net economic value to Ford,'' one executive involved in the deal said.
Regardless of the outcome of the debate, some employees with Ford Aerospace say that they are getting more comfortable with the Loral victory. ''I think they were very smart to make the deal and beat out the other two groups,'' one middle manager said. ''What I have heard is that Loral's history with pension plans has been a very good one. That means more to me than anything else.''

HEADLINE: Industry's Output Flat Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Automotive output dropped sharply in July, leaving overall industrial production unchanged from June, the Federal Reserve reported today. It noted that the economy continued its slow growth in most other areas of manufacturing.
The Federal Reserve said that ''excluding motor vehicles, industrial output rose two-tenths of a percent last month, about the same rate of growth that has been evident so far this year.'' 
Weakness in auto sales has been a major factor behind the economy's sluggishness this year, but Michael P. Niemira, an economist with the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, said he expected a strong increase in vehicle production this month.
 
'Intentional Car Buildup'
''We're going through an intentional car buildup in the third quarter,'' Mr. Niemira said, pointing to a backlog of just 55 days' supply compared with the normal supply of 60 to 65 days.
Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, said he thought the auto industry was positioning itself for a possible strike when the Big Three labor contracts expire this fall.
Today's report also said there was a drop in the production of stone, clay and glass products that was a sign of weakness in construction.
Overall industrial production has fallen twice so far this year: 1 percent in January and one-tenth of a percent in April. But the rates of growth in the other months have been less than 1 percent. In June the gain was four-tenths of a percent.
Output in manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods inched down one-tenth of a percent in July, after a gain of three-tenths of a percent in June. The June figure was a revision from a rise of five-tenths of a percent first reported.
Output of durable goods, which are vehicles and other relatively expensive items expected to last at least three years, fell four-tenths of a percent and offset a gain of four-tenths of a percent in June.
Manufacturing of nondurable goods like food and clothing was up three-tenths of a percent, after an increase of two-tenths of a percent a month earlier.
 
Mines and Utilities
Output at mines jumped 1 percent, after a flat June, while utility production was off four-tenths of a percent, after a 1.9 percent gain in June.
The Fed said its industrial production index in July stood at 109.9 percent of its 1987 base.
The Fed also said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities - which usually move in tandem with industrial production -slipped two-tenths of a percentage point, to 83.4 percent. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels.
The operating rate at factories producing durable goods fell five-tenths of a percentage point, to 81.6 percent, while the rate at plants making nondurable goods was unchanged, at 83.9 percent.
The operating rate at mines was up 1.1 percentage points, to 90.2 percent, while it slipped to 85.7 percent, from 86.2, at utilities.

HEADLINE: Market Flat, With Dow Up By Only 0.50

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market ended flat for the second consecutive session, but only after fighting off earlier weaknesses in very choppy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the trading session up 0.50, to 2,748.27.
The backdrop for most of yesterday's trading included a rally on the Tokyo stock market, where the Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 1,439.59 points, or 5.4 percent, to 28,112.12. It was the Nikkei's third-highest one-day gain. 
But in trading in Tokyo today, the Nikkei retreated, falling 562.68 points, or 2 percent, to close at 27,549.44.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, volume totaled 135.2 million shares, with gainers outpacing losers by almost 3 to 2.
The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks was up 1.12 points, to 411.45, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index, 0.67, to 340.06. The American Stock Exchange index rose 70 basis points, to 340.64.
 
Drop in Bonds and Dollar
Prices moved broadly higher in early trading yesterday amid signs that the crisis in the Middle East might be easing, and that moved the Dow up more than 15 points. Later, news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had opposed holding an early meeting and raising agreed production quotas pushed the stock market down through noon as oil futures rose, bonds fell and the dollar fell.
As optimism of a solution to the Middle East crisis began to fade, stock prices fell early in the session but investors remained hopeful that today's meeting between President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan will produce something positive.
''In all it was a dull day,'' said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/ Twenty-First Advisers Inc. ''A day filled with a lot of offsets: The dollar ended higher, which bodes well for United States exports in the future. Crude oil prices rose, but oil stocks fell because of profit taking.''
Economic reports on industrial production for July, which was unchanged after two consecutive monthly advances; capacity utilization for July, down slightly, and inventory and sales for June, had little effect on yesterday's market.
Mr. Stovall did note that in the inventory liquidation figures for June there was an inference that excess inventories may have already worked themselves out and that would help make any recession a short-lived one.
Merck rose 7/8, to 87 7/8; Procter & Gamble was up 3/4, to 83 1/2, and Johnson & Johnson advanced by 1 1/8, to 68 3/8. Also traders said that there was heavy buying of the Johnson & Johnson stock because of early positive results from an AIDS treatment using photopheresis equipment.
Among the big gainers were Novo-Nordisk A/S, a Danish biotechnology group that makes synthetic insulin, up 3 1/8, to close at 54 5/8 on a report of strong earnings; CBS, up 3 5/8, to 181 5/8, and Medtronic, a maker of cardiac pacemakers, up 3 1/4, to 82 1/8.
Ambase, an insurance holding company whose disappointing second-quarter earnings results may have weakened its bargaining postion with bidders interested in its Home Insurance Company unit, fell as its banks demanded an early agreement. The stock dropped 4 3/4 to close at 2 3/4 on 1.9 million shares traded, the second-highest volume on the Big Board.
Wal-Mart Stores was the most active stock, with 2.03 million shares traded. Wal-Mart slipped 1/4, to 30 1/4, even though David Poneman, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said Wal-Mart and Target Stores had increased their shares of the apparel and furniture markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, at Low Against Mark In Europe, Recovers in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the German mark in domestic trading after sinking to an all-time low against the mark in Europe.
Against other major currencies, the dollar finished mixed in domestic trading after falling broadly overseas.
Gold prices turned lower after rising in recent sessions because of worries about war and inflation resulting from tensions in the Persian Gulf. 
The dollar sank to a record closing low of 1.5605 marks in Europe, down from 1.5685 marks late Tuesday and below its previous trading low of 1.5615 marks on Jan. 4, 1988.
Dealers said the dollar drifted even lower as trading began in New York with the currency dropping to about 1.5540 marks early in the session.
Despite the recovery against the mark, John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank, said he did not think the sentiment toward the dollar had changed. ''It was just oversold against almost all currencies, and many participants were short dollars,'' he said.
Many analysts say weakness in the American economy will eventually force the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates to avoid a recession at a time when Germany, Japan and other nations will be increasing their rates to curb inflation. The net effect will be to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors, currency analysts say.
In New York, the dollar fell to 147.65 Japanese yen, from 148.85 yen late Tuesday. Earlier, it fell to 147.15 yen in Tokyo, from 149.90 yen at Tuesday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted at 147.15 yen.
The dollar also fell worldwide against the British pound. The pound rose to $1.9000 in New York, from $1.8970 late Tuesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.9045, from $1.8930 late Tuesday. The dollar also gained against the Swiss franc, French franc and Italian lira in New York while falling against the yen, British pound and Canadian dollar.
Dollar rates as of late yesterday in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.30735 Swiss francs, up from 1.3042; 5.2570 French francs, up from 5.2555; 1,149.75 Italian lire, up from 1,149.25, and 1.14345 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14425.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.3005 Swiss francs, down from 1.3055; 5.2365 French francs, down from 5.2695; 1.7579 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7675; 1,145.75 Italian lire, down from 1,152.50, and 1.1435 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1452.
Gold for current delivery fell $2.20, to $402.60 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank quoted gold at $402.40 late yesterday, down $1.60 from Tuesday's late bid.
Earlier, gold fell to $401.25 an ounce in London, from $410.25 late Tuesday, and to $398.75 in Zurich, from $412 late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $9.50, to $401.50 an ounce.
On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery fell 12.3 cents an ounce, to $5.068.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Y.&R. Buys An Agency In Prague

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
YOUNG & RUBICAM said yesterday that it had bought an agency in Prague, making it the latest American agency to further expand its presence in Eastern Europe.
The new agency, Young & Rubicam Czechoslovakia, is a venture between Y.&R. and AB Line Studios, a small private agency in Prague. Y.&R. will own most of the new agency, and its managing director will be Jiri Kratena, the founder of AB Line Studios. No terms were disclosed.
''We've been studying the business opportunities in Eastern Europe for the last two years, and we decided that along with Hungary, Czechoslovakia offers the best possiblities for growth,'' said Joseph DeDeo, the president and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Advertising. Y.&R., which has worldwide billings of more than $6 billion, set up an office last year in Budapest. 
Because of the political and economic changes in Eastern Europe, large agencies have been scrambling to establish beachheads in the region. Although it is not creating any advertising as yet, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide opened an office last month in Prague to analyze business opportunities in that country. Saatchi also has agencies in Hungary and Poland and plans to open one in Yugoslavia in the fall.
In addition, Ogilvy & Mather recently announced the appointment of a new executive to spearhead the agency's move into the area. Wolfgang Slupetsky, the head of Ogilvy's Austrian office, will oversee the agency's fledgling offices in East Germany, Budapest and Moscow, as well as its expansion into Poland, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia.
For agencies, the move eastward is motivated by their clients' desire to sell their products in Eastern Europe's growing free-market economies. ''Some of our biggest clients like Colgate, Kodak and Xerox are making serious plans to move into these markets,'' Mr. DeDeo said. ''We want to be there to help.''
Some analysts said agencies had often been forced by clients to open offices in other countries, even though the operations might not prove profitable for a number of years.
''International agencies open branches in places like East Europe because they simply cannot afford to say no to their big clients,'' said Alan Gottesman of Paine Webber Inc.
Mr. Gottesman said American agencies doing business in Eastern Europe were also hampered because they could not rely on picking up many local accounts to help make their offices going concerns.
Agencies and their clients are primarily banking on the future success of economic revolution in Eastern Europe. ''These won't be big markets for us for a long time,'' said Robert James, the chairman and president of McCann-Erickson, which has offices in Hungary and Yugoslavia. ''But that is the way it's always been in building an international business.''
Nonetheless, some of operations are already showing modest signs of success. Mr. DeDeo said that after just a year, its Budapest office had shown a profit, largely because of the success of Adidas athletic footwear, one of its main clients.
McCann's Hungarian branch is also turning a profit. McCann's clients there include Coca-Cola, Del Monte and Nestle. McCann intends to open branches in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and possibly Poland.
But setting up shop is not easy. Since the primary agencies in Eastern European countries are owned by the state, agency's like McCann have had to forge relationships with other media companies. In Yugosalvia, for example, McCann created its agency there by forming a venture with a Zagreb television production company.
''There are few private agencies to pick from, so we find a media-related company that we think will work the best in setting up an agency,'' Mr. James said.
Y.&R. was lucky to find an experienced private ad agency to be its partner in Czechoslovakia. Mr. Kratena, who founded AB Line Studios two years ago, was one of the first to create consumer-oriented advertising in Czechoslovakia, Mr. DeDeo said. Mr. Kratena's agency has created consumer ads for Kotva, a department store in Prague. The agency's other primary clients are Radio Vox, a private radio station and Motokov, a trading company dealing in consumer and industrial goods.
Before opening his agency, Mr. Kratena was a film director who made documentaries for Czechoslovak television.
In a telephone interview from Prague yesterday, Mr. Kratena said he had to teach himself how to create ''Western style'' advertising.
''There was no where in my country to learn how to make advertising aimed at consumers,'' he said. ''I taught myself by watching commercials when I visited Western countries.''

HEADLINE: Plan to Freeze Manila Debt

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANILA, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The Philippine Senate approved a resolution today asking President Corazon C. Aquino to negotiate a 30-month moratorium on payments on the country's $26 billion foreign debt.
The Senate resolution, which passed on its second reading, still requires a third vote. It then must be reconciled with a similar resolution, passed by the House of Representatives last month, before being sent to Mrs. Aquino.
Legislators want to divert the money to help pay for rebuilding areas of the country damaged by the earthquake last month that killed 1,650 people.
Senators estimate the country will be able to save $3.5 billion a year if a moratorium can be negotiated.
Lawmakers said a debt freeze, opposed by foreign bankers, has become a more attractive option because of a possible economic slowdown after the Persian Gulf crisis.
The Finance Secretary, Jesus Estanislao, and the governor of the central bank, Jose Cuisia, who just returned from the United States and Japan, said the country's main donors and creditors were willing to provide the debt relief and money needed to rebuild the Philippines.
Mrs. Aquino has ruled out any confrontational approach to the country's foreign debt problem, saying it would alienate the nation from the international financial community.
