HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: JORDAN VAGUE ON EMBARGO; TEHERAN TO BACK SANCTIONS; NEW THREAT MADE IN KUWAIT;
FOREIGNERS WARNED

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON Aug. 16

 BODY:
The Iraqi occupation authorities today ordered 6,500 American and British citizens trapped in Kuwait to assemble at two hotels in the Kuwaiti capital and threatened to remove the foreign residents forcibly from their homes if they refused.
The State Department said American and British diplomats in Kuwait, who received the order from the Iraqi authorities, reported that they had been given two hours to obey the instructions. Administration officials said they feared the order was a prelude to confinement of Americans citizens in Kuwait or Iraq.
Fifteen hours after the Iraqi deadline, however, ''very few'' Americans had obeyed the order, said Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman. ''Most of the Americans are not interested,'' he added. 
Up to that point, there had apparently been no Iraqi action to enforce the order, which described the Americans and Britons as ''restrictees.''
 
No Advice From Embassy
The American Embassy informed American citizens of the Iraqi order, but officials offered no advice whether or not to comply. While the State Department told the Iraqi authorities and reporters that they thought the Americans would be better off remaining at home, its representatives in Kuwait left the decision whether to move to a hotel up to the American residents and visitors in Kuwait.
''We're not instructing them one way or the other,'' Mr. Boucher said. ''We don't know what if any actions the Iraqi authorities might be thinking of taking.''
Asked if the United States was abdicating responsibility by avoiding explicit direction to the Americans, Mr. Boucher said, ''We don't have the authority to order Americans to do things.'' He added that Americans were being informed that the United States was demanding that the order be rescinded.
American officials continued to refuse to characterize their citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait as ''hostages,'' saying use of the word might incite President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and make efforts to free them more difficult. But they privately acknowledged that it appeared that the Iraqis intended to use the captives either as bargaining chips or as shields against whatever military operations may come.
A senior State Department official said the Iraqi order ''obviously increases our concern for the well-being of foreign nationals.''
The British Foreign Office Minister, William Waldegrave, called the Iraqi order ''grave and sinister.''
Mr. Boucher told reporters at the State Department that the action ''was totally uncalled for.''
He added, ''We have instructed our charge in Baghdad to contact the Foreign Ministry immediately to protest the action, to demand an explanation, to stress that force must not be used against Americans, and to remind the Iraqi Government of its responsibility to safeguard American lives and property.''
Later, the Iraqi Foreign Ministry said it knew nothing about the military order in Kuwait.
 
Other Foreigners Unrestricted
It appeared that the Iraqis had singled out the estimated 2,500 Americans and 4,000 British out of more than a million foreigners they have refused to let leave Iraq or occupied Kuwait. Other foreigners may still move around Kuwait freely. A group of 117 foreigners, including 38 Americans, have been held under armed guard by Iraqi forces in Baghdad for almost two weeks.
In daily conversations with American officials in Washington and Baghdad since the invasion of Kuwait two weeks ago, Iraqi officials have given American officials varied and contradictory explanations of why they will not let foreigners out of territory they control. In recent days, they have said they will not release the foreigners until the United States stops threatening their country.
Mr. Boucher said top Iraqi military commanders summoned Nathaniel Howell, the United States Ambassador to Kuwait. Mr. Howell was instructed to tell all Americans that they had to move to the International Hotel, situated across the street from the American Embassy, in two hours. ''They explained that the order was the result of concerns about the protection of the American community from unspecified threats,'' Mr. Boucher said.
A State Department official who insisted on anonymity said ''the Iraqis did imply they would go out and find the people'' if the American Embassy did not gather them together at the hotel.
 
Called Safer at Home
Mr. Howell responded to the Iraqi order by saying it was impossible for his embassy to contact every American in Kuwait in so little time, and even then, it could not order its citizens to leave their homes. He added that he thought American citizens would be safer in their homes anyway.
But the American Embassy called as many American citizens as it could to inform them of the Iraqi order, but without recommending what they should do.
The Iraqi order produced a strong response from members of Congress. ''The Iraqi directive is clearly a hostile act,'' said Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester. ''I think it is important for President Bush right now to send a message that if Saddam Hussein intends to make the Americans hostages, he must know we will respond accordingly.''
Mr. Waldegrave, the British official, said he feared that the Westerners rounded up in Kuwait would be ''interned somewhere - most likely in Iraq.'' He said his Government intended to raise the matter in the United Nations.
 
8,000 Escape to Jordan
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 16 (Special to The New York Times) - Jordanian border officials reported today that at least 8,000 foreigners streamed across the border with Iraq during the 24 hours ending this afternoon.
Three naturalized Americans, originally from India, were among those who made their way into Jordan along with three naturalized Britons who had been born in Tanzania and a French woman born in Madagascar.
The Americans were the first to make their way out of Baghdad since Saturday, when 10 people attached to the United States Embassy and a 10-year-old California girl crossed into Jordan.
The three latest American arrivals passed through the border checkpoint unnoticed by a group of foreign journalists. Then, after driving an additional 220 miles, they checked in at the American Embassy here.
Reuters news agency reported that the Soviet Union was planning to run a convoy of cars and trucks with 230 Soviet citizens from Baghdad and Kuwait in the next day or two.
The Soviets estimate that 7,830 of their citizens were in Iraq and 880 were in Kuwait when the Iraqi invasion began there Aug. 2.

PUB-DATE: August 17, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1644 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: JORDAN VAGUE ON EMBARGO; TEHERAN TO BACK SANCTIONS; NEW THREAT MADE IN KUWAIT;
PEACE HOPE FADING

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE, Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan failed today to make significant progress toward easing the Middle East crisis, and Mr. Bush was apparently unable to win ironclad assurances from the King that he would halt shipments to Baghdad through the Jordanian port of Aqaba.
''I did not come away from that conversation with a feeling of hope'' that President Saddam Hussein would withdraw from Kuwait, Mr. Bush said as a mood of heightened hostility settled over the impasse, now two weeks old.
 
The View From Iran
After a two-hour meeting at the President's home in Kennebunkport, Me., Mr. Bush said he had won the Jordanian leader's promise to enforce United Nations sanctions against Iraq, but he acknowledged that he was still worried about potential cheaters. For his part, King Hussein told reporters that he intended to honor the trade embargo but was still seeking clarification as to its exact terms.
Although that seemed to leave room for cargoes to move up the desert road from Aqaba to Baghdad, there were indications that Iran, to which Iraq made peace overtures on Wednesday, might not be willing to ship food and other goods to Iraq, as American officials had feared. 
President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran was quoted by the official Iranian press agency as saying that Iraq must ''evacuate Kuwaiti territory.'' A person with close ties to the Iranian Parliament told Reuters that Teheran would under no circumstances violate sanctions.
 
Two Tugs-of-War
In effect, two tugs-of-war were under way. The American point of view seemed to be prevailing in Iran, with the Iraqi position more persuasive in Amman.
President Hussein, Iraq's leader, denounced President Bush in a broadcast today as a ''liar,'' the same word Mr. Bush used about him on Wednesday, and said thousands of Americans would go home ''shrouded in sad coffins'' if war came. That, together with King Hussein's revelation that he had brought no message after all from President Hussein to the United States, doused the already slight hopes of an early diplomatic solution to the crisis.
Tonight, instructions formally putting into effect the American-led naval blockade that Mr. Bush ordered last Sunday were issued by the Pentagon to United States warships in the Red Sea, the Persian Gulf, the Mediterranean Sea and the Arabian Sea. They were said to authorize the use of the minimum force, like shots across the bow, to block Iraqi commerce. The Navy's interception zone includes the approaches to Aqaba. Intelligence officials here said they were concerned that the Iraqi leader, cornered, was ''starting to flail around'' in a way that could produce some rash military action. But President Bush responded with markedly mild words, both to President Hussein's accusations and to news that Baghdad had ordered 2,500 Americans in Kuwait to gather in a hotel there, threatening that laggards would be forcibly rounded up.
The United States and Iraq moved more troops toward the heavily armed frontier between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Above them, Saudi and American pilots, flying joint combat patrols, played a cat-and-mouse game in which American fliers several times ''locked on'' to Iraqi planes with their fire-control radars, only to have the Iraqis turn and head for home.
Pentagon officials disclosed that more than 45,000 marines were joining an American ground force in Saudi Arabia that is expected to reach 100,000 in the next few weeks, and the Pentagon estimated that 160,000 Iraqi troops were massed opposite the Americans, in and around Kuwait.
Another sign of the growing intensity of the crisis came in Geneva, where a senior American arms negotiator, Stephen Ledogar, said the United States reserved the right to retaliate in kind if President Hussein used nerve or mustard gas, as he has suggested.
Although the Iraqis are believed to have installed Soviet surface-to-air missiles around the Kuwait airport, fears that a large-scale new hostage crisis might be at hand prompted one member of Congress, Representative Lawrence J. Smith, Democrat of Florida, to urge the President to dispatch military planes to pick up all Americans. Mr. Bush should tell the Iraqis, he said, that if there was trouble, ''the President of the United States will consider it an act of war.''
 
Jordanian Is Grim
The situation with regard to the port of Aqaba, through which goods bound for Baghdad have been flowing unimpeded despite the sanctions, remained clouded after the talks between Mr. Bush and King Hussein.
Looking grave, the King told reporters that his country had decided to observe the sanctions when they were adopted by the Security Council on Aug. 6. He said there had been no change in his Government's position as a result of his trip to the United States and declared that ''there are no shipments at the moment'' through Aqaba to Iraq.
But he added a comment echoing those of the Jordanian Foreign Ministry in recent days, to the effect that Jordan, as a country whose economy could be shattered by sanctions, had a right to appeal to the United Nations for special asssistance under Article 50 of the Charter. And he said that Jordan could not afford to entirely close Aqaba, which he plaintively called ''our only outlet to the sea and the rest of the world.''
Asked by Mr. Bush to explain what the King meant, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d made a seemingly different point, suggesting that the Jordanian leader had been talking about a provision that permits shipments of food and medicine for humanitarian reasons.
 
'Send a Message'
Asked whether he was satisfied that goods would no longer go through Jordan to Iraq, Mr. Bush replied: ''I'm not satisfied to total satisfaction on any point regarding the sanctions. We've got to guard against cheaters. But what I am is encouraged that Jordan, prior to the King's coming here, took this position, and I think that is encouraging, and I think it might send a message to some who need a little leadership in that regard.''
Mr. Bush has threatened to block the port to Iraqi ships, but he has also offered to help offset the cost of sanctions to Jordan, which sends nearly half of its exports to Iraq and buys 90 percent of its oil from its bigger neighbor.
The President said no shipments of oil appeared to be coming out of Iraq, ''and that is very positive because 90 percent of their foreign exchange is based upon petroleum.''
King Hussein called the President ''an old friend of mine,'' but Mr. Bush signaled that deep disagreements remained between the two, chiefly over the use of American troops in Saudi Arabia, when he failed to escort the King to his helicopter on departure. Asked if he had any reason for hope, King Hussein, under great economic and political pressure to side with Iraq, answered: ''I suppose one has to have hope. Without hope you can't get anywhere.''
 
Few Will Risk Attack
Lloyd's List International, a shipping publication, reported that traffic was thinning in any event at Aqaba and that Iraq's fleet of 80 tankers and cargo ships appeared to have stopped trading entirely. Peter Tudball, vice chairman of the Baltic Exchange, an international organization that coordinates freight and ship movements, said that ''there certainly wouldn't be anyone, at the moment, willing to take any cargo into Aqaba'' because of the threatened naval quarantine of the port.
''All shipowners will be wary,'' Mr. Tudball said. ''They don't want an Exocet missile going through their ships. That limits their trading possibilities in the future.''
About 150 trucks, many of them bound for Iraq, roared up the highway from Aqaba today, but shipping agents said most were carrying goods unloaded before the sanctions were voted. Only one ship, the Norwegian-owned Tanga, was discharging cargo for Iraq.
Iran's President, Mr. Rafsanjani, made his comments about Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait in a telephone conversation with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, an important figure in making the economic sanctions work.
The Iranian press agency quoted Mr. Rafsanjani as saying that peace with Iraq and support for Iraq's annexation of Kuwait were wholly different matters. Some Middle East specialists had speculated that a new alliance between Teheran and Baghdad was in the works that would give the Iraqis a way around the trade embargo.
Mr. Bush also talked by telephone with Mr. Ozal today and said he was ''somewhat optimistic'' that the sanctions were going to stick.
 
Coup Report Discounted
Almost lost in the flurry of developments was a report by Egypt's Middle East News Agency that Iraqi officers close to President Hussein unsuccessfully tried to assassinate him on Wednesday. Baghdad denied it, and no hint of it was heard elsewhere.
It was also reported, this time from Tokyo, that Saudi Arabia had announced a 20 percent cut in oil production, just when Iraqi and Kuwaiti production has been at least temporarily taken off the world market. The Riyadh Government denied that, but it said it has asked for an early meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss the new price and supply situation.
Nigeria and other nations objected, apparently hoping to force Western nations to run down their unusually large reserves, which would give the OPEC producers more leverage.
On the eve of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's trip to Saudi Arabia to visit American troops there, the Pentagon announced the departure of two major troop units - the 3d Armored Cavalry Regiment from Fort Bliss, Tex., and the 4th Marine Amphibious Brigade, which will set sail from Norfolk, Va., in a flotilla of 13 vessels, headed by the assault ships Guam, Nassau and Iwo Jima.
Oil prices resumed their climb as a nervous market contemplated the continuing loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. Business Day, page D1.

HEADLINE: New Mission at Energy Dept.: Bomb Makers Turn to Cleanup

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Less than two years after the Energy Department acknowledged it had caused grave pollution problems at active and inactive nuclear weapons plants in more than 30 states, the department is headed toward becoming the Government's largest environmental agency.
Accelerated by the end of the cold war, new spending by the Department on its own environmental problems is soaring, while the Environmental Protection Agency is receiving only modest budget increases.
Nuclear weapons plants that have sustained the worst environmental damage of any Government installation are now base camps for biologists, chemists, soil scientists, hydrologists, engineers and other technical specialists. Lured by multimillion-dollar contracts, they are beginning a research and cleanup program that could cost $200 billion or more over the next 30 years and is destined to become one of the country's largest and most expensive public works projects.
 
Test of Government's Ability
At the Hanford Reservation nuclear plant in Washington State alone, the environmental thrust could swell employment from the current 13,000 workers to 15,000 in a couple of years. 
The cleanup program at nuclear weapons plants is emerging as a costly test of the Government's ability to confront complex environmental problems. And the rush of attention and spending has top Energy Department officials, Congressional leaders and critics worried.
Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat who is the chairman of a House committee that has spent years investigating the Energy Department, said: ''Is there an anxious feeling in Congress about this cleanup program? You better believe it.
''We know we're turning this over to the same contractors that caused the problem, the same people who watched it happen and did little or nothing to prevent it. They are being rewarded for the past mistakes. But we have no other choice but to let the fox clean up the chicken house.''
 
A Reversal in Priorities
The enormous spending on environmental programs, which began in 1989 under John S. Herrington, the former Energy Secretary, and has grown under Secretary James D. Watkins, represents a nearly complete turnaround for the nuclear weapons industry. For 48 years, production of nuclear materials for atomic bombs was regarded by top officials and line workers alike as the industry's most important job.
Evidence of the new priorities came a year ago, when Mr. Watkins said bonuses to contractors who run the weapons plants would be based more on their environmental performance than on meeting production quotas.
Pushed by the public, by Congress and by its own safety officers, the Energy Department has acknowledged the extent of the problems and is sending technical experts around the country to devise cleanup plans.
In no other nuclear weapons plant in the United States has the transformation from producing materials for atomic weapons to cleaning up radioactive and chemical wastes come more suddenly than at the 560-square-mile Hanford Reservation near Richland in eastern Washington. Hanford began operating in 1943 to manufacture plutonium for the bomb that destroyed Nagasaki two years later, and continued producing atomic weapon material until December 1988, when its last processing plant was closed for safety reasons.
Mr. Watkins vowed a year ago to turn Hanford into what he called ''a world class environmental research laboratory,'' and has lavished hundreds of millions of dollars on the plant this year for a cleanup program that could last 50 years or more and cost $50 billion, according to some estimates.
In Richland and its neighboring cities, Pasco and Kennewick, the prices of homes are increasing, office space is becoming more scarce and a boom-town atmosphere is taking hold as contractors move in to share the cleanup money.
 
Defense Department, Too
The Defense Department, which this year will spend $600 million on cleaning up chemical lagoons, water and other contamination, is also awakening to the extensive pollution at its own bases and production plants around the country. In June, Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, proposed shifting substantial sums from production of equipment to solving environmental problems.
The Energy Department acknowledges that its record on large projects has been poor over the last two decades. More than $15 billion was spent since the mid-1970's on new plants that simply did not work or failed to work as promised, department audits show. Billions more was spent on excess costs due to poor management.
Last month the Energy Department said the cost of cleaning up the weapons industry in the next five years would be 50 percent higher than it estimated just a year ago. The department has sought management assistance from the Army Corps of Engineers.
Mr. Watkins and his top environmental official, Leo P. Duffy, have said the agency has neither the technical experts nor the technology for the project, which is the most complex the nuclear weapons industry has tackled since the 1940's and early 1950's when the atomic bomb was invented and the industry was created.
This fiscal year, the Energy Department will spend $2.3 billion to develop plans and start cleanup programs in the weapons industry, almost a quarter of the $9.65 billion to be spent on nuclear weapons programs. The department's total environmental budget this fiscal year is $3.4 billion, the agency comptroller's office said.
 
May Overtake E.P.A.'s Spending
In the 1991 fiscal year, which begins in October, the Energy Department's budget for environmental programs will grow to $4.3 billion, more than four times what it was in 1985. Most of the money, $2.7 billion, is to be spent on programs at the agency's weapons plants and laboratories in 12 states.
If spending on waste and pollution in the nuclear weapons industry continues to grow at the pace it has for the past two years, the Energy Department may overtake the Environmental Protection Agency as the Government's largest environmental agency in 1992, budget officers in both agencies say.
The budget for the Environmental Protection Agency, which oversees environmental programs for the entire country, is $3.1 billion this year, including $1.3 billion for the program to clean up the worst toxic waste sites. In addition, the E.P.A. administers $2.4 billion for sewer projects and water treatment plants, bringing its total budget this year to $5.5 billion. In the 1991 fiscal year, the E.P.A. budget will grow to $5.8 billion, according to Congressional and agency estimates.
 
Dangers Were Known
In its 45 years of producing materials for weapons, Hanford's nuclear reactors, processing plants, machine shops and other installations produced radioactive wastes that will remain toxic for centuries.
The plants managers knew of the danger, Government documents show, but in the 1940's, 50's and 60's they sought to save money and routinely dumped millions of gallons of radioactive material on the ground or into shallow pits, long trenches and ponds. Contamination on the surface is spreading by 20 acres annually, the most recent analysis shows, and radiation is steadily leaking into groundwater and the Columbia River.
Where the managers took precautions of isolating the most dangerous wastes in tanks, studies have shown that some has leaked. Westinghouse Hanford Company, the Westinghouse subsidiary that has operated the plant for the Energy Department since 1987, has identified 1,100 sites that are contaminated. The Energy Department last year signed an agreement with the State and the E.P.A. that sets a 30-year schedule for cleaning them up.
''We give Hanford credit for helping the nation maintain its strategic deterrent for so many years,'' Mr. Watkins said last month at a news conference in Washington. ''But now is the time to pay the piper and clean up the 40 years of generation of a variety of waste.''
The difficulty and expense of the task are illustrated by several projects under way at Hanford that are costing fortunes. In one, slightly radioactive chemicals are being removed from four concrete pools, each about as large as an Olympic-sized swimming pool. The job, begun in 1985, will not be completed until 1992 and will cost nearly $16 million.
 
Encasing Wastes in Glass
The largest environmental project currently planned for Hanford is a $1.44 billion plant that will turn 28,000 cubic yards of radioactive liquid and sludge into glass, an easier form for permanent storage. Compounding the problem is that some of this waste in tanks at Hanford has broken down chemically and could explode, Energy Department specialists say.
The plant is in its final design stage and could be completed by the end of the decade. A similar plant has been built in South Carolina at the Savannah River Plant but is not operating properly. Robert W. Brown, the deputy project manager at Hanford, promises that ''our plant will work when it's finished.''
As important as the new equipment is, changing the longtime attitudes of Hanford's workers toward environmental matters is even more vital for the project to succeed. Energy Department officials have been urging Hanford's 13,000 workers for months to replace their fervor for fighting the cold war with new zeal for confronting an opponent many have long regarded with contempt.
Clearly, the officials are having some success, if only because that is a cause for which they have shown they are willing to spend money. ''Are we all becoming environmentalists? Not likely,'' said Jerry Holloway, a spokesman for Battelle Pacific Northwest laboratories, a division of Battelle Memorial Institute that is one of Hanford's largest contractors and a center of environmental research here. ''But we can see where the money is going and where the jobs are.''
Only two years ago, as Hanford's military mission ended, economists were predicting a slump in the area's economy. Now some are worried about a housing shortage; employment at the plant is expected to grow to 14,000 next year and could reach 15,000 or more, the highest in decades.
The money being spent on the cleanup has tempted top Energy Department officials who are pursuing environmental contracts. Michael J. Lawrence, the manager of Hanford since 1984, left the Energy Department on July 28 after a 21-year career to become a top executive at Chem-Nuclear Environmental Services, a subsidiary of Waste Management Inc. that was formed in January to compete for Energy and Defense Department environmental contracts at Hanford and other weapons plants.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE LAST MONTH BY A SHARP 0.4%

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
In a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy, the Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected increase that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis.
But a troubling indication of a weakening economy came from the Commerce Department's report that housing construction fell by 2.6 percent in July, the sixth straight month of decline. The report said housing activity last month was at the lowest level since September 1982, during the last recession.
Yesterday's economic statistics caused prices in both the stock and the bond markets to tumble. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.83 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,681.44, and the price of the Treasury's bellwether long bonds fell more than $15 for each $1,000 face amount, sending the yield up to 8.92 percent, the highest level in more than three months. [Pages D1 and D12.] Pressure on the Fed Today's economic statistics could put pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy when its policy makers meet on Tuesday. Some economists say that the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, are caught in a bind between a course intended to dampen inflation, at the expense of pushing the economy into a recession, and one that tries to avoid recession, at the expense of making inflation worse. 
''We are facing an ugly combination of lousy growth and too much inflation,'' said Donald Straszheim, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company. ''And the Fed's anti-inflation policy has been a failure.''
Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said: ''Inflation looks worse and so does the economy. The likelihood that the economy can handle the upcoming energy shock and still have a downward glide and avoid a recession is pretty dim.''
Mr. Greenspan, who was appointed Federal Reserve chairman in 1987, long withstood pressures from the Adminstration to make credit more readily available. He contended that the chances of a recession were low and that fighting inflation should be the Federal Reserve's top priority. Cutting interest rates, he feared, would cause prices to rise even more in an already-inflationary economy. He did move to make credit more available last month but said fighting inflation was still the priority.
Today's data highlight Mr. Greenspan's quandary, and have caused economists to differ on what the Federal Reserve should do. The rise in consumer prices would indicate that the Federal Reserve should not ease credit, but the prolonged drop in housing construction would indicate that it should.
Adding to the problem is the certainty that inflation will rise in the months ahead - some analysts say the rate for August might be double that of July -because of rising energy prices. Still, the July index of producer prices released last week, an indicator of future economic strength, showed a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent, which was seen as a sign of a weakening economy and a declining demand from consumers for goods.
''The pressure will be on the Fed to ease credit next Tuesday,'' said Mr. Straszheim of Merrill Lynch. ''The housing numbers indicate the economy is staggering and would suggest easing credit. But easing would be risky when we've got as much inflation as we have. My guess is that they will just stand pat for a while.''
 
A Forecast of Inaction
Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust Company, said the combination of indicators could freeze the Federal Reserve into inaction, with the rising inflation numbers precluding any efforts to lower interest rates. ''They are in a position where the economy is sluggish, the housing market is crying for relief, and inflation is still unabated,'' he said.
One important consideration for the Federal Reserve, he added, is maintaining the confidence of the bond markets by not giving the appearance that the central bank has abandoned the fight against inflation.
The Federal Reserve tries to influence interest rates by raising or lowering the Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge one another for short-term loans. In July, the Federal Reserve lowered the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point. But Mr. Greenspan said that the action was taken to counter a shift by banks to an overly restrictive lending policy and that the move should not be seen as a softening of his anti-inflation position. Bond prices rose slightly after that, although many bond traders said they felt the Federal Reserve's action was premature.
While many economists say that the effects of anti-inflation efforts take time to show up, others like Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University, say that the economy is already in a recession. He termed the recession mild and said it would ''be one of the mildest recessions as measured by the barometers we use.'' Others were less optimistic.
Some said the economy was now mired in ''stagflation,'' a combination of slow growth and inflation last seen in the late 1970's and followed by a recession in the early 1980's.
 
A Call for Action
''We are teetering close to the edge of zero or negative growth in the economy,'' said Frederick Sturm, an ecnomist with Fuji Securities Inc. ''And if they wait until the economy is into a recession, they may have to ease willy-nilly. The time to take action is now. Perhaps they can say that they haven't abandoned their anti-inflation policy, but may have to take a holiday from it.''
Joel Popkin, an economic consultant and former assistant commissioner in the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said: ''The anti-inflation policy has been in place a year and a half, and it's got to be scrapped. The Fed has got to show it will not tighten credit because of the oil shock, but it can't ease credit willy-nilly either. It's got to convince the markets it's loosening, but only on a temporary basis.''
Prices rose across the board in July, particularly in the service sectors. What was particularly troubling was that core inflation, which excludes food and energy prices, rose by six-tenths of 1 percent, higher than the overall rate. Rising shelter and medical costs led the way, and sharp rises were also noted for tobacco products, resort travel and used cars. Medical costs rose nine-tenths of 1 percent. But energy costs fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Navy Begins Blockade Enforcing Iraq Embargo

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
The United States said today that its naval forces in the Persian Gulf, the Gulf of Oman and the Red Sea had begun their blockade of vessels carrying oil, food and other supplies to and from Iraq and Iraqi-controlled Kuwait.
The naval quarantine took effect at 8 P.M. Eastern standard time, or at 3 A.M. Friday in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials said. President Bush ordered the blockade on Sunday but it did not begin until the Pentagon completed its instructions to the Navy.
Even before the blockade began, most ships in the region had been honoring the international embargo on commerce with Iraq. A formal notice advising commercial shippers of the naval action has now been issued, a Pentagon spokesman said. 
The Pentagon said American commanders were authorized to use only the minimum force needed to halt any shipments of embargoed cargo. The main zones in which ships would be intercepted include the Persian Gulf waters south of Kuwait, the Gulf of Oman and the northern part of the Red Sea, including the Gulf of Aqaba.
 
Word 'Blockade' Still Avoided
The order covers ships sailing to and from Iraq and Kuwait as well as vessels from other ports carrying goods and supplies bound for Iraq and Kuwait. The Administration has described the naval effort as ''interdiction'' rather than using the word blockade.
Vessels headed to or from other destinations, like Jordan, will be stopped only if the Navy has reason to suspect that the ships are carrying cargo destined for Iraq, a Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said. If officers find prohibited cargo, they will have the authority to take the ship into custody, officials said.
Pentagon officials said the Navy's instructions had been prepared earlier but that the White House apparently did not want to issue them until King Hussein of Jordan left for home after a meeting today with Mr. Bush in Kennebunkport, Me. King Hussein has said that a total blockade of the Jordanian port of Aqaba on the Red Sea would be devastating to his country's economy.
Mr. Williams said that while the Pentagon had identified the main zones for intercepting ships, enforcement action in other parts of the region could not be ruled out. He said that no ships carrying goods to and from Iraq were close enough to port to pose an immediate test of the embargo.
If a vessel is to be halted, he said, American naval officers will first signal by radio, loudspeakers, flags, blinking lights and other means. The ship would then be boarded.
 
'Minimum' Force Unclear
If a ship refused to stop, the Navy would then be authorized to use the minimum force needed to halt it. Mr. Williams declined to specify what force could be used, saying that those orders were classified. But naval experts outside of Government have said that such action could include firing warning shots across the bow of a ship, or at its rudder or motor to disable it.
In addition to ships traveling to and from Iraq and Kuwait, the United States is continuing to monitor an Iraqi vessel in the Mediterranean that is loaded with tank engines and other military supplies purchased in Poland. Other ships are also said to be under surveillance.
The beginning of the naval effort was announced as the Pentagon confirmed that American F-15's flying patrols over Saudi Arabia near the Kuwait border locked their weapons radar onto an Iraqi jet Monday night after it entered Saudi air space. Apparently sensing that it was being targeted, the Iraqi plane turned around and flew away, the officials said.
The encounter came to light after a pool of reporters with the American forces in Saudi Arabia quoted several Air Force crew chiefs as saying that American fighter planes had locked their radars onto Iraqi jets. When a plane ''locks on'' a weapons radar, it directs a radar beam at an enemy aircraft so that it can fire an air-to-air missile at it.
The Pentagon initially said it could not confirm that such encounters had taken place, but later acknowledged the incident.
Ground crew chiefs told the pool reporters that Iraqi planes had turned back after American planes locked the weapons radar on the aircraft. Warning systems enable pilots to determine when another plane has locked its weapons radar onto them.
 
'Cat and Mouse'
''There's been a little cat and mouse but when the weapons lock on, they're gone,'' said a crew chief quoted in the pool report.
Col. John McBroom, commander of the First Tactical Fighter Wing, declined to confirm the encounters or to say how close the planes had come.
''All I'll do is remind you our radars can lock on at pretty good range,'' the pool report quoted him as saying.
Pentagon officials also provided new details today about an encounter several days ago between the American Navy and an Iraqi vessel.
Pentagon officials said the Antietam, an American guided missile cruiser, had spotted an Iraqi merchant ship near Shah Allum Shoal in the Persian Gulf that appeared to be maneuvering in an erratic fashion. The Iraqi ship was equipped with large cranes.
 
U.S. Wary of Mines
The United States Navy believes that this part of the gulf could be a likely site for laying mines because the shoal limits ships' maneuvering room.
When the Antietam directed a Navy helicopter to approach the merchant ship, Pentagon officials said, the deck crew of the Iraqi vessel quickly covered up the items on the deck and went below. The Navy later designated the region a mine-warning area, but no mines were found there, officials said.
Defense officials said there had been a report on the discovery of a mine in the Gulf area, but that the mine may have been left over from the Iran-Iraq war. Fighting between the two countries ended when a cease-fire was declared in 1988.
The Pentagon said today that the cost of deploying forces in the Gulf to defend Saudi Arabia is projected at $1.2 billion through the end of September.
The estimate does not include the cost of the potential mobilization of some reserve forces. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told President Bush on Wednesday that it would be necessary to call up some of the reserves, Administration officials have said, and Mr. Bush said today he was considering such a step.
Nor does the Pentagon's estimate include possible additional military construction projects, or the cost to the Defense Department of rising fuel prices.
The Pentagon has refused to state publicly how many troops are now in Saudi Arabia, but one military official estimated ground forces there at about 30,000.
 
Dependence on Reserve Forces
While President Bush has not yet said whether he will call up the reserves, or how many might be needed, military officials say that such a move would be needed to support a long stay in Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said that the military is heavily dependent on the reserves for major operations. He said the 1.6-million member reserve force accounts for two-thirds of the Army's combat support units, from cooks to military police to medical specialists.
Reserve forces also make up 93 percent of the Navy's stevedores, 82 percent of the Navy's minesweeping ship crews, 62 percent of the Marines' bulk fuel handlers and 67 percent of the Air Force's medical evacuation crews.
The President has the authority to call up as many as 200,000 members of the reserve forces for 90 days. He can extend the call up for another 90 days.
American officials familiar with intelligence reports reported today that Syria has moved a significant force to its border with Iraq to defend itself and help pin down the Iraqis.
There have also been continued intelligence reports of Kuwaiti resistance to the Iraqi occupation, as well as reports of widespread Iraqi looting in Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From TV Interview With Iraqi Official

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview by Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq with Ted Koppel on the ABC News program ''Nightline'' Wednesday, as transcribed by Journal Graphics.
We don't have any intention against Saudi Arabia. This has been a fabricated allegation, sorry to say, by the American Administration, but that is the truth.
Iraq has never had an intention to attack Saudi Arabia militarily. This has been used as a pretext for the American intervention in the region, the American mass of arms of all kinds, in this region. 
We made it clear to the Saudi officials from the very beginnning of the crisis that we don't have such an intention. We said that clearly in the meeting in Cairo.
We said we are ready to provide any guarantees on the bilateral level, or under the auspices of the Arab League. They did not listen. They listened to you! They listened to the allegations and wrong stories that were brought from Washington.
As far as Iraq is concerned, we don't have any intention against Saudi Arabia, as I said. There is no reason for Iraq to attack Saudi Arabia.
 
No Claim on Saudi Arabia
People don't send their armies without reasons, sincerely, across the border. We didn't have a border conflict with Saudi Arabia. We didn't ever claim that Saudi Arabia was part of Iraq.
We didn't have a political dispute with Saudi Arabia, an economic dispute with Saudi Arabia. So wars or military actions must have reasons. You don't do that, you see, you don't move your military forces without reasons.
If the United States has sent this big arsenal to the region, to defend Saudi Arabia against an alleged attack from Iraq, I think the United States is losing its time, its money, its fuel and its nerves. Because there is not such an intention in Iraq.
The explanation here or the interpretation here in Iraq and in the region is that the United States has come to commit aggression against Iraq. To weaken Iraq, to dominate the whole region with its vast oil resources. We anticipated that a few months ago when my President spoke in the summit of Amman.
 
U.S. Domination Charged
He said that the United States was planning to dominate the region, to be the sole dominator of oil market, of the policy of oil, the production, the pricing, etc. in order to safeguard its needs first. Secondly, to dominate this strategic product and use it in its hegemonic policy in the whole world.
So this is the interpretation here. If the United States has another interpretation it has to convince people. Because this mess has been built on an alleged fabrication.
We did not commit an aggression against Kuwait. We have another version of the story. As I said, this is a question which has been living with us, with the Iraqis, with the region for a very long time. And experienced politicians in the region know the facts. . . .
Why things happen now and they did not happen before? Well, it might be philosophical, but from the political side, I would say that we tried, we did our best to live in peace with the rulers of Kuwait, tried to reach a normal relationship with them, with the safeguarding of at least the minimum possible rights of Iraq. They did not cooperate. They insisted on denying everything to Iraq. They insisted on conspiring against Iraq. . . .
 
Conspiring Against Us
I have to be frank. Yes, we made it, we made it clear. I sent two letters to the Secretary General of the Arab League. And I said that these people were conspiring against us with the United States.
They wanted not only to destabilize Iraq, but they wanted to impoverish Iraq. They wanted at least to bring Iraq to its knees. What does it mean when they deliberately try to cut off half or almost half of the income of the Iraqi people by resorting to a policy in oil production, which has no reasonable reasons? . . .
There was an agreement in the OPEC. And they had to stick to their quota, which was one-point-five. They did not respect their quota. They flooded the market with a glut of oil.
They brought down the prices from $18 per barrel, to almost $11 per barrel. And that is a conspiracy! That's a war. And here I have to bring your attention to a fact.
 
A War Against Iraq
During the summit which was held in Baghdad, at the end of the summit, my President spoke frankly, sincerely, to all the leaders, in the presence of those who are concerned.
He said: ''Look, my dear brothers, a number of oil producing countries are resorting to a policy which equals a war. War can be done by arms, war can be done by economy, economic means. This is a war against Iraq. We cannot sustain it. Please don't follow such policy.''
They listened to President Saddam Hussein. As I said, he spoke in a brotherly, sincere manner. But even after that, they insisted on that policy, and they spoke in an arrogant manner that they would continue it. So we reached the conclusion that this handful of sheiks, corrupt sheiks, selfish sheiks, wanted to destroy this nation, wanted to destroy this country.
Though Kuwait was small part of Iraq in the past, we could have co-existed with it. But when that small part of Iraq is used to destroy the motherland, then things have to be corrected. And that's what happened in August this year.

HEADLINE: After Long Decline, Teen Births Are Up

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
An 18-year-long decline in teen-age birth rates has reversed itself abruptly, with the sharpest increase among mothers 15 to 17 years old, the Federal Government reports.
The finding, by the National Center for Health Statistics, drew immediate concern from health experts and social scientists who chart the health risks and economic hardship long associated with unwed teen-age motherhood.
''Any time you see an increase in births to younger teens, that's alarming,'' said Ron O'Brien of the Children's Defense Fund, a nonprofit advocacy group based in Washington. ''Teen pregnancy is a roadblock to all kinds of things for young people, and the younger it happens, the more of a roadblock it is.'' 
Researchers said it was not clear whether the rise in births to teen-agers reflected more sexual activity, less use of contraception and abortion services, or a combination of both factors.
 
Still Well Below '72 Figures
But Jacqueline Darroch Forrest of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit research organization, said recent studies indicated an increase in the number of teen-agers who are sexually active and an increase in the use of some contraception, particularly condoms. It was not clear, she said, whether pregnant teen-agers were more reluctant to seek abortions or were finding them harder to obtain. The number of doctors, clinics and hospitals performing abortions has declined in the past five years.
The health statistics center, a division of the Department of Health and Human Services, said the teen-age birth rate reached bottom in 1986 after declining steadily since 1970. It began climbing in 1987, and in 1988, the last year covered by the statistics, it recorded a sharp increase, returning to the levels of the late 1970's.
In 1988, the number of babies born to 15- to 17-year-olds exceeeded 168,000. This was the highest number in a decade but well below the peak figure -more than 230,000 in 1972, the year before the Supreme Court overturned state laws against abortion. There were slightly more women in that age group in 1972 than in 1988.
 
One Million Out of Wedlock
From 1986 to 1988, the birth rate among 15, 16- and 17-year-olds jumped 10 percent, to 33.8 per 1,000, meaning that more than 1 in 30 women in that age group had babies in 1988.
In all, 322,000 babies - about one-twelfth of the 3.9 million born in 1988 -were born to unmarried teen-agers. The number of births to all unmarried women also rose, exceeding one million for the first time.
Dr. Forrest of the Guttmacher Institute said publicity about state laws that require teen-agers to notify at least one parent before an abortion may have dissuaded some from seeking them. ''Young kids who may be hearing this discussion may get the wrong understanding, that either abortion is not allowed for them or they have to have the consent of their parents and the consent of both parents,'' she went on. ''The legal niceties are hard to distinguish.''
This year the Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of Ohio and Minnesota statutes requiring that at least one parent of an unmarried woman under 18 or younger be notified before she could receive an abortion. Under both laws, a young woman can seek a judge's approval if she feels she cannot notify a parent.
Asked whether the new figures would change the Bush Administration's opposition to increases in Federal family planning budgets, Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, told reporters at a breakfast meeting in Washington today: ''We do have a commitment to family planning. We separate out family planning from abortion. We do not believe that abortion is family planning.''
 
'Behavior Changes'
Clarke Forsythe, general counsel for the Chicago-based anti-abortion group Americans United for Life, said he doubted that the rising birth rates reflected teen-agers' unwillingness to seek abortions in states with stricter laws. In Minnesota, he said, the rates of teen-age pregnancy, birth and abortion all fell in in the first half of the 1980's, when its parental notification law was in effect. ''When restrictive laws are in place,'' he said, ''behavior changes.''
Stephanie Ventura and Caroline Lewis, the Federal demographers who wrote the new report, said unmarried teen-agers accounted for about one-third of all the unmarried mothers in 1988, down from 53 percent in 1972. But compared to the early 70's, when more than two-thirds of teen-age mothers were married, two-thirds of the teen-agers who gave birth in 1988 were unmarried.
The sharpest increase in births to young teen-agers, according to the report, came among whites. The birth rate among young black women increased more slowly.
The report showed a continuation of other patterns, in particular the increase in births to women over 40, which have risen by a third since their low point in 1983.
The trend toward more births to women aged 35 and older also continued, reaching its highest level since 1971. But the birth rate for that age group was still less than half what it was in 1960, near the peak of the baby boom.

HEADLINE: Audit Shows Railroads Are Remiss on Payroll Tax

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
A number of the country's major railroads and railroad-related businesses are failing to pay large amounts of payroll taxes to the Federal Government to finance the unemployment, retirement and medical benefits for the industry's workers, an audit indicates.
A report by the Inspector General of the Railroad Retirement Board, which was made available to several news organizations today, found that in a three-year period, 14 of 19 small to medium-size rail organizations neglected to pay $52 million in payroll taxes. It attributed the noncompliance in large part to underpayment of taxes on vacation and holiday pay and faulted the Internal Revenue Service for lax audits of payroll procedures.
An official of the Association of American Railroads said that the trade organization was ''aware of the Inspector General's allegations,'' but would have no comment on them. 
While the report said it could not deduce from this limited audit what taxes the remaining 1,157 railroad employers may have failed to pay in the 1980's, investigators said that they estimated the loss of revenue to the retirement board, a government agency, to be in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
 
Warning About Future Benefits
The tax deficiency does not mean that pension benefits and medical bills of railroad workers and their families have gone unpaid. In fact, the Railroad Retirement Fund currently pays $7 billion in benefits each year to 967,000 retired railroad workers. However, Government officials warned that in the future the fund would be unable to cover its obligations. There are currently more than 300,000 railroad workers.
Bush Administration officials and Congressional investigators familiar with the audit added that without better tax compliance by the railroad industry, the taxpayers will almost certainly have to ante up billions of dollars over the long run to cover the shortfall in funds for pensions and medical care for retired railroad workers.
Such a taxpayer bailout would be small compared with the savings and loan scandal, but it would come at a time when the resources of the Government will be more strained than they are now, they added.
In addition to the investigation by the Inspector General, the failure to pay taxes by the industry is being examined by the House Government Operations Committee and the Office of Management and Budget.
 
Earlier Warning by Darman
Richard G. Darman, the budget director, flagged the growing concern about the railroad pension system in his budget report last January, in which he identified the inadequately financed pension system as one of the growing number of contingent liabilities of the Federal Government that could come back and bite taxpayers.
He described them as ''hidden Pacmen waiting to spring forward and consume another line of resource dots in the budget maze.''
In particular, he noted that the Railroad Retirement Board's fund is currently underfinanced, on an actuarial basis, by $14 billion. This means that by the time the last worker covered by the pension system retires, the fund's shortfall would total at least that amount, and because of certain Government guarantees, the taxpayer would be left with the bill.
The issue of tax noncompliance is also being investigated by the Government Operations Committee, whose chairman, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat from Michigan, complained that the Bush Adminstration had not given this issue a high enough priority.
''The audits clearly demonstrate that the insurance and retirement funds of American railroad workers and their families are well below the radar of protection and oversight against financial predators,'' he said. ''Railroad employees' payroll taxes are not scrutinized by the Internal Revenue Service, internal auditors or public accountants.''
 
Industry Opposition Reported
Congressional investigators and a Bush Administration official said that Inspector General William J. Doyle 3d, after initially getting cooperation from the industry on his audits, was encountering considerable opposition from the industry.
''It appears the railroad industry is starting to circle the wagons,'' said one Congressional aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''He is having trouble getting access to records.''
Efforts to reach Mr. Doyle by telephone were unsuccessful.
The report by Mr. Doyle attributed the tax noncompliance in large measure to failure by the I.R.S. to audit payroll tax procedures by the railroad industry. The report carefully couched the loss of tax revenues as an issue of noncompliance, rather than alleging that the industry had intentionally underpaid taxes, which would be tantamount to fraud.
''The Office of Inspector General had serious concerns that the Railroad Retirement Board had no method of insuring that the railroad employers were complying with the railroad employment tax laws,'' the report said. ''As a result, the office initiated a strategy to perform payroll audits of the employers.''
It added, ''The statute of limitations allows us to go back only three years, and as a result significant tax revenues may be lost.''
Specifically, the report found that from 1986 to 1988 the group of 19 companies underpaid payroll taxes by $52.3 million, and that after adding I.R.S. penalties and interest, that amount is currently worth $73.6 million.
Congressional investigators said the industry's giant railroad networks had not yet been audited for payroll tax compliance by Mr. Doyle.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Quiet, Please! Air Traffic Rerouted From U.S. Open

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
As a result of the intercession of New York City's No. 1 tennis fan, players at this year's United States Open are less likely to be thrown off their games by the incessant roar of departing airplanes. Fans at the National Tennis Center should benefit, too, by hearing the distinct thwock of each serve and volley, not to mention the full range of Monica Seles's grunts and Andre Agassi's groans.
Responding directly to an appeal from Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that special takeoff procedures normally put into effect at La Guardia Airport only during the two days of men's and women's singles finals would be extended to the entire 14-day tournament, which begins Aug. 27 and runs to Sept. 9.
That means that to the extent weather conditions permit, planes taking off during tournament hours will not use the notorious Runway 13, whose normal takeoff pattern takes planes directly over the tennis stadium in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. 
 
Would Bypass Park
And when conditions do force the use of Runway 13, planes will follow an established but rarely used takeoff pattern that bypasses the park.
The decision by the F.A.A. to modify takeoff patterns during the tournament came in response to a joint request by Mayor Dinkins and the Queens borough president, Claire Shulman, the same request, an aide to Shulman noted, that she had made routinely to the F.A.A. year after year without noticeable effect on F.A.A. procedures.
The difference this year, according to the Borough President's counsel, Nick Garaufis, was the enthusiastic intervention of a ''forceful'' mayor, who, as one of the mayor's spokesmen, Annabel Franzeschini, put it yesterday, ''really loves tennis,'' so much, she noted, that ''he plays almost every day.'' (By contrast, the Mayor's predecessor, Edward I. Koch, was famous for his active aversion to any athletic endeavor notJU involving chopsticks.) In addition to his own love for tennis, Mayor Dinkins had another incentive to press especially hard for the F.A.A.'s cooperation this year. The United States Tennis Association, whose lease on the National Tennis Center expires after the 1994 tournament, is expected to decide before the end of the year whether to renew the lease or move the tournament elsewhere. Such a development, the Mayor said yesterday, would cost the city economy more than $100 million in revenues from the two-week event.
Complaints about the noise of La Guardia takeoffs have been almost as incessant as the takeoffs themselves (about 500 a day) ever since the Open moved from its former home at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills in 1978.
 
Curren Still Skeptical
Players often gripe about the distraction of departing aircraft, although few quite as forcefully as Kevin Curren, who once expressed the wish that the low-flying planes should be used to bomb the stadium.
Yesterday, Curren remained skeptical about what effect the new procedure would have. ''I'm sure it will definitely help,'' he said from Indianapolis. ''But in my eyes, the Open still lags behind the other majors with atmosphere. That's why they're looking for another venue. I don't think the fact that they're rerouting the planes will all of a sudden make it the best grand slam. You have to look at the overall picture.''
In announcing the changes, the F.A.A. stressed that takeoff patterns to be used during tournament hours were all well-established routines that posed no threat to safety or convenience of passengers.
''They will cause no delays,'' said Kathleen Berger, a spokesman for the F.A.A.'s regional commissioner, Daniel Peterson.
If weather or other conditions force the F.A.A. to resume using Runway 13 for takeoffs and to employ the alternate flight path to avoid Flushing Meadows, she said, the silence at the stadium would be achieved at the expense of residents of ''a small area of Flushing,'' the very residents, she ackowledged, whose complaints years ago led the F.A.A. to route Runway 13 takeoffs over the park in the first place. ''We plan to monitor things very carefully,'' she said. If all goes well, however, planes leaving La Guardia during tournament hours will simply use the airport's two other takeoff paths, No. 31, which is No. 13 going in the opposite direction, and No. 4, which heads straight over Flushing Bay. (No. 4's opposite, Runway 22, is almost never used for takeoffs because it leads to heavily congested areas.)

HEADLINE: Democracy Betrayed in Myanmar

 BODY:
It seemed like a fairy-tale ending to 28 years of ruinous military dictatorship in Myanmar, formerly Burma. In May, in the country's first free election since 1962, an overwhelming majority voted for a party of persecuted opposition democrats, the National League for Democracy.
But Myanmar's people have scarcely lived happily ever since. Their best remaining hope for compelling their rulers to honor the popular will is for increased diplomatic and economic pressure from the international community, including the United States. 
The Slorc - the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council - has been acting as if the election never occurred, and as if the Slorc itself had not pledged to turn over power to the victor. The newly elected legislators have still not been allowed to take their seats. Worse, the Slorc now says that the assembly will be allowed to do no more than adopt a Slorc-approved constitution. Then it will be disbanded and another assembly elected under new electoral rules.
Meanwhile, the leading figure in the National League for Democracy, Aung San Suu Kyi, remains in prison, even though her nominal sentence has run out. Hundreds of her party colleagues also remain jailed. Demonstrators supporting the election results and commemorating past massacres have been shot at, and in some cases killed.
The United States has properly kept its diplomatic distance from the Slorc since troops mowed down Burmese democrats in the streets two years ago. And Congress recently passed a bill sponsored by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York imposing economic sanctions if President Bush cannot certify concrete steps toward democratic rule by Oct. 1.
That will help, but the Slorc would be even more impressed by pressure from Myanmar's neighbor and trading partner, Thailand, and from Asia's economic power, Japan. Developments from South Africa to the Persian Gulf suggest that the international community can exert effective pressure, but only if it acts in concert.

HEADLINE: Letter;
Now Here's the Deal With the Oil Moguls

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Saddam Hussein is surely a villain worthy of the next round of Rambo movies. But as we commit ourselves to defend the rich, conservative, Persian Gulf monarchies, the American public and Congress deserve to know fully the deal we have made over the years with Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. The deal seems to include the following main components: (1) The gulf monarchies agree to pump oil, lots of oil, in excess of the quotas of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. This oil surplus angers other petroleum exporters, but holds down world prices and our balance-of-trade deficit. (2) The rich, thinly populated gulf monarchies, not needing nearly all the oil revenue, agree to put much of it in United States banks and investments. This inflow of oil dollars is extremely important for our credit markets, property values, interest rates and the dollar. (3) The United States, in return, agrees to defend the gulf monarchies, first from Iran, now from Iraq.
Georges Clemenceau, the French statesman, once said, ''A drop of oil is worth a drop of blood.'' If it is Arab oil for American blood, let us know the full terms.
 
MICHAEL ROSKIN
Professor of Political Science
Lycoming College
 Williamsport, Pa., Aug. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: LAW: AT THE BAR;
More lawyers are less happy at their work, a survey finds.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
An American Bar Association survey has corroborated what has become increasingly apparent to lawyers, legal recruiters and psychiatrists: job dissatisfaction among lawyers is widespread, profound and growing worse.
Since a similar survey was taken in 1984, the number of lawyers saying they are ''very satisfied'' with their work has decreased by 20 percent, to slightly more than 3 in 10. The rest, from all levels of seniority and kinds of practice, report that they are less fulfilled, more fatigued, more stressed, more caught up in office politics, more likely to be in unhappy marriages and more likely to drink excessively than they once did.
Authorities on the legal profession said the results reflect the growing economic pressures on lawyers in an adverse economy. ''People were miserable before, but were willing to put up with it because they were making a lot of money,'' said Celia Paul, whose six-year-old counseling service for disaffected lawyers now handles 2,000 people a year. ''If there's less money, other rewards have to fill that vacuum, and they just aren't there.'' 
Other explanations, they say, include the volatility of the legal marketplace, even among partners, and the coming of age of a younger generation that entered the profession either with unrealistic expectations or, in many cases, almost by accident.
''For about the past 15 years it has been sort of a knee-jerk thing that if you decide not to go to medical school or business school, you go to law school by default,'' said Carol M. Kanarek, a New York-based consultant on legal personnel matters.
That impulse, she said, was spurred on by the feelings that a law degree is ''infinitely flexible'' and that the profession is glamorous - an impression fostered by television portrayals of lawyers as sexy characters driving sports cars and working on cutting-edge issues.
''As a result, the gap between expectations and reality is much greater than in the past,'' she said. ''Our parents' generation of lawyers tended to have a more realistic sense of what the practice was all about.''
The bar survey also found that at a time when teetotalism is increasing, there has been ''an astonishing rise'' in drinking among lawyers, particularly women. In 1984 less than half of 1 percent of those surveyed reported consuming six or more drinks a day. That figure has now risen to 13 percent, including one in every five female lawyers.
That, in turn, is part of the still greater malaise among women in the profession, even as their numbers continue to grow.
Those questioned in the survey were selected at random from lists containing the names of almost all lawyers in the United States, both A.B.A. members and nonmembers. In March each was mailed a copy of the survey; those failing to respond to that or a follow-up postcard were then interviewed by phone. They were promised confidentiality.
Only 3 to 4 percent of the 2,289 lawyers participating in the survey, conducted by the bar association's young lawyers division, said they planned to leave the profession in the next two years. But even if an exodus is not imminent, the survey says, the prevailing levels of unhappiness bode ill for the law profession and the people it employs and serves.
''The increased stress of dissatisfaction and billable hours have disturbing and important implications for the profession,'' says the report, which was released at the bar group's recently concluded annual meeting in Chicago. ''These lie in the area of increasing social dysfunction or destructive behavior by lawyers and the impact of this behavior on themselves, their families, their quality of work and productivity, their firms and their clients.''
Ronald L. Hirsch, the A.B.A. official who conducted the 1990 and 1984 surveys, said the greatest change was not so much in the depth of the dissatisfaction as in its scope, which he attributed to ''a deterioration of the law firm environment.''
Mr. Hirsch said the bar association planned to hold what he called an ''ice-breaking, seminal conference'' next April, at which lawyers, psychologists, sociologists and others would discuss the growing malaise among lawyers and what could be done about it.
Twenty-two percent of all male partners in private practice said they were dissatisfied with their work, as opposed to only 9 percent in 1984. For female partners, the figure rose to 42 percent from 15 percent. Forty-three percent of all men in solo practice said they were dissatisfied; among women, it was 55 percent.
''It's not just young lawyers and it's not just in the largest firms,'' said Mr. Hirsch, a former senior administrator at the National Opinion Research Center in Chicago. ''It's systemic. It's everywhere.''
According to the survey, public notions of how much money lawyers make, based largely on the hefty salaries paid to beginning lawyers at large firms in New York, are wildly exaggerated. Fifty-nine percent of all lawyers nationwide earn less than the $83,000 paid to beginning lawyers on Wall Street. But unhappiness over pay is not a principle cause of low morale among lawyers.
Instead, the despair is felt over quality-of-life issues. Respondents cited growing political intrigue and backbiting in the office, greater pressure to work longer hours and a concomitant decrease in personal time and time with families. Half of those surveyed in private practice reported working at least 200 hours a month, up from only 35 percent six years ago; 13 percent say they work more than 240 hours.
In nearly every category, women report greater job dissatisfaction than men.
The women interviewed were less challenged intellectually by their work than were men, found the office atmosphere less congenial, complained that they had fewer chances for advancement than men, were less likely to be judged solely on the quality of their work and were more likely to feel they did not have enough time for themselves.
The disaffection has spread to the upper reaches of the profession, where the lucrative salaries based largely on seniority, collegiality and security have waned in a newly competitive marketplace.
''The camaraderie and the loyalty have broken down,'' said Elaine P. Dine, a legal recruiter in New York. ''With everything bottom-line orientated, many partners feel as though they're employees of a corporation rather than members of a firm.''
Perhaps more than any lawyer in the land, Alan U. Schwartz of Los Angeles personifies the upheavals and unhappinesses of a newly peripatetic profession. (Among Mr. Schwartz's clients is Mel Brooks. In the movie ''Spaceballs,'' when Mr. Brooks declared, ''May the Schwartz be with you,'' it was to Alan Schwartz that he was referring.) For 21 years Mr. Schwartz worked in the gentlemanly world of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst, where his clients included Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter. The firm disintegrated in 1982, and since then Mr. Schwartz has gathered little moss.
From Greenbaum he moved to Barovick, Konecky, Braun, Schwartz, Kay & Schiff, which merged with Fulop & Hardee, which then fell apart. He went to Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, which closed in early 1988. From there he went to the Los Angeles office of Shea & Gould, which also disbanded, then to Meyerson & Kuhn, which recently filed for bankruptcy. He is now at Cooper, Epstein & Hurewitz in Beverly Hills.
''It was much more of a profession when I started,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''People did not expect to make big bucks so much as they expected a kind of way of life and practice.''
Some younger lawyers have even decided to abandon law entirely in favor of something they enjoy doing. In April 1988, Lynn Armentrout, a 1981 graduate of New York University Law School, took a leave of absence from her post at the Legal Aid Society office in the Bronx to pursue a career as a dancer. She has since decided not to return to law.
''I went to law school to make a difference in the world and I wasn't,'' said Ms. Armentrout, a 35-year-old dancer with the Isadora Duncan International Institute. ''What was missing is the emotional and spiritual content - all the things that make life important.''
At WEGX-FM in Philadelphia, a lapsed lawyer named Sam Milkman is the host of a top-40 music show twice weekly. It is only one of the many tasks handled at the station by Mr. Milkman, a 27-year-old Cornell Law School graduate who until March was an associate at the Philadelphia law firm of Ballard, Spahr, Andrews & Ingersoll.
''I always felt like a misfit as a lawyer,'' said Mr. Milkman. ''I found myself in the middle of depositions not really caring what the outcome was.''
In making his move, he said, he was the envy of his former law firm colleagues. ''One of the associates, who has since become a partner, said, 'When one of the prisoners breaks free all of the prisoners are happy,' '' Mr. Milkman recalled. Maura Carlin, 29, of Manhattan was a litigator at Sidley & Austin before deciding to take a long-postponed shot at broadcast journalism. ''I can't tell you I hated the law or practicing it because it's not exactly true, but there was something else I really wanted to do and this is the time to try it or I'd be too old,'' she said. ''I always had this vision of myself saving the world, and the practice of law as I knew it was very far from that.''
Ms. Carlin said she was prepared to take as much as an 80 percent cut in pay. Speaking of her new salary, she said, ''It's such a ridiculous number, it's comical.''
