LENGTH: 2002 words

HEADLINE: Surrealism Meets Politics in Festival Latino Film

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
In ''Gentile Alouette'' (''The Colonel's Star''), one of the most intriguing features to be shown in the 1990 Festival Latino Film series, Geraldine Chaplin portrays a Hispanic movie actress working in Paris who is stalked by a colonel of the secret police of an unnamed Latin American country.
The colonel, who is played by Hector Alterio, a star of the critically acclaimed 1985 film ''The Official Story,'' was once involved with the woman, and now he suspects her of being politically active in an anti-Government group. His memories and suspicions fuse in fantasy scenarios of capturing the elusive, chameleonlike woman who is ultimately invulnerable.
The French-Chilean allegory, written and directed by Sergio Castilla, combines surrealism and high comedy in a visionary style that with its echoes of Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Luis Bunuel seems quintessentially Latin American in spirit.
''There has always been a strong element of surrealism in Latin American culture,'' Mr. Castilla said recently. ''If you go all the way back to 'Don Quixote,' there are many surreal elements of fantasy and ghosts. You have surrealism in American movies too, but it is confined mostly to genre pictures.'' 
''Gentile Alouette,'' which is to be shown on Aug. 28, 29 and 30, is among the 28 contemporary feature films in the festival, which has its first screenings today at the Worldwide Cinemas. Of those films, 25 are to be in competition for awards. The competition is only one arm of a festival that is to show some 150 films during two weeks. There are also to be separate retrospectives of Mexican, Argentine and Cuban movies and a program of documentaries and experimental and short films.
 
'A More Serious Event'
This is the sixth year of the Festival Latino Film, which is presented by Joseph Papp's Public Theater, and the second year that it has been a competitive event. The only other Latin American film event of comparable scope, said Cecilia Vega, who directs the festival with Oscar Ciccone, is the noncompetitive Havana film festival, which has been in existence for 12 years.
The New York competition was inaugurated, Ms. Vega said, to give producers more incentive to participate and to gain more attention from the press.
''Because of money problems in Latin American countries, it has often been difficult to get the films,'' she said. ''Since becoming competitive, it's become a more serious event, and producers have been more willing to invest in subtitles. This year, many of the producers and the stars will be here.''
The contestants this year were chosen from about 100 entries. Eleven countries are represented, including the United States. Among the new films in competition, the first two to be shown, at 6:45 and 9 this evening, are ''Cien Veces No Debo'' (''A Hundred Times, No'') from Argentina and ''Lo Que le Paso a Santiago'' (''What Happened to Santiago?'') from Puerto Rico.
Alejandro Doria's ''Cien Veces No Debo'' is a scathing satiric farce that ridicules the duplicitous sexual morality of the Argentine bourgeoisie. When the daughter of a middle-class Buenos Aires couple announces to her parents that she is pregnant and that she isn't certain who the father is, they frenziedly attempt to arrange a respectable-looking solution to the situation.
The portraits of the family members are etched in acid. The spoiled slatternly daughter rejoices in her sexual powers. Her father can barely conceal his desire for her, while her mother's curiosity about her daughter's sexual life is intense to the point of prurience. The mother is played by Norma Aleandro, who starred in ''The Official Story.''
Jacobo Morales's ''Que le Paso a Santiago,'' which is not in competition, explores love after the age of 60 and features Tommy Muniz and Gladys Rodriguez, the stars of ''Los Garcia,'' a popular Puerto Rican television series. Mr. Muniz portrays a retired widower and former accountant who confides his feelings to a mysterious woman who befriends him after a chance meeting.
The film, which was nominated this year for an Academy Award as best foreign film, is the third feature by the writer and director, who is also an actor, a poet and a popular Puerto Rican broadcasting personality. Earlier this month, he performed at the Public Theater with his ''Saturday Night Live''-style comedy troupe, Los Rayos Gamma (the Gamma Rays).
Mr. Morales recently said that his main character came into focus after he had seen a Puerto Rican production of Neil Simon's play ''The Sunshine Boys.'' ''Santiago,'' which has been sold for international distribution, cost a half-million dollars to make, he said, and is the first of his three films to have made a a profit.
''In Puerto Rico, we have all the elements to establish a very modest film industry that can do three or four films a year,'' he said. ''But with a population of only three million, we don't have enough people to recoup the investment without other markets.''
 
A New Yorker's Roots
''El Sol y la Luna'' (''The Sun and the Moon''), to be shown on Wednesday and next Friday and Saturday, is the festival's only American entry and its only English-language film. It describes a New York City woman's awakening to her Puerto Rican cultural roots. In the throes of a midlife crisis, she visits the South Bronx neighborhood where she grew up and organizes a tenants' association in her relatives' run-down apartment building. At the same time, she becomes involved with a lawyer who is active in the Puerto Rican separatist movement.
The film represents the directorial debut of Kevin Conway, who was recently seen Off Broadway as the unscrupulous Wall Street profiteer in the drama ''Other People's Money.''
Mr. Conway said recently that he had been involved in helping raise money for ''The Sun and the Moon'' and assumed the director's reins only after the original director became ill.
''The story intrigued me because my former wife is a Hispanic-American woman,'' he said. ''The film deals with the cultural schizophrenia of Puerto Rican Americans. They're divided between America and an island that many of them consider a country with a different culture and language than the United States.
''At the same time, they are already American citizens who are only three hours away by plane from New York and Chicago.''
 
A Film Noir
Some other competing films that have generated positive advance word of mouth include ''Baton Rouge'' from Spain; ''Kindergarten'' and ''Ultimas Imagenes del Naufragio'' (''Last Images of the Shipwreck''), both from Argentina; ''Festa'' (''Party'') from Brazil, and ''La Bella del Alhambra'' (''The Belle of the Alhambra'') from Cuba.
Rafael Monleon's ''Baton Rouge,'' which is to be shown tomorrow and on Tuesday, is a sexy film noir that stars three of Pedro Almodovar's favorite actors: Carmen Maura, Antonio Banderas and Victoria Abril. They respectively portray a wealthy woman, her scheming gigolo lover and the ruthless psychiatrist the two consult to cure her nightmares.
Jorge Polaco's ''Kindergarten,'' an obsessive love story to be screened tomorrow and on Monday, has the distinction of being the only Argentine film since the country's return to democracy to have been officially confiscated by the Government and labeled pornographic. Eliseo Subiela's surreal ''Ultimas Imagenes del Naufragio,'' to be shown on Aug. 27, 29 and 30, tells the story of an aspiring novelist whose life is taken over by a family that insists that he write its future.
Ugo Giorgetti's ''Festa,'' which has screenings tomorrow, Monday and Wednesday, is a comic variation on Sartre's ''No Exit.'' Two pool sharks and a harmonica player who have been hired to entertain at a fancy Sao Paulo party wait for what becomes an eternity in the host's basement. ''La Bella del Alhambra,'' a musical to be shown on Tuesday and Thursday, re-creates the Cuban cabaret world of the 1920's.
 
Heeding Hollywood
The festival's three retrospective series, to be screened at the Worldwide Cinemas, re-examine national cinematic traditions of Mexico, Cuba and Argentina. All three reflect a growing respect among Latin American film makers for work that pays heed to Hollywood styles and methods of movie making.
''During the 60's, Latin American film makers became very politicized and backed away from an industry they saw as based on the Hollywood models,'' said Paul Lenti, a press representative for the festival and a student of Latin American film.
''A lot of it came from the political movements in Cuba and Chile, but it was also influenced by the French New Wave. Then, the idea was to use cinema not just to entertain but to change society. But a lot of those social and political films became dated very quickly, and they didn't impact on the community as much as those films that used fiction to put across a message.
''That's why in the last five years the whole stress has been in getting back to the script. With that has come a re-evaluation and a new appreciation for work that in the past had been denigrated.''
The Mexican Films From the Golden Age series, which is to begin today, concentrates on six movies made in the 1940's and 1950's and featuring such stars as Dolores de Rio, Maria Felix, and Pedro Armendariz. It includes the Dolores del Rio classic ''Maria Candelaria,'' which is to be shown today and tomorrow.
The era being examined was one in which Hollywood producers invested money in Mexico to compete in the Latin American market, Mr. Lenti said. That investment had a political objective. Because Argentina had declared itself neutral during World War II, a goal was to destroy the Argentine film market, which was Mexico's main competitor in the Latin American sphere.
The Argentine retrospective, which is to begin on Sunday, consists of 16 films, beginning with ''Tango!,'' the first optical sound film produced in Argentina, in 1933, and featuring the popular star Libertad Lamarque. It ends in the late 1950's. The Argentine films, unfortunately, have no subtitles.
The 30-film Cuban historical survey, which is to begin on Wednesday, represents the largest retrospective of the Cuban cinema yet screened in the United States and the first to include Cuban films produced before the Communist revolution. The panorama was assembled by the Government-financed Cuban Film Institute I.C.A.I.C. (Instituo Cubano del Arte e Industria Cinematograficos), which was largely responsible for establishing Cuba as a significant film-making country in the 1960's. The best-known work to be shown is probably Tomas Gutierrez Alez's 1968 film, ''Memorias del Subdesarrollo'' (''Memories of Underdevelopment''), which is to be screened on Thursday.
 
With Documentaries
Rounding out the festival is its program of documentaries, experimental films and short fiction, which this year consists of 56 films of every shape and size from 14 countries, with Brazil and Cuba the most heavily represented. The series runs from Aug. 24 to 30 at the Public Theater. Films of special note include ''Desembarcos'' (''When Memory Speaks''), an Argentine film about the need to remember the thousands who were kidnapped and murdered during the military dictatorship; ''Permiso Para Pensar'' (''Permission to Think''), also from Argentina, which uses archive clips to explore the Juan Peron era, and from England, Jana Bokova's urban documentary ''Havana.''
If the Festival Latino series demonstrates the artistic richness and breadth of Latin American cinema, perhaps even more crucial is its role in keeping the economic lifeblood of a fragmented industry circulating.
''We want to create both a market and a base for the distribution of Latin American films,'' Ms. Vega said. ''Last year, our audience was 50 percent Latino and 50 percent Anglo-American. In the United States, the Latino population is more than 30 million. It is an important market for our cinema. Our festival is proving that the audience for Latin American films exists.''

PUB-DATE: August 17, 1990

SECTION: Section C; Page 24, Column 1; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
In 1988, Habsburg, Feldman, a little-known Geneva-based auction house with lofty ambitions, opened a New York City office in a grand town house on the Upper East Side.
The company, which had built its reputation primarily by selling clocks and watches, stamps and Art Deco furniture, wanted to expand its operation. It quickly added a department of Old Masters and 19th-century paintings. Then it created a department specializing in Impressionist, modern and contemporary art and hired Thilo von Watzdorf, a 17-year veteran of Sotheby's, to run it.
For the first year or so, the investment seemed to be paying off. As the auction market boomed, so did Habsburg, Feldman. But eventually the company's own unrealistic expectations and a precarious economy took their toll. Undercapitalized and overextended, Habsburg, Feldman started to sink. In April, David Feldman, one of the auction house's founders, left the company. 
Now, Habsburg, Feldman is retrenching. It has eliminated both of its paintings departments, and it has made major staffing cuts, both in New York and in Geneva. The company is even putting its town house headquarters up for sale.
In September, a group of Geneva investors, headed by Lowe Finance, will hold a majority of the company's shares, and the auction house will be renamed Habsburg & Company.
 
A 'Fatal' Market
''We really had no option,'' said Geza von Habsburg, one of the firm's founders, who ran Christie's office in Geneva for nearly 20 years. ''A small firm such as ours can barely survive in a buoyant market, but in a slump, as we are experiencing now, it's fatal.''
To some art-market specialists, this is a tale of naivete, the story of a group of auction-house veterans who should have known better. Experts say the New York operation was doomed from the start. ''They drew a road map that was not possible to follow,'' said Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's New York. ''The company expected instant results and got them the first year because the market was with them. But as soon as things went bad, they ran scared.''
Unlike small, local auction houses like William Doyle, which cater to the lower end of the market, Habsburg, Feldman tried to compete internationally for high-priced works of art and in the process was forced to stretch beyond its means. It issued lavish catalogues, often sending them to clients by overnight mail. It also produced a newsletter and held countless, opulent receptions.
''In order to enter into a new field, we had to be particularly aggressive,'' said Mr. von Habsburg, a great-grandson of Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria. ''We offered guarantees that were too big and put reserves on paintings that were too high.'' Guarantees are the prices the auction house assures that a seller will receive from the sale of his property; reserves are the confidential minimum prices below which the house will not sell property.
 
'The Kiss of Death'
In today's competitive climate, in which there are only so many good pictures on the market, Habsburg, Feldman was often forced to settle for selling second-rate works of art. ''Consigners are reluctant to risk selling big-ticket items to people who don't have a proven track record,'' explained William Doyle, owner of the Manhattan-based auction house that bears his name. ''As a result, Habsburg, Feldman was left to sell dealer's goods, paintings that had been on the market for too long. And that's the kiss of death.''
Moreover, said Francois Curiel, the managing director of Christie's Europe, ''There exists a lack of expert business-getters in the auction world itself. But for a new company, it's particularly hard to recruit them. And if the kitchen can't produce the food, then they're in real trouble.''
Even so, in the beginning Habsburg, Feldman did better than it expected. In its first year and a half in New York, the house sold art and objects worth more than $50 million. It was this spring, when the market began to soften, that things fell apart. Two sales in particular were disasters: in the house's May sale of Impressionist and modern pictures, 85 percent of the works found no buyers, and in a spring sale of contemporary Soviet artworks 50 percent of the goods remained unsold.
''Initially, 40 percent of the group's profits were from the Impressionist and modern paintings,'' Mr. von Wazdorf said. ''But at the first sign of trouble, the board of directors in Geneva decided to pull the plug on the whole department.''
 
The Boutique Approach
Like Sotheby's and Christie's, where the departments of modern and contemporary paintings are the main source of profits, Habsburg, Feldman expected money from sales of paintings to carry the New York operation. By marketing itself as a boutique firm - a small operation that showed works of art in a homelike setting - Habsburg, Feldman hoped to attract important clients by stressing its exclusivity and personal service.
''We were offering people an alternative,'' Mr. von Wazdorf explained. ''A proper international auction house where paintings wouldn't get lost, as they so easily could in the large sales at Sotheby's and Christie's. Pictures were even marketed in an international way, with previews in Japan.''
Initially, some were intrigued. Bryn Mawr College, for example, consigned Marc Chagall's ''Violoniste au Monde Renverse'', an early work dating from 1929 that sold in May 1989 for $4.62 million, a record price for the artist.
And during its first year in New York, the auction house reported five record sales of works by artists including Kees van Dongen, Maurice de Vlaminck and Auguste Rodin. ''When I had stock to get rid of, they were a good showcase,'' said Marzina Marzetti, the director of the Urban Gallery in Paris and vice president of that company's New York operations. ''I sold several works of art that would have gotten lost at Sotheby's or Christie's sales. Still, I would never have given them an important painting to sell.''
 
In Hindsight
As in any business, timing is everything. ''Looking back I realize we started too late,'' Mr. von Habsburg said. ''If we had gone into business five years earlier, we'd be all right now.''
And Mr. Feldman said the owners really had no idea what they were in for. ''We didn't know the auction world well enough,'' he said. Mr. Feldman is credited with creating several successful art businesses, including one of the largest stamp houses in the world.
Along with the struggles of putting together strong sales and carrying a large overhead, the company also faced difficulty in collecting payments from buyers. ''We have been out of pocket for over $10 million of receivables,'' Mr. von Habsburg said. ''A big company can absorb such problems. We can't.''
Internal conflicts, culminating in Mr. Feldman's departure, added to the company's problems. His reasons for leaving the auction house, he said, centered on personality clashes as well as basic business differences. This leaves three men to run the company: Mr. von Habsburg, Osvaldo Patrizzi, a Geneva-based auctioneer who is an expert on clocks and watches, and Karl Wellner, the chief executive of the company's New York office.
 
New Strategies to Compete
''We have decided to stick to fields we know we are good at,'' Mr. von Habsburg said. ''Clocks and watches, silver and Art Deco. That's not to say that we won't be venturing into new areas. We're planning a sale of jewelry and another of Old Master paintings. The company is also going to hold special events such as exhibitions where the works of art will be for sale and silent auctions.''
''In order to compete, we have to find new approaches to the market,'' he added. ''And to stick to niches where we can supply objects to the public that others can't.''

THE ECONOMY
 
The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected gain that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis. The increase was a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy. [Page A1.] 
 
Housing starts fell 2.6 percent last month from June, the sixth straight monthly decline, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said. [D4.] The number of new shopping-centers being built in the U.S. fell sharply in the first half of 1990, a trade group said. [D2.]
 
THE OIL JOLT
 
President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan failed to make significant progress toward easing the Middle East crisis, and Mr. Bush was apparently unable to win ironclad assurances from the King that he would halt shipments to Baghdad. [A1.]
 
A number of commercial ships are anchored outside the entrance to the Persian Gulf, Gulf tanker rates have fallen and most Iraqi-owned commercial ships are not trying to pick up or unload cargoes around the world, experts said. [A12.]
 
Oil prices moved higher, with contracts for September delivery closing at $27.36 a barrel, up 90 cents. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
 
The chief executive of Cetus has resigned in the wake of a blow from the F.D.A. that has clouded the company's future. [D1.]
 
Exxon received a bill from the I.R.S. for nearly $7 billion for the years 1979 through 1982, but it said the amount in serious dispute was $2 billion, which grew out of an argument over how it priced oil bought from Saudi Arabia during that period. [D1.]
 
The financial performance of Donald Trump's casinos declined further in the second quarter, according to S.E.C. documents. [D2.]
 
Hewlett-Packard is moving the headquarters of its personal computer group from California to Paris. [D3.]
 
General Electric's aircraft engines division plans to cut 1,500 jobs in its U.S. operations by 1992. [D3.]
 
The emergency power sources that kept the banking system in business after last Monday's power failure in New York are showing signs of wear, causing a new round of problems. [D6.]
 
Some railroads and railroad-related businesses are failing to pay large amounts of payroll taxes to the Federal Government to finance benefits for the industry's workers, an audit indicates. [A16.]
 
The U.S. is no longer competitive in markets for consumer products like telephones and facsimile machines and is losing ground in markets for business and telephone company equipment, a study shows. [D16.]
 
MARKETS
 
The stock market tumbled to its lowest close in more than three months. The Dow fell 66.83 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,681.44, the fourth biggest one-day decline in points this year. [D1.]
 
Treasury bond prices plummeted and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels since early May. [D12.]
 
The dollar tumbled to an all-time low against the mark during domestic trading. The currency was also sharply lower against the Swiss franc and British pound. [D13.]
 
The prices of gold futures surged on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Livestock and meat prices were mixed. [D13.]

HEADLINE: Pemex Adopts a Corporate Tone

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Since Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, many industrialized nations have looked nervously to countries like Mexico, one of the largest producers of oil outside the Middle East. But Mexico's state-owned oil company, long past the glory days of the early 1980's when prices were high, will probably not be much help. Short of cash, it is worried about its ability to produce enough oil even to satisfy domestic demand, Indeed, the company, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, is being forced into an important change: The institution that represents a nationalist aspiration to run the economy free of foreign interference is beginning to behave like an international corporation. It is seeking foreign investment and cutting costs, reducing the multimillion-dollar social programs it has subsidized for decades.
''What is forcing the change is the realization that we will not have enough energy,'' said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, publisher of an economics newsletter. ''Over the long run, unless we put enormous sums into petroleum and petrochemicals, we will have to import these products.''
The failure to invest significantly in oil exploration - capital spending has fallen from nearly $6 billion in 1981 to just over $1 billion - has reduced Pemex's potential output in recent years. 
Even if Pemex finds the money to undertake all-out exploration, the additional oil would not be available for three or four years, experts say. And some Mexican Government officials have expressed reluctance to increase exports sharply because this would deplete reserves and once again make the country overly dependent on oil revenues.
For the United States, which relies on Pemex for 7 percent of its oil imports and could put pressure on Mexico for more if Middle East supplies tighten, the changes at Pemex are not likely to show up in increased imports of oil. But Mexico has agreed to help out other nations temporarily by increasing exports by almost 10 percent for two months.
The meaning for Mexico of the changes at Pemex is that the big state company is beginning to chip away at its traditional role as a sort of symbolic bulwark against foreign interference. It is also reducing its huge support for Mexican society and becoming more of a profit-making company eager to exploit Mexico's huge oil reserves. Pemex not only supplies such services as secondary schooling and day care, but also spends hundreds of millions of dollars on contracts to build roads, bridges, housing and oil tankers.
On Fortune magazine's list of the world's 50 largest industrial companies, Pemex had $15 billion in 1989 revenues. That represented 6 percent of Mexico's gross domestic product, and Pemex's oil sales abroad brought in 23 percent of the nation's export revenue. The taxes funneled to the Government - nearly $8 billion in 1989 - are far and away its largest single source of revenue.
The tax drain is an important reason for Pemex's cash shortage. The other major reason is the collapse in oil prices in the 1980's, which deprived Mexico of billions of dollars in annual revenue.
Recognizing Pemex's key role in the economy - and the Mexican psyche - President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has promised never to sell the company. ''This decision is irrevocable,'' Mr. Salinas said in a recent speech, although he has put many other state companies on the block to raise money for debt repayment and to finance social services.
But even without privatization, Pemex is slowly acquiring the characteristics of a private corporation.
 
Evidence of Cost-Cutting
The cost-cutting by Pemex shows up in a number of ways. The Oil Workers Union once controlled the construction contracts awarded by Pemex; now they go up for competitive bidding. The Pemex labor force has been shrunk from 213,000 in 1988 to 150,000 today. The number of children in Pemex-operated secondary schools has dropped by 5,000 since 1982, to fewer than 50,000.
On another front, Pemex is for the first time allowing foreign investors to become involved in the processing of crude oil into petrochemicals. And while Pemex is not now planning to extend foreign involvement to other areas, including a stake in the exploration and pumping of oil, the decline in oil production is increasing the possibility that foreign companies may some day be given such a stake.
Until now, exploration and production have been assigned by the Mexican Constitution only to the state. Foreign companies are hired to run rigs, but they are never given what they most want in return: the right to keep a percentage of oil discovered.
 
Petrochemical Shortage
Under the current system, Pemex has been unable to produce enough petrochemicals to supply Mexican-based manufacturers of plastics, film and other products, and it lacks the money to build plants by itself. So the company changed the rules to get around a legal prohibition on foreign investment in basic petrochemicals.
Dozens of petrochemicals were classified in 1988 and 1989 as non-basic. That has allowed Pemex to negotiate with Mitsui, Celanese and other companies abroad for financing to build petrochemical plants. If agreements are reached, Pemex would own these plants, and would repay the loans not with cash but by delivering to the investing companies petrochemicals produced at the plants. This sort of payment in kind gives foreign companies a hook into Pemex that has not existed before, business people say.
Two petrochemical plants in mid-construction were completed in this fashion earlier this year, although no deals for new plants have been signed.
 
Exploration Stake Sought
One reason is that foreign oil companies want to tie petrochemical financing to a greater stake in oil exploration, said Gabriel Szekely, associate director of the Center for United States-Mexican Studies in San Diego and a consultant to Pemex and to foreign oil companies.
''They are saying that they should therefore get into the development and pumping of crude with the right to keep some of the oil discovered,'' he said.
Mexican Government officials say that Pemex will not - legally cannot - give ground on so key a tenet of the nationalized oil industry. But the failure to invest significantly in oil exploration has reduced Pemex production from 3 million barrels a day before petroleum prices collapsed in the early 1980's to 2.7 million barrels a day now. Some 1.2 million barrels of this daily production are exported, about half of it to the United States.
With domestic oil consumption rising (Pemex keeps retail gasoline prices at less than 50 cents a gallon) and production falling, many experts say that Mexico will become an oil importer by the end of the century unless more is spent on exploration.
 
A National Irony
Importing oil would be ironic for a country whose oil reserves are roughly equal to those of the United States, according to Joseph Riva, the oil expert at the Congressional Research Office in Washington. The United States produces some 7 million barrels a day and if Mexico were to approach this level over the next decade, it might rival some Middle East countries as a source of supply for the United States.
Despite the march toward a free enterprise strategy, Pemex officials and many Mexicans resist pushing up production beyond the nation's needs and roughly the present export levels. Even the Iraq-Kuwait crisis, with its promise of higher crude oil prices for months to come, does not seem to tempt many Mexicans.
''In the short term, increasing exports of Mexican crude may be beneficial, but in the long term, such exports could eventually harm our country,'' said an editorial in the daily newspaper El Universal that reflected the opinion of some Government officials. ''It would be absurd if future generations of Mexicans had to buy oil overseas, principally from the United States, whose proven reserves will remain more or less intact due to the fact that it is cheaper to buy oil here than to extract it there.''

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Resume Rise as Tensions Grow

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices resumed their climb yesterday, as a nervous market contemplated the continuing loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude, the heightened tensions in the Middle East and a delay by OPEC members in increasing their oil production.
In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil for September delivery closed at $27.36 a barrel yesterday, up 90 cents from Wednesday.
Traders said the market also rose on confusing news about the level of output by Saudi Arabia. The Japanese Foreign Ministry said early yesterday in Tokyo that Saudi Arabia had notified American, European and Japanese oil companies of a 15 to 20 percent planned supply cutback in September, but the Saudis later denied making such a notification. Industry experts said oil jargon might have created the confusion. 
Reassessing the tightening embargo on Iraq and Kuwait, oil company executives and other experts are also concluding that more than the loss of crude is involved; the United States Navy is now also blocking the output of three sophisticated Kuwaiti refineries, which could create further tightness in the market for refined products, especially gasoline. Gasoline may be due for further increases anyway because prices thus far do not fully reflect increased crude costs, oil company executives say.
The rise in oil prices yesterday seemed to indicate a changing mood among traders. Last week and earlier this week, analysts said the absence of major developments in the Persian Gulf contributed to price stability. But now the mood is changing about who would benefit from a status quo, especially since Saudi Arabia has called for, thus far unsuccessfully, a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to permit higher production. Saudia Arabia can produce far more oil, and Venezuela promised to do so, but they want an OPEC agreement first.
Analysts think an OPEC meeting would be exceptionally difficult because it would produce a dispute over who would represent Kuwait, among other problems. The organization met during the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq, but was not able to accomplish much, experts say.
Iran had some extra oil in storage and has been able to move it to market, experts say, but little if any oil from increased production is reaching the market.
''Last week people thought that no news was O.K. news, because there would be good news forthcoming,'' said Cheryl J. Trench of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. ''Now, not only have we not had good news, but we've had little negative pieces that are troubling.''
 
Saudi Request
Two such pieces of news today were a Saudi request for an emergency OPEC meeting, without a date or time being established, and the report of lower Saudi production next month.
Vahan Zanoyan of the Petroelum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington, said the Saudis appeared to have cut ''nominations,'' but not deliveries. Nominations are orders from oil buyers, and they may have risen sharply in recent weeks. Even if the Saudis cut the nominations, the volume of deliveries could still rise from previous levels, he said.
But ''what's dominating the market now is the probabilty of a flare-up,'' Mr. Zanoyan said.
Shahrokh Nikkhah, an oil specialist at Prudential-Bache, said: ''The market obviously believes the only way out of this is a military solution.
''The market is anticipating, if not an all-out military conflict, certainly the potential for some skirmishes, which could lead to acts of terrorism against Saudi facilities, Kuwaiti facilities or even Iraqi facilities.''
While prices may already incorporate the fear of more fighting, they do not approach the levels that would be reached if that fighting occurs, or even if no new production comes into the market, analysts say.
''We are very bullish on this market,'' Mr. Nikkhah said. ''The probability of it going to $32 to $35 a barrel is very, very good.'' With military action, he said, ''the market could spike up substantially higher than $35.''
Lacy H. Hunt, an economist who specializes in oil at Carroll McEntee & McGinley, a government securities dealer, said: ''The longer this drags on, the more it serves to constrict oil supplies. At some point in time, it will be necessary to gradually release supplies from our Strategic Petroleum Reserve, in order to prevent prices from going a lot higher.''
The Bush Administration has thus far resisted that move.
 
Five Million Barrels a Day
Mr. Hunt said that with the current crisis, five million barrels of oil a day had been removed from the world market. That compares with the four million barrels at the time of the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74, and about two million barrels at the time of the Iranian revolution, in 1979.
In addition, he said, the shortfall will be felt more this time because the United States now imports half its oil, up from about 45 percent in 1979, and 35 percent during the Arab embargo.
The American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade association, reported yesterday that imports accounted for 51.3 percent of the oil used in this country in July.
The institute reported deliveries of imported oil had been 6.5 percent higher than in the previous year, but that consumption had probably not grown that much, indicating that users at various levels were accumulating inventory, probably because prices were rising or expected to rise further. The report covers the period before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
Refining at Capacity
The United States imports about 20 percent of its refined products, and domestic refineries are running at virtually full capacity. Experts say that relatively few foreign refineries can make gasoline for export to this country; only half make unleaded fuel, for example, which accounts for about 94 percent of the American market. In addition, wide areas of the United States now require the use of specially formulated fuel with low butane content, to cut air pollution.
Apart from the rise in crude prices, many analysts are predicting that the price of gasoline will rise. A top executive of a leading oil company said yesterday that while his company was selling gasoline for about 10 cents a gallon more in the last six weeks, the cost of its crude oil had gone up about 25 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall To 3-Month Low Point

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market tumbled yesterday to its lowest close in more than three months after being pummeled throughout the day by a worse-than-expected inflation report, falling bond prices, higher oil prices and unsettling news from the Middle East.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.83 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,681.44 - its lowest level since May 1 when it was 2,660.92. The drop was the fourth-biggest one-day decline in points this year.
With yesterday's close, the Dow has retreated more than 10 percent from its peak of 2,999.75 on July 17. Some traders say that when the market pulls back more than 10 percent from its high, it is an indication that the decline could be more than a correction. 
Overseas markets declined as well yesterday. In Tokyo, the Nikkei stock index fell 562.68 points, or 2 percent, to 27,549.44. Japanese stocks continued their retreat today, with the Nikkei dropping 700.58 points, or 2.54 percent, to 26,848.86 by midafternoon. Pressures on Wall St. There were other pressures on Wall Street yesterday morning. The Government reported that the consumer price index had risen a sharply higher-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent in July and that housing starts had fallen 2.6 percent last month.
These reports undermined the bond market, where the price of the benchmark 30-year bond plunged and its yield soared to 8.92 percent, from 8.75 percent on Wednesday. [Page D12.] Investors were also unnerved by higher oil prices and tough talk by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
Volume on the Big Board remained relatively light, with 138.8 million shares traded, compared with 135.2 million on Wednesday.
In the broader market, declines outpaced advances by a ratio of about four to one, with 1,300 falling and 330 gaining. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 7.67 points, to 332.39, and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks fell 9.18 points, to 402.27.
 
'Market Was Disappointed'
''Basically, the market was disappointed over the C.P.I. in the morning, which crept into the market all day, and that did not include data collected before the Iraqi invasion,'' said Ron Schroeder, chief investment officer at J.&W. Seligman & Company. He expects the next consumer price report to be even higher because of the jump in oil prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Mr. Schroeder said the real damage to stocks might have come from the sharp rise in Treasury yields. Higher yields generally encourage investors to move their money to bonds from stocks.
He added that bond yields were likely to remain high. ''The threat of higher inflation and a softer dollar makes it hard for the Federal Reserve to ease,'' he said.
Concern that the Federal Reserve Board would neither be able to reduce interest rates to help avoid a recession or raise them to help fight inflation added more worries to an already unsteady market.
The last time the Dow dropped more than 10 percent was in late 1987, when it fell 12.9 percent from a post-crash high of 2,027.85 on Oct. 21 to a low of 1,766.74 on Dec. 4.
Yesterday, traders reported some futures-related selling after the inflation and housing-starts reports were released.
 
Hussein Depresses Stocks
After a slight recovery in the morning, the market was hit when President Hussein of Iraq indicated that he would not compromise his position in the Middle East. Traders saw this as another sign that there would not be a quick resolution of the crisis.
There was little program trading in advance of today's ''double witching hour.'' The double witching hour, as opposed to a triple witching hour, involves the simultaneous expiration of stock options, stock index options and the major-market index futures. The major-market index is made up of 20 blue-chip issues, but it is not as widely watched as the S.&P. 500. Instead, it is considered confirmation of the Dow because it has 17 of the 30 Dow stocks, including A.T.& T., I.B.M., General Motors, Coca-Cola and General Electric.
Birinyi Associates Inc., which tracks program trades made by large institutions and brokers, reported only three big sell program trades all day. The net total decline in the Dow from the program trades throughout the day was 25.51 points.
Yesterday's low volume magnified the selling pressure, some traders said.
Mr. Schroeder said there could be a bright side to yesterday's activity. ''When the market reacts in the way it did, it does so in a broad-brush way, taking down stocks across the board and creating buying opportunities in certain stocks,'' he said. Among the stocks he mentioned were Dillard Department Stores, which fell 1 3/8, to 82 5/8; Newell, off 7/8, to 26 3/8, and Tyco Laboratories, down 1 1/2, to 54 3/4.
The most-active stock on the Big Board was Ohio Edison, which fell 2 1/2, to 17 3/8, on 2.19 million shares. The utility received a disappointing rate increase from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio.
 
Pharmaceutical Stocks Off
Some pharmaceutical stocks also dropped. Eli Lilly, was down 4 1/8, to 71 1/2, and Merck, was also down 4 1/8, to 83 3/4.
Security Pacific lost 3, to 28 3/4, after the California banking said it was increasing its provisions for loan losses in the second half of the year.
Bankers Trust New York also fell, losing 1 1/4, to 37, after it said its problem loans might continue to rise for the remainder of 1990.
Deere dropped 3 5/8, to 60 5/8, a low for the year amid signs that the farm economy will weaken and hurt the company's core farm-equipment business.
And Hewlett-Packard lost 1 7/8, to 35 7/8, after the electronics company reported worse-than-anticipated earnings.

HEADLINE: Mall Building Has Slowed

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Reflecting a cutback in lending by commercial banks, the number of new shopping-center starts in the United States fell sharply in the first half of 1990, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group based in New York.
The council, which conducts quarterly surveys of its developer members, said that construction of new shopping centers fell 24 percent below the level a year earlier, the worst performance in a decade.
There were 1,529 shopping-center starts in 1989; if the current decline is sustained for the rest of the year, there would be only 1,130 starts in 1990. 
The decline was widespread, with reductions in all parts of the United States. The greatest drop, 28 percent, occurred in the Northeast, which includes the Middle Atlantic States. The other declines were 19 percent in the Midwest; 26 percent in the South, and 22 percent in the West.
In the survey of 450 developers, the council found that 78 percent said the most common problem affecting bank lenders was the inability to obtain construction loans from commercial banks. About 40 percent of all recent credit applications made by the respondents were not approved, the council said.
Developers said that tougher lending agreements and practices were responsible for the financing lag, including demands for excessive documentation, more borrower equity, additional collateral on existing loans, reduced loan amounts and higher fees and interest rates. Banks are refusing to finance joint equity ventures, the council said, renewing or extending existing loans and foreclosing in some cases.
Developers said the banks told them that stricter lending policies were the result of having tougher bank regulators and examiners, new limits on commercial and real estate loans, new capital requirements and bank directors' concerns about personal liability.
Developers said that if these conditions persisted into 1991, they were concerned there would be layoffs, corporate restructurings, discontinued operations and abandoned projects.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ames Will Close Office in Syracuse

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Ames Department Stores Inc. said it would close its regional accounting office here in a companywide plan to consolidate jobs and cut costs. The closing of the Ames downtown Syracuse office will put nearly 160 people out of work, a company spokesman, Bill Roberts, said. 
Ames filed for Chapter 11 protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Code in April, just two years after acquiring the Zayre discount store chain. Zayre had an accounting operation in Syracuse. Ames decided to move some of its operations from its headquarters in Rocky Hill, Conn., to Syracuse. Those responsibilities will now be shifted back to Rocky Hill. Mr. Roberts said probably fewer than 10 jobs would be transferred to Rocky Hill. Most of the jobs in the accounting office are clerical. Ames plans to close 221 stores nationwide in the consolidation.

HEADLINE: Hewlett In Move To France

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16

 BODY:
In a move reflecting the growing importance of the European market, the Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it was moving the headquarters of its personal computer group from Sunnyvale, Calif., to Grenoble, France.
Hewlett-Packard also reported declining earnings today for its third quarter. Shares in the company, which were already depressed in anticipation of a disappointing quarter, dropped $1.875, closing at $35.875 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 
Official Appointed
Along with the move to France, Hewlett-Packard announced that Jacques A. Clay, who is currently general manager of the Grenoble personal computer division, has been appointed general manager of the personal computer group. Mr. Clay, who is 47 years old, succeeds Robert L. Puette, who left Hewlett-Packard in late June to become president of Apple Computer Inc.'s U.S.A. division.
Mr. Clay joined the company in 1973. A native of France, he has a marketing degree from Ecole Superieur Commerce in Lyons, France, and a bachelor's degree in law from Grenoble University. He has held various management positions in Grenoble and Sunnyvale.
''Currently, international markets represent more than half of Hewlett-Packard's sales of PC's and terminals and have great potential for expansion,'' Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's executive vice president and head of the company's computer products sector, said in a statement. ''As such, it is quite opportune to have an international PC group headquarters.''
Hewlett-Packard has a more dominant position in the European PC market than in the United States, Mr. Clay said in a telephone interview. ''HP has been in Europe 30 years and we have been very active in the PC business since the early 80's, so we were one of the first entrants there,'' he said. Because of this lead, ''we were able to get substantial market share.''
Europe has always played a countercyclical role to the United States computer market, because it typically trails both the up and down swings in the United States economy. In addition, ''Europe right now is a little more attractive because of the investments pouring in,'' in anticipation of the removal of trade barriers in 1992 and opportunities stemming from the opening of Eastern Europe, Mr. Clay said.
 
Regional Headquarters
The personal computer group will keep its four regional headquarters in Grenoble, Sunnyvale, Singapore and Guadalajara, Mexico. The regional headquarters will all retain their present management, the company said. Mr. Clay will head both the worldwide and European PC operations.
The naming of Grenoble as group headquarters will not involve increasing the company's work force in Europe. The company has 4,000 workers in France.
Hewlett-Packard has two industrial sites in the Grenoble region that produce personal computers, terminals and cardiology equipment. Grenoble also distributes all Hewlett-Packard PC's sold in Europe and conducts research and development on PC's.
''International growth will be the geographic area where all domestic, European and Asian PC companies get the most bang for their buck in terms of ability to sell volume,'' said David Korus, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody. ''Hewlett, with a less intensive retail scheme in the United States than some of the others, would like to maximize their presence in Europe, where they can get the most return,'' he said.
Although most analysts anticipated a disappointing quarter for Hewlett-Packard, the company's revenues and earnings still fell below estimates. In addition, the company expressed caution about the prospects for growth in coming quarters.
For the quarter ended July 31, Hewlett-Packard had earnings of $178 million, or 73 cents a share, down 4.8 percent from $187 million, or 79 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fell 2.6% in July

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Construction of new homes fell for the sixth straight month in July, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said today.
Housing starts fell 2.6 percent last month from June and were 19.4 percent lower than in July 1989, the Commerce Department said.
Building of single-family homes fell 1.4 percent last month, while apartment building was down 6.5 percent, the department said. 
 
Below Expectations
Total housing starts dropped to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million units in July, from 1.18 million in June. Economists had expected a rise to a rate of 1.19 million units.
The last time housing starts were lower was nearly eight years ago, in September 1982, when starts were at a rate of 1.14 million a year.
Industry analysts, who had predicted a slight rise in building activity last month, said it appeared the industry's hopes were falling victim to a gradually deteriorating economy.
''It looks like housing is performing a fairly classic role of leading us into a recession,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders.
''There's not even a potential bright development,'' Mr. Seiders said, citing rising unemployment and an expected rise in inflation that will further shrink the buying power of potential home buyers. ''We're sort of surrounded,'' he said.
Analysts said the decline was a result of tight credit for builders, mortgage rates above 10 percent and the economic uncertainty that is making consumers wary of big new financial responsibilities.
Not since the June-to-November period of 1981 has home construction fallen for six consecutive months, department officials said.
 
Downturn Is Widespread
The weakness was widespread geographically. Housing starts were lower everywhere except in the West, where they rose 8.2 percent. They fell 5.3 percent in the Northeast, 5.5 percent in the Midwest and 6.7 percent in the South.
Even the normally optimistic National Association of Realtors sounded gloomy today.
John Tuccillo, the group's chief economist, said building was being choked off by tighter lending. He also said demand from buyers was fading. ''People simply are uncertain about what lies ahead, and they are pulling out of the market,'' he said.
 
No Sign of Upturn
Building permits, an indicator of future activity, fell 2.6 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.08 million, after rising 4 percent in June.
Construction of single-family homes fell in July by 1.4 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 873,000 units, after falling by 1.3 percent in June.
Construction of apartment buildings fell by 6.5 percent, to a rate of 275,000 units, after a 4.9 percent drop in June.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Surge to Three-Month High

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices plummeted yesterday and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels since early May, as traders reacted with alarm to a disappointing report on inflation and heightened tensions in the Middle East.
The inflation report showed that the Consumer Price Index had risen four-tenths of 1 percent in July. Even though the figure was only slightly higher than expected, market participants were disturbed by it because, excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, the core inflation rate had risen six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Worse, the recent sharp rise in oil prices since the beginning of August is almost certain to push the overall inflation rate higher in coming months. 
 
'Some Bad News Ahead'
''Over time, I think the oil price shock will be deflationary, because it is having an adverse effect on purchasing power,'' said Joseph Carson, a senior economist at the Chemical Bank. ''But in the next few months there is some bad news ahead for consumer prices. An increase of seven-tenths of a percentage point in the index for August is something that could be easily attained.''
Yesterday's inflation report appears to reduce the likelihood that the Federal Reserve Board will move soon to lower short-term interest rates, traders and analysts said.
Bond prices softened considerably after the consumer price numbers were released in the morning. And they plummeted later in the day after highly bellicose statements from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq flashed across trading screens. The situation was made even gloomier by reports that 2,500 Americans in Kuwait had been ordered to by Iraqi authorities to gather in the Kuwait Hotel to protect them against ''unspecified threats.''
''The market was on the defensive to begin with,'' after the inflation statistics were released, said James R. Capra, senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''The Iraqi developments only made matters worse.''
 
Bonds Fall More Than 1 1/2 Points
The gloom and confusion was most readily reflected in the price of long-term Treasury bonds. But short-term interest rates also surged.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 1/4, down more than 1 1/2 points, or more than $15 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.92 percent, up sharply from 8.75 percent late Wednesday. It is the highest yield on the benchmark bond in more than three months.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year Treasury notes were offered at 99 27/32, down 30/32, to yield 8.77 percent. The 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, down 5/8, to yield 8.45 percent. And the 8 percent two-year notes fell 9/32, to a late offered price of 99 27/32, to yield 8.08 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates also moved up. Three-month bills were offered in late trading at a discount rate of 7.48 percent, up 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates, meanwhile, rose by 12 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.45 percent. One-year bills rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.30 percent.
 
Federal Funds Rate Rises
The session was also marked by a rise in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, but analysts said the increase was largely a result of technical difficulties associated with the fire in downtown Manhattan on Monday rather than any change in Fed policy.
''I think the Fed's operations each day this week have made it clear that this has nothing to do with a policy change,'' said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation.
During the day, the Federal funds rate moved in an unusually wide range of 8 5/8 percent to 8 1/8 percent, well above the 8 percent rate that is considered to be the Fed's target.
In the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices also took a beating. Corporate bond traders said prices of most actively quoted issues fell by as much as 1 1/4 points, but added that trading was light. And prices of most municipal bonds fell by 3/4 point to a full point, traders said.
 
Security Pacific's Offering
Among new issues, the Security Pacific Corporation offered $100 million in three-year senior notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 8.85 percent notes, which mature Aug. 15, 1993, were priced at $99.955 to yield 8.867 percent, 67 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Aug. 6. The report had no noticeable effect on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at an All-Time Low Against Mark in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled to an all-time low against the German mark during domestic trading as heightened tensions in the Middle East and signs of United States economic weakness spurred a wave of selling.
The dollar was quoted at 1.5525 marks in late New York trading, down from 1.566 marks late Wednesday and from 1.5645 marks Tuesday, the previous low in the modern mark's 42-year history.
The dollar was also sharply lower against the Swiss franc and British pound. The pound rose to $1.9095 in New York, from $1.9090 late Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.8985, from $1.9045 late Wednesday. 
''As long as the U.S. is involved in this crisis I think we're going to find that the dollar is not the safe haven it once was during international crises,'' said Scott Horwitz, a vice president for foreign exchange trading with Bank of Boston.
After rising in overseas trading, traders sold heavily in New York after a fiery speech by Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, that offered little hope of a quick end to the standoff over the invasion of Kuwait.
That normally would support the dollar, but the weak state of the U.S. economy has overwhelmed the currency's traditional attractiveness as a haven during times of international turmoil.
A Government report that consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July added to pessimism about the economy's course and contributed to the selloff.
''Even though the tension may have escalated in the gulf, the market is focusing on two trajectories in the U.S. economy - weaker growth and higher inflation,'' said Marc Chandler, a currency analyst with MMS International in Chicago.
In New York, the dollar fell to 147.25 Japanese yen, from 147.65 yen late Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo, it rose to 147.90 Japanese yen from 147.15 yen at Wednesday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted at 147.62 yen.
Other dollar rates as of 4 P.M. in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.2915 Swiss francs, down from 1.30735; 5.2220 French francs, down from 5.2570; 1,143.25 Italian lire, down from 1,149.75, and 1.14815 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14345.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.5630 German marks, up from 1.5605; 1.3025 Swiss francs, up from 1.3005; 5.2495 French francs, up from 5.2365; 1.7610 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7579; 1,149.75 Italian lire, up from 1,145.75, and 1.1477 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1435.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Are Up Sharply As Investors Seek Security

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The prices of gold futures surged yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as developments in the Persian Gulf initiated a rally in oil prices, a dive in the stock market and a renewal of inflation fears.
On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures were mixed, while grains and soybeans also finished mixed.
Gold futures settled $6.20 to $6.90 higher, with the contract for spot August delivery up $6.60 at $409.20 an ounce. Silver was 9.9 cents to 10 cents higher, with the spot August contract at $5.168 an ounce. 
The perceived safety of precious metals lured investors from the stock market as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq unleased new demands.
The crisis in the Middle East has given gold a shot in the arm, but Fred Demler, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. in New York, said he was optimistic on gold, based on the market's factors of supply and demand, even before Iraq invaded Kuwait slightly more than two weeks ago.
''Once the Mideast situation blows over, we think there will be a setback in gold prices, but then we think they'll strengthen again based on other fundamentals,'' he said.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, livestock and meat futures were mixed, as cattle traders evened up their positions before today's monthly cattle-on-feed report is released by the Agriculture Department.
The report is expected to show active placements of cattle onto feedlots and active marketings off feedlots last month.
Live cattle settled 0.10 cent lower to 0.12 cent higher, with the August contract at 78.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.05 cent lower to 0.20 cent higher, with August at 89.97 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.10 cent lower to 0.70 cent higher, with August at 57.57 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to 0.05 cent higher, with August at 48.95 cents a pound.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain and soybean contracts ended narrowly mixed in lackluster trading as buying prompted by Middle East tensions offset selling pressure stemming in part from forecasts for good growing weather in the Midwest during the latter half of next week.

HEADLINE: Study Finds the U.S. Lags In Communications Goods

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A study of the nation's telecommunications equipment industry, released yesterday by the Commerce Department, has found that the United States is no longer competitive in markets for consumer products like telephones and facsimile machines and is losing ground in markets for business and telephone company equipment.
For the last five years, the United States has run an annual trade deficit in telecommunications equipment of about $2 billion. The study cited data that blamed an inadequate American educational system, a failure of American companies to incorporate technical breakthroughs into products quickly and the relatively high cost of raising money in the United States. 
Foreign market barriers to imports and foreign governments' subsidies to domestic producers have also hurt American equipment producers, the study said.
 
Antitrust Review Urged
The study called for a review of the application of antitrust laws to American telecommunications companies and recommended that the research and development tax credit be made permanent.
But the most serious problem appears to be a growing shortage of qualified workers, said Janice Obuchowski, the Assistant Secretary for Communications and Information. ''It's not clear that we're going to be able to sustain our strength unless we turn around our educational system,'' she said.
For example, the New York Telephone Company said it tested 57,000 job applicants in 1987 and found that 54,900, or 96.3 percent, lacked basic skills in math, reading and reasoning.
Congress ordered the Commerce Department to perform the study when it passed the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988. James W. McConnaughey, a senior economist from the department's National Telecommunications and Information Administration, managed the project.
 
No Innovative Conclusions
The study did not reach any innovative conclusions, but did provide large quantities of data to document the conventional wisdom about declining American competitiveness, Mr. McConnaughey said. ''Instead of talking in glittering generalities, I think we've got some specifics,'' he said.
From 1984 to 1987, the American share of the world market for voice-grade corporate switchboards fell from 29 percent to 26 percent, the study said, while the share of data-grade switchboards plummeted to 36 percent from 100 percent, as European and Japanese companies entered the market.
The American share of the fiber-optic equipment market dropped to 50 percent from 75 percent in the period while the share of modems for sending information between computers fell to 37 percent from 49 percent.
American companies performed best in sales of central office switching equipment, which was a $6 billion market in the United States last year.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BUSH SAID TO APPROVE PLAN TO ACTIVATE SOME RESERVES; U.S. TAKING OVER 38 AIRLINERS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to call up a limited number of military reservists because of the Middle East crisis, Administration officials said today, and the Pentagon commandeered 38 wide-body jets from 16 airlines to carry troops and cargo to the region.
As the emergency entered its third week, the United Nations Security Council expressed ''concern and anxiety'' about hundreds of thousands of foreigners, including 3,000 Americans, who are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, with evidence mounting that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq may plan to intern them.
The Speaker of the Iraqi Parliament, Sadi Mahdi, said today that Baghdad would not permit foreigners from ''aggressive nations'' to leave Iraq as long as it was threatened with war, the official Iraqi press agency reported. Mr. Mahdi said that Westerners would be moved to vital oil and military installations in Iraq and in occupied Kuwait.
As the American military deployment continued, allies like Japan, West Germany and France debated how far they should go in their involvement in the gulf conflict. [Page 6.] 
 
2 Iraqi Vessels Detained Two United States Navy ships, the guided missile cruiser England and the frigate Bradley, detained a pair of Iraqi coastal vessels in the gulf, but they were found to be empty and were permitted to proceed toward Iraq, the Pentagon said.
The two vessels were the first intercepted by American sailors during the first 24 hours of the official naval blockade, but they were not boarded.
Mr. Bush, who is back at his vacation home at Kennebunkport, Me., is expected to sign orders soon calling military reservists to active duty for service in the Persian Gulf or at home.
One official said that the number would probably not exceed 2,500 or 3,000, at least at first, and would be composed mainly of cargo handlers, medical teams and other specialists, but he cautioned that details were still under study.
Other Pentagon aides have said the total might reach 80,000, including members of the Army, Navy and Air Force reserves. Up to 200,000 of the nation's 1.6 million reservists are legally subject to immediate Presidential activation.
 
Cheney Sees 'Long' Stay
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney suggested today while en route to Saudi Arabia that the American troop commitment there would be ''long,'' perhaps lasting years.
The decision to take over the airliners, under a program known as the Civil Reserve Air Fleet, which had never been used before in its 30 or so years of existence, suggested that the Pentagon intended to speed up the already fast-paced deployment.
Pentagon officials who disclosed the decision said the airlines involved have only 24 hours to deliver the planes to staging points.
For the second time in less than a week, Saudi Arabia turned away an Iraqi tanker trying to reach the Red Sea oil terminal at Yanbu to break the international trade embargo, and American warships were tracking another Iraqi merchant ship, apparently laden with food, in the Red Sea not far from Jordan's port of Aqaba.
The American ships are enforcing an embargo on all shipments to or from Iraq, including food. Under the United Nations sanctions, there is an exemption on ''supplies intended strictly for medical purposes and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs.''
 
In a Famine, Policy Changes
White House officials have conceded that changes in American policy would be needed if widespread famine developed in Iraq, but they argue that this would be well into the future.
Jordan, through which large amounts of grain and other foods have been passing to Iraq during the last two weeks, has asked for a clarification on food, which a special United Nations committee is to provide on a case-by-case basis.
Jordan is also seeking relief under a provision in the United Nations Charter that gives countries the right to seek aid if they are ''confronted with special economic problems'' arising from their application of sanctions.
After an informal meeting convened at Britain's request, the Security Council voted to ask Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to take whatever steps he considers appropriate to free the foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait.
 
U.N. Chief Urged to Act
Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative, said that Mr. Perez de Cuellar ''should become immediately engaged in this humanitarian crisis.''
American policy-makers said any attempt to rescue the ''restrictees,'' as Iraq calls them, would be tactically all but impossible, given the large number of people involved and the strength of Iraqi defenses. But they expressed bitter frustration over inability to visit or even find 35 Americans who were moved from the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad during the night.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said the 35 were probably taken to another hotel. But the Administration was unable to discover exactly which one, although the State Department said it might be the Melia-Mansour Hotel. Mr. Fitzwater said there were some indications that the Iraqis wanted to keep the Americans away from correspondents.
Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, bluntly described the 3,000 Americans and 3,400 Britons who have been detained as ''hostages'' whom the Iraqis intended to use ''as pawns in their game.'' For the time being, at least, ''we're going to have to live with that,'' he said.
Iraq's public comments on the foreigners have been inconsistent. Earlier this week, the Foreign Ministry said the foreigners would not be free to leave until the crisis ended, but Iraq's Ambassador in Washington, Mohammed al-Mashat said: ''They are not restricted at all, and will be allowed to leave in good time.''
 
Foreigners Cross Desert
Three Americans and six other foreigners, who feared being forcibly rounded up in Kuwait after Baghdad issued an order for them to gather at a seafront hotel, disguised themselves as Arabs, climbed into a pair of Land-Rovers and drove in a 13-vehicle caravan through the desert into Saudi Arabia today.
Mary Rindzius, who is from California, dyed her blond hair black to help avoid arousing suspicion.
''As soon as we left the paved road, we ran into Iraqis and they said we had to go back,'' said Stephanie McGehee, an Arabic-speaking photographer for The Associated Press. ''We moved away, then took another turn through the desert and made a dash for it. It was very, very terrifying.''
President Bush reacted in measured tones, telling reporters as he began a round of golf at Kennebunkport: ''I don't think that anybody ought to be moved against their will in contravention of international law.''
 
New Yorkers Talk Tough
Two New York Democrats used much tougher talk.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said that if Mr. Hussein chose ''to show his contempt for the the laws protecting civilians, he will surely reap the whirlwind to follow.'' Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, speaking in Israel, said that if any American was ''brutalized or tortured or killed'' the United States would retaliate ''in a way that will result in the destruction of the military and economic infrastructure of Iraq'' - presumably meaning that the United States would bomb Baghdad and other targets.
Mr. Cheney set out for Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to visit American troops amid signs that the United States was building considerable offensive capacity into its huge military deployment to the Middle East, which President Bush has described as ''entirely defensive'' in character.
 
Stealth Aircraft and B-52's
The deployment of F-117 Stealth aircraft, as well as B-52's, the assignment of highly mobile marine forces and the presence of landing craft all suggested that Mr. Bush wanted to keep open the option of moving into Kuwait with force if economic sanctions failed to dislodge the Iraqis.
Baghdad taunted American troops in Saudi Arabia today, telling them in English-language broadcasts that they would be swallowed up the shifting desert sands.
Japan was reported to be pondering the dispatch of minesweepers to join the international armada in the Gulf.
The Soviet Union said it would send troops if the United Nations called for military action, and in New York, a special committee met to discuss compliance with trade sanctions.
Ultimately, the committee could move toward imposing a United Nations blockade to enforce them and could even send troops. For the moment, only the United States and Britain, citing a self-defense request from the exiled Government of Kuwait, have ships on blockade duty.
The Pentagon's decision to use commercial aircraft means that 38 planes, divided between passenger and cargo jets, will be pulled out of regular commercial service. Because vacation travel is at a peak, most of the long-range jumbo jets pulled from passenger service were fully booked, and airline officials said some flights would be canceled. But they said that passengers would be transferred to other aircraft or to other airlines.
