PUB-DATE: August 18, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1070 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
For Iranians, a Windfall

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
As a result of Iraq's surprise offer this week to meet Iran's terms for a peace treaty, Teheran faces one of the most fundamental questions of its 1979 Islamic revolution - whether to use its new position of strength to weaken Iraq or to join with it to push the United States, their common enemy, out of the region?
The answer is: Iran doesn't have to do anything. It gains the most by simply letting the crisis in the gulf run its course.
''Iran's best policy is to sit on the sidelines, get its peace treaty, wait for the Arabs to fight it out and hope in the end that Saddam will be humiliated and the foreign forces will leave,'' said Shaul Bakhash, a historian who has written extensively about Iran. 
Since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq seems to be gambling that peace with his onetime archenemy will remove a possibility that Iran will mass troops on his border. He would then be free to transfer military units to the Saudi front to face forces deployed by foreign nations, including the United States. A Way to Evade Sanctions? President Hussein may even have hoped that Iran, in return for regaining its territory, its prisoners and an accord on the vital Shatt al Arab waterway, would help Iraq evade the world trade embargo.
Today, as a first gesture, Iraq sent 1,000 Iranian prisoners of war home and began pulling back some troops from Iran territory along the border.
In the aftermath of the devastating earthquake this summer near the Caspian Sea, Iran is not in a military mood. Its five-year economic plan includes little spending to rebuild the armed forces.
Even a limited buildup of Iranian troops along the border would not have constituted a serious threat to Iraq.
As for a trade embargo, the issue is not whether there will be trade between the two countries but rather how much.
 
Trade Even During War
Trade is controlled not by the politicians in Teheran but by merchants along the border. Even at the height of hostilities in the eight-year war, carpets, livestock and food flowed freely into Iraq and consumer goods moved into Iran, mostly at night through the mountains of Kurdistan.
Other goods were transshipped through Dubai and other ports. Even Turkey, with its superior border controls, finds it difficult to block traditional smuggling routes along the long border with Iraq.
Iran has little to gain and much to lose by forging an alliance with Iraq and violating the embargo. Massive amounts of food and other consumer goods on cross-border highways might bring Iran hundreds of millions of dollars, but that is a tiny amount compared to what it could get out by selling its cooperation to the rest of the world.
Iran has already indicated that it would welcome the kind of help the Arab nations provided to Iraq during its war with Iran.
Just days after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, traveled to Oman and other small gulf states with an offer of cooperation in exchange for financial assistance.
Iran could also use the crisis to repair its severely damaged ties with Saudi Arabia.
 
Inducements for Embargo
''Iran might find itself in a position to bargain with countries that will say, 'Maybe Iran will break the embargo so let's ask Iran what it will need to keep the embargo on,' '' said Gary Sick, a former official at the National Security Council, who is writing a book on U.S.-Iranian relations.
At home, the burning issue for Iranian leaders is the importance of economic reconstruction and the establishment of better economic ties with the industrialized world.
Iranian leaders, particularly President Hashemi Rafsanjani, would oppose any attempt to sabotage Iran's five-year plan, which depends on $28 billion in foreign borrowing.
Since the plan was approved in January, Iran has assiduously courted possible lenders. Early this year, for example, it held preliminary talks with the International Monetary Fund, for the first time since the 1979 Islamic revolution, and received a World Bank mission to discuss borrowing for construction and social projects.
 
Japan's Aid Sought for Dam
Just last month, Iran requested Japanese participation in financing a $3.5-billion dam on the Karun River.
Certainly, Iran and Iraq share interests that could be exploited to the advantage of each. Both countries are eager to see the withdrawal of American forces from the region.
Iran wants to conclude a peace treaty with Iraq and will readily embrace President Hussein's proposal if it does not come with strings attached. The last few months have witnessed open cooperation between the two countries on higher oil prices.
But the goals of Baghdad and Teheran are linked only up to a point. Animosity between the two countries runs deep, largely a result of the eight years of fighting that killed more than a million people. The Teheran leadership would find it difficult to explain a policy of accommodation to its people.
Over the long run, it is not in Iran's strategic interest to strengthen Iraq or its control over occupied Kuwait.
Despite a promise by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died in 1989, to throw the ruling families of the gulf states into ''the dustbin of history,'' Iran is more interested in the territorial integrity of the region, and Mr. Rafsanjani has called on Iraq to ''evacuate Kuwaiti territory.''
 
'Struggle for Dominance'
''Iran is engaged in a permanent geopolitical struggle for dominance in the gulf and anything that threatens it is unacceptable,'' said Graham Fuller, former vice chairman of the National Intelligence Council at the Central Intelligence Agency. ''It doesn't want to see Iraq permanently strenghtened by the acquisition of Kuwait's oil wealth.''
Part of that struggle is Iran's desire to end intervention in the gulf, and leaders in Teheran have already called for a withdrawal of all foreign forces.
But Iranian leaders must know that an alliance of convenience with Iraq to push American and other forces out of the gulf could backfire.
Iraq's determination to hold on to annexed Kuwait will prolong the presence of foreign forces in the region rather than send them away.
Besides, it would be difficult for Iran to calibrate such an alliance so that it would be just strong enough to maintain the crisis at its present level but weak enough to keep President Hussein under control.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Energy Policy Trade-Off;
Dependency Is Price Of Years of Cheap Oil

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In the spring of 1986, George Bush traveled to Saudi Arabia to plead with the world's biggest oil exporter to stop flooding the market. Mr. Bush told the Saudis that their overproduction, by driving down the price, was jeopardizing the American oil industry, in turn undermining the nation's economic strength and security.
Now, President Bush finds himself imploring the Saudis to raise production by about 35 percent, or two million barrels a day.
Both pleas were probably well advised in the circumstances, many energy specialists believe. What the about-face in the United States' position underscores is the extent to which American policy sought to take advantage of an oversupply of oil to keep prices down - at the cost of a higher level of dependence on imported oil.
 
Relying on Foreign Oil
Before the latest round of increases that followed Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, a gallon of gasoline cost less, adjusted for inflation, than at any time in the last 30 years. At the same time, the United States' dependence on imported oil has grown to slightly more than 50 percent of consumption. 
In deciding to pursue a laissez-faire policy that had the benefit of stimulating economic growth, the United States relied heavily on an economic analysis that ignores the political instability of the Middle East, where world reserves are concentrated. But Adam Smith's economics breaks down when confronted by the barrel of a gun.
While the Reagan Administration did build a stratetgic stockpile of oil, many critics contend that its overall policy allowed the country to forget various hard-won lessons from the 1970's.
''We fell into a dangerous complacency as oil moved into ample supply and prices tumbled,'' said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International and a high-ranking State Department economic official during the Reagan Administration. ''We assumed the problems of the 1970's were permanently behind us.''
Heavy-handed Government intervention has been largely discredited, with widespread agreement that the Government's price and allocation controls were responsible for gasoline lines in the 1970's. The Reagan Administration veered to the other pole. Eight days after his inauguration, Mr. Reagan lifted all remaining price controls on oil and began a policy under which the United States, the world's biggest oil consumer, relied almost exclusively on unfettered market forces to direct supply and demand.
Subsidies for synthetic fuels disappeared; consumption taxes were shunned; conservation was played down; ration coupons were destroyed.
Critics predicted that decontrol would unleash huge price increases -and the Government enacted what became known as a windfall profits tax to capture the anticipated revenue. But instead, prices promptly sank, a sustained 65 percent decline that brought oil briefly below $10 a barrel in 1986 before prices rebounded to the teens.
Consumers and politicians found it appealing for the world to be awash in inexpensive oil, and they also enjoyed the lingering benefits of the era of expensive oil. These included new oil from producers outside OPEC and various increases in oil-use efficiency. Indeed, the low-priced oil helped propel an expansion of the American economy that is now in its eighth year, a peacetime record.
 
Cannot Compete Successfully
But an almost exclusive reliance on the free market came up against a major obstacle, one quite apart from guns. It is the geologically grounded fact that the United States, even with sophisticated technology, cannot compete successfully in the oil business with countries whose fields are vastly bigger and whose production costs are only a few dollars a barrel.
''For the last decade we have allowed market forces to determine energy outcomes,'' said James R. Schlesinger, a former Energy Secretary. ''But since the U.S. is the highest- cost producer in the world - the comparative advantage lying elsewhere -this has caused a steady decline in U.S. production.''
The drop in domestic production has been 19 percent in the last five years and 24 percent from the record 9.6 million barrels a day in 1970. The United States, with Alaska's North Slope now past its peak, produced at a daily rate of 7.3 million barrels in the first half of this year, only half its consumption.
With foreign oil cheap and plentiful, there was progressively little incentive for Americans to produce more - or consume less. While some measures raising energy efficiency, like higher standards for home insulation, remain in place, relatively little attention is paid to curbing oil demand. Big cars, in fact, have made a comeback.
Reflecting a 75 percent drop in exploration since the early 1980's, as measured by the number of rigs in operation, much of the domestic oil industry's equipment is stacked up and much of its expertise scattered.
Synthetic fuels programs withered because falling prices required ever- higher subsidies. And when marine oil spills resulted in stepped-up demands by environmentalists for moratoriums on drilling or production in certain areas, there was little political counterweight.
At the moment, for example, the 90,000-barrel-a-day Point Arguello field off the California coast cannot be tapped because state and local permits have not been issued. Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, calls the situation ''a little awkward'' at a time when the United States is pressing other countries to increase their production.
The main visible oil initiative of the Reagan Administration was to fill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which now holds 590 million barrels of oil and which could within a month pump out some 3.5 million barrels a day.
 
Policy Called Ineffective
''The Administration's oil policy has been to enhance energy security while maintaining economic competitiveness and environmental quality,'' the Energy Department declared in a 1988 review. But critics contend the policy amounts to little more than an ineffective blend of ideology and expediency within a political system in which there are 43 states that consume more oil than they produce.
''There is no policy, of course,'' declared James E. Akins, a political and economic consultant and former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. For all its failings, the Carter Administration's energy program, he said, at least had the right goal - ''to decrease our dependence on imported oil.''
The Bush Administration, which in July 1989 began a study of the nation's energy situation that is due on the President's desk in December, has found no need to draw on the strategic reserve in response to the Iraqi invasion. No shortages have yet emerged, the price of oil is still moderate by the standards of the last 15 years and the Administration, in any event, is disinclined to tamper with the market.
Yet Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore acknowledged in an interview this week, ''It's been rather easy for the country to sit back and let our growing energy problem continue to get worse.'' He said Mr. Bush's energy agenda would not be the same as Ronald Reagan's.
While what Mr. Moore described as the Reagan policy of ''let the market do it'' was not being repudiated, there have been renewed Government efforts to supplement market forces, he said.
''Already you've seen an activism,'' Mr. Moore said, ''to use the Department of Energy as a bully pulpit'' to explain the energy facts of life and to build support for the inevitably hard decisions that will flow from the emerging study of national energy strategy.
The department, in offering some preliminary ideas this week, mentioned such demand-side palliatives as pumping up underinflated tires, strictly observing speed limits, car pooling, driving the more fuel-efficient car when there is a choice and making it easier for industry to switch fuels, such as from oil to natural gas.
Some analysts insist on stronger measures. Peter G. Peterson, a private banker and former Commerce Secretary, characterized the 1980's as a ''period of lethargy'' and ''costless choices'' and said one answer was taxes.
''I don't think there's any doubt that we should have had a substantial energy-consumption tax,'' Mr. Peterson said. Not only would it have cut imports and aided the environment, such a tax would also have substantially reduced the budget deficit, he said.
Others favor an import fee, which would also have the effect of raising the world price of oil, aiding domestic producers. There is also growing talk of a ''carbon tax'' on all forms of polluting fuels.
But whatever the remedy, declared Charles Ebinger, a consultant with the International Resources Group here, ''We've got to get some kind of consensus that energy is indeed a strategic issue.'' He said consumers must also be weaned from a misplaced sense of entitlement that fostered a belief that energy should be abundant and cheap.

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT LOWEST IN 7 YEARS

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit narrowed a surprising 35 percent in June, to $5.07 billion, its lowest level in seven years. Exports surged to a record and a slowing economy at home cut imports sharply. But economists expect rising oil prices and other factors to push the deficit back up again.
The shrinking of the trade gap was a generally positive report at a time the Bush Administration and analysts are worried about the economy. The nation is near or in a recession, economists say, and the surge in oil prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is expected to push inflation, already near 6 percent, even higher.
The rise in exports, some economists said yesterday, helped to keep the economy above water. But the sharp decline in spending for imports was seen by some as a sign that the already weak economy could succumb when the oil price shock begins to filter through. 
 
No Help for Stocks
The news did not help the financial markets because the crisis in the Persian Gulf, rising oil prices and the fear of a recession are the driving forces these days. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.64 points, to 2,644.80. The dollar also fell, although a smaller trade deficit is usually positive news for the currency. And the bond market was stable, torn between worries about inflation and the prospect of lower interest rates if there is a recession.
Roger E. Brinner, chief economist at Data Resources Inc. in Massachusetts, said the overall report from the Commerce Department was positive: ''These figures say that if we hadn't had the Iraqi invasion and the threat to consumer confidence, this economy could have escaped a recession.'' But, he added, he now thought that economic growth would begin to decline, starting the first recession in nine years.
''I take it negatively,'' Michael J. Drury, senior economist at the Boston Company Economic Advisers in Boston. ''The numbers suggest that the economy is in trouble,'' he said, referring to the import decline.
But Ara Jelalian, the international economist at the First Boston Corporation in Chicago, said the rise in exports gave him more data for his forecast that the economy will avoid a recession. ''We can still count on foreign growth even if the consumer pulls back,'' he said.
 
A More Difficult Task
While the concern about a recession is growing, the combination of a rise in exports and a decline in domestic demand produces the slower overall economic growth that the Federal Reserve has sought in its effort to bring down inflation. The sudden rise in oil prices, because it both adds to inflation and cuts growth, has made the central bank's job much more difficult and the formula less palatable.
For the first half of the year, the American trade deficit is now $45.8 billion, or about $91 billion at an annual rate. If the deficit comes in at that level for the year, it would be about $18 billion lower than in 1989 and represent another significant step toward taming the nation's troublesome trade deficit.
But because of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq and the resulting jump in oil prices, which are now up 64 percent since Aug 1., the trade deficit figures for July onward should be higher. Economists said, however, that the increase from oil is not expected now to push the trade deficit higher than $100 billion for the year.
Several economists said yesterday that this oil-induced growth in the trade deficit should not be taken as a negative. They said they expect the non-oil portion of the trade deficit, which is now down significantly from last year, to continue declining.
This deficit averaged $5 billion a month in 1989 and fell to around $3.5 billion the first five months of this year. It was $1.4 billion in June. And it is this deficit that economists take as a measure of America's competitiveness abroad and the ability of the country's exporters to continue providing the economy with growth as demand declines at home.
In addition to oil price increases, analysts said the trade deficit could be pushed up in the next months because the jump in exports in June depended on sectors that can be volatile, in this case airplanes, food, feeds and beverages.
The rise in exports in June, by $1.5 billion, to a record $34.3 billion, showed that the economy was much stronger at the end of the second quarter than recent economic data had shown and that this sector was still providing the economy with some life. Mr. Brinner and Mr. Jelalian said the export increase combined with the decline in imports, which were both unexpected, would force the Commerce Department to raise the 1.2 percent growth rate for the economy in the second quarter to 1.5 percent to 2 percent.
 
Sign of a Slowdown
At the same time, the decline in imports, which fell by $1.2 billion, to $39.4 billion, was seen as another sign that the economy was slowing down. Half the decline was in lower oil imports at lower prices than in May. Some economists said the oil decline should not be counted when estimating the weakness of the economy because the numbers can be volatile. But Mr. Drury noted that the decline in non-oil imports was still sharp.
Mr. Brinner said he thought that the future impact of the oil price rise alone, which would curtail economic growth by reducing discretionary spending, would not be enough to send the economy into a recession. But he said the increase had also hurt consumer confidence, making people less willing to spend. ''The direct impact of higher oil prices we could absorb,'' he said. ''But if you add to it a loss of confidence of the consumer that lasts through the fall, we have a recession.''
The deficit for June, on a seasonally adjusted basis, fell $2.7 billion, from $7.77 billion in May. This was the lowest level for the deficit since the $3.96 billion deficit in June 1983.
Of the $1.5 billion rise in exports, 62 percent, or $922.7 million, came from sales of airplanes, computers and spacecraft. A jump in the sale of airplanes and airplane parts abroad accounted for $483 million. Another $276 million is from computer and computer parts sales. And exports of spacecraft and parts rose $163 million. About $500 million came from sales abroad of foods, feeds and beverages.
Exports of passenger cars to Canada at $55.1 million, Japan at $5.5 million and other countries at $31.5 million all declined.
On the import side, the $600 million drop in the value of oil imports resulted from a decline in the number of imported barrels of crude oil by 26 million, to 252 million, and the average price for a barrel fell 93 cents, to $14.64. This is far below the $28.63 close for oil yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The other import declines were in consumer goods, about $300 million, and industrial supplies and capital goods, including an $82 million decline in general industrial machinery.
With a lift from the declining dollar, the United States continued to have a trade surplus with Europe of about $800 million. Its deficit with Japan, however, rose to $3.1 billion, from $3 billion in May.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Japan Considers a Role in Gulf Force

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In what would be Japan's boldest involvement in a possible military confrontation since World War II, the Japanese Government indicated today that it was considering sending nonmilitary support personnel to back American and other forces opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman, refused to identify the options being considered. He stressed at a briefing here that Japan, which is more dependent on Middle Eastern oil than any other industrialized nation, would abide by its Constitution, which forbids its use of armed forces for all but defensive purposes. 
But he asserted that the Government was moving swiftly toward deciding on what he called some unprecedented steps to take part in the trade embargo being enforced against Iraq. This stood in contrast to the signs of confusion earlier this week on how the Government would respond to the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
Japanese press reports said that the possibilities ranged from dispatching transportation and communications experts to sending medical personnel. One report quoted a Japanese official who was not named as saying Japan might send minesweepers.
 
'The Earliest Possible Time'
Mr. Watanabe would not comment on these possibilities, but he ruled out sending military personnel without a change in the law, which he indicated was not likely because of the time it would consume.
''We feel time is short and we have to make our position firm at the earliest possible time,'' Mr. Watanabe said.
''Please don't think we are only considering sending money,'' he added. ''We are considering everything.'' Japan would not wait for a United Nations declaration supporting joint military action before committing itself, Mr. Watanabe said.
Japan's Constitution permits Japan to field only defensive forces. It has been interpreted as forbidding Japan from using its military power more than 1,000 miles from its shores.
Public opinion has tended to oppose strongly any move to become a major military power, although the Government has quietly initiated a major military buildup over the last decade, in response to American prodding.
But the Government has been struggling to develop a more assertive foreign policy to give it a voice in international affairs commensurate with its immense economic influence.
The briefing was held after Taro Nakayama, Japan's Foreign Minister, left Tokyo for an official nine-day trip to Saudi Arabia, Oman, Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. Mr. Nakayama was sent in the place of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who abruptly decided on Monday not to go himself on the long-planned visit.

HEADLINE: Equity Was Right the First Time

BYLINE: By Paul Winfield; Paul Winfield, an actor, is currently appearing in the film ''Presumed Innocent.''

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
When Actors Equity took its stand on ''Miss Saigon'' in favor of fair casting opportunities for its minority members, I stood 100 percent behind my union. Now that it has reversed its decision, I am just as firmly opposed.
Equity barred the casting of Jonathan Pryce, a Caucasian, in the role of a Eurasian in ''Miss Saigon'' for the Broadway run of the show. The union took the position that an Asian actor should have been given the opportunity to play the part. In retaliation, the British producer, Cameron Mackintosh, cancelled the show's American production, calling the Equity position racist. 
What is actually an extremely complex issue about equal opportunity in the professional theater was reduced to jeers about ''creative freedom'' and ''reverse racism.'' Equity was accused - wrongly - of formulating a policy that would prevent minority actors from being cast in Shakespeare, and of rolling back the gains we have made toward color-blind casting over 25 years.
While color-blind, or non-traditional, casting is a laudable concept, too many of my colleagues are never offered opportunities to play against ''type,'' especially on Broadway. And, as ''Miss Saigon'' proves, they have a hard enough time even getting the roles that are written for minorities.
But the most important issue raised by ''Miss Saigon'' is whether British producers will abide by our open casting policies when London hits are imported to Broadway. Right now, we don't have any kind of reciprocity or parity from Britain. We are barred from jobs there and when they come here, we are told ''take it or leave it.''
When James Earl Jones wanted to re-create his starring role in ''The Great White Hope'' in England, he was denied the chance because he is not a member of British Equity. When he was invited to play Othello for the BBC, black British actors rebelled against an American taking what few jobs they had. For all their protests, a white actor, Anthony Hopkins, played the role in ''brown face.''
Why must the members of my union be forced to live by another country's rules and casting traditions on their own ground? Why not have equitable, open readings for all roles, even in Broadway shows with $25 million in advance ticket sales?
Yes, I want to continue to be considered for traditionally white roles when I'm the best available actor. But on Broadway, the best available actor is somehow always, in box office terms, the most ''economically viable'' actor, i.e., white.
Just over two decades ago, Andre Gregory cast me in the role of the Gentleman Caller in Tennessee Williams's ''Glass Menagerie'' It was the inaugural season of the multiracial Los Angeles Inner City Cultural Center, subsidized by city schools. The casting was so unusual at the time that, to avoid having student audiences misinterpret a black man playing a white woman's suitor, I submitted to two hours of makeup daily to become a white man.
Importantly, the Inner City theater company presented many more productions that were racially mixed but without ''white face'' or other disguises. Today, drop into any high school or university across this land and catch the rainbow families inhabiting ''Our Town,'' ''You Can't Take It With You'' and other classics. Color-blind casting simply reflects the population of this country.
British producers have yet to catch up with America's open casting policies. And until they do, minority actors should not be denied employment in ethnic roles on Broadway.
Economics dictate that ''Miss Saigon'' will probably go on, but the issue it raises must not escape us again. It must not be raised after the fact, for the right reasons at the wrong time, or as a small missile in major economic warfare. Fairness must be the standard under which we operate.
Equity, which has been accused of blundering into this controversy, need only enforce the ground rules. What few job opportunities there are for minority actors must not be taken away before they have had a chance to audition. Visitors must observe the local customs as surely as the Shuberts and the Nederlanders must.

HEADLINE: Who Will Control the Legacy of the Woodstock Nation?

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHEL, N.Y., Aug. 16

 BODY:
For 21 years, this rural Catskills town has lived peacefully with its legacy as the site of Woodstock, the music festival that defined an era.
But eras change, generations grow old and new ones come along. And as thousands of Woodstock pilgrims gathered at Max Yasgur's farm this week to commemorate yet again the anniversary of the festival, Bethel is grappling with how to deal wtih its past without forsaking its future.
The farm's owner wants to capitalize on the site's historical value, holding gatherings and renting spots for vendors and campers. A developer who lives nearby has sued the owner and the town to stop this year's celebration, which he says is destroying the value of his properties. The Town Supervisor envisions condemning the site and creating, say, an arts and music center for tourists. 
At the same time, more than 3,000 people have set up camp on the farm, trying to recreate the mystique of the original. Most of them were too young to attend or were not born when the original festival drew 400,000 people here in 1969. We Are Stardust. . . ''It's like a flower of the 60's that's blossomed all over again,'' said Steve Wargo, a 42-year-old railroad worker from Stamford, Conn. ''It's like sacred land.''
The Town Supervisor, Allan C. Scott, said, ''Some people might say it's blasphemous, but I think this town has to realize that there's a big economy associated with this.''
For 19 years after the festival, which lasted from Aug. 15 to Aug. 17, no one paid much attention to the site. In 1984, a modest memorial appeared, but except for the occasional tourist and some intrepid interlopers who made yearly pilgrimages to the Mecca of the hippie generation, the site remained pastoral.
Then last year, spurred by nostalgia and vast amounts of media attention, 250,000 people passed through to celebrate Woodstock's 20th anniversary - a sort of spontaneous happening that many said was as groovy as the original.
''We saw plenty of smoke last year before we saw the flames,'' said Steven Dubrovsky, a real-estate developer, who lives a mile down the road. ''The people who live around here got the feeling it just sort of happened, like Woodstock. This year, it's a whole different atmosphere than Woodstock.'' We Are Golden. . . Mr. Dubrovsky, 41, owns 250 acres of rolling countryside straddling Hurd Road, near the festival site. Since he and his wife, Linda, moved here in 1983, his company, the Woodstone Developing Corporation, has built 15 country estates along Filippini's Pond, where concertgoers skinny-dipped, then and now.
His troubles began last month when campers arrived and built makeshift camps in the woods overlooking the site. Most were members of the Rainbow Family, a loosely knit spiritual group that wanders the country.
Mr. Dubrovsky said they - and later the vendors and hundreds more campers - had been lured to the site by organizers of a 21st anniversary festival. As the crowds have grown so has the noise, and panhandling campers have harassed neighbors, he said.
''Throughout the year, you see people of all ages stopping, looking around and saying, 'Hmm,' '' said Michael Mitchell, a vice-president at Tiffany and Company who lives near the site. ''That's what it should be.'' This year's free-for-all, he added, ''creates a different atmosphere.''
Then, earlier this month, Mr. Dubrovsky was showing a 10-acre property to a prospective buyer. As they drove near the site, they saw a man defecating on the side of the road.
''I saw a half-million dollar deal go down the drain,'' he said. ''I'm out of business until this thing is resolved.''
Mr. Dubrovsky, Mr. Mitchell and four other neighbors sued the town and the farm's owner, June Gelish, charging that a commercial festival violated the town's zoning laws. The town in turn joined in the suit, and last a State Supreme Court judge ordered Ms. Gelish to stop promoting commercial activities on the farm.
But more Woodstock pilgrims arrived. The activities have an air of unorganized organization. Security guards charge $5 for parking. The Rainbow Family has built an ''Info Booth'' and a free kitchen. Vendors are selling tie-dye shirts, jewelry and assorted Woodstock paraphernalia. We've Got to Get Ourselves. . . ''This is like a clandestine concert,'' said Will Hoppey, who said he was organizing the bands. ''Nobody has given us permission. And nobody has stopped us.''
On Wednesday night, Arlo Guthrie, one of the original performers, played for an hour, culminating his performance with a rendition of ''Amazing Grace.'' Rumors have spread that other original performers, including Carlos Santana, would perform.
Like others her age, Marla Bailey, a 19-year-old waitress from Hortonville, said she wished she had been at Woodstock, but ''it's a high just being here.'' Barefooted and wearing a tie-dye swimsuit, she said she was a child of the 1960's - ''I'm just not from then.''
A lawyer for the homeowners, Robert M. Rosen, said the lawsuit accomplished nothing. ''You can't start a stone rolling from the top of a hill and expect it to stop,'' he said. ''There is practically no way to stop these activities short of calling out the National Guard.''
Mr. Scott said that is out of the question. For his part, he has, bullhorn in hand, gone to the farm, urging people, ''in the spirit of Woodstock,'' to leave.
''It's obvious someone is conducting commercial activities at the site,'' Mr. Scott said. ''But it's unclear who that might be. We're powerless really. We've passed the legal stage. Now, we have to look to control the situation until Tuesday.'' Back to the G-a-a-r-rden! After that, the Town Board will try to condemn the farm and preserve it as a landmarked historical site, Mr. Scott said. With grants or other financial backing, the town could possibly create a yearly festival.
Jeff Gelish, whose mother, June Gelish, owns the 39-acre chunk of the Yasgur farm that includes the natural amphitheater that was the festival's epicenter, said his family has no control over the campers or the vendors. The family has twice gone to the town with plans for celebrations, but they have been rejected.
Plans for this year's gathering were aborted by the lawsuit, Mr. Gelish said, and his mother, distressed by the dispute, ''has gone into seclusion.''
Standing on the crest overlooking the stage, he said his family has been saddled with providing water and sanitation for the pilgrims. He said security guards ''are asking for donations'' to raise money for water and Port-o-Sans. Two 6,000-gallon water tankers arrived this evening, in addition to 15 portable toilets.
''It's just too bad we can't connect with the right people in government and give it the respect it deserves,'' Mr. Gelish said. ''Now, everybody's trying to get a piece of the pie.''

HEADLINE: New York's Guard Feeling Mideast Ripples

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 17

 BODY:
For Sgt. Michael Bruce, a paramedic in the 105th Military Airlift Group of the National Guard here, the hardest part of the Persian Gulf crisis has been explaining the possible mobilization of the American reserves to his 7-year-old son, Christopher.
''He knows I haven't been with him for the last couple of days because I'm playing G.I. Joe - that's what he calls it,'' said Sergeant Bruce, 34, of Highland. ''I told him that I may have to go play G.I. Joe for a while, and my son asked why, and I explained that you've got bad G.I. Joes and good G.I. Joes. You can't really get into politics with a 7-year-old.'' 
These are turbulent moments for the 1,600 men and women in the nation's largest Air National Guard unit, based at Stewart International Airport in the Hudson Valley, as they await a potential call-up. White House officials said today that President Bush had agreed in principle to call up a small number of reservists for important support jobs, including cargo handling and medical work.
Almost all the guard members here come from within 100 miles, including Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey. About 900 are considered traditional guard members, part-timers with outside jobs who drill at the base one weekend a month and train two full weeks during the year, usually in the summer. The rest are full-time technicians responsible for day-to-day operations.
Though they are trained in warfare, the doctors, accountants, paramedics, lawyers and correction officers making up part of the country's ''citizen militia'' are usually called on for missions that are not strictly military. Last year, they flew supplies to Armenia after the earthquake and then to the victims of Hurricane Hugo on Puerto Rico and in the Virgin Islands.
The prospect of being called to supplement United States forces in the Middle East in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has charged this base with a peculiar mix of dread and excitement.
''Actually, I'm scared to death,'' Sergeant Bruce said. ''But if they need me, I'll go.''
Since the Defense Department hinted this week that it might tap its reserves, Sgt. Paula Page, 27, of Queens, a freelance writer and a member of the 105th Group for three years, said she had thought of little else. ''I keep wondering who's going to take care of my daughter, and whether we'll have an active or passive role,'' she said.
But it could also be their moment of glory. ''Being in the guard is sort of like being on a bench in a baseball game,'' Sergeant Page said. ''And then suddenly, you get to put your skills to use.''
Battle zones are not completely alien to guard members. Some volunteered for the American operation in Panama; 758 troops from Stewart airlifted more than two million pounds of cargo. ''Panama was our first involvement in a hostile theater,'' the commander of the 105th, Col. Paul A. Weaver Jr., said. ''We all looked at one another and realized that it wasn't a humanitarian mission. But I didn't see anybody go out the door either.''
There are 92 Air National Guard flying units, part of a total of 1,339 units. There are 3,500 Army National Guard units.
The fleet of the 105th is made up entirely of C-5A Galaxy transports, the largest aircraft in the Western world. No Air National Guard units have the immense planes, which are painted in green and brown camouflage. With a cargo compartment measuring 121 feet long, 19 feet wide and 13 feet high, the C-5A can haul 12 military helicopters, or, as a fact sheet points out, 10,682 bushels of unshelled peanuts or 26 million Ping Pong balls.
 
Bigger Than Wrights' Flight
''It's a lumbering giant and it flies like a luxury car,'' said Colonel Weaver, striding proudly through a plane's belly as he pointed out that the Wright brothers could have made their first flight in it, considering that the flight was 120 feet.
Virtually from the instant Mr. Bush committed forces to the Middle East, the unit here has been involved voluntarily, with more than half of its 12 C-5A's taking supplies and personnel to what is referred to as the ''theater.'' Colonel Weaver refused to say how many members had gone where, but he said they were ''flying into all of our allied nations'' in the Middle East.
''Even without a Federal call-up, people are banging on the door to participate,'' the colonel said.
But a call-up would be different. Some or all of the 1,600 troops would have to report immediately to the base. Wills would be made out, immunizations given, gear and uniforms checked and assignments made, either to the Middle East, another base in the United States or here at Stewart. ''This place would be buzzing,'' Colonel Weaver said.
 
Disagreement About War
Although a sense of duty prevailed on the sun-drenched base, guard members were not in complete agreement as to the worthiness of spilling blood to repel Iraq.
''I believe it's a good cause,'' Sgt. Barry Tabachnick of Newburgh, a correction officer and a medical technician in the guard, said. ''The United States has been pushed around by other countries enough. Our economy is based on oil, and by the Iraqis' taking it over, they could control our whole system.''
To Sergeant Bruce, however, ''war is needless.'' A former combat medic in the Marines, he said he joined the guard after leaving the military so he could have ''some control'' over his assignment in the event of war.
''If they chose for me, I'd have to be a trained killer,'' he said. ''But my job is to alleviate pain and suffering, and I'd rather save a life than take one.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 21, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 18 about preparations for the mobilization of the 105th Military Airlift Group of the National Guard at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., misstated the number of Air National Guard units equipped with C-5A Galaxy transports. There is one, the 105th. The error was brought to The Times's attention on the day of publication, but the correction was improperly delayed through another editing oversight.

HEADLINE: Rising Deficits Could Force Fare Increase or Cuts in Transit

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Declining bus and subway ridership, a sharp rise in fare-beating and a weak regional economy could lead to substantial reductions in service and capital improvements and, possibly, another fare increase, New York City transit officials said yesterday as they released new deficit projections.
After a decade of healthy revenues and ambitious capital spending, the Transit Authority is scrambling to cope with rapidly swelling deficits. The 1990 deficit, estimated a few months ago at $83 million, is now expected to be $109 million, according to figures released at the agency's monthly meeting yesterday. 
The agency also released its first estimate of the 1991 deficit, which is between $200 and $250 million.
To meet this year's deficit the agency has already frozen hiring, scaled back painting projects and cut the number of late-night trains on a number of lines.
 
Offsetting the Shortfall
To meet next year's gap, the agency plans to offset about half of the revenue shortfall through cost-cutting measures, including continuing the hiring freeze, reducing management ranks, and adopting other operating efficiencies, said Dave A. Winfield, the agency's executive vice president.
But the remaining $100 million would have to be made up by a fare increase, sharp cuts in service, a rise in state subsidies or by settling new union contracts for far less than is now expected, he said. The Transit Authority plans to submit various alternatives to its board in the coming months, he said.
''If the current trend continues and things stay as they are, we face the possibility of cutbacks in service, fare or subsidy increases or very minimal union settlements,'' Mr. Winfield said.
The cutbacks already planned will save the Transit Authority about $83 million this year, and the agency plans to use $19 million from a discretionary fund to help offset the 1990 shortfall. The remaining $7 million is expected to come from a reduction in bond interest payments, Mr. Winfield said.
But consumer advocacy groups yesterday assailed the authority's plans to cut subway service, in particular, the reduction of late-night service. They called on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Board, which is the Transit Authority's parent agency, the Mayor, the Governor and the State Legislature ''to stop the wholesale destruction'' of transit service.
''We are witnessing the beginning of curtailed late night and weekend service, and this is a precedent we cannot allow to happen,'' said Stephen Dobrow, vice chairman of the New York City Transit Authority Advisory Council, an independent consumer group. ''We see very little evidence of belt-tightening and other efficiencies at the Transit Authority. What we do see is a rush to cut service.''
The lines that will be affected by the service reductions are the A, B, C, D, E, F, G, J, M, N, Q, R, 3, 4, 5, and 6. Most of the service reductions are at night and affect the length of time between trains.
Jared Lebow, a spokesman for the Transit Authority, described the service changes as minor, except for the elimination of the B train at night along Central Park West. Mr. Lebow said that about six passengers a car use it at night and that the agency would save $1.3 million by eliminating it. After 7 P.M. the B train will replace the Q shuttle that runs from Rockefeller Center to Long Island City.

The Oil Jolt
 President Bush has decided in principle to call up a limited number of military reservists because of the Middle East crisis, Administration officials said. The Pentagon commandeered 38 wide-body jets from 16 airlines to carry troops and cargo. [1.] Japan indicated that it was considering sending nonmilitary support personnel to back American and other forces opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. [6.] Saudi Arabia stressed to other OPEC members that it was seeking a meeting to discuss raising production. Oil prices continued to advance, rising $1.27 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to close at $28.63. [33.] Higher oil prices could create much greater hardships in dozens of third world nations because their economies are in far worse shape than during the last oil shock a decade ago. [33.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 Walter R. Yetnikoff, the chief of CBS Records, has signed a new contract under which he will remain as chief executive for two years and then become a consultant to the company, several top-level industry executives said. Markets

It was the Dow's lowest closing level since March 1, when it was 2,635.59. For the week, the Dow lost 71.78 points. [33.] The Government securities market stabilized. HEADLINE: Dow Drops By 36.64, To 2,644.80

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market closed with another sizable decline yesterday, finishing a tumultuous week down sharply. It had experienced even steeper declines earlier in the day that activated the New York Stock Exchange's restriction on program trading.
Traders cited continuing worries about the economy, a still-fluid Middle East situation, rising bond yields and steeper oil prices.
After tumbling more than 66 points on Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell yesterday by 36.64 points, or 1.37 percent, to 2,644.80. For the week, the drop in the Dow was 71.78. Yesterday's closing level was its lowest since March 1, when it was 2,635.59. In early afternoon trading, the index was once down 60 points. 
 
A Quiet 'Witching Hour'
Yesterday was also a ''double witching hour,'' which involves the simultaneous expiration of stock options and stock index options, as well as the Major Market Index futures. Futures for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index do not expire in a double witching hour, as they do in a ''triple witching hour''; they will expire next month.
The witching effect on yesterday's market was minimal, traders said. Indeed, it was one of the quietest witching hours in a while. When the market is undergoing a broad upward or downward trend, the number of last-minute orders is usually not so large, and the price swings are usually not so severe, they added. But buying related to certain options and futures contracts did help to cut the day's losses almost in half.
Volume was heavy for a summer Friday, but not for an options expiration day, said Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company. The total number of shares traded on the Big Board was 212.6 million, up from 138.8 million the day before. Declines exceeded advances by a ratio of better than 4 to 1, with 1,330 stocks down and 310 stocks up.
 
S.& P. 500 Index Off 4.56
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell by 4.56 points, to 327.83, while the Nasdaq composite index was down by 8.78 points, to 393.49. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 3.22 points to finish at 333.61.
Mr. Metz said: ''The market is basically gripped by risk-aversion. Presently, it is true for both the equity and bond markets.'' Mr. Metz added that he had observed a sense of helplessness among traders and a general feeling that the market cannot go up again.
''But at some point,'' he said, ''the most urgent sellers will be out of the way. And the market will define the low at the end of the trading range. I think we're almost there.''
''The problem is, no one has a convincing scenario as to how the Persian Gulf situation will end,'' he added. ''It raises anxiety and erodes confidence at best.''
Before the opening bell in New York, many overseas stock markets were already depressed by the gloomy outlook of the United States economy and by Middle East tensions.
The Tokyo 225-share Nikkei index plunged 762.72 points, or 2.77 percent, to 26,786.72 yesterday, on top of the previous day's slide of 562.68 points. Mideast and Inflation The market received a bit of good economic news in the morning, but it appeared to be overshadowed by the Middle East worries and Thursday's bad report on inflation - a higher-than-expected Consumer Price Index. The Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit narrowed 35 percent to a seven-year low of $5.07 billion in June. But analysts said they expected it to resume growing once the impact of higher oil prices took effect.
By noon the market had fallen more than 50 points, setting off a ''circuit breaker'' - the New York Stock Exchange's 50-point index-linked trading rule, which was in effect most of the day. When the Dow falls more than 50 points, the rule restricts traders who use computer programs to initiate sell orders. Such programs are not permitted to sell stock on a downtick, or when a stock's last sale is lower than the previous sale.
Going into the weekend, investors were uneasy about holding positions, especially with prospects fading for an early settlement of the situation in the Middle East. Oil prices rose - on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the settlement price on a barrel of light crude was $28.60, up $1.27, in contracts for September delivery -and transport stocks weakened, with the USAir Group off 1/4, to 17 1/2; UAL down 3/4, to 101 1/2; Federal Express down 1 3/4, to 34 3/8; Airborne Freight down 1, to 20 5/8, and British Airways down 1 1/8, to 29 7/8. The stocks of oil producers, the chief beneficiaries of the rise in oil prices, accounted for many of the big gainers on the Big Board. ARCO rose 2 1/2, to 137 1/2; Texaco was up 1 5/8, to 63 7/8; Royal Dutch Petroleum gained 1 3/8, to 84 3/4, and British Petroleum was up 1 3/4, to 86.
Wal-Mart Stores, down 1 1/8, to 28, was the biggest trader on the Big Board, with 4.1 million shares. Other big retailers' stocks also declined, reflecting concern that retail sales would decline if the economy slid into recession.

HEADLINE: Saudi Move For OPEC Meeting

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia, laying the basis for a sharp increase in its oil production without OPEC's approval, stressed to other members of the organization yesterday that it was seeking a meeting to discuss the issue and that opposition to such discussion was not reasonable.
The Saudis are arguing that the embargo of oil from Iraq and Kuwait is hurting third world countries, which generally have no oil-storage plants and are running out of supplies.
The oil minister of Iraq, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, meanwhile, reiterated a threat against nations that raise production and said the Saudi call for a meeting was a cover for their intentions to do just that. And an official in Venezuela, the other member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries with a substantial capacity to increase output, said the country still preferred to get OPEC approval but was nearly certain to produce more oil regardless of what OPEC did. 
 
Worries About the Weekend
Fear of military action dominated the oil markets yesterday, with traders' worries about what might happen over the weekend leading them to bid up prices. In contracts for September delivery, oil prices rose $1.27 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, closing at $28.63 a barrel. Wholesale gasoline rose 8.51 cents, to $95.97 a gallon, a record in five years of futures trading.
Nauman Barakat, a trader at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said that if the military standoff continues, ''the mid-$30's area should not be ruled out.'' If war breaks out, he said, prices would quickly jump $5 a barrel, but if 2.5 million to 3 million barrels a day of new production comes on stream, ''the market may come off by $5 or so.''
Saudi officials sounded firm yesterday in their determination to pump more oil, although they have expressed such willingness more than once since Aug. 7, when the United States committed troops to defend Saudi Arabia.
 
'Just Go Ahead and Do It'
''Our main concern is the overall world oil-supply situation,'' said one Saudi official in a telephone interview. ''Our concern is the overall international economy and what would happen if ample supplies are not available. If it means we will have to unilaterally act, or if it means that some members of OPEC will have to go about a decision, we will just go about it, just go ahead and do it.''
The official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, noted that the current OPEC agreement calls for production of 22.5 million barrels of oil a day, and a $21 minimum ''reference price.'' Now, he said, production is about 18.5 million barrels a day and the price is about $26. ''Definitely, this situation warrants a meeting,'' he said.
Saudi Arabia could increase its production by two million barrels a day ''by tomorrow morning,'' he said, and could add an additional 500,000 barrels a day quickly thereafter.
An oil expert in the Persian Gulf said that in November and December of 1988, the Saudis had demonstrated they could produce eight million barrels a day, slightly more than the level now being proposed.
In Venezuela, an official who refused to have his name or position disclosed, said his country was trying hard to work within the structure of OPEC. ''The only way you really could keep control in the market, over supply, is to have some kind of commitment'' within the organization, he said. If an agreement is not possible, the official said, Venezuela will make a decision on its own and, ''I'm sure it will be very favorable to the United States.''
''We are a part of the Western Hemisphere,'' he said, ''and we must look to the Western Hemisphere.'' Venezuela's Spare Capacity During the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74, Venezuela raised its production by about 1.5 million barrels a day. At the moment, its spare capacity is about 500,000 barrels a day.
Several people well acquainted with Venezuela said yesterday that the final decision appeared to rest with the President, Carlos Andres Perez. Iraq and Kuwait between them have an OPEC quota of 4.6 million barrels a day, but analysts say they may have been producing slightly more than that before the Aug. 2 invasion by Iraq and subsequent embargo on their shipments. In addition to the 3.2 million barrels a day that Saudi Arabia and Venezuela could add to world supplies, experts say the United Arab Emirates could add 250,000 to 300,000 barrels to its July production, at least for a few weeks, and might quietly do so.
In Colombia, an OPEC member but a small exporter, the state-owned oil company said yesterday that it would increase oil production by 15,000 barrels a day.
 
Nigerian and Algerian Opposition
But the President of Nigeria, Ibrahim Babangida, reaffirmed on state radio yesterday that his country would abide by its OPEC quota. Algeria also expressed opposition to a meeting, according to Saudi officials.
Outside observers say the situation is extremely difficult for OPEC. If members act unilaterally, said Cyrus H. Tahmassebi, the chief economist of Ashland Oil, ''whatever discipline there may be will collapse.''
''It will create a lot of ill feeling among OPEC members and political problems,'' he said.
But if prices rise too high, Dr. Tahmassebi said, the result will be increased conservation and other developments that will hurt the long-term market for oil.
Sizing up the votes at a possible OPEC meeting, David T. Mizrahi, editor of Mideast Report, a New York-based newsletter, said that of the 13 members, Iraq and Kuwait were unlikely to attend. He said the nations that would favor increased production were Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Ecuador, and possibly Indonesia. That would constitute a majority at a meeting, he said. As the maneuvering among OPEC members continued, prices in this country rose, especially for gasoline. In Los Angeles, ARCO, which imposed a freeze on gasoline prices on Aug. 8, reported that 270 of its stations, primarily in Southern California, had run out of unleaded regular because they were selling it at 5 to 13 cents less than competitors.
Douglas Elmets, a spokesman for the company, said that ARCO had bought 100,000 barrels of gasoline on the spot market and had hired every delivery truck it could, in addition to its own fleet, to keep its stations supplied. ''Our volumes are just amazing,'' he said, adding that sales were up 10 pecent.
The company appeared to be trading profit for market share and floods of favorable publicity. The supplies it bought on the spot market cost $1 a gallon, and it was selling for an average price of $1.16, a margin that Mr. Elmets confirmed was not covering all costs.

HEADLINE: Market in U.S. Securities Steadies

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Government securities market stabilized yesterday after prices plunged and interest rates soared during the previous session. Dealers described yesterday's relatively lackluster trading activity as a tug-of-war between market participants influenced by inflationary fears and further weakness in the dollar and those counting on a continuing decline of the economy.
As a result, prices of Treasury coupon issues traded in a narrow range for most of the day, with the new benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue that matures in 2020, ending at 98 3/32, off 3/32 on the day, while its yield rose a basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 8.93 percent, from 8.92 the day before. One week ago, the long bond's yield was 8.79 percent. 
Among other Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 8 percent notes of 1992 were unchanged at 99 27/32 with a yield of 8.08 percent; the 8 percent notes of 1993 rose 1/32, to 99 13/32, for a yield of 8.22 percent.
 
Long Notes Slip
The closely watched long notes, the 8.75's of the year 2000, slipped 2/32, to 99 24/32, for a yield of 8.79 percent, up from 8.67 percent a week ago. During the week, the yield on the 10-year Japanese ''long bonds'' rose to 8.05 percent from 7.98 percent, and the yield on the same West German bond maturity climbed to 8.89 percent from 8.83 percent.
With the worldwide demand for credit increasing, the competing rates on the Government bonds of major industrial countries not yet having rampant inflation are carefully studied by investment portfolio managers.
Leif H. Olsen, who heads an economic consulting and financial management organization bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn., said: ''The next batch of economic data due out in September should clearly show the economy in a decline. Perhaps this is why the market tended to ignore the sharp rise in the July Consumer Price Index and the impressive improvement in our trade balance for June. Both indicators did not reflect the surge in oil prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.''
In any case, he added, ''the Fed can not ease credit with energy prices and inflation climbing each day.''
The Federal Reserve, for its part, intervened to add reserves to the banking system through repurchase agreements. But the move was considered one of several taken by the Fed this week to offset the distortions caused by the power failure in New York's financial district earlier this week. As a result of the breakdown in computer and other transfer systems, which have now been restored, some banks were either debited for payments already made while others were given credit for much larger ''floats,'' in effect money claimed to be en route, than were warranted.
In any case, the Fed's intervention had little impact on the key Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans. The funds traded between 8 1/8 percent and 8 3/16 percent almost all day.
 
Little Change in Bill Rates
There was little change in the discount rates on Treasury bills, which would be the most immediately influenced by shifts in Fed policy. The rate on the 90-day bills dipped a basis point, to 7.49 percent; six-month bills were off three basis points, at 7.44 percent, and the one-year bills declined two basis points, to 7.30 percent.
The Treasury announced that it would auction $10.5 billion of new one-year bills next Thursday.
In the corporate bond market, the mounting financial problems of the Trump Organization depressed prices of its debt. Late in the day, dealers said the Trump Plaza Funding's 12 7/8 percent first-mortgage bonds were off 1.5 points, at 68 bid, while Trump's Castle Funding's 13 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds were also marked down 1.5 points, to 47, and the Trump Taj Mahal Funding lost a point, at 41 1/2. A point is equivalent to $10 for each $1,000 of face value.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Generally Down, Hits A New Low Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar sank to another record low yesterday against the German mark and fell against all other major currencies except the Japanese yen, reflecting continuing pessimism about the state of the American economy.
The dollar dropped to 1.5485 German marks in Europe, from 1.5630 marks late Thursday. Its previous closing low in Europe had been 1.5605 marks, set on Wednesday. 
In New York, the dollar ended at 1.5500 marks, a new low for that market. The dollar's previous low in New York had been 1.5525 marks on Thursday. For the week, the dollar sank by 6.7 percent against the mark in domestic dealings.
 
Small Trade Deficit
The latest decline came despite the United States report of an unexpectedly small trade deficit of $5.07 billion in June. Dealers said traders shunned the dollar because they believe that the economy may be headed into a recession and that the Federal Reserve will have no choice but to encourage lower interest rates.
When United States rates are falling relative to those in other countries, the dollar is less appealing to foreign investors.
''Dollar traders are just not interested in the trade picture,'' said Walter Simon, a currency options trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company. ''They are interested in the whole weakening of the U.S. economic climate.''
Dealers in Europe said the dollar was hurt by reported comments from the West German central bank's vice president, Helmut Schlesinger. He was quoted as saying that the dollar's decline fit the central bank's strategy because it reduces West German import prices.
The dollar rose in New York against the Japanese yen, to 147.60 yen, from 147.25 late Thursday.
The dollar lost ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound rose to $1.9230, from $1.9095 late Thursday. Sterling rose to $1.9195 in London, from $1.8985 late Thursday.
Other dollar rates as of 4 P.M. in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, were: 1.2820 Swiss francs, down from 1.2915; 5.1975 French francs, down from 5.2220; 1,142.25 Italian lire, down from 1,143.25, and 1.14365 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14815.
In the precious metals market, gold prices were mixed. After gold posted gains in other markets, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $408.50 an ounce as of 4 P.M., down 50 cents from Thursday's late bid.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose 40 cents, to $409.60.
Earlier, gold rose to $409.25 in London, from $403.50 late Thursday and to $408.25 in Zurich, from $401.25 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $9.95, to $410.96.
Silver for current delivery rose 1.1 cents an ounce, to $5.179, on the Comex. Silver rose in London to $5.20, from $5.13 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Put the Old U.& D. Back on Track

BYLINE: By Donald L. Pevsner; Donald L. Pevsner, a native New Yorker, is a lawyer and consumer advocate.

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
Imagine you are seated in a rustic railroad passenger car, near a majestic river. The whistle blows, and you're under way - behind the nostalgic chuffing of steam power. Shortly, the level track gives way to a stiff climb, and the little engine must really work to get you up the grade. You emerge alongside the shore of a pristine reservoir, surrounded by wooded mountains, and skirt its banks for several miles. No roads intrude to mar the timeless beauty of the setting. Then you roll alongside a rushing mountain stream, world-famous for its trout fishing. Deer browse nearby, leaping at your passage.
Soon, a wall of mountains appears in your path. To surmount this obstacle, you traverse a sweeping horseshoe curve - so steep that even short freight trains were once forced to tackle it in two sections, rejoining at the top after ''doubling the hill.'' At the summit, the tracks run right by the front entrance of one of the country's largest ski resorts, and continue down the mountain into a beautiful, rural river valley. The stresses of big city life have been left far behind. 
The setting for this journey is not Colorado or California, but begins less than 90 miles north of midtown Manhattan, in Kingston, N.Y. - eastern terminus of the most scenic branch-line railroad east of the Rockies, the Ulster and Delaware . Though you cannot ride the U.& D. today, its passenger trains faithfully served the Catskill Mountains from 1872 to 1954, heading west from the Hudson River at Kingston past Ashokan Reservoir, Esopus Creek, Phoenicia, Pine Hill, Highmount (now the site of state-owned Belleayre Mountain Ski Area), Arkville and Roxbury to Stamford, N.Y., with service extended to Oneonta, N.Y. in 1900. This magnificent little line single-handedly opened up the Catskills in Ulster and Delaware Counties as a major resort area. At its peak, in 1913, it carried 676,000 passengers.
Then began the long, painful slide to oblivion. As regional highways improved and passenger-car ownership exploded, ridership declined. The Great Depression and World War II finished the job, while trucks took away the once-lucrative freight business. On March 31, 1954, the last, sad passenger train left Oneonta for Kingston. In 1965, the line's owner, the New York Central Railroad, abandoned it west of Bloomville. Finally, the last freight train rolled into history on September 28, 1976, as a New York State trooper stood memorably to attention at a Catskills grade crossing, his hat solemnly doffed and crossed over his heart.
Two years later, Ulster County, spent $1.5 million in taxpayers' money to acquire the Ulster portion of the line (38.6 miles from Kingston to Highmount, N.Y), with the announced goal of restoring steam-powered excursion trains to the Catskills. And the Delaware County trackage was acquired by the abutting towns, with funds for the purchase provided by the public-spirited A. Lindsay and Olive B. O'Connor Foundation of Delhi, N.Y. The Foundation proceeded, in 1981, to spend an additional $1.7 million to create the ''Delaware & Ulster Rail Ride,'' currently running diesel-powered excursion trains on an isolated five-mile line segment.
Yet Ulster County has no plans, 12 years after acquiring the line, to pay the approximately $8 million it would cost to restore it. As a direct result, a suitable steam locomotive and coaches owned by the current line lessee, the Catskill Mountain Railroad Corporation, remain stored in Kingston. The most scenic portion of the U.& D. remains impassable to excursion trains. Further, Ulster County refuses to even entertain the prospect of line renovation for a connection to Delaware County until at least the year 2011.
This short-sighted position robs the two counties of the financial bonanza that would result from a working line with tourist traffic originating at both ends.
When one considers the enormous economic benefits of steam tourist railroads in sites as diverse as Durango, Co.; Chama, N.M.; Williams, Ariz.; and Scranton, Pa., together with the superb location of Kingston, N.Y. - within an easy day's drive of more than 45 million people - it is difficult to understand or excuse the Ulster County Legislature's studied inaction.
Consider, for example, 200,000 annual railroad riders spending just $100 each in the two-county region. Given the acknowledged 8-to-1 multiplication of tourist dollars in any local economy, the new visitors would circulate $160 million through the region every year. Just one year's sales tax revenues would amply pay the one-time cost of the needed renovations.
Clearly, in the absence of a desirable private foundation or corporate support, it is up to Ulster voters to induce their elected officials to promptly restore this irreplaceable historic resource.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Hostages in Forefront

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
 In declaring that he would use foreigners as a shield against Western attack, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has placed these captives at the forefront of the Persian Gulf crisis in just the manner the Bush Administration hoped to avoid. Mr. Hussein and Mr. Bush are now engaged in a struggle within a struggle, namely over whether the fate of the Americans and other foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq will weaken the international resolve to squeeze Baghdad hard enough to force a withdrawal from Kuwait.
For Mr. Hussein, foreign captives now appear to be his weapon of choice for countering the international quarantine that the United States has erected around him. He is threatening the welfare of the thousands of foreigners trapped inside Iraq and Kuwait if the United States and its allies do not back off.
For Mr. Bush, the challenge is to avoid letting the fate of the captives become the determining factor in his handling of the gulf crisis and to prevent a groundswell of public sympathy for the trapped Americans that could sap the country's willingness to confront Iraq, even with the use of force if necessary. 
Britain, France and other countries with citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait face similar tests, and the reaction of one may influence the conduct of the others.
 
Captives' Names Undisclosed
It was precisely to limit this danger that the White House, from the very beginning of this crisis, has leaned over backward to avoid using the word ''hostage'' to describe the trapped foreigners, and has even tried to pretend that their status was a secondary issue. Apparently in an effort to keep the issue from developing a human face in the United States, the State Department has refused to make public the names of any of the Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq, saying it would violate their privacy and subject their families to incessant inquiries from the press.
White House aides said the President went on vacation to Kennebunkport, Me., partly to persuade Mr. Hussein that unlike Jimmy Carter he was not becoming obsessed with recovering hostages or losing sight of the original goals of the United States military intervention in the gulf.
Even after the latest threats from Iraq, the White House still tried to sound a restrained note about the foreign captives. It said, ''The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct.'' But this use of language about international norms and laws only underscored a larger problem for the Administration represented by the captives issue. President Hussein parted ways with all accepted norms of international conduct a long time ago. He plays by his own rules, which are no rules at all.
The Iraqi leader is saying, in effect, that he is prepared to subordinate all questions of international law and civility to preserve his occupation of Kuwait. He will hold foreigners at key military and civilian installations to deter attack by the Western forces ranged against him, and he will put his captives on the same starvation diet that the United States is trying to put the Iraqi people on.
When faced with hostage crises, Mr. Bush's two predecessors, Mr. Carter and Ronald Reagan, found it difficult to subordinate the lives of American captives to their larger policy goals. Both the Carter and Reagan Administrations were politically damaged by their efforts to free hostages -Mr. Carter in the failed attempt to rescue the American diplomats in Iran and Mr. Reagan in the attempt to win release of Americans in Lebanon that led to the Iran-contra scandal.
 
A Harder Dilemma for Bush
But the dilemmas for Mr. Carter and Mr. Reagan were, in some ways, simpler. The hostage crises were forced on them by kidnappers from afar. The fate of the hostages - and how much to do or not to do on their behalf - were the central issues. The larger issue involved was whether the United States might be encouraging further hostage-takings by bargaining with terrorists and kidnappers.
The situation is different for Mr. Bush. The central issue for him, as he has defined it, is the reversal of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to preserve the international order and the protection of vital American economic interests in Saudi Arabia. The question Mr. Bush may soon be squarely facing is whether, in pursuit of his larger goals he would be ready to risk the lives of the 3,000 Americans, as well as other foreigners, in Iraq and Kuwait.
The strain of that looming question seems to be taking a toll on the President, who does care about the lives of American captives and is not very good at playing the cold-blooded decision-maker concerned only about the national interest.
He was clearly in a testy mood this morning when he spoke with reporters while playing golf in Kennebunkport. When reporters asked him if he had been in touch with the White House Situation Room about the latest developments in the crisis, he snapped, ''I talk to them every morning at 5:30 A.M., and I am not going to take any comments up here.''
 
Some Unattractive Options
His options at this time are not particularly attractive. Mr. Bush can continue to respond in a restrained manner to the Iraqi leader's escalating use of American and other foreign captives, seeking United Nations condemnation as he has done, and hope that the Iraqi threats will not be carried out. But that would seem to be a holding action at best.
Attempting a rescue mission would be highly risky, given the degree to which the foreign nationals are spread out and the likelihood that any rescue attempt would precipitate not only violence against the civilians by Iraqis, but also the outbreak of a full-scale war.
Another option, which Administration officials say they have ruled out, would be to restrict Iraqi citizens and diplomats in the United States. American officials say this is would ''not be appropriate,'' and would be stooping to Mr. Hussein's tactics.
In the end, though, if the crisis keeps escalating, Mr. Bush may have no choice but to make the hardest choice of all: putting the national interest, as he defines it, ahead of the safety of the American civilians caught in the vortex of a distant war.
