HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF
FOREIGNERS IN IRAQ WILL SHARE IN HARDSHIPS, BAGHDAD WARNS; SAUDIS TO INCREASE OIL OUTPUT;
'ACT OF WAR' SEEN

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Declaring the American-led naval blockade ''an act of war,'' Iraq said tonight that thousands of foreigners, including infants, who have been turned into hostages would suffer the same food shortages as Iraqis.
Iraqi officials announced Friday night that as many as 10,000 American, British and other foreign citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait would be scattered among Iraqi military bases, oil production sites and industrial installations to serve as virtual human shields against any attack by the growing American and Arab military forces stationed in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region.
The Iraqi Government left no doubt tonight that it had dramatically raised the stakes by seizing the foreigners to use them as hostages, saying that was ''one of the means for achieving peace.''
 
Will 'Play Host'
''The people of Iraq have decided to play host to the citizens of these aggressive nations as long as Iraq remains threatened with an aggressive war,'' the Speaker of the Iraqi Parliament, Saadi Mahdi Saleh, said in a statement issued late Friday night. 
In an emergency session tonight, the United Nations Security Council unanimously approved a resolution demanding that Baghdad allow foreigners to depart immediately from Iraq and Kuwait. [Page 10.] The White House today called the holding of foreign citizens ''totally unacceptable,'' saying, ''The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct.''
 
Where Language Matters
The Bush Administration has avoided using the word ''blockade'' because a blockade, in international law, is generally associated with declared wars. The Administration has preferred the word ''interdiction.''
France expressed its indignation today over Iraq's refusal to release Western civilians and warned Baghdad of ''grave consequences'' if the security of any of the 560 French citizens in Iraq or Kuwait was endangered. In London, the Foreign Office said only that it was aware of the Iraqi announcement.
The Iraqi authorities have ''been coordinating with a number of state ministries and installations that have the required accommodation facilities throughout the country,'' the Speaker's statement said, ''including the Ministry of Oil, the Ministry of Military Industrialization, the armed forces and air bases and other ministries and institutions and the refinery complex in Kuwait and other places, so they are provided with the appropriate accommodation.''
About 2,500 Americans are in Kuwait and rougly 600 more in Iraq, among perhaps 10,000 foreigners, including more than 4,000 British citizens who have been told they cannot leave.
The Iraqi announcement raised the prospect that they would be moved in groups to potential military targets from Kuwait's desalinization plants in the south to Iraq's main oil fields in the north. The places they could be interned could include the critical chemical warfare plants, other defense factories, air bases and military barracks.
Any air attack on these targets -which military experts saw as the most efficient way to strike at the Iraqi military machine - would risk killing the foreigners.
 
Escapes on a Huge Scale
More than 100,000 foreigners, mostly Arabs and third-world nationals working in Kuwait or Iraq have been allowed to flee over the Saudi Arabian and Jordanian borders. A small number of Westerners have also managed to escape in this manner.
Keeping the foreigners at the potential target sites, the Iraqi Government said, ''will only keep the threat of war and aggression at bay.''
The Iraqi announcement tonight said the United States and Britain had ''gone beyond an economic boycott'' to a state of war.
''They embarked on the implementation of an economic blockade by force of arms against Iraq, including food and medicine, and this is an act of war under world norms and international law,'' the Iraqi statement said.
American and British warships in the gulf and Red Sea have been authorized to use force if necessary to prevent merchant ships from carrying cargo to Iraq. On Friday, under the new orders, American ships for the first time stopped and checked two Iraqi coastal vessels, but allowed them to pass when they were found to be empty.
 
Equal Treatment
The Iraqi statement, issued in the name of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs, said the children of foreigners, including babies, would share the same fate as Iraqi children. No accurate figures were immediately available, but there are believed to be hundreds of children among the trapped foreigners.
''The measures have caused and will cause shortages in imported food, especially milk for the Iraqi babies,'' the statement said. ''We have decided to treat babies of foreign families equally to those of Iraqis according to our humanitarian principles.''
Adult foreigners being held hostage, the statement said, could expect to eat less.
''Because foreigners are not going to be members of the military forces and are not going to participate in any activities related to war,'' the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs said, ''their share of food, the quantity and quality will be affected by the fact that our imports of food will be reduced.''
Iraq had low supplies of food before its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and now has little oil money or access to international markets to replenish its supplies. As of July 25, the Iraqi Government had enough wheat for two months of normal consumption, enough rice for three months, enough beans and barley for a month and less than two weeks' worth of corn, said John P. Parker, an Agriculture Department economist who studies Mideast food supplies.
During the day today, the Government issued a statement saying that ''brother Egyptians'' were excluded from the categories of foreigners who were not allowed to leave. Earlier, there had been a directive to treat Egyptians well even though their Government had sent forces to Saudi Arabia, giving an Arab ingredient to the American ground deployment. Both moves appeared to be attempts to appeal to popular sentiment.
Mr. Saleh, the Parliament Speaker, said in his statement that the American and other Western governments ''are intent on launching a war to starve the Iraqi people in a brutal way unprecedented in history.''
The Iraqi official went on to say that ''foremost of sacred missions should be the protection of peoples from aggression and injustice and the assurance of peace, and any conduct that in the end promotes this noble and humane objective gains deep legitimacy, which is the substance of the divine, secular and international laws.''
The taking of the foreigners hostage and the plan to hold them in potential military targets, he said, was devised ''out of our faith in this sacred mission.''
 
People of Many Nations Involved
In addition to the British and American contingents, there are thousands of other nationals from countries which have joined the actions against Iraq for its takeover of neighboring Kuwait who are now trapped.
Besides 850,000 Egyptians in Iraq and Kuwait, these include Japan, with roughly 600 citizens; Italy, 480; France, 560; West Germany, 560; Ireland, 350; Greece, 250; the Netherlands, 230; Spain, 230; Australia, 160; Denmark, 100 and Belgium, 60. There are also hundreds of people from Sweden, Switzerland, Austria, Finland Luxembourg and New Zealand.
Iraq also continued to warn that it would not hesitate to use chemical weapons.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Largest Force Since Vietnam Committed in 15-Day Flurry

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In only 15 days, while Congress was scattered on summer recess and much of official Washington was on vacation, senior Bush Administration officials have committed the United States to its broadest and most hazardous overseas military venture since the Vietnam War.
Unlike the Vietnam engagement, which was improvised and incremental, the buildup in the Persian Gulf is guided by long military contingency plans that made deployment possible virtually overnight.
But to the public and most politicians, the impact of that buildup is only now taking shape. Military strategists, economists, and politicians say it is potentially enormous, affecting the economy, politics and international relations for years. 
The Administration has been reluctant to disclose the full extent of its military commitment, with Pentagon officials declining to tote up exactly how much armor or how many troops it is sending, or intends to send, or to say how long it expects they will be there, or to make public assessments of the risks to American personnel or prestige.
What is publicly known is that 20,000-plus soldiers are in Saudi Arabia, about 35,000 more are on 59 ships ringing the Saudi peninsula or bound there and up to 45,000 Marines are heading for the Persian Gulf.
How long the forces will be in place is something the Bush Administration has deliberately kept vague. ''Where we'll be a year or two from now, I wouldn't want to speculate,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said on Friday.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware said today he was ''struck by the size of this.'' Mr. Biden, a Democratic member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said in a telephone interview from his home state: ''This is a big, big deal. I think the President has an obligation to put in as many forces as necessary to take care of the troops we have there.
''But quite frankly, I never contemplated talk of 250,000 troops in Saudi Arabia, or talk of an American presence there of several years,'' he said.
While not criticizing Mr. Bush's actions, he said the scope of the American action demands ''not only some consultation, but some extensive debate'' about the need for allied and Arab involvement in the crisis.
The decision that put in motion the most rapid military buildup in American history was effectively made by President Bush and a small circle of advisers in a weekend at Camp David, shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Most Congressional leaders were informed of the operation after it was ordered. Only one influential lawmaker, Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgian who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, appears to have been consulted in advance. So far, no member of Congress has proposed hearings to discuss ramifications of the action.
Most public figures scrambled to support the President's decision, but a handful of supporters like Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who is on the Armed Services Committee, have begun raising the first caution flags about the operations.
''I think we'll stand it for a long period of time, as long as there are not casualties,'' Mr. McCain said in a telephone interview from Arizona. ''If you get involved in a major ground war in the Saudi desert, I think support will erode significantly. Nor should it be supported. We cannot even contemplate, in my view, trading American blood for Iraqi blood.''
The American public will undoubtedly back Mr. Bush's commitment to Saudi Arabia, and thus to American access to world oil production, said James Schlesinger, who was Defense Secretary, Energy Secretary and Director of Central Intelligence in the 1960's and 1970's.
''But it is not clear that there is strong public support for a rollback in Kuwait, especially if it will require heavy American casualties,'' he said in a telephone interview from Ohio. He said it was not clear that Americans had even considered the question of restoring the ruling family of Kuwait, although that ''has become a major policy objective of the United States.''
 
Lessons of the 1960's
As the Vietnam experience proved, public debate and Congressional action do not guarantee wise policymaking, several Bush Administration officials and former Government officials from the 1960's said in interviews this week. These officials also noted that President Bush has tried to build public support for his Persian Gulf decisions, holding several press conferences, making a televised speech and in general arguing the case that vital national security interests are at stake.
In the atmosphere of crisis, there is no evidence that extensive debate or consultations would have changed the American commitment in any way.
But some officials said that in keeping with Mr. Bush's demonstrated penchant for making decisions in secret, the White House has kept Congress, citizens and foreign leaders alike in the dark about the ultimate scope of the operation.
The pivotal decisions have been made by Mr. Bush and a handful of his top advisers, including the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft; Defense Secretary Dick Cheney; Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, said Friday that the United States could easily be forced to maintain ''a more or less permanent force'' in the gulf, although probably under United Nations supervision.
Because the troops and supplies have long been paid for, the major costs so far are for transport and maintenance at wartime readiness. But a prolonged stay would require other expenses, like building shelter for thousands of soldiers now living in tents.
The ultimate costs are unknown, said a Congressional budget analyst who is a military expert.
''But if you have a shooting war,'' he said, ''all bets are off. Then you consume ammunition, fuel, and hardware. You start to replace tanks and planes and missiles. You increase your presence, and the cost jumps, depending on how hot it gets.''

HEADLINE: Military Agency Loses Authority Over Civilian Computer Security

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
President Bush has ordered a quiet dismantling of an aggressive Reagan Administration effort to restrict sources of computerized information, including databases, collections of commercial satellite photographs and information compiled by university researchers.
The Reagan Administration early on established a central office in the National Security Agency to set standards for the security of Federal and private computers. A Presidential order in 1984 expanded the power of the office and created a new security category of sensitive but unclassified information.
The moves were aimed at reducing unauthorized uses of computerized information and at restricting authorized uses so that foreign countries could not piece together sensitive information to learn the nation's secrets.
Civil libertarians raised alarms, saying they feared limits on the free flow of information. Some lawmakers and computer industry officials said they worried that the National Security Agency, a military agency responsible for electronic intelligence gathering, would somehow use its power of setting computer security standards to get around the very security systems it was regulating. 
 
Decentralizing Oversight
Congress passed legislation in 1987 to take away the agency's expanded powers and to give oversight of private security systems to a branch of the Commerce Department. But not until last month did President Bush sign a classified memorandum that tells the security agency to shift its focus to Federal classified systems, revising the original Reagan Administration orders. A summary of President Bush's directive was made public later in the month.
This month the security agency began disbanding its National Computer Security Center, moving most of its 300 employees into new jobs in the more secret communications security section inside the agency. A spokeswoman for the National Security Agency said on Friday that the agency would announce the change in the next few days.
Now some computer security experts say they are concerned that the Bush move goes too far in decentralizing oversight for computer security. An agency official warned that the United States was now in danger of losing its leadership in computer security to European countries that have been investing heavily in new technologies. And some private computer company officials say there is a risk that the security of commercial computer systems will not be a priority under the new system.
The Security Center was established in 1981 as part of the Reagan push to establish a centralized office for military and civilian computer security alike. The center developed computer security standards and evaluated commercial security products. The 1987 law shifted oversight of civilian and unclassified Federal computer security systems to the Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology. The revised directive brings Administration policy in line with the 1987 law.
 
Concern About Espionage
Jerry Berman, director of American Civil Liberties Union's information technology project, praised the latest change, saying, ''By drawing this line between classified and unclassified information and communications systems it provides protection for insuring the free flow of information and the public's right to know.''
Concern over the original directive reached a peak in 1986 after representatives from Government agencies visited at least six private information companies, including Mead Data Central, the publisher of Nexis and Lexis electronic databases. Government officials asked if the company would be willing provide lists of subscribers but the company refused, saying it would be an unconstitutional invasion of privacy.
The officials said at the time that they were concerned that foreign agents would be able to piece together classified information by using various commercial and Government databases that were not classified. The officials were also concerned that economic competitors of the United States would be able to steal strategic technology found in the databases.
While civil libertarians generally praised the moves, information industry executives said that the Bush Administration changes raised new questions about the direction of the nation's policies on information and computer security.
An increasing reliance on computer networks for the nation's commercial, educational, scientific and military operations lead some executives to argue that the country is not spending enough to protect its computer systems.
 
'A Black Hole'
''The Bush Administration is more sophisticated than the Reagan Administration in terms of how they're going to handle the issue,'' said Kenneth B. Allen, senior vice president for governmental relations at Information Industries Association, a trade association based in Washington. ''But it's putting the whole thing into a black hole. The issues regarding sensitive information or computer security haven't gone away.''
Civil libertarians have continued to express concern about Government monitoring of private information, including public electronic mail and computer conference systems. After recent Federal investigations into computer break-ins, several computer industry executives established an organization called the Electronic Freedom Foundation to fight perceived violations of the rights of computer users.
But some computer security experts said the disappearance of the National Center for Computer Security had left a vacuum because Congress had never given its civilian counterpart, the National Institute for Standards and Technology, adequate financing. The military computer security arm has received 10 times the money that the institute received, said Government officials.
''What about the banks and the insurance companies?'' asked Stephen T. Walker, a former Pentagon official who is now president of Trusted Systems Inc., a developer of computer security systems. ''Nobody is looking out for the private sector. The question is how are we going to serve public interests as well as those of military organizations?''
He said that under the new directive, less attention was likely to be paid to the security of mainstream commercial computer security products. And he said the nation would become more vulnerable to computer intrusions and possibly electronic sabotage if more effort was not directed at securing both Government and commercial computers and computer networks.
The original policy directive, NSDD 145, issued by President Reagan in 1984, gave the National Security Agency, the Department of Defense and the president's national security adviser leading roles in establishing data security policy and standards. It also created a category of Government information called sensitive but unclassified.
That category could have included a wide variety of technical sources of information including computer databases, libraries of commercial satellite photographs and information housed in universities.
 
Fewer Turf Battles
The revised directive shifts the security agency's focus to the national security systems that contain classified information and cryptographic data and gives the National Institute of Standards and Technology the task of protecting and evaluating commercial computer security.
''The revision essentially blesses what we are now doing,'' said John Lyons, director of the institute. Acknowledging reports of turf battles over the setting of computer standards, he said, ''There are always going to be conflicts between military and civilian agencies on these issues.'' But he added that the relationship between the institute and the security agency had recently improved.
Several Government officials and agency consultants said that the move shifting the functions of the National Computer Security Center inside the N.S.A. was being made to consolidate both the computer security and communications security work done by the agency into a single organization.
''It's the result of an old war between the cryptographic side and the computer side of the agency,'' said a computer scientist who has consulted with the agency and who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''They've decided to enforce a common ground so there is one management. The National Computer Security Center will exist only as a mail drop and phone answering service.''

HEADLINE: 3 Youths Guilty of Rape And Assault of Jogger

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Three young men were convicted last night of raping and beating a jogger in Central Park but were acquitted on the most serious charge they faced, attempted murder.
The verdict was reached after 10 days of bitter jury deliberations, and it ended a chapter in a case that has become a milestone in the public's sense of helplessness against the violence of lawless teen-agers. The crime itself had triggered both fear and soul-searching as experts tried - and failed - to explain what could lead seemingly ordinary young men to commit so vicious an act and to do it so icily.
The verdict was delivered in a packed, tense courtroom at 7:15 P.M. As the jury foreman, Earle Fisher, told the clerk of the jurors' decision on each charge, the defendants, Antron McCray, 16 years old, Yusef Salaam, 16, and Raymond Santana, 15, sat motionless at the defense table.
 
Detectives Raise Fists
Perhaps in response to Justice Thomas B. Galligan's warning against outbursts, there was little other reaction in the courtroom - except for the lead detectives in the case, who made fists of victory in the back of the courtroom and pounded them one on top of the other, expressing their elation. 
Bobby and Linda McCray, the parents of Antron McCray, comforted each other as Mrs. McCray sobbed quietly.
Sherronne Salaam, Yusef Salaam's mother, who was barred from the courtroom for screaming ''liar'' at one prosecution witness, did not know the verdict until a pack of reporters rushed out of the courtroom and raced past her in the corridor outside.
''What happened?'' she cried as she recoiled from the rush.
Although the defendants faced the same charges as adults would have, they will be sentenced on Sept. 11 as juveniles. They face a maximum of 5 to 10 years, as much as they would have received if convicted of attempted murder. They will serve the first part of their sentences in a juvenile detention center and go to state prison when they turn 18.
If they were to be sentenced as adults they would face from 16 and two-thirds to 50 years in prison.
 
Acquittal Explained
Members of the jury who agreed to be interviewed last night said the deliberations were so emotional that they often descended into screaming and name-calling. [Page 33.] Asked why the youths had been acquitted of attempted murder despite the jogger's near-fatal injuries on the night of April 19, 1989, one juror, Charles Nestorick, said: ''it was a very, very painful decision.''
''It was very dark in the park and we believed that they didn't realize how much damage they were doing,'' he said. ''They were too young to know.''
Another juror, Rafael Mirandez, said, ''They had knives and didn't use them.''
A third, Ronald Gold, said he had resisted convicting Mr. McCray of rape until yesterday. He changed his mind, he said, after watching the youth's videotaped confession played one last time.
''I sat and looked at the video one last time, and I gave up,'' he said. ''I felt that he had done it. I looked at the way he told the story, and I felt that he actually believed it.''
Confessions by Mr. McCray as well as by Mr. Santana were videotaped by the police after the youths had been seized as suspects, and the tapes became crucial elements of the prosecution's case. The police had also obtained signed written statements from the two that had incriminated them, as well as a written but unsigned statement from Mr. Salaam detailing his involvement.
Moments after the verdicts were read, Justice Galligan revoked the bail of Mr. McCray and Mr. Salaam, ordering them to jail on Rikers Island. Mr. Santana has been incarcerated, unable to make bail, since he was captured on Central Park West moments after the 30-year-old investment banker was attacked.
Three other defendants charged with rape, attempted murder and assault will be tried this fall. They are Kevin Richardson, 15, Steven Lopez, 16, and Kharey Wise, 18, the only one who will be both tried and sentenced as an adult.
Throughout the trial the Manhattan courthouse at 111 Centre Street has been the scene of frequent and volatile demonstrations, most by people protesting that the trial was grounded in racism, that the defendants were falsely accused and that they could not get a fair trial. Last night, a protest turned ugly when several demonstrators rushed at Elizabeth Lederer, the lead prosecutor, making threats and shouting obscenities.
''The devil herself, she's going to pay for it,'' some shouted through a phalanx of detectives encircling her.
 
Denies Making Mistake
Robert P. Burns, the lawyer whose defense of Mr. Salaam was criticized during the trial as risky and at times sloppy, was jeered by the protesters.
''Very incompetent! Traitor!'' they screamed. One man yelled, ''He's no Alton Maddox or Mason.''
He then stopped to answer questions from reporters. ''I am very surprised by the verdict,'' he said. ''The public got this case all wrong. This was not a racial case. This was about the relationship between the police and minority people who are accused of crimes. It was only racial in the sense that the jogger was white and the defendants black and Hispanic.''
Asked if he made a mistake in putting Mr. Salaam on the stand, he said: ''No, not at all. I would do it again because putting him on the stand forced the public to take a closer look at the case. Everyone thought it was an open-and-shut case that would be completed in a few weeks with a guilty verdict. But that didn't happen because they saw what kind of person Yusef was, and that there was more to it than the police had told them.''
Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said last night: ''From the beginning I have insisted that this was not a racial case. The city is ill-served by those who have sought to exploit it to divide the races and advance their own private agendas.''
Even at the beginning of the trial nearly eight weeks ago, prosecutors said they would have trouble getting a conviction on the top count because they would have to prove beyond a reasonable doubt, as Justice Galligan instructed the jury, that each of the defendants intended to kill the woman, even if not with his own hands.
Nevertheless, the verdict was regarded as a major victory for the prosecution, given that there was no physical evidence or eyewitnesses who placed the defendants at the scene of the attack.
''It was the confessions, only the confessions,'' said Michael Joseph, the lawyer for Mr. McCray.
Peter Rivera, the lawyer for Mr. Santana, said the verdict ''was a case of middle-class morality convicting the defendants even before they came to court.''
Howard Diller, the lawyer for Mr. Richardson, who will be tried this fall, said, ''I strongly believe that prosecution will learn from this trial and bring a much tighter case against us.''
The emotions of the trial are likely to linger far beyond the verdict. In much the same way that the stabbing of Kitty Genovese in 1964 in view of her neighbors came to symbolize the indifference of New Yorkers toward brutal crime, this case crystallized the helplessness many feel when teen-agers rampage down a city street, a subway train or a park road.
The viciousness of the attack on the jogger appalled blacks and whites alike. But even before the case went to trial, issues of racism that went far beyond the question of whether the rape was racially motivated were written indelibly into the case.
 
Scottsboro Boys Recalled
Early on, many blacks worried that angry whites would stigmatize all young black males. And many blacks said the defendants had been railroaded, likening them to the Scottsboro Boys, nine black youths who became a cause celebre after they were accused of raping a white Alabama woman.
Questions were raised about a double standard: had the crime against a white Salomon Brothers investment banker received media attention denied nonwhite rape victims?
Some blacks questioned the competence of the suspects' lawyers, two of whom were assigned by the court because the defendants could not afford private counsel. There were times when the examinations conducted by Mr. Burns, the lawyer for Mr. Salaam, seemed to help the prosecution as much as the defense.
The case, like the Bensonhurst and Howard Beach trials, where victims and attackers were of different races, also played a part in New York City's mayoral race.
 
'Boyfriend Did It'
The lengthy proceedings polarized a city still divided over Tawana Brawley and other racial cases. Outside the courtroom the small but well-publicized group of protesters who championed the defendants also vilified the victim, accusing her of being sexually promiscuous, questioning her reasons for being in the park on the night of the attack, and screaming, ''The boyfriend did it.''
Last night a leader of the protest, the Rev. Al Sharpton, said the convictions ''will inflame the city.''
Through it all, the anonymous presence of the jogger stood out in the complicated, noisome trial. Every detail of her long, arduous recovery - as well as her amnesia about the attack - was chronicled in the newspapers. Her 12-minute testimony was the emotional high point of the trial, but even her name, which most newspapers did not print, became a battleground. The Amsterdam News, a black-owned newspaper, defiantly published her identity, contending that she had been granted special consideration denied to teen-age suspects whose guilt had not yet been proved.
The jurors - four of them white, four black, three Hispanic and one Asian - deliberated for 10 days. They asked to review a great deal of the evidence and for written testimony read and reread. No detail seemed too minute; one request was for the testimony of a police officer who reported a small fire in Central Park the night of the attack.
In the end, they were apparently convinced that what the police said the three had confessed to was essentially true: that the jogger had been raped and hideously battered and that all three young men had helped do it.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2663 words

HEADLINE: On Soviet Farms: Collective Indifference

SERIES: Soviet Food Crisis: Farms Without Farmers - First of two artilces.

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIKHEYEVO, U.S.S.R.

 BODY:
On a rainy day in late July, the Dawn Collective Farm resembles a hog wallow in which someone has planted discarded tractor parts, rusting sheds and weathered buildings, creating a powerful impression of gloom and neglect.
Along the muddy ruts that pass for roads, groups of men tinker with aging combines or stand about smoking, some of them red-eyed and sullen from the previous night's drinking. They wait with an air of indifference for enough sun to dry the sodden grain fields and let the harvest begin.
Outside the peeling administration cabin is an honor roll of top workers, like the one posted in every Soviet factory. The honorees include a mechanic, an engineer, a driver, a brigade leader and a cook. 
A visitor who has come looking for some understanding of why this resource-rich country cannot feed itself has just found a first clue: on the Dawn Collective Farm, there are no farmers.
''These people have long ago acquired the habit of working under someone else's command,'' said the farm chairman, Viktor A. Gulov, a newcomer here and a reformer. ''They are used to being told, 'It is time to go and plow, time to harvest, time to use the rakes.' And if nothing grows, it's not their responsibility.''
Mr. Gulov arrived at the Dawn Collective Farm in March determined to turn this indifferent proletariat into ''masters of the land.''
Like most reformers in the Soviet Union, he is frustrated from above by a rigid system that rations his fertilizer and gasoline, sets his prices, oversees the conformity of his management policies and then requisitions almost everything he produces - meat, milk, grain and potatoes.
But he contends the greater problem - and the one most in his power to combat - is below, the human factor, because no amount of economic liberty can feed the country unless there are willing farmers.
Probably no subject has consumed so much of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's time, or caused his economists so much chagrin, as the degeneration of Soviet farming.
Until the late 1920's, when forced collectivization transformed farming into a rural factory system, the nation was an exporter of wheat, rye, barley and oats.
Today, agriculture employs an astounding 19 percent of the Soviet workforce - in the United States, the figure is 2 percent - and absorbs 17 percent of all investment. Yet even in a good crop year like this one, the Soviet Union will import millions of tons of food, and still the populace will complain of hunger pangs.
 
Visit to Canadian Farms: Rebuke to Soviet System
 Mr. Gulov, who is 42 years old, comes to this problem as a missionary for a kind of farming that is alien to the Soviet system.
A big man with a square face and wavy hair, he grew up on a state farm on the southern steppes, but he would look at home at a fair in Iowa. He keeps Dale Carnegie self-improvement books on his shelf.
Fifteen years ago he read an account of farming in Canada - the northern latitude is not unlike Russia's farm belt - and it set off a rethinking that is still under way. Last year, Mr. Gulov was part of a small Soviet delegation to Canada where he found every day a rebuke to Soviet experience.
''When I was in Canada, I saw a 6-year-old boy, a farmer's son, who could drive a tractor,'' he says. ''The boy has his duties, he is paid, and he makes plans. By the time he is 14, he will be able to buy a car. He is already a farmer.
''Here we have lost the tradition. It's gotten so bad that in school they warn children: 'If you don't study hard, you will stay on the collective farm to work.' ''
When he was the director of a large collective farm near Rostov, in the richer south of Russia, Mr. Gulov applied his theories with great success. He reorganized the farm into a conglomerate of small, self-sufficient, profit-oriented teams, called cooperatives, a step in the evolution toward real farms.
 
When Fear Disappears, What Is the Stimulus?
 ''It's simple,'' he says. ''People need a reason to work. The reason can be fear, but fear is disappearing in this country. So you have to give them some other stimulus.''
In Rostov, they earned more money, but there was also the satisfaction and responsibility of stewardship.
The Rostov success got Mr. Gulov on the A-list of Soviet farm managers who get invited to Kremlin meetings where President Gorbachev, also from the southern steppes, conducts meetings on the dismal record of Soviet agriculture.
In March, forced to leave Rostov because of his son's allergic condition, Mr. Gulov settled here and set out to duplicate his experiment in tougher circumstances.
 
Different Territories; Far Different Attitudes
 In Rostov, where the climate is better and the Don Cossacks had a tradition of private farming, collectivization had not fully exterminated the will to farm. But here, 100 miles southwest of Moscow, where the Dawn Collective Farm occupies 20,000 acres, there is little history of commercial farming.
Before the collective farms were organized in 1929, it was mostly subsistence farming. Women tended the fields and cows while the men joined construction crews to bring in money. After collectivization, the workers were sharecroppers.
''We never farmed for money,'' said Mariya Ivanova, 64, as she put up salted pickles in her wooden house on the collective farm. ''We worked for shares.'' Those who have ambitions are often lured away to Moscow. Those who stay behind are mostly educated for rote, factory-style labor and not the complexities of modern farming.
Most have not finished high school. They work an 8-to-5 day, and line up at the pay window to collect their paychecks.
''Liquor and drinking are all they are interested in,'' Mr. Gulov lamented one evening, his optimism flagging a bit in the face of his labor material.
They are wary of change and cynical about reformers. Mr. Gulov, with his southern accent, his enthusiasms and promises, is the sixth chairman of the farm in 10 years, and no one interviewed during three days on the farm expected him to stick around long enough to make a great difference.
''He should have taken time to get the lay of the land,'' said one farm wife, waiting in line at the general store. ''Instead, from the first day he started to break things down. And people here had gotten used to doing things a certain way.''
 
A Welfare Community In a Rural Setting
 The Dawn Collective Farm is less a business than a cradle-to-grave welfare community. For its 186 workers and their families, the farm provides cheap housing, kindergarten, a cultural center and gardens.
The garden plots seem to get more attention than the communal lands, for the simple reason that they repay each family's labor with food. Private plots account for about 3 percent of Soviet farmland, but produce nearly a third of the country's meat, milk and vegetables. The communal lands provide a paycheck but there is nothing much to spend money on here.
A general store about 200 yards from the gate of the collective farm shows little evidence of being in a food-producing region. It stocks bread, canned beets, some salty cheese, soap, shovels and, for ration coupons, lump sugar. But no meat and no vegetables except a crate of tiny green tomatoes.
The farm residents make do with bicycles and motorscooters. The waiting list for a car is years long.
Most residents are without telephones. Even Mr. Gulov, when he wants to call Moscow, drives eight miles to the post office in Medyn, the regional center. The farm also supports 120 pensioners.
 
Too Many Distractions From Task of Farming
 As director, Mr. Gulov is responsible for obligations that in other societies are the business of local governments - road paving, telephone installation, kindergartens, entertainment. One morning, he was busy lobbying a state construction crew from the neighboring region to build 10 houses for farm families. The builders plead other priorities and a shortage of building materials. Mr. Gulov wheedles and jokes, but gets no commitment.
''I'm not a balletmaster,'' he snapped. ''Yet I am the one who is supposed to arrange for dance classes at the cultural center. It's absurd.''
To Mr. Gulov's mind, the fatal flaw of this collective life is the notion that everything is ''ours'' and thus belongs to no one.
During a drive across pastures, Mr. Gulov pointed out a deep gouge in a river bank where a careless, or tipsy, tractor driver toppled his vehicle down the slope. He shook his head in dismay as if to say, ''Imagine a farmer doing that if he owned the tractor!''
A visitor to a collective farm is likely to hear the same joke repeated to make the point about collectivization: ''Which is better, individual sex or group sex?'' the joke goes. ''Group sex, of course, because it leaves you time to goof off.''
 
Weaning Farm Members To Work on Their Own
 Mr. Gulov's scheme is to wean people from collectivization by breaking the farm into smaller units and giving workers more responsibility, edging toward real farming.
His first step here was to divide the farm into 14 cooperatives, some devoted to farming and others to support services such as equipment maintenance, fuel and veterinary services.
Later, he says, the cooperatives will evolve into a cluster of autonomous businesses. The farm bookkeeping office, for example, is to become a peasant bank, plugged into a new commercial banking system. His administration office will become a marketing agency and extension service.
One of the more radical changes he intends to spring on the collective farm is to cut the labor force in half by letting the women stay home, if they choose, to tend their children and the garden. Now they are legally obliged to hold jobs but they still end up doing the household chores after a full day's work.
The collective farm's property will be further subdivided into smaller farms, at first on a leased basis.
''We need 50 good farmers to have 50 farms,'' he said one night over coffee in the office of the local Communist Party boss, whose approval is essential for every move by the farm director.
''The remaining people can hire on as contract laborers, but they will have to perform or no one will need their services,'' he said.
''At the end of the first year, those who successfully managed the farm will be able to buy the land for a small price and become landowners.''
At this point the party chief, Vladimir P. Glushakov, loudly set down his coffee cup and interrupted: ''I disagree. The land cannot be turned into private property.''
The party leader, while generally in favor of Mr. Gulov's experiment, contends that the state must remain the ultimate owner, with power to give the land to the workers it deems most capable.
Mr. Gulov says that without the security of being an owner, no farmer will put money into improving the property.
''In Canada we met two brothers working on a farm,'' Mr. Gulov said. ''They produce twice as much wheat per acre as their neighbors. But nobody takes the neighbors' farm away from them.''
The party boss was insistent: ''Only those who can take care of the land must use it, not lazy bums.''
''What you suggest means living under the Sword of Damocles. Your land can be taken from you at any time,'' the reformer replied. ''The minister doesn't like you, and you lose your land. With your system, I do not want to become a farmer, because if anything happens - say Colorado beetles ruin my potatoes - then you can say I am a bad guy and I lose my farm.''
They argue good-naturedly for half an hour, and Mr. Gulov lets the party boss have the last word:
''From the point of view of morality and ethics, selling land is blasphemy,'' the party chief says. ''The land should not be treated as some prostitute who goes with the guy who pays the highest price.''
But later, in his truck heading home, Mr. Gulov is still fuming: ''Now you see why I say I need a lawyer for the farm.''
 
What the Workers Fear: Loss of Their Security
 Mr. Gulov's ideas encounter just as much reluctance from his workers as they do from the party.
Aleksei Yegorov, the farm electrician and overseer of the liverstock equipment, is one of Mr. Gulov's most trusted workers. The son of a local blacksmith, he has no interest in leaving the area. But he said that except for a few old-timers, everyone is apprehensive about the idea of owning a piece of land and farming it for profit.
''Let's say I buy land,'' he mused, as he and a visitor toured the repair sheds that are his domain. ''What am I going to grow on it? Where am I going to sell my crop? What kind of equipment am I going to need? It would be very hard to get started.
''When my father was still alive - he hoped one day to have his own land - maybe I would have gone into business with him. But now, you see, I'm a mechanic. I don't work the land. I'm 40 years old.''
He dreads even more the idea of having to venture into a market and sell. He has tried a few times with the meat and vegetables his family raises on their private plot, taking their produce to the city market. Now they sell their surpluses to a state organization.
''I'm used to the idea that I should not work for myself, but for the collective farm,'' he said. ''I'd have to forget all my experience to remake myself into something else.''
Sergei Dvukhsherstnov, 26, is chairman of one of Mr. Gulov's new cooperatives but he, too, seems uncertain.
He points to a huge combine that belongs now to his cooperative, bought on time from the collective farm. How much did it cost? He does not know. Nor does he know the price the state will pay this year for grain.
''In a year, he'll know those things,'' insists Mr. Gulov.
Much as he disparages the collective farm system, Mr. Gulov believes collectivization must endure for a while to ease new farmers toward independence.
 
An Independent Farmer Meets With Hostility
 A few miles up the road from the Dawn Collective Farm, in Medyn, Nikolai Fyedkin doubts seriously that collective farms will cooperate in their own demise. Mr. Fyedkin, the son of Siberian peasants who took up individual farming under the agrarian reforms of 1910, has been fighting to get started as a farmer on his own.
In June, on the strength of his 24 years experience on state farms, he finally got a collective farm to rent him 40 acres, a broken tractor and five cows. He salvaged and repaired a primitive mower and horse-drawn rake. But he says he has encountered constant resistance.
''They will never help me, because I am undermining the foundation they sit on,'' he said. ''They are just waiting for my project to fail.''
''They blame the problems of the collective farms on the farmers,'' he said. ''But many of the people are capable. All they need is property and some guarantees.''
Mr. Gulov admires dreamers and pioneers like Mr. Fyedkin who have set out to become family farmers in the Soviet Union - the newspapers frequently recount their duels with the incorrigible bureaucracy - but he believes the Soviet Union cannot leap from its state-run factory farms directly to a land of family farmers.
Even if some peasants are ready, Mr. Gulov says, the system is too obstructive for someone to fight it and find time to farm, too.
When Mr. Gulov needs extra hands to bring in the harvest, for example, he turns in time-honored fashion to the local party boss, who calls factory directors in surrounding cities to mobilize workers as temporary field hands. Who will turn out for Mr. Fyedkin?
When gasoline is scarce, as during this year's harvest, Mr. Gulov spends hours lobbying local officials, who in turn lobby Moscow for emergency deliveries. A farmer on his own, he says, would be out of luck.
''I have nothing bad to say about Fyedkin,'' Mr. Gulov said of the individualist up the road. ''But you have seen what I have to contend with. Who is going to tend Fyedkin's cows while he is doing battle with the bureaucrats?''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Statement by Iraq's Social Ministry

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Iraqi Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs about the treatment of foreigners in Iraq, as transmitted by the Iraqi press agency and translated by Reuters:
In the light of the decision taken by representatives of the Iraqi people and announced by the President of the National Assembly yesterday affirming that the people of Iraq are a peaceful people who want peace and reject wars and those calling for them, And as the Iraqis have committed no aggression against the West and have not harmed its legitimate interests, And as certain Western countries have adopted a hostile attitude toward the people of Iraq at the instigation of the United States of America without any justification, and the U.S.A. and those who cooperated with it are inciting war against Iraq in addition to occupying Arab land and Muslim holy shrines in Hejaz and Nejd, And as the presence of Western foreigners in Iraq may be one of the means for achieving peace and preventing aggression and war, thus making the American President and those allied with him reconsider his aggressive policy, The Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs announces the following: 1. America and its allies have gone beyond an economic boycott, which in essence means a ban on commercial exchanges. They embarked on the implementation of an economic blockade by the force of arms against Iraq, including food and medicine, and this is an act of war under world norms and international law. 
This measure has led and will lead to a shortage in imported food, including milk for babies.
As the world's babies, irrespective of their nationalities, are God's beloved and the beloved of the leader Saddam Hussein, and in harmony with our humanitarian principles, we have decided to treat babies of foreign families that the people have decided to host fully equally with the babies of Iraq in determining their needs. Should there be a shortage in babies' milk, medicine and other requirements because of the boycott, then whatever shortages of food, medicine, clothes or anything else affecting the babies of Iraq will also affect them equally. 2. In view of the circumstances of the boycott and economic blockade imposed by the U.S.A. and its allies through pressure, armed force and in a unilateral manner on Iraq, it will not be possible to insure food for all adults in the manner we desire. Some Europeans, and the British people in particular, have passed through such an experience or something similar to it. Thus, they appreciate such circumstances and the measures necessary.
Accordingly, it is quite natural that priority be given, as far as the type and quantity of food are concerned, first to the armed forces, because they are the shield of the homeland and the people against aggression, and then to workers in plants, factories and administrations related to war operations. The others will have a different level of interest.
And as the foreigners in question will not be among those engaged in the armed forces or activities related to them, their share of the food, the quantity and type, will be affected along with that of other Iraqis by our imports of food in one way or another. 3. On the basis of No. 2 above and to insure the necessary level and quantity of food for foreigners and Iraqis, the right solution is to end the boycott that the United States imposed on Iraq and the economic blockade that Bush and his allies are engaged in imposing by force of arms and unilaterally on Iraq. And as an advanced and speedy measure, everything related to food, medicine and humanitarian materials and goods should not be boycotted.
We call on the families of foreigners in Iraq, those in solidarity with them, and humanitarian associations in the West and in the world to raise their voices in support of these noble, humanitarian aims.
May God's success be with those advocating peace and love and rejecting war and enmity.

HEADLINE: Trouble on the Range as Cattlemen Try to Throw Off Forest Boss's Reins

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Aug. 14

 BODY:
In the high sage and scrub forest of southern Idaho, a handful of cattlemen have squared off against a stubborn United States ranger in a battle over land, water and a way of life as old as the mythology of the American West.
At one point, the squabble nearly became a shooting war as armed Federal officials confronted a group of cowboys and accused them of violating lease restrictions as they grazed their herd in the Sawtooth National Forest.
This week, a rancher said he and the other men who run cattle on public land south of here are ready to ''cut the throat'' of Donald Oman, the district ranger, if the Government does not transfer him.
 
Grazing Rights at a Price
The outcome of this conflict between ranchers and a ranger could determine how far the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management are willing to go to enforce new grazing guidelines called ''Change on the Range'' for the 250 million acres of public land used by cattle and sheep owners and managed by those two agencies. The guidelines are intended to limit overgrazing and abusive land practices. 
For generations the Government has sold to cattlemen the right to graze their herds on public meadows and grasslands, seeking to encourage the ranch economy and protect the land at the same time. The leases include restrictions on how many cattle are allowed, which environmentally fragile areas must be fenced off and how water holes are to be protected.
Some rangers and other critics of the Government's policy say the fees are too low, the herds are degrading the national forest land and the restrictions are being routinely ignored by ranchers who use their political influence with Western senators to undercut efforts to enforce the rules.
The cattlemen say that they protect the range as best they can, and that when they slip up, they have usually been given the benefit of the doubt. Their view is that a few zealous supervisors led by Mr. Oman are threatening their way of life.
Mr. Oman has been with the Forest Service for 26 years, but it has only been in the last three years that he was assigned to the Sawtooth Forest, a heavily grazed area. The ranchers want him removed from the district, where 320,000 acres of national forest are under his supervision. Most of that acreage is used as grazing land by 30 ranchers, who hold permits to run about 7,000 cattle over the dry and hostile terrain.
''Either Oman is gone or he's going to have an accident,'' said Winslow Whitely, who has one of the biggest herds in the district. ''Myself and every other one of the permit holders would cut his throat if we could get him alone.''
 
'Yes, It's Intentional'
Asked if he was making a specific threat on the life of the district ranger, Mr. Whitely said, ''Yes, it's intentional. If they don't move him out of this district, we will.''
Mr. Oman said he was appalled at how heavy grazing has destroyed fragile grasslands, ripped up narrow streambeds and changed the natural character of much of the land. The ranchers are angry at him, he said, because he insists that they live up to the stewardship terms of their contracts, and because he has confronted those who have defied him.
''This land belongs to 250 million Americans, not just the guy with the cattle-grazing permit,'' the 46-year-old Mr. Oman said.
Late last year, the cattlemen contacted the office of Senator Steven Symms, Republican of Idaho, asking that Mr. Oman be transferred from the Sawtooth's Cassia District. After several meetings among Forest Service officials, aides of Senator Symms and the ranchers, it was agreed that Mr. Oman would be transferred, according to several people who attended the meetings.
But instead of accepting a transfer, Mr. Oman filed a whistle-blower's complaint with the Inspector General's office of the Agriculture Department, which operates the Forest Service. The whistle-blower law is intended to protect Federal employees who feel they are being harassed for speaking out about specific abuses.
Mr. Oman said he does not want to leave the district or get in a prolonged fight with his superiors. ''The Forest Service is my life,'' he said. ''I practically wear green shorts to bed with my badge on them.''
 
'No Plans' to Remove Ranger
This week, Agriculture Department officials said they had completed a lengthy investigation of Mr. Oman's complaint, but have not reached a decision on whether he will remain district ranger in southern Idaho.
''There are no plans to remove Don Oman at this time,'' said Wallace Shiverdecker, a Forest Service spokesman. His superiors declined to comment about Mr. Oman while a decision is pending.
Mr. Oman's complaints have underscored several major land issues that have long been a source of conflict in the West, where ranchers have been grazing cattle on public land for more than a hundred years.
More than half of the 250 million acres of Government land subject to livestock grazing is in poor condition from overuse and lax land management, according to a recent report by the National Wildlife Federation and the Natural Resource Defense Council. In the Sawtooth National Forest, a two-million-acre expanse that embraces the desert district in the south and the alpine country north of Sun Valley, 37 percent of the grazing land surveyed by the General Accounting Office in 1988 was found to be in poor condition.
The accounting office, the investigative arm of Congress, reported that cattle had overgrazed meadows and stripped streams of vegetation, leading to erosion and consequently making it more difficult to support fish and other wildlife.
But cattlemen say it is in their best interest to keep the land in good shape. And Randall Brewer, of the Idaho Cattle Association, said that only isolated areas had been badly damaged.
 
History of Catering to Ranchers
The Government study said the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management have a history of kowtowing to the cattle industry.
''There's an old saying in the Forest Service that if you cross a stockman, you can expect to be shipped to Siberia tomorrow,'' said Jim Prunty, who retired from the service two years ago and, now as a private citizen, is trying to document land abuses here.
''Don Oman was the first person ever to say no to these people and that's why he's in trouble,'' Mr. Prunty said. ''They may sacrifice him at the Forest Service, but what he's doing is right. The grazing practices on these lands are leaving a legacy of desertification and destruction.''
Mr. Oman said he is not opposed to cattle grazing in the national forests, but he has insisted that the ranchers do more to repair the land. In the last three years, he has issued citations, threatened to revoke permits and required ranchers to repair fences and watering holes.
To the ranchers, Mr. Oman's worst offense was an unannounced cattle count last fall, in which the ranger, accompanied by two armed Federal officials, surprised a group of cowboys who were running their herd through the forest. Mr. Oman said he needed armed support because the ranchers had threatened his life. The cattlemen accused him of using ''Gestapo tactics,'' and some of the men said the situation nearly ended in a shootout.
Mr. Oman said the count showed that the ranchers had more calves on public land than their contract allowed. The ranchers responded that a handful of extra animals had slipped through.
 
Curious Costs of Grazing
Economics is another bone of contention between cattlemen and managers of public land. The ranchers pay only $1.81 for one month of grazing for each thousand-pound animal. The rate represents one-fifth of private grazing costs, Government studies show.
By Mr. Whitely's estimates, he will make about $250 in profit for each cow. With a permit that allows him to graze 1,563 animals this year, he stands to make just under $400,000, assuming that every one of those cattle is eventually sold.
When Federal officials proposed changing the grazing rate in 1986, President Ronald Reagan issued an executive order that retained the cost formula. Last year, the Forest Service spent $34.5 million on its range management program, and took in only $10.9 million in grazing fees.
Asked why the money-losing grazing program has changed little over the years, Deen Boe, the Forest Service's deputy director for range management, said, ''It's a political thing. We deal with what we're given.''

HEADLINE: 'Council School' Offers Training to Hopefuls

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
In an era devoted to managing skills and behavior - where finishing schools and canine obedience schools exist near treatment centers for sex or food addicts - perhaps it was inevitable that New Yorkers would get a training program for City Council aspirants.
The $300, three-week program will offer classes on the city's political structure, fund-raising, speech-making and press management, and will be limited to 50 ''serious contenders'' for Council seats. The application deadline is Sept. 1 for a course that begins on Oct. 15.
Already, people are talking about the ''Council school.'' And even if it is perceived as a tad idealistic in a city with a wary electorate bitten hard by fiscal problems, racial tension and crime, it is also greeted as a nice try. 
 
Larger Talent Pool
''Anything that would encourage people to run for office is a good idea,'' said Council Speaker Peter Vallone. ''What makes this a particularly unusual election is that with the 16 new seats there is more chance than ever to level the playing field for newcomers. Usually, incumbents have the advantage.''
The Council, long considered the Rodney Dangerfield of local politics, ascended to the center of city government with the demise of the Board of Estimate last week.
Sixteen new Council seats have been added to handle the new responsibilities.
But just how eager ordinary New Yorkers are to negotiate the campaign trail, however, remains to be seen. Only six applications have been received by the La Guardia Public Life Training Center. David Fleischer, associate director for the center at the Bank Street College of Education, said there have been 350 requests for applications.
''With the 16 new Council seats under the charter revision there has to be a much greater talent pool that is drawn from for the Council to be effective,'' said Mr. Fleischer, a lawyer and former campaign manager for Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan.
''My belief is there are a lot of good, decent people out there who haven't given up on the city,'' Mr. Fleischer said. ''There are a lot of people who would run for office if they had the knowledge of how to do so.''
 
Scholarships Are Available
The nonpartisan center will disband after the course and will not endorse candidates. Its co-sponsors include the New York City League of Women Voters and the New York Public Interest Research Group. The idea for the center, Mr. Fleischer said, came from discussions with about 100 political pundits, elected officials and educators. Their search was for a vehicle to help people enter politics.
Mr. Fleischer said the center is particularly interested in helping gay, women, black or disabled candidates. The two-page course application asks for recommendations and references, campaign experience, two essays on why the applicant wants a Council seat, their community work and people who have shaped their thinking. Scholarships are available.
Trainees will be selected by a board that includes former Mayor John V. Lindsay, the former school board president, Robert Wagner Jr., and the president of the League of Women Voters, Laura Altschuler.
Teachers will include Fred Schwartz, chairman of the charter revision committee, and an assortment of economists, issue advocates, journalists and other specialists.
 
Seeing Council as Creative
''I think it's a perfect example of groups of people recognizing the significance of the new Council under charter,'' said Eric Lane, counsel to the charter commission. ''I think it's an excellent idea.''
''If it's motivational, if it's creates interest, if it creates information about the government it's very useful,'' Mr. Lane said of the center. ''If 50 percent of what is intended gets done, that's good.''

HEADLINE: Homeless Man Is Indicted in Rutgers Fires

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 18

 BODY:
An unemployed homeless man has been indicted on charges of setting fires at three fraternity houses and two private residences near the Rutgers University campus here.
The Middlesex County Prosecutor, Alan Rockoff, announced Friday that a grand jury had returned a five-count indictment on Wednesday against the man, Brian Keith, 33 years old. 
Mr. Keith was arrested on June 19 on charges of setting the fires the previous night. There were no injuries.
If convicted, Mr. Keith, who was being held at the Middlesex County Adult Correction Center in North Brunswick, faces a 20-year prison term and fines up to $100,000 for each aggravated arson count against him, Mr. Rockoff said.
He declined to discuss a possible motive for the fires.
Fires that burned through the three fraternity houses and two private homes on June 18 left 35 Phi Gamma Delta brothers without living quarters.
Damage to the private homes and the other fraternity houses was minimal, but the first-floor of the Phi Gamma Delta house was gutted.
Mr. Rockoff said Mr. Keith last worked at Revlon Inc., in Edison, about a year ago and was one of 14 tenants housed at a motel there by the Middlesex County Board of Social Services.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Lehigh;
A Condo Project Strikes the Fancy Of Many Parents

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa.

 BODY:
Harold K. Tish said he knew that his University Square condominium project was going to be a success when he received a letter from a Lehigh University alumnus living on a remote island in the South Pacific. The alumnus, Thomas A. Bayer, was interested in buying a condominium for his daughter, Melissa, an incoming freshman at Lehigh.
''Here's a guy a world away who is interested in University Square,'' Mr. Tish said.
To bolster the local economy and to expand student housing options, Lehigh has been advising Mr. Tish on his project, which enables parents of Lehigh students to buy condominiums for their children and to realize tax advantages and, perhaps, a capital gain on an eventual sale. 
University Square is being promoted by the university's housing office, and the condos have been advertised in the campus newspaper and Lehigh's alumni magazine.
Mr. Tish said his $2 million project not only offers 14 two-bedroom condominiums, for between $85,000 and $90,000, but also includes offices and retail outlets.
 
Still Recovering From Slump
''This is the only mixed-use, upscale project of its kind in our area,'' said Mr. Tish, a real-estate developer from central New Jersey who moved to Bethlehem this year.
University Square, Mr. Tish predicted, will serve as a catalyst for other business ventures in South Bethlehem. The local economy has been slow to recover from the slump of the early 1980's that forced thousands of layoffs at the community's lifeblood, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
Many of the local businesses rely on Lehigh's 7,000 students to survive.
''This campus isn't busy just during the school year. It hops 12 months of the year,'' said Barbara Kreppel, Lehigh's director of auxiliary services. ''And there's a lot of opportunities to forge business-university partnerships.''
In 1988, when Mr. Tish first bought the half-acre property on the campus's main business strip, his idea was to market condominiums exclusively to the parents of students. But by the time the units were completed and ready for sale last November, Mr. Tish had received inquiries from a wide range of prospective buyers - from Lehigh employees to alumni. Tax Write-Offs, Anyone? Mr. Tish said parents who buy the condominiums can write offs mortgage interest and the monthly $64 maintenance fee. Since each unit can house up to four students, parents can also hire their sons or daughters as managers of the unit, paying them to collect rents, a salary that can be written off as a business expense, Mr. Tish said.
Half of the 14 units have been sold so far: 4 to students or their parents, 2 to alumni and 1 to a university employee. Mr. Tish said since none of the purchased units have been put up for sale, it is difficult to determine their resale value.
The units, equipped with washers, dryers and dishwashers, are housed in two red and dark green stone buildings.
Owen and Rose Carlin of Mendham Township, N.J., bought a unit last fall after their son, Thomas, a sophomore at the time, was unable to get on-campus housing through a lottery system.
''Our feeling was that it was certainly a break-even situation,'' said Mr. Owen, a retired chemical engineer. ''We figured we would save on housing costs for two years and then after our son graduated, we might realize a capital gain.''
Ms. Kreppel said working with Mr. Tish is part of an initiative by Lehigh to help continue South Bethlehem's renaissance, which has an active merchants' association.
Ms. Kreppel worked with Mr. Tish in luring business tenants to University Square. The new tenants included a travel agency and a printing company that have large contracts with Lehigh. A bank has also signed a lease.
''We're currently talking to a bagel company to rent space,'' Ms. Kreppel said. ''If we've had one outstanding request from students, it's to have a bagel shop on campus.''

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Anglo-American Music And a World Attuned

BYLINE: By John Rockwell

 BODY:
If the arts are mankind's mirror, then international popular music may be a reflection of international politics and economics. Or so I brooded recently in Hamburg, West Germany, listening to the music on a restaurant sound system. The fare consisted of a nonstop onslaught of English and American pop hits, not a German among them.
At the same time, the hippest thing in Manhattan is West African and Brazilian bands at S.O.B.'s, Kilimanjaro or the Beacon Theater. There is a powerful crosscurrent at work in the pop world today, as third-world and European musicians synthesize Anglo-American stylistic signatures with their own language and musical traditions. 
What is trendy today may well be massively popular tomorrow, presaging a reversal in the mainstream's flow. Such shifts not only reflect larger patterns in the relationship of the industrialized West to the rest of the world, but also suggest that third-world pop musicians may have hit upon what made Anglo-American pop so powerful in the first place.
What shapes musical fashion? One argument is that with the eruption of energy in the 1950's and 60's that defined modern popular music, something so potent was born of the blend of American black music, American and English white folk music and electronic amplification that it swept the world like an irresistible tide.
That potency was part esthetic - no one had heard anything like this before - but the music's power was also moral and political. It represented a liberation from constraint, an assertion of self. And as much as repressed American teen-agers in the 50's and idealistic world-changers in the 60's felt that extramusical impact, so do Eastern Europeans and Chinese and South Americans feel it today.
But there is a more cynical analysis to explain the domination of Anglo-American pop over the last generation. By that theory, American rock owes its success to marketing muscle: it is popular not because of intrinsic worth but because record companies, tour promoters and radio stations united monopolistically to drive out the competition, both economic and stylistic.
My own view, born of the belief that capitalism reflects genuine consumer desires, is that these interpretations are by no means antithetical. Even if Anglo-American rock has been artificially reinforced, the fact remains that it is indeed popular, and exerts an enormous impact worldwide. Last week, according to Billboard magazine, the top ''pan-European'' singles artist was M. C. Hammer and the top album seller was New Kids on the Block.
But if the domination were so complete, American trend-setters would not be doting on the likes of Salif Keita of Mali, Youssou N'Dour of Senegal and Milton Nascimento of Brazil. Especially outside Western Europe, indigenous folk styles and hybrid forms of electrified pop have been flourishing all along. If Anglo-American cultural capitalism were as all-powerful as some fear, it would have squelched such competition long ago. Now, capitalists are looking for ways to exploit the competition.
Instead of repressing indigenous talent, Anglo-American pop has encouraged it. What we are now seeing is the flowering of a generation of non-English-speaking pop stars who have adapted local languages and folk idioms to Anglo-American musical styles, above all electric guitars and a rock-solid beat. They have fashioned danceable, impassioned syntheses that are doubling back to influence English-language pop.
This all corresponds to larger patterns of post-imperialist politics and economics. English is the language of international politics and finance, and many world leaders wear Western-style suits, fly in Western airplanes and stay in Western-style, if not Western-owned, luxury hotels.
In popular music, however, English cannot dominate to the same degree that it does in diplomacy and finance. That is partly because it is a demotic art, appealing to the masses. Language binds a culture together: popular musicians use the native language as a political act - just as German composers did in the early 19th century, rejecting the bondage implied by composing their operas in the then-international musical language of Italian. The international popularity of Italian opera or pop songs in English or, now, songs in Zulu or Senegalese ultimately attests to the dominating power of music over words.
Thus popular music today has become a crossfire of conflicting, stimulating international and national influences, particularly in this era of rampant nationalist pride. Anglo-American rock and dance music remain ubiquitous because they are still esthetically effective and perceived as trendy - emblems of the good life to the rest of the world.
But increasingly, native-born, native-speaking pop stars have arisen throughout the world, speaking colloquially to their countrymen and often providing political and moral models in the same manner as American and English pop icons of the 60's. The singer and composer Fela Anikalupo Kuti, so popular that he talked of running for president of Nigeria, and the late reggae singer Bob Marley, almost assassinated as part of Jamaica's bitter political polemics, are but two examples.
That moral urgency, apart from the timbral allure of exotic trappings, may be the underlying reason for the success of so many third-world bands among American taste-makers. These are musicians who don't just offer something piquant to a jaded musical palate. They sing and play with a fervor born partly of raw talent and partly of excited ambition. But their intensity also owes something to an extramusical aura that has eluded too many Anglo-American pop stars of the 1980's, co-opted by the very marketing forces that won them international stardom in the first place.
