PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1850 words

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Today's Yellow Brick Road Leads Straight to Hell

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
Sailor and Lula, the strangely sympathetic misfits in David Lynch's ''Wild at Heart,'' drive a big old convertible from Cape Fear, N.C., through New Orleans and on to Big Tuna, Tex. They are preoccupied with making love and steering clear of the law, but they always keep an eye on the yellow brick road.
''Too bad he can't just visit that old Wizard of Oz and get some advice,'' Sailor says sincerely when Lula tells about her cousin Dell -a Lynchian creature who doesn't need a heart or brain or courage, just the sense to stop putting cockroaches in his pants.
Where Dorothy tells Toto, ''I've a feeling we're not in Kansas anymore,'' Lula cruising down the highway and crossing state lines also knows a turning point when she sees one. Smoking a cigarette, snapping her gum and letting her long blond hair fly in the breeze, she tells Sailor, ''I guess you broke parole now.'' 
And when they land in dusty little Big Tuna, the lovers sense they can't outrun their bad luck anymore. ''I know it ain't exactly the Emerald City,'' says Sailor, and soon Lula has to admit, ''Seems we sort of broke down on the yellow brick road.''
A violent story of romance on the run, ''Wild at Heart'' both idolizes and undermines the most beloved of all road movies and points to a new twist in the genre. Though few do so as blatantly as Mr. Lynch, some of today's most astute and talented directors have also created road movies that subvert the classic route to Oz. Their films reflect contemporary struggles against crime, violence and unemployment, yet they are unwilling to surrender the dreams of freedom and happiness the road has traditionally represented.
Films like ''The Wizard of Oz'' (1939) and Preston Sturges's ''Sullivan's Travels'' (1941) defined the standard pattern for road movies: whether the hero was a scarecrow or a rich film director bumming cross-country during the Depression, characters traveled through danger and disillusionment to healthy self-knowledge and back to the safety of home. They followed an optimistic course as old as the American West and as deeply entrenched in our culture as Whitman's ''Song of the Open Road.''
But today's best road movies are bizarre, comic, one-way journeys to the dark side of self and society. ''Wild at Heart'' and Jonathan Demme's ''Something Wild'' portray the road as a lurid, chaotic, criminal place where characters discover their worst nightmares come true. In Jim Jarmusch's ''Stranger Than Paradise'' and in the young Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki's current ''Ariel'' (strongly influenced by American movies), the road is a bleak and grimy landscape where hapless, unimaginative heroes seek out small grains of luck or love. These roads are fraught with dangers more real than flying monkeys; botched robberies, prison cells and even death are surprisingly common.
On one level, such films are the cultural descendants of cynical 60's road movies like ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and ''Easy Rider,'' stories of thwarted freedom that sharply defined the distance between respectable, law-abiding society and the rebellious counterculture at its height. The lawless heroes of ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and ''Easy Rider'' were symbolic free spirits, and the fact that they were ultimately destroyed only made these films more of a rallying cry against social conservatism.
But the new road movies are more ambivalent. They often have forced happy endings, which suggest a nostalgic longing for the road to Oz even while the film's surface depicts a broken-down society. And their humor offsets the characters' fear of a journey into the metaphorical darkness of the open road and of their own hearts.
In ''Wild at Heart,'' all the references to ''The Wizard of Oz'' -including Lula's wicked mother riding through the sky on a broomstick and Glinda the Good Witch descending to earth in a bubble - are Mr. Lynch's additions to the spare, realistic novel by Barry Gifford on which the movie is based. But even without that obvious motif, ''Wild at Heart'' would be a pure example of the new, subversive road movie.
As they run from Lula's disapproving mother, who has put a private detective and a hired killer on their trail, Sailor and Lula (Nicolas Cage and Laura Dern) experience an ominous sense of death on the road. The radio news is full of reports of necrophilia and crocodiles eating corpses in the Ganges. They pull over to a roadside accident and see a young woman die before their eyes. Yet when they run out of money in Big Tuna, Sailor leaves their shabby motel room to take part in a robbery that he says will give them enough cash to go ''far down the yellow brick road.'' The road, yellow brick or otherwise, still represents a bright future, against all the harsh evidence. And the robbery, one of the most violent scenes in recent movies, only proves how misguided Sailor's hopes have been.
Like Mr. Lynch's films, especially ''Blue Velvet,'' Jonathan Demme's are also marked by a strong sense of the texture of American life. Even more than Mr. Lynch, he finds America on the road. In ''Melvin and Howard,'' Melvin Dummar drives along in his pickup truck and stops for a straggly old man who claims to be Howard Hughes. This is the basis for the classic Demme scene in which Melvin and Howard bump along the road in the pickup singing one of Melvin's original songs, ''Santa's Souped-Up Sleigh.''
But Mr. Demme's sense of the road is at its most astute and vibrant in ''Something Wild.'' Like Lula in ''Wild at Heart,'' Lulu in ''Something Wild'' is Dorothy turned inside out, hellbent on leaving home and finding sexual adventure on the road. When Lulu (Melanie Griffith) kidnaps Charlie, the buttoned-down businessman played by Jeff Daniels, she takes him from New York to Pennsylvania along the kitschy roads of small-town America. In a motel room, she handcuffs him to a bed and wildly distracts him while forcing him to talk to his boss on the phone.
She crashes her old green convertible into a flashing sign that reads: ''Whoa! You just passed the best scrapple in Penna.'' They travel along a road filled with liquor stores, signs for real-estate companies, used-car dealers and gas stations with convenience stores that sell drinks, baseball caps and souvenir T-shirts that read ''Virginia is for lovers.'' This witty, cluttered, tacky route redefines the idea of the romantic, wide-open road.
And just when Lulu seems transformed into a girl with an All-American past, her criminal ex-husband appears. Soon Charlie is implicated in an armed robbery, is forced to confront his own uneasy attraction to Lulu's disreputable life, and finally engages in a violent confrontation with the ex-husband. ''Something Wild'' suggests that being dragged onto the road frees Charlie from his repressive, unnhappy past. But the upbeat ending is undermined by the film's dark and violent episodes.
There is nothing so violent in Jim Jarmusch's genial films. For him, the road is not sinister; it is merely banal. In Mr. Jarmusch's brilliant and unpretentious deadpan style, ''Stranger Than Paradise'' overturns the classic image of America as a boundless paradise and an Eden for immigrants. When a young woman named Eva travels from Budapest to live with her aunt in Cleveland, she stops in New York and stays with her cousin Willie. For her, New York is the inside of Willie's shabby apartment.
And the rest of America seems just as cramped. When Willie and his friend Eddie - both small-time gamblers in slouchy hats - drive to visit Eva, the road to Cleveland evokes a slushy industrial landscape that seems especially stark in the film's black-and-white photography. Finally Eddie realizes, ''It's funny. You come someplace new and everything looks just the same.''
Aiming for adventure, the trio heads to Florida, where Eva is left in a tiny motel room while Willie and Eddie go to the race track. Except for the weather (''Now we look like real tourists,'' Willie says after he buys everyone sunglasses), they might as well be in Cleveland.
This low-key comic approach to life on the road - the road to limited possibilities - also informs Mr. Jarmusch's ''Down by Law,'' in which three men find themselves in a shared jail cell where they dance around and sing, ''I scream, you scream, we all scream for ice cream.'' They escape to become fugitive companions in the Louisiana bayou. Except for the trees, they might as well be in Cleveland, too. And as the hero of Mr. Kaurismaki's ''Ariel'' drives a Cadillac convertible through the snowy landscape from Lapland to Helsinki, it looks like all roads lead to Cleveland. ''Ariel'' features a landscape as bleak as Mr. Jarmusch's and an unemployed hero named Taisto, who is even more bereft of imagination than Willie and Eddie.
Though Mr. Kaurismaki has been compared to Mr. Jarmusch, his sense of the road is both more dangerous and more hopeful. Almost at once, Taisto is robbed of all his money at a hamburger stand. Later, his luck changes when a meter maid who is about to write him a ticket falls in love with him instead. Yet other twists of bad luck follow a pattern typical of the subversive road movie: prison, an escape, a bank robbery and eventually a murder in self-defense. Along with the meter maid and her son, he escapes on a cargo ship called Ariel, which will take them to Mexico, while ''Somewhere Over the Rainbow'' in Finnish is sung in the background. As in ''Wild at Heart,'' this pointed reference suggests how far film makers have come from ''The Wizard of Oz,'' even while the song acknowledges the movie's tenacious hold on our imaginations.
In fact, the ending of ''Wild at Heart'' may be the best expression of how deeply Oz has shaped the contemporary road movie. Without revealing the film's ending, it is possible to say that it is more upbeat than the one in Mr. Gifford's novel and that it involves Glinda, who tells Sailor, ''If you're truly wild at heart you'll fight for your dreams.'' The creators of today's road movies recognize that the road leads to the nightmarish wilds of society and of their characters' own hearts. But in their films' happy endings, they fight for the persistent hope that the road still leads to a place where dreams come true.
It is a dream that wrestles with reality and with other kinds of road movies. In some films the road remains a simple convenience, as in ''Rainman,'' where it allows Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman to be isolated together; the road and the landscape are mere backdrops. But in the Australian trilogy ''Mad Max,'' ''The Road Warrior'' and ''Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome,'' the road is a post-apocalyptic battleground for survival; civilization has virtually crumbled; cars have become weapons for futuristic gladiators, and gasoline is a commodity worth killing for. It is a cartoonish version of the journey to self and society, but one that is in tune with the new, subversive road movie.
It is easy to imagine ''Somewhere Over the Rainbow'' as a heavily ironic comment on Mad Max's adventures, easy to see how far film makers have come from the road to Oz.

PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2106 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
In the Brazilian Jungle They Have a Story to Tell

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: BELEM, Brazil

 BODY:
Working in the jungle one degree south of the Equator, the heat on the set repeatedly hit 108 degrees. At dusk, tropical downpours washed out key shots day after day. Exotic ailments felled several of Hollywood's finest. During one week of night shooting, the call sheet warned actors of ''insects and crawly things around the set.''
Finally, the actor Tom Waits rose up one evening from the torpor of the Hotel Anaconda bar. Wild-eyed and disheveled, he angrily confronted Hector Babenco, the film's Argentine director.
''Don't jerk us around!'' the perspiring Mr. Waits ranted. ''We're American citizens! You got that? American citizens!'' 
Mr. Babenco, suppressing a smirk, replied in broken English: ''Please - complain it to your American Embassy. Use my radio - no charge.''
In the humid blur of the Amazon, it was not a revolt on the set, but practice for a scene of a movie version of Peter Matthiessen's 1965 novel, ''At Play in the Fields of the Lord,'' which is now being shot in the Brazilian jungle.
The script features Indians, missionaries, gold miners and ''developers of the forest.'' But the assemblage of acting, writing, directing and producing talent guarantees that this will not be a rain forest quickie.
The screenplay is by Mr. Babenco and Jean-Claude Carriere, who also wrote the screenplays for ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' and for a number of Luis Bunuel's later movies.
Mr. Babenco, who is currently Latin America's most prominent director, also directed ''Pixote,'' ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' and ''Ironweed.'' The producer is Saul Zaentz, who also produced ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' ''Amadeus'' and ''Unbearable Lightness.''
The cast includes the largest collection of North American acting talent seen in South America in many years: Kathy Bates, Tom Berenger, Daryl Hannah, John Lithgow, Aidan Quinn and Mr. Waits.
''A film like this comes along once every 10 years,'' said Ms. Hannah, who plays a missionary's wife. ''Very few films really have the intention of being something. When you get an offer like this, you jump at it.''
From another side of the Belem Hilton swimming pool, Mr. Lithgow, who plays Ms. Hannah's intolerant missionary husband, said: ''The film is about the collision of cultures, the destruction of one culture by another. These are mighty issues to grapple with. These are people who make serious films.''
The movie is set in Mae de Deus, an imaginary Amazonian river town that represents a sordid end of the line for ''Western civilization.'' Upriver are the Niaruna Indians, inhabiting a universe still undisturbed after five centuries of European colonization of the continent. Enter two American missionary couples bent on converting the heathen. Enter two American soldiers of fortune (Mr. Waits and Mr. Berenger) who lose their way in the forest and land their 1957 Beaver DeHavilland on the town's grassy airstrip. Painted on one side of the fuselage is the duo's business card: ''Small Wars & Demolition.''
Playing the Americans off against one another, an unscrupulous Brazilian police chief (Jose Dumont) is willing to use either American Bibles or American bombs to open the Niaruna area up to ''progress,'' in the form of ranchers and gold prospectors.
But a bombing mission goes awry when one of the mercenaries (Mr. Berenger) resuscitates his Cheyenne Indian roots. He literally bails out of the Western world and joins the Niaruna.
In interviews in Belem and on the jungle set, Mr. Babenco and the actors bridled at suggestions that ''Fields of the Lord'' might represent the latest twist on a long-running Hollywood formula for success: set dramas involving first-world protagonists against third-world backdrops. (Examples of the genre might include ''Missing'' and ''Out of Africa.'') ''This is not going to be a velvet painting for white people and their problems,'' growled Mr. Waits, a blues singer who can be as wild-eyed and disheveled off the set as on.
In his 11th-floor hotel suite overlooking this river port, Mr. Babenco, who was born in Argentina but has lived in Brazil for the last 18 years, echoed that conviction. ''The Indians are the most important part of the movie,'' he said. ''The Indians are not an excuse for the Anglo-Saxons to do their thing.'' As if to underline the point, he had decorated two walls of his suite - home for the six months of filming - with a collage of color photographs of aboriginal peoples from the Amazon to Africa.
''These human beings live in perfect harmony with the environment; they are the real keepers of the forest,'' the director said. ''Then we white people tell them how great our civilization is, how great our God is. The transparent universe is broken.''
Except for scenes on an American Indian reservation and at Venezuela's Angel Falls, ''Fields'' is being shot in Brazil. One third of the movie will be filmed at an Indian ''maloca'' or traditional style thatch-roofed roundhouse that has been built in theforest, 30 minutes by boat up the Guama River from here. Unwilling to be ''a character of their cultural destruction,'' Mr. Babenco has refused to film in a real Indian village. To cast the Niurana, a mythical tribe, the director assembled 140 Indians from ranches and roadsides all over the Amazon.
''They don't speak Portuguese; they don't even know what a movie is,'' the director said.
A talent scout found one protagonist, Samuel Karaja, a Bororo Indian, lying intoxicated on a bench at the Brasilia bus station. Mr. Karaja, will play Aeore, a Niurana warrior who favors murdering the missionaries.
''It's the most perverse and contemptible way of destroying a civilization - and it has been happening since the 15th century,'' Mr. Babenco said, recalling a visit last year to a Yanomami Indian village in the northern Amazon that had fallen under the tutelage of a Protestant mission.
Down by the hotel swimming pool, Mr. Waits, who plays the mercenary Wolf, had a blunter view of the catechizing zeal of the Amazon's missionaries. ''The missionaries get into the hearts and minds of Indians through Bic lighters and Johnnie Walker scotch,'' he charged in a gravelly voice. ''I don't understand people who feel compelled to shove their religion down other people's throats. It's like painting a fence. You don't want to miss a spot, or else God will get mad.''
On film, Mr. Berenger in the role of Moon, the half-Cheyenne adventurer, will demand of a missionary, played by Aidan Quinn: ''If the Lord made Indians the way they are, who are you people to want them different?''
Symbolizing the double threat to the Indians, the film's logo shows a lone tribesman aiming an arrow at an airplane. ''The Indian shoots an arrow in the direction of the plane, which casts a shadow in the shape of a cross,'' reads the script. ''The arrow flies up into the air and falls again. The Indian shouts at the plane - without being heard.''
Ms. Bates plays Hazel Quarrier, a missionary wife. ''We are not doing a putdown of Christianity or of missionaries, who, rightly or wrongly, have given a lot of their lives,'' she said. At one point in the script, Mrs. Quarrier teaches the Indian children to sing in Niurana, ''Jesus Wants Me for a Sunbeam.''
In this aging river port, long the gateway to the Amazon, members of the local missionary community have expressed their disapproval of the film project, but ecclesiastical objections are the least of the obstacles facing ''At Play in the Fields of the Lord.''
Ever since reading the novel a quarter of a century ago, Mr. Zaentz has wanted to produce a film version. But Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer refused to sell or act on the film rights. ''Every time a new management came in at M-G-M, they were insecure,'' said Mr. Zaentz, who is 69 years old, over lunch at a Japanese restaurant, a favorite with non-Portuguese-speaking members of the crew because of its picture menus.
Finally, a deal was struck in 1988, and Mr. Zaentz bought the rights. By that time, copies of Mr. Matthiessen's book were scarce. The copy the producer finally obtained for Mr. Babenco bore the stamp ''San Antonio Public Library.''
The screenplay was written in close collaboration with Mr. Matthiessen, who is expected to visit the set in October.
Filming in this locale has proved no easy task. Clovis Bueno, the Brazilian production designer, searched the Brazilian Amazon for three months for a village that could serve as Mae de Deus. He finally gave up and decided to construct an artificially somnolent village at the edge of a rubber plantation owned by the local affiliate of the Pirelli tire company. The only rent demanded by Pirelli was the removal of a barge loaded with tropical timber that had sunk, blocking a waterway. The barge was removed.
Scouting around Belem for bona fide shack material, Mr. Bueno found some slum residents who were moving into new public housing. Offers of $100 cash for each shack were snapped up. ''They adored it; it turned into a big party,'' Mr. Bueno recalled of the slum-dismantling project. Where new planks were needed, instant aging was accomplished with acid baths, sand blasting and blow torches. The result is convincing, down to the rotting dugout canoes converted into herb planters.
The Amazon town is so convincing that the Pirelli manager has asked the film makers to tear down the set after filming. He is afraid that squatters will move in after Hollywood moves out.
Set on a fork of the Guama, an Amazonian tributary, the site was too marshy for a landing strip. A boardwalk runway had to be built of piles, railway ties and dirt.
While the film's producers were engrossed in the art of producing artificial languor and decay, the outside world intruded. On March 15, Fernando Collor de Mello was inaugurated as President of Brazil. To cool Brazil's 85 percent monthly inflation rate, he immediately froze virtually all bank accounts over $1,200 for 18 months.
''We had $250,000 frozen,'' said Paul Zaentz, the associate producer and a nephew of the producer, making a nasty face. Gyrations in the cruzeiro-dollar exchange rate added more costs, pushing the total budget from $24 million to $28 million.
While the cast and crew of 290 people became frequent flyers on Varig airline's weekly Miami-to-Belem air hop, the film's transportation fleet here swelled to include 2 airplanes, 2 helicopters, 10 boats and 39 cars. ''We have everything that people avoid in movies - tides, boats, airplanes, children,'' said Paul Zaentz. To film at the Indian village and at the mission site, the production will house the crew on a cruise ship which will be anchored one and a half hours upriver from Belem.
Local conditions present local solutions. ''The 'bug wrangler' is a specialist who searches the set for scorpions, snakes and tarantulas - and takes them away,'' said Paul Zaentz in the safety of the Hilton cafeteria. Another job of the bug wrangler will be to drug a butterfly so a missionary child, played by Niilo Kivirinta, will be able to catch it. Locals suggested mixing rum with pineapple to slow down the butterfly.
''We are one degree off the Equator,'' said Chris Newman, the sound recorder, describing a new set of problems. ''All day long the sun is directly overhead, then at 6 P.M., it drops like a stone. If you put a mike on an overhead boom, it casts a shadow. If you put mikes on the actors, they sweat into them and the mikes have to be replaced.''
To further complicate making the soundtrack, jungle background noises constantly change - frogs, cicadas and diesel-engine fishing boats. Said Mr. Newman: ''When you cut all that together, you have to make it believable.''
Although the actors have their own trailers on the set, most major players have been briefly laid low by a variety of ailments - dehydration, diarrhea, voice loss and bacterial blood poisoning.
Fortunately, most angry passions have been restricted to the script. Several players attributed this to the calming influence exercised by Saul Zaentz, a bearish, bearded man who is quietly determined to shepherd his 25-year-old dream into film. If all goes well, filming will conclude in November and the film will be in American movie houses by the end of the summer of 1991.
''Last night, Saul showed us how to play hearts,'' said Ms. Bates. ''You usually associate producers with suits with hovering. You can see the meters running in their eyes.''
Citing his close working relationship with the producer, Mr. Babenco said: ''It was only after five weeks of shooting that I got around to signing the director's contract. We had never discussed money or time.''

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC VIEW;
Now, a Real Vixen. That's Plausible Casting

BYLINE: By Donal Henahan

 BODY:
I'm sure many thoughtful people were upset recently by the Actors' Equity decision to refuse permission for an Englishman to portray a Eurasian pimp in an American production of the musical ''Miss Saigon.'' The issue of artistic freedom, after all, does arouse emotions in the hearts of almost every American, and rightly so. But I suspect I also speak for a sizable minority of theatergoers, and specifically operagoers, in fully supporting the action of the American actors' union. It is about time some action of this sort was taken.
We - if I may presume to speak for this side of the question - have long borne opera's obsession with disguises, makeup, charades and illusions of all sorts. Why? Because commentators have insisted for nearly 400 years that without illusion opera could not exist. Nobody, so the rationale goes, would leave the comfort of hearth and television set to attend an opera unless lured by these childish devices. Truth, we were told, simply does not work in opera. Why else would there be such an emphasis on rouge, masks and dim lighting? Such is the low estimate of the operagoer held by virtually everyone in the opera business. 
Now, however, buoyed by the liberating action by the actors' union, I feel free to call for realism in the musical theater. Realism and, of course, democracy. Opera has never been an equal opportunity employer, but the way to that goal may now be open. Here are a few suggestions for change, not all of which will be immediately realizable, I know, considering opera's infamous reluctance to move with the times.
Everyone agrees that it is no longer tolerable that the leading characters in ''Aida,'' ''Otello'' and ''Madama Butterfly'' be sung by heavily made-up imposters. For too long, these roles have been assigned on the basis of vocal suitability and availability, or in some instances artistic talent. The need for a change here is too obvious to belabor.
But what about the Turks in ''The Abduction From the Seraglio'' and the Arabs in ''The Italian Girl in Algiers''? How can opera producers go on insisting that these works need to be staged even if ethnically plausible singers are not available? In fact, isn't it clear that such alleged comedies about Western dominance over the ''lesser breeds without the law'' ought to be withdrawn from circulation?
Discrimination in opera is rarely subtle. Although Verdi's music shows some sympathy for Falstaff, it is common staging practice to depict him as a vulgar, womanizing fatso. All right, if that is what the director believes the public wants, but must the role be awarded almost every time to someone who needs stomach padding and a false red nose? Is it possible there are no naturally portly men or women out there willing to portray Falstaff? (I mention women in this context because it is easy to overlook the feminist aspect to this question - the recent triumph of a female ''King Lear'' reminds us how shortsighted and biased most theatrical directors still are.) In the interests of realism, opera certainly must abandon the ridiculous convention of the travesty role, which in works like ''Der Rosenkavalier'' and ''The Marriage of Figaro'' forces women to dress up like men and pretend to make love to other women. This is matched in decadence only by the mirror-image convention that allows men to parade around in female costumes in those same works.
I am not sure what stand to take on another affront to realism, the widespread practice of assigning castrato roles to women in ''Orfeo'' and similar Baroque works. There may not be enough unemployed castratos around nowadays to fill these parts, but if that is true it would be a good argument for dropping Baroque operas from the repertory until the shortage has been remedied, preferably not by the traditional methods.
In the same vein, might not opera companies be asked, as tactfully as possible under the circumstances, why the leading part in ''La Traviata'' cannot be assigned to someone with practical experience as a prostitute. Most Violettas appear to have no clear idea of what the role requires in mental and physical preparation. The last Violetta I saw would have been quite at home in the local library, absorbed in mastering the Dewey Decimal System. It is surprising, in fact, that the association of professional prostitutes (oh, yes, there is one) has not lodged a complaint against the discriminatory casting of Verdi's otherwise convincing opera.
The foolishness that passes for opera tradition defies complete indictment because it is all-pervasive. Are there really no hunchbacks with talent in America? Must the operagoer's sense of the credible be affronted by a Rigoletto whose pillow keeps slipping from side to side? Are there really no native Albanians who could be cast in the important romantic roles in ''Cosi fan tutte''? In every production of Mozart's opera that I have ever seen those parts are doubled by the tenor and baritone who sing Ferrando and Guglielmo.
I have witnessed, as we all have, the unsavory spectacle of German singers pretending to be French, of Englishmen pretending to be ancient Greeks, of Americans pretending to be just about anything but good Americans. I have seen, more often than I like to remember, opera singers pretending to be actors and actors pretending to be opera singers. I have seen unindicted criminals pretending to be directors.
I don't know if an embrace of total realism would solve all of opera's problems, but the need for a radical change is obvious. One result might be to eliminate the ultimate operatic silliness: when one is asked to believe in singers made up as animals, as in Janacek's ''Cunning Little Vixen.'' The casting of genuine foxes, hedgehogs and so forth could only promote plausibility. I hope some foresighted union will pressure opera companies in this area, following the Actors' Equity lead. It would strike a blow not only for enlightened casting policies but for animal rights.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fake vixens, like Gianna Rolandi, offend our sense of appropriate performers. (Martha Swope/New York City Opera)

HEADLINE: Oil's Big Chance To Shape the Future

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
For oil companies, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has created a host of uncertainties about prices and supplies. But there is no question that the Mideast crisis, however it is resolved, has the potential to reshape the industry.
Not since the embargoes and sharp oil-price increases of the 1970's have oil companies faced the prospect of coping with a new, if as-yet-undefined, order among their major crude suppliers in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. And not in a decade or more has the industry had as promising an opportunity to influence critical decisions on how and where the United States will meet its energy needs in coming decades and to reverse what it considers excessive sensitivity to environmental issues.
''There is the potential for a changed environment for the industry, more so than at any time in the past 10 years,'' said Bernard J. Picchi, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. ''The issues have now captured the attention of everyone in Washington and of the man on the street.'' 
For the first time in more than a decade, Congress and the Administration are likely to focus seriously on whether the United States has endangered its own security by becoming overly reliant on foreign oil - the country imported half of its oil needs in the first half of this year, a record - and on whether the industry should be provided with financial incentives to reverse a decline in domestic exploration and production.
After years of seeing new domestic drilling projects thwarted by environmental concerns, and despite a public image badly damaged by recent oil spills, the industry could get a renewed and possibly more receptive hearing for its argument that a fear of accidents should not cripple the nation's ability to supply more of its own energy.
''The national security aspects of oil had been completely subordinated in recent years to the environmental concerns,'' said John H. Lichtblau, head of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. ''Now you have the emphasis coming back to the security aspects. If there is a conflict between the two, it may no longer be automatically resolved in favor of the environmentalists.''
 
Investing the Profits
Assuming that crude oil prices remain relatively high, the crisis will have the immediate effect of generating more profits for many oil companies, although lower earnings from refining operations could hold down their gains. Companies will have to decide how much of those profits to invest in new exploration and production - and where that investment should go. The Chevron Corporation, for one, decided earlier this month to spend an additional $100 million this year to produce more oil in existing domestic fields. Others are seeking new places to drill abroad, including the Soviet Union.
Analysts and industry executives say some companies might respond by putting more emphasis on their production and marketing of natural gas, which although plentiful and inexpensive relative to crude oil is still the poor relation of the industry. Other companies might make more extensive commitments to developing alternative-fuel businesses. None seem likely to diversify outside of the energy field. The momentum for change could evaporate if the crisis is resolved quickly. And barring widespread shortages or dramatically higher prices, the Federal policy formulation process is likely to move slowly. Congress, which virtually ignored energy policy issues while oil flowed abundantly and relatively inexpensively over the past decade, has an understandable aversion to adopting any measures to help the industry at a time of rising prices.
Oil company rhetoric notwithstanding, policy changes in Washington to encourage more domestic production could never eliminate the nation's need for foreign oil. New domestic production is unlikely to offset the decline in output from sites that are slowly being pumped dry. At the giant Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska, for example, production is expected to decline from 1.3 million barrels a day to 500,000 in 10 years. In any case, the major companies continue to see more potential for new finds abroad.
''I don't care how much you drill in this country, you will never be able to replace imports with domestic sources,'' said Robert K. Watson, a New York-based energy specialist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental activist group.
Still, there are some indications that the pendulum is beginning to swing back in favor of whatever domestic sources can be found. Just a few days after the invasion of Kuwait, the Senate approved an amendment to the Defense Authorization bill requiring that the President take steps to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil. Among the steps required by the amendment, offered by Senator Frank Murkowski, a Republican from Alaska, would be opening to exploration and production Federal lands that have previously been off limits, including the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. (See box.) Avoiding Hard Choices The legislation, which still faces a long battle before it could become law, also calls for oil import fees, tax and other incentives for domestic production and further conservation efforts. The actions, virtually all of which are supported by oil companies, would be required whenever imports exceeded 50 percent of the nation's oil needs.
''We are now relying on military force rather than energy policy for our energy security,'' Senator Murkowski said. ''Americans find it unacceptable to put American lives at risk because we have not made the hard choices to formulate a policy.''
After years of standing on the sideline, the Federal Government also decided last week to involve itself in a long-running environmental dispute over when the industry will be able to start pumping oil from a large field off the central California coast.
The Energy Department started trying to mediate the battle between Chevron, which leads an industry consortium, and local residents, who have held up production by pressuring state officials to deny the oil companies permits to transport the oil by tanker to refineries in Los Angeles. The project could eventually produce 100,000 barrels of oil a day, or about 15 percent of the amount the United States had been receiving from Iraq and Kuwait.
The industry's foes have by no means disappeared. Environmentalists continue to make forceful arguments against giving any breaks to oil companies, citing the damage that can be done by a single accident like the Exxon Valdez spill last year and the industry's spotty record of concern for the coastal and wilderness areas where most potential new oil finds are located.
Other critics say the answer to the nation's energy problems lies not with propping up the oil industry but in promoting alternative sources, including everything from nuclear power and natural gas to solar power, or in doing more to promote conservation and fuel efficiency.
''Energy efficiency is America's largest and least expensive energy resource, and we need to do more to tap it,'' said Mr. Watson of the Natural Resources Defense Council. ''The future is in using energy efficiently and getting it from alternative sources. Any additional drilling in environmentally sensitive areas would be a drop in the bucket in terms of the total amount of energy consumed in the United States.''
Moreover, the expressions of outrage among consumers and politicians earlier this month over the gasoline-price increases that followed so quickly on the heels of Saddam Hussein's grab for Kuwait were a reminder that Big Oil has never had many friends.
Several companies, led by the Atlantic Richfield Company, responded to complaints about price-gouging and to President Bush's call for restraint by capping wholesale gasoline prices temporarily. Fearful that allegations of profiteering could lead Congress to impose another windfall-profits tax on the industry, oil executives embarked on a public relations blitz to explain the complex oil markets and defend their actions.
Industry executives also tried again and again to reframe the debate in terms of national security instead of fouled beaches and exorbitant profits. But they clearly have a long way to go.
''The oil industry is one of this country's great assets,'' said George Babikian, president of ARCO's refining and marketing division. ''But these days, you mention oil company and people see some big, fat, greedy guy with a cigar and dirty fingernails counting his money. We don't have a hell of a lot of credibility.''
Greedy or not, the industry will have plenty of additional loot to count if prices stay up. Higher crude oil prices can have a dramatic impact on the bottom line, especially for those companies that produce more of their crude than they purchase from OPEC or other suppliers. ARCO, for example, produces virtually all of the crude oil that it refines into gasoline, jet fuel and other products. As a result, it stands to benefit substantially from higher crude prices. For every $1 increase in the price of a barrel of crude, ARCO's after-tax profits would rise by $140 million, or 83 cents a share, over the course of a year, according to the First Boston Corporation. Since early July, prices have soared $10 a barrel, to more than $28 on Friday.
For companies like the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation, which purchase roughly half of their crude oil from foreign sources, the benefits are not as dramatic, but they are still important. Exxon, for example, would reap an additional $272 million in after-tax profits, or 22 cents a share, for each $1 increase.
Higher profits mean the companies would have more money available for exploration and development projects or to make existing projects more efficient.
''I know we would take those profits and plow them back into exploration and bring more oil to the market,'' said Mr. Babikian of ARCO. ''We could do that at a faster clip to help find oil or develop oil fields that we know have more oil in them.''
 
Texaco Wish List
James W. Kinnear, Texaco Inc.'s chief executive, said that if more money becomes available for capital spending, the company would like to increase its investments in areas like coal gasification. Mr. Kinnear said the company would also like to spend more on recovering additional oil from nearly depleted fields.Processes like injecting water or carbon dioxide underground can force more oil to the surface.
''Each one of those things has the effect of bringing more energy on stream for the United States,'' Mr. Kinnear said.
Many companies had already begun to increase capital spending modestly because the nation's energy demands have been rising steadily. Most analysts and executives said sustained prices above $25 a barrel would be enough to spur significant additional drilling activity.
But industry executives and analysts say that in the absence of new incentives to drill in the United States, most new projects will continue to be abroad. The United States no longer has the equipment to support a return to the level of drilling activity experienced during the early 1980's. The most promising regions for new oil finds are overseas, and even if environmental concerns in the United States abate, the delays and expense they cause are unlikely ever to completely disappear.
''It will be much easier to explore for oil in parts of the world that do not have the luxury of worrying about environmental concerns,'' said Vahan Zanoyan of the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington.
 
Boost for Natural Gas
For all these reasons, some analysts believe that oil companies will now be willing to spend billions of dollars on pipelines needed to develop the country's mammoth natural gas reserves, although any such efforts may encounter their own environmental obstacles. The huge costs of building a national delivery and storage network have greatly limited the use of natural gas.
''I think you'll find a very strong push for a pro-active natural gas policy,'' said Joseph Stanislaw, managing director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass. ''You'll see oil companies making themselves into oil and gas companies, with non-gas players making alliances with gas players.''
William L. Randol, an analyst at First Boston, said companies such as Chevron and Amoco that have large natural gas reserves may start pushing for legislation to mandate more use of natural gas in industries where either gas or oil can be used as fuel.
''I do think there is the possibility of fuel switching and I think the price of natural gas will probably increase,'' said Mr. Kinnear of Texaco.
Of course, the pace and nature of change in the industry will depend to a large extent on Arab and OPEC politics, and no one at this point has a clear idea of what that might entail.
''The old OPEC is dead,'' said Mr. Stanislaw. ''The new OPEC could have many faces.''
 
THE POTENTIAL ALONG THE BEAUFORT SEA
The coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge runs for 100 miles along the Beaufort Sea in the northeast corner of Alaska, a desolate region that is home to caribou and other tundra wildlife and is virtually untouched by man.
But the area is also widely considered to be the most promising in the nation for a major new oil find, putting it squarely in the middle of the debate over how to balance environmental concerns with the nation's need for more energy sources.
So far, Congress and the Bush Administration have turned a deaf ear to the industry's calls for opening the coastal plain first to limited test exploration and ultimately, if enough oil is found, to full-scale development and production. In the wake of the Iraq crisis, however, the industry is intensifying its lobbying efforts, and some in Congress, including Senators Frank Murkowski and Ted Stevens of Alaska, are calling for the issue to be placed back on the national agenda.
No one knows for sure how much oil there might be below the coastal plain. A report by the Energy Department estimated that the area could yield between 600 million barrels of recoverable oil - a relatively small find - and 9.2 billion barrels, roughly the equivalent of the giant Prudhoe Bay field just to the west.
''It's the only place we could expect to make a find that would add significantly to the country's reserves over the next few decades,'' said Tom Cook, an exploration representative for the Chevron Corporation in Alaska.
The companies that most need oil from the coastal plain are those that have the biggest existing investments in Alaska's North Slope, primarily the Atlantic Richfield Company and British Petroleum. They have already invested billions in building the trans-Alaska pipeline to carry oil south from Prudhoe Bay; the companies say it would be relatively easy to build a spur line 100 miles or so into the coastal plain to feed new oil into the existing system.
''The technology is there to do it with minimal impact and very low risk to the area and to wildlife,'' Mr. Cook said. Environmentalists are aghast at the very idea. ''We have a 20 percent chance of finding a significant amount of oil, and a 100 percent chance of trashing one of the environmentally pristine areas of the country,'' said Robert K. Watson, an energy specialist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. Mr. Watson said the idea that the companies could develop the coastal plain in an environmentally sound manner is absurd. ''If you've ever been to Prudhoe Bay, you've seen that they've completely steamrollered it,'' he said. ''They've completely ignored any environmental sensitivities.''
 
LITTLE HOPE IN SYNFUELS
It seemed like a great idea at the time. At the behest of President Jimmy Carter, the Federal Government in 1980 undertook what was supposed to be a massive effort to promote the development of synthetic fuels to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil. With oil prices at $32 a barrel and the economy suffering from its second oil-price shock in seven years, the effort seemed justified, and Congress authorized the expenditure of as much as $88 billion. By the 1990's, synfuels were supposed to account for 25 percent of the nation's energy needs.
Within a few years, though, oil prices started tumbling and synthetic fuels - like gas produced from coal or oil produced from shale - no longer made much economic sense. Companies started bailing out of development projects, the Reagan Administration turned hostile to the program and the entire effort eventually died.
Today, with oil prices rising again and the nation once more concerned about reducing its oil imports, synthetic fuels remain a tantalizing but probably unrealistic solution.
A few companies, including Texaco Inc., are still investing in coal gasification and other synfuels projects. But most experts believe there will not be any major push into synthetic fuels unless oil prices go much higher and stay there for a long period.
''There are a lot of projects that could get off the ground with a lot of Government funding,'' said John C. Sawhill, who headed the program as Deputy Energy Secretary during the Carter Administration. ''But frankly I think it would be a mistake. As far as making a dent in the U.S. energy supply, I think we ought to forget about synfuels in the 1990's.''

HEADLINE: Currency;
Down, Down, Down

 BODY:
It happened. The dollar fell last week to its lowest level against the German mark since that currency was created 42 years ago. There was no celebration. With the United States facing a possible recession, there is little the Federal Reserve can do to counter the fall, which can add to inflationary pressures by raising the cost of imported goods. Those pressures have already been magnified by the huge increase in oil prices since the Middle East crisis began. By week's end, the dollar fell to 1.5495, just over two pfennigs below the previous low close in New York of 1.5700, reached on Dec. 31, 1987. Now traders are waiting to see how soon the dollar will reach its all-time low against the Swiss franc, which closed Friday at 1.2830. The current low, 1.2690, was also reached on Dec. 31, 1987.

HEADLINE: Unions Are Expanding Their Role to Survive in the 90's

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Organized labor, battered by union-busting, concessions contracts and shrinking membership during the 1980's has begun to expand its services to attract new members and remain relevant for the ones they already have.
Labor leaders and experts say the organizations, to survive, will have to evolve more fully into providers of financial and social services, offering discount credit cards, for example, and readily available family counseling.
''Unions will have to become more social service organizations if they are to have much of a future,'' observed Audrey Freedman, a labor economist at the Conference Board, a business research organization in New York, ''Individual workers feel alone and at risk. Unions might provide a communal organization for individuals, although they are not doing it now.''
''Unions will have to offer innovative and different services,'' agreed Douglas Fraser, the former president of the United Automobile Workers. ''We can expand the employee assistance programs we have now to prevent alcohol and drug abuse to include family counseling and social services. They have to be available near where people work to do much good.'' 
Unions have already begun to make such changes by offering low-cost credit cards and checking accounts, but they will have to continue to do more, analysts say, because of the events of the 80's.
In particular, deregulation and international competition have severely limited organized labor's ability to win economic gains for workers. A return to the steady wage and benefit gains of the 50's, 60's and 70's, is not, they say, in the cards.
Unions no longer dominate entire industries, like automobiles, steel and rubber, the way they once did. Imports and nonunion domestic competitors do not allow companies in those industries to pass on higher labor costs to consumers as they once did. And changes on the factory floor that have given workers more discretion over how they do their jobs may make unions less important as processors of employee grievances.
Nevertheless, some positive signs for labor have emerged. For one thing, breaking unions appears to be losing its appeal as a management technique. Frank Lorenzo, who broke the pilots' union at Continental Airlines and tried to repeat the tactic at Eastern, has left the airline business. Greyhound Lines Inc., which hired permanent replacements for its striking bus drivers, was forced into bankruptcy and may find itself owned by an investment group that includes its opponent, the Amalgamated Transit Union.
''After Eastern and the Greyhound debacle, I don't think it is going to be fashionable to try to break unions,'' said Ben Fischer, director of the Center for Labor Studies at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. ''It seems more effective at breaking companies than breaking unions.''
It's not that employee-employer disputes are a thing of the past. Nasty fights are certain to break out, for example, as the rising cost of health care prompts more corporations to try to trim coverage and shift some of the payment burden to employees. Job security will be a quarrelsome issue as well, with unions trying to protect current employment levels while companies seek lower-cost outside suppliers. But the clout of unions to influence the outcome of future battles has clearly been weakened.
Many union members feel President Ronald Reagan set the tone for the 80's, hurting organized labor badly when he broke the strike by the Professional Air Traffic Controllers, and the union along with it, in 1981.
There have, nevertheless, been some signs of union strength recently at the bargaining table and on the picket line. The Communications Workers of America successfully resisted demands by the Nynex Corporation to shift health care costs to workers, although it took a four-month strike to make the company back down. And the United Automobile Workers sent a signal to the General Motors Corporation that it is prepared to act tough by striking a parts plant over local issues before the Sept. 14 expiration of the national contract.
But the U.A.W. is no longer promising members that the once-sacred 3 percent annual pay increase, the so-called annual improvement factor, will be restored. Instead, it is likely to settle, as it has in recent negotiations, for some lump-sum increases that are not added into the wage base used to calculate pension and other benefits. Indeed, the union's chief goal is greater job security for workers in an industry where increasing sales of foreign-made vehicles are forcing plant closings and layoffs.
Unions are looking for new routes to relevance because their numbers in traditional industries have been declining. The United Steelworkers of America once counted over one million members. Today it has less than half that. Only the rapid growth of unions whose members work for units of government, like teachers and municipal workers, and the reaffiliation of the teamsters' union has enabled the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to sustain its membership at more than 14 million.
''Thirty-nine percent of all people who are represented by unions are in the public sector, and it will probably be over 50 percent by the end of the decade,'' Ms. Freedman said. ''That's a different world that was not under the competitive pressure of the private sector.'' There has been less pressure to cut jobs in the public sector.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. unions managed to sign up only 40,000 to 60,000 new members a year through traditional organizing during most of the 80's.
One method the federation is using to expand its membership is to create a new category of worker, called an associate member. An associate member is one who is not working in a union shop, but who wants to be affiliated with a union and participate in its benefit programs.
Associate membership is tied to a program the organization calls Union Privilege, available to both menbers and associates. In addition to the credit card (a Mastercard from the Bank of New York), Union Privilege includes reduced-rate legal services, supplementary life insurance, mail-order pharmaceuticals, higher rate savings accounts.
According to an A.F.L.-C.I.O. spokesman, 78 of the federation's 90 unions have signed up for at least one Union Privilege program. The credit card has been most popular, with more than 1.4 million currently in use.
The labor organization is planning to extend the program to include portable health insurance coverage for workers who lose their union jobs and reduced-rate home mortgages, college loans and auto insurance.
''Union Privilege's ultimate objective in developing a program of benefits is to find ways of using those benefits to attract new members to unions either as full members, or where full membership is not possible, as associate members,'' the executive council of the federation said in its 1989 convention report.
Unions are targeting former members now in nonunion jobs for associate status as well as union loyalists at locations where organizing drives failed and nonmembers in locations where union status is not necessary.
For example, the American Federation of Teachers has been recruiting non-A.F.T. teachers. The federation has also mounted a television advertising campaign with the theme ''Union, yes.''
Some people outside the labor movement see associate membership as an important tool to help recruit the droves of white-collar workers who have been wary of unions because of their blue-collar, heavy-industry image. They note that union representation among white-collar workers is considerably greater in Canada and Great Britain, than it is in the United States.
''Unions will have to think more broadly about what kinds of services they can offer workers outside the formal collective bargaining process,'' said Casey Ichniowski, an associate professor at the Columbia Business School. ''Associate-style unionism can be an important precursor to formal relations.''
Professor Ichniowski noted that teachers, policemen and firefightersbelonged to fraternal and professional organizations that evolved over time into bargaining agents for their members.
Peter Drucker, the noted student of management, sees broader union services as an alternative to an otherwise inevitable decline. ''The union might reinvent itself as the organ of society - and of the employing institution - concerned with human potential and human achievement, and with optimizing the human resource altogether,'' he wrote in a recent book, ''The New Realities.''
Such a union would retain some of its traditional role. ''The union would still have a role as the representative of the employees against management stupidity, management arbitariness and management abuse of power,'' he wrote. And there is a model for such an institution. ''Such a role may sound utopian, but it is pretty much the way the Japanese labor union functions,'' Mr. Drucker wrote.
Other union movements faced with declining membership and influence are considering similar approaches. ''Unions have to focus on the workplace, but their role goes beyond bread and butter,'' said William Callaghan, an economist with Britain's Trades Union Council.
In fact, the council recently adopted elements of the Union Privilege program, including a credit card and low-cost auto insurance and is seeking to expand. ''We've even pinched the 'Union, yes' campaign,'' Mr. Callaghan said. Although the prevailing opinion of the moment is that the unions must try these steps at revitalization, there are some who doubt that unions will have a great effect, given their inability to produce rich contracts and insure availability of jobs. ''The balance of power,'' said D. Quinn Mills, a professor at the Harvard Business School, ''remains with management.''
 
CAN UNIONS REGAIN THEIR LOST MOMENTUM?
''The concessions bubble has passed,'' declared Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., meaning that the period when unions would willingly surrender to management is over.
''The 1980's were difficult years for trade unions, for the economy and for workers,'' Mr. Donahue said.
But, he added, ''Many unions have gained back what they gave up. The 1990's look like a brighter period for us.'' Mr. Donahue's vision of the future includes unions offering more services to members and prospective members, new laws to facilitate organizing and union participation in worker involvement programs.
Services provided by the union will go beyond the credit card and group purchasing opportunities currently available, he said. One possibility is keeping workers up to date on what is happening in the economy beyond the immediate workplace.
''As the world grows more complicated, people are hungry for information. They want to know about health and safety, where job training is available and where jobs are going,'' he said.
Mr. Donahue contends that the current system of organizing workers under the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board has become too cumbersome, expensive and time consuming.
''We need legislation that will give employees additional ways to participate in collective bargaining. The current system is such a legalistic hassle that some of our unions are avoiding it,'' he said.
And worker involvement plans, such as self-managing teams on factory floors, provide with opportunities that go beyond the old role of processing grievances.
''When you are handling a grievance you have the interest of only a small percentage of the members. The magic of worker participation schemes is that they involve a new layer of union activists that can fulfil a role beyond shop stewards,'' Mr. Donahue said.

HEADLINE: All About/Meteorological Services;
The Diverse New Industry of Private Weather Forecasting

BYLINE: By NOAM COHEN

 BODY:
Wertfilms Inc. chose to shoot Nissan commercials in Seattle because it wanted skies that were overcast but not on the verge of a deluge. So the producers called Northwest Weathernet Inc., a private company that could render specific forecasts. ''Five or ten miles can make a difference,'' said Phil Breuser, the vice president of Northwest Weathernet. ''We can go hour-by-hour if they want.''
Private weather services, long used by fliers, farmers and shippers, are exploiting broad new markets. Although their annual revenues still total only about $200 million a year, many major industries depend on their work. Private meteorologists influence commodity prices, the outcome of lawsuits and government policy on global warming. They study where and whether new power plants should be built, and some - called forensic meteorologists - testify on the causes of airplane crashes.
On radio and television, Accu-Weather and the Weather Channel feed the growing demand for weather news. And Europeans, frustrated by the expense of their own government weather services, sometimes buy information in the United States. 
Private weather companies have new opportunities because the National Weather Service wants to confine itself to general forecasts and emergency warnings. For other, more specific information, the agency plans to refer callers elsewhere. ''The policy of the Administration has been to encourage private meteorology,'' said Louis J. Boezi, a deputy director of the service.
Under proposed new guidelines, the agency would shun what it calls ''specialized services.'' So someone asking whether the outlook for temperature, humidity and rain would be right for pouring a concrete foundation in the middle of next week would be told to call a private company. These companies typically charge $100 an hour, with the cost for a single forecast running between $25 and $75.
 
Military Roots
Filling a Niche Left by Government
 Private weather services are at least as old as the Old Farmer's Almanac, first published in 1792. But the modern industry began at the end of World War II, when meteorologists trained in the military started their own businesses to serve shipping and aviation. In 1955, the American Meteorological Society's directory listed 22 companies. Now it lists 112. Industry executives say the business is growing about 5 percent annually.
About 30 percent of the growth in forecasting assignments has come from utilities, somewhat less than 30 percent from transportation and about 20 percent from construction, says Jeffrey C. Smith, executive director of the Commercial Weather Services Association, a trade group. Utilities need environmental advice and early warnings of when foul weather might bring down transmission lines. Construction crews need to have enough notice of storms to come down from high-rise projects.
The increasing complexity of forecasts, and government's more restricted role, help increase revenues for private services. But sales remain dependent on the economy. ''We're a service industry,'' said Austin Dooley, general manager of the New York office of Oceanroutes Inc., which plans shipping routes. ''If cargo isn't produced and exported, and if the ships aren't sailing, we aren't going to have any business.''
 
Air-Quality Specialists
A New Emphasis On the Environment
 When North American Weather Consultants of Salt Lake City was founded in 1950, it provided forecasts and cloud-seeding for farmers. Now the company is more concerned about artificial weather of another sort: the pollution that issues from plants, especially those owned by utilities.
Only two companies listed air quality as their specialty in the American Meteorological Society's 1965 directory. This year, 44 did.
Gauging the amount of pollution escaping from a power plant smokestack is only half the task, weather services say. Determining how the emissions are dispersed and how they interact with other pollutants is also crucial. A power plant that would be fine in Omaha might fail to meet Federal standards in Los Angeles. ''Meteorology controls, to a large extent, the pollution in the air,'' said Don A. Griffith, a vice president at North American. Power companies also consult with meteorologists to decide on how much their emissions need cleaning up.
North American's own fortunes have been a barometer of the nation's environmental concern. The company only entered the air-quality business in the middle 1960's. The Clean Air Act was passed in 1970, and air quality consulting grew to become two-thirds of the company's business. But in the early 1980's, when emissions enforcement eased up and power plant construction slowed, it shed nearly 40 of its 60 employees.
Then came oil spills and a revived environmental movement. In the last few years, North American has begun expanding again, especially to help coal-generated power plants meet new governmentstandards. But so many pollution experts quit in the 1980's that the company cannot grow as quickly as it wants. ''We can hardly hire qualified people in air pollution anymore,'' said Keith J. Brown, the company president.
He says that North American's revenues will approach $3 million this year, about half from pollution work - a ratio he expects to rise to 75 percent in another few years. As Mr. Brown said, ''The 90's is the decade of the environment.''
 
An Insatiable Public
The Appetite For Weather News
 For two private weather forecasters, the broadcasting business seems to be raining money. Accu-Weather Inc. in State College, Pa., furnishes forecasts for about 3,000 clients in radio, television and other industries. The Weather Channel is available on cable in 45 million homes.
Accu-Weather, which considers itself the nation's largest private forecasting company, refuses to disclose its revenues but says that it has been growing at 10 percent a year. Founded by Joel Myers when he was a graduate student at Pennsylvania State University, Accu-Weather now has 225 employees.
Accu-Weather provides not only the forecasts for 125 radio stations and 200 television stations, but also about 40 meteorologists to explain the news on the air. Dr. Myers asserts that Accu-Weather's success comes from a recognizable name and better forecasts than the National Weather Service. The service declined to respond.
But Accu-Weather also owes some of its growth to the Weather Service's decisions in recent years to keep its own forecasters off the air. Alaska is one of the few places left where a Government weatherman delivers television and radio forecasts; river ice reports for fishermen are standard. Elsewhere, the Weather Service provides only the general forecasts that television and radio announcers can rip and read.
The Weather Service also does not illustrate its forecasts with whiz-bang graphics, leaving more opportunities for Accu-Weather and the Weather Channel. The only cable network devoted to round-the-clock weather, the Weather Channel has artists and computer experts to keep finding flashier ways of presenting the weather. Their latest: three-dimensional renderings of storm systems.
Media analysts say that the Weather Channel, founded in 1982 and owned by Landmark Communications Inc. of Norfolk, Va., is enjoying steady growth. Paul Kagan Associates. estimates its 1989 revenues at $31.5 million, with operating cash flow, or profits before taxes and depreciation, of $10 million. This year, Paul Kagan projects cash flow of $12 million on revenues of $35.3 million.
The National Weather Service has been one of the channel's greatest supporters. The agency has computer-coded its local forecasts so the channel could present each area with its own weather report. And the Weather Service makes certain that the Weather Channel receives weather warnings and watches the moment they are issued.
But just as specialized services have arisen to fill out the details in the National Weather Service forecasts, specialized cable channels - offering local reports for aviators or farmers, perhaps - might someday supplement the Weather Channel. ''I think you will see people popping up with this,'' said Edward Gross, the constituent affairs chief for the National Weather Service. But some might prefer receiving specialized forecasts on a different screen than their television, he added. ''The question is whether cable will satisfy those needs or the home computer will.''
 
THE BUSINESS IN EUROPE
The few private weather forecasting companies in Europe - an estimated 10 - find they get almost as much encouragement from America as at home. Harry A. Otten, whose Meteo Consult BV in 1986 became the first private forecaster in the Netherlands, was looking to package weather data for broadcasting, agricultural and energy companies. But the fees he was charged by the Dutch Government were hefty.
''In the United States, it is thought that taxpayers pay for the data, so they should be able to get all the data,'' he said. ''In Europe, it is thought that taxpayers pay for the data, so they should not be able to make a profit from it.''
Mr. Otten initially paid his Government $600,000 a year, but threatened to get his information far less expensively by computer and telephone from private American services. (British weather companies are also obtaining information from the United States that is far cheaper than what's available at home.) By 1988, the Government had cut its price to $200,000. It was not a total victory, however. Mr. Otten says that companies forecasting weather in the United States can get good information for a tenth the price.
Meteo Consult, with a staff of 16, still has the Government as its major competitor. The Dutch agency provides forecasts tailored to specific business needs - for a fee. ''Sometimes the Government is cheaper, but we have to be more accurate,'' Mr. Otten said.
Meteo Consult's enterprise has its roots in the United States. Mr. Otten, who had worked for the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute as a forecaster and later as a television weatherman, took a year-long sabbatical at Pennsylvania State University. There, he consulted for Accu-Weather and came up with the idea of bringing private forecasting to the Netherlands.
With trade barriers coming down in the European Community, Mr. Otten feels, governments will be less able to throttle private weather companies. The growth of private meteorology in Europe might be slow, but as Mr. Otten said, ''Accu-Weather didn't have 16 employees after its first five years.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
How the Big Oil Companies Blundered

BYLINE: By ALAN TOWERS; Alan Towers is president of Alan Towers Associates, a public relations firm in New York.

 BODY:
The rush by oil companies to raise gasoline prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was a tremendous public relations blunder. By raising prices, these companies unraveled the thin cloak of credibility around their industry.
It is no secret that the oil industry has not excelled at public relations. It paid too little attention to public opinion during the 1973-74 oil embargo. Angry public reaction to rising prices made Big Oil No. 1 on America's most despised list. Congress followed by confiscating oil profits through the Windfall Profits Tax. 
Surely, all this should have been a lesson too painful for the oil companies to forget. But they did. Americans were angered by sudden, aggressive gas price increases. Once again, oil management miscalculated public reaction by failing to see price as a public relations lever, not just a financial calculation.
Several major producers finally agreed to hold or reduce prices. But the rollback came only after Congressional hearings, accusations of antitrust violations and threats of another tax.
Oil is not the only industry that has controlled a vital commodity, sought to take advantage of market imbalances and met with a public relations disaster. During the early 1980's, the property and casualty insurance industry raised premiums so high that public swimming pools and ski slopes were forced to close. Auto insurance costs accelerated beyond the reach of many drivers. Public anger came swiftly and predictably: tort reform to reduce court awards was stopped, and New Jersey, Pennsylvania and California mandated lower auto insurance rates.
In New York, accusations of rent gouging has created a populist drive for commercial rent control - legislation feared by real estate interests. The city's economic problems have cooled things down, putting supply and demand in closer balance. But with a liberal Democratic Mayor in City Hall and the chief proponent of controls now Manhattan Borough President, legislated commercial rents now have a fighting chance.
What can we learn from these lessons? Is it simply impossible for companies to pass along higher costs when the public welfare is involved? The answer illustrates the ironies of capitalism and democracy: in a free economy, the public's opinion is the most powerful regulator.
More pricing controversies will erupt soon if the cost of oil rises. But in all these cases, the cost of a product is only half the issue. Equally important is avoiding the attitude that pricing of a vital product is strictly the province of the private provider.
A company's reputation is its most valuable asset. Leaving pricing decisions for critical products within the marketing and finance departments alone may not provide the broader view required to protect this fragile asset.

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Looking Beyond the Mideast Crisis

BYLINE: By ROBERT C. ALTMAN; Roger C. Altman, assistant secretary of the Treasury from 1977 to 1980, is vice chairman of the Blackstone Group.

 BODY:
The conventional wisdom in Washington was that President Bush took an immense risk when he shifted his stance on tax increases. But even before the Middle East crisis, the bond market was sending a different message. It signaled that major economic benefits would flow from a White House budget deal. Only if fiscal policy is tightened appropriately can interest rates come down and growth resume.
The bond market has been signaling this throughout the negotiations on the budget deficit. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds was just under 9 percent immediately before the announcement of a budget summit between Congressional leaders and the Administration. Then, after the announcement, bonds immediately rallied, driving down the yield to approximately 8.60 percent. When the budget negotiations in Congress stalled, rates went back up. But then, when President Bush made his shift on taxes, yields fell to below 8.5 percent. 
Right now, all financial markets are in turmoil because of uncertainty over oil prices and supplies. But as soon as this volatility eases, it will become clear that budget cuts in the $5o billion to $60 billion range - which Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, termed ''major, substantive and credible'' - would push down interest rates to more than offset the economic drag of a tighter budget.
The Federal Reserve demonstrated in June that it is prepared to loosen monetary policy as a budget pact emerges. This should happen as soon as Congress realizes that the Persian Gulf imbroglio could swell the deficit even further. Without an energy tax, the budget package may be a bit smaller in its impact the first year. But, as long as the future cuts are solid, the pressure on Treasury borrowing and inflation will still be reduced. This will give the Federal Reserve its rationale for further easing of interest rates. In fact, in testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan predicted that a real budget deal could lower interest rates by as much as two full percentage points.
Over the last 25 years, there have been several instances when budgets were cut at the same time that interest rates were eased - in 1964-65, 1971-72 and 1986-87. In each case, growth increased the following year, typically by a substantial margin. The stimulus from a looser monetary policy overcame the drag of a tighter budget. With sharply lower interest rates now in the offing, there is reason to expect the same result in 1991.
Internationally, the economic consequences of this policy mix will be highly positive. Since President Bush's shift on taxes, lower interest rates have caused the dollar to soften considerably. This softer dollar will spur exports just at the right time. Growth in Europe is running substantially above American levels and the demand for our products is accelerating there. In this environment, American growth can get a major boost from rising net exports. And, with lower interest rates causing private investment to pick up too, our overall competitiveness will strengthen.
The budget pact also should restore our economic negotiating leverage, particularly with Germany and Japan. Washington finally will have held up its end of the bargain to reduce the trade and payments ''imbalances'' which have clouded economic relations at the negotiating level for six years.
For example, President Bush's shift on taxes broke the deadlock in the tense Structural Impediments talks with Japan and produced a surprise, favorable agreement. Forty-eight hours after the President made his move, the Japanese Government committed to a $300 billion 10-year program of public infrastructure investment at home. This spending, which will move Japan closer to a consumer society and raise its imports, had long been an American goal.
Perhaps the most important result of the President's decision, however, could be to restore a period of bipartisan economic leadership in this country. In recent years, deficits and the politics of taxes have paralyzed Washington and undermined public esteem for all government. But, Mr. Bush's bold move, and the corresponding spending cuts which the Congressional leadership will support, may usher in a period of bipartisan cooperation on economic policy. It is evident that in the 1990's Americans want leadership. On economics, Mr. Bush is showing that he understands this need.
