PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1641 words

HEADLINE: POLICE WORK;
Hanging Tough Won't Be the Only Test of Leadership

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE race is on. President George Bush versus President Saddam Hussein. There is no prize for coming in second.
Mr. Hussein's strategy is now clear: by presenting himself to the Arab masses as Robin Hood, come to steal from the rich Kuwaitis to give to the poor and come to purify the Arab world of corrupt lackeys and infidels, the Iraqi President hopes to generate enough popular support that it will become impossible for his fellow Arab rulers to isolate him for long.
President Bush's strategy, at least for the near term, is also clear: hold together a diverse Arab and international coalition boycotting Iraq long enough to choke Saddam Hussein, if not to death, at least into saying he will vacate Kuwait. 
The question is who will last longer? Saddam Hussein, all but cut off from world trade essential to his survival, or George Bush's coalition, which could slowly be eroded by its conflicting interests and priorities, not to mention by the brooding antipathy toward the United States now bubbling up on the Arab street.
Of course, the answer will depend in part on the steps and missteps made by the unpredictable Iraqi leader - steps over which Mr. Bush will have little control. But from Mr. Bush's perspective, it will also depend heavily on his own ability to lead the domestic and international coalition that he has assembled down what is an essentially uncharted course.
Because the gulf crisis is truly the first post- cold war crisis, everyone involved is a novice. They are on a course where surprises will be lurking around every corner. Experience may count less than instinct, intuition and adaptability.
Consider just a few of the lessons imparted by this crisis. It has already shown that the post-cold war era might be as dangerous, if in different ways, as the cold war was. While the two superpowers were focused on Europe, regional superpowers like Iraq were acquiring weapons of mass destruction that now enable them to act independently.
President Bush also appears to be learning that post-cold war crises, involving bizarre coalitions of Western and Third World nations, can require more sophisticated, imaginative and subtle American leadership than demanded by the black and white, largely static, confrontation with the Soviet Union.
More countries are involved, there seem to be more competing interests, and the actors are less predictable.
In the Middle East, in particular, the interests of certain Arab states in blunting the Iraqis is tempered by their disquiet about being in league with their former colonial occupiers. For American policymakers, falling back on hard and fast ideologically driven positions can be dangerous.
The Administration has already discovered tensions between its short-term interests in the Persian Gulf and its long-term interests, said Robert W. Tucker, an expert on the geopolitics of the Persian Gulf at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.
Washington's primary short-term interest in the gulf was insuring that Saudi Arabia was not attacked or intimidated by Iraq, because that would had have serious implications for Western economies dependent on Saudi Arabia's oil and its policy of keeping prices low. That interest has been achieved with the introduction of American troops.
But America also has a long-term interest - the stability of pro-American regimes in the gulf and the desire of the United States to remain welcomed in the Middle East at large. The danger now, argued Mr. Tucker, is that if the United States goes to war with Iraq to dislodge it from Kuwait, it could provoke an anti-American Arab reaction that would not only threaten every pro-American regime in the area, but also sour United States relations with the Arab world for years to come. Dislodging Saddam Hussein from Kuwait is an American interest and desirable, but doing it by force - either intentionally or inadvertently - could badly damage longer-term interests.
What Washington also has discovered is that even in this new multipolar world, only the United States is able and willing to be the policeman. The time has not come yet for America's last hurrah.
Why? Because, said Joseph S. Nye, Harvard University professor of international relations, America remains the only country with enough hard power - aircraft carriers and marines - and soft power - diplomatic sway - to launch and sustain the sort of massive initiative being undertaken to counter Iraq. That is why, when Mr. Hussein moved, it was no accident that all eyes turned to Washington for a response.
''Obviously we have weaknesses and strengths,'' said Mr. Nye. ''But the mistake many analysts were making was to take a single anecdote illustrating American weakness, such as a decline in auto sales or the fact that the Germans concluded a deal with Gorbachev, and extrapolating from that to some very broad general conclusion that we were going down the tubes. We still have a lot more strengths than weaknesses.''
 
The Equivocation of Europe
It would be equally mistaken, though, for Washington decision-makers to exaggerate their prowess on the basis of this crisis. To be sure, in the developing world military power still counts for a great deal and no nation can bring more of that to bear in third world conflicts than the United States. In the developed world, however, where economic might, trade surpluses and financial balances - not guns - are the stuff of power, Washington is still indisputably slipping behind Germany and Japan.
Another belief that seems to have been deflated by this crisis is that the new Europe, with its formal economic merger set for 1992, would become the world's third superpower. While the French and British have sent limited naval forces to the gulf, the French insist they will do it their way, the Germans have been discussing what to do, and the rest of Europe has played no role except supporting sanctions and quietly wringing their hands. The Italians, Spaniards and Greeks in particular are highly attuned to the anti-Saudi, pro-Hussein mood in the Arab street and want to keep their options open for the future.
Back in the 1950's the Europeans tried to portray another Arab leader - Nasser - as a Hitler and they feel they got badly burned by it at Suez. Save for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, European statements are devoid of the moral arguments coming out of Washington. For them, this is business, and business is business.
''This crisis really exposed the hollowness of European pretensions,'' said Bernard Lewis, a Princeton University historian.
''Here was a major crisis that affected Europe far more than the United States, since the Europeans are far more dependent on Persian Gulf oil than the United States. But nevertheless, the great new European colossus that we have been hearing about has either been passive or responding to the American initiative and not launching anything of its own.''
But this crisis is also revealing that acting as the world's cop, and persuading the American peo ple to make the sacrifices inherent in this role, is no easy task. Americans are not entirely comfortable sending their troops to distant corners of the third world, for vaguely defined vital interests.
Even in the crisis in Kuwait, where the stakes are clear - oil and evil personified in a single dicta tor - the President has had to grope a bit to justify the operation. He could not rely on the prefabricated justifications of the cold war era, and this meant thinking afresh about exactly what was at stake and how to explain it, both to the American people and to the allies.
The President's groping was clearly in evidence last week when he went to the Pentagon to give his first major address justifying the intervention.
''Our jobs, our way of life, our own freedom and the freedom of friendly countries around the world would all suffer if control of the world's great oil reserves fell into the hands of Saddam Hussein,'' he told the employees, generals and admirals. It was intriguing to hear the President evoke ''our way of life'' as his main motif. That is a value that was also often evoked in the struggle against Communism.
''There is one big difference though,'' said Michael J. Sandel, the Harvard University political theorist. ''When we talked about defending 'our way of life' in the cold war, we were talking about upholding basic democratic freedoms and a society based on the rule of law. When Bush says that 'our way of life' is threatened in the Persian Gulf, it is not our higest values that are threatened, not our democratic principles. It is a way of life dependent on cheap oil and profligate energy use to which he is referring.''
The way of life that used to be evoked in confronting Communism was ''something to be proud of,'' added Mr. Sandel. ''But when Bush evokes it here, it is just a polite way of referring to a bad habit.''
Which goes to the very core of the leadership challenge that Mr. Bush confronts. Newspapers are replete these days with generally approving articles about George Bush's ''decisiveness.'' Indeed, the President has acted decisively to counter both the economic threat posed by Saddam Hussein and his threat to world stability.
But the larger answer to the Gulf crisis is not simply to ask Americans to confront Saddam Hus sein, but also to ask them to confront themselves and to live in a way that would make the United States energy self-sufficient. Since the crisis began Mr. Bush has mentioned the ''C-word'' - conservation - only once. He has been decisive in compensating for America's energy vulnerability by moving troops, but he has yet to show a similar decisiveness in addressing the root of that vulnerability by moving the nation to greater conservation. In that sense, his leadership has been incomplete.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
What IS Youth Coming To?

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
FOR years Americans have been bludgeoned by one report after another documenting what a mess the new generation is supposed to be. Their grade point averages and S.A.T. scores are falling while high school dropout rates are rising. They don't know when the Civil War was or what Lithuania is.
But even the most jaded observers seemed to take notice this spring when a report by a panel, including Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, and Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, came to the disturbing conclusion that teen-agers are less healthy today than their parents were when they were the same age. Because of drinking, drugs, unplanned pregnancies, violence, suicide, venereal disease and emotional problems, many of today's teen-agers ''are unlikely to attain the high levels of education achievement required for success in the 21st century,'' according to the commission, which was formed by the National Association of State Boards of Education and the American Medical Association.
The implication, it almost seemed, was that America was raising a lost generation, an army of aging Bart Simpsons, possibly armed and dangerous. Their Holden Caulfield was Clay, the withdrawn California freshman wandering through a suburban wasteland of drugs and anomie in Bret Easton Ellis's 1985 novel ''Less Than Zero.'' Instead of Woodstock, they had MTV. 
Is there anything to these fears, beyond the ritual anxiety each generation feels about its successors? Have a significant number of post-boom babies really inherited serious handicaps, perhaps from the social revolutions of the 1960's and early 70's? Given all the choices they have, why do these young people seem so confused?
These questions are being asked by social scientists, who are doggedly tracking the lives and times of nearly 37 million people between the ages of 15 and 25. The answers, as far as they exist, are inconsistent enough to make demographers wonder if there's a ''they'' out there after all.
A few things are clear. The people born in the late 1960's and early 70's have sex earlier than their parents did and marry later. They buy more condoms than their older brothers and sisters did, but the youngest of them, the 15- to 19-year-olds, have more babies. In surveys, they say they care about poverty and the environment, but they vote less often than their predecessors did and pay less attention to the news. They spend more time in school but they learn less. Overall, they take fewer drugs than their older brothers and sisters did. But more of them kill themselves, and each other, than was true for the generations that went before.
Many linger longer on the threshold of adulthood, hanging around college and their parents' homes the way they used to hang around the mall. Gingerly threading their way through a landscape littered with choices, they have an acute sense of what each choice may cost.
Andrew Cherlin, a sociologist at Johns Hopkins University, explained the squeamishness this way: ''Half of these children spent some time in single-parent families growing up. This is the first generation to feel the full impact of the great rise in divorce.''
Some psychologists and sociologists contend that the divorces of the 60's and 70's have had long-term pernicious effects on children's emotional health and on their ability to make commitments; but others argue that parental love and involvement are the deciding factors - not marital arrangements.
It is important to keep in mind that some ills afflicting young adults afflict the rest of society as well. Teen suicide, for instance, is near a record high - but so are overall suicide rates.
''For anyone to say it's a lost generation is pretty extreme,'' said Andrew Kohut, director of surveys for the Times-Mirror Company of Los Angeles, whose June study of young people's tendency to stay away from the ballot box and tune out the news was called ''The Age of Indifference.''
''This is a generation that hasn't been touched by any larger thing,'' he said. ''It hasn't been challenged. It may be now coming head to head with its challenge,'' he added, in a rueful reference to the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Reynolds Farley, a demographer at the University of Michigan, said: ''Since the end of the Vietnam War, we have had nothing cataclysmic that would be threatening to young people in the sense that World War I, World War II or the Depression were threatening to people. To some degree that widens your choices -you're not threatened with military service, not threatened with very high rates of unemployment. There's a wider array of choices, and that may be disconcerting, or troubling.''
But the range of options depends on your parents' economic situation. According to economists, two decades of factory closings have left little semi-skilled or unskilled work to go around, unless young people want to contemplate a lifetime of flipping hamburgers. The uniting theme for this generation may be life in an age of limits. But while people near the top of the economic scale are plagued by too many choices, the people near the bottom have too few. ''Maybe you can't make a general statement about this generation because the prospects for the haves are so much different than the prospects for the have-nots,'' said Mr. Cherlin.
At the lower end of the economic scale, the problem is lack of skills and growing competition, from immigrants as well as native-born Americans. Leonard Gordon, an Arizona State University sociologist, says one consequence is a sharp increase in hostility among the races. A small but growing group of white students are ready to accept and endorse racial stereotypes, he said.
''When we ask students what their aspirations are, there is no difference between black and white students,'' Dr. Gordon said. ''But there's an enormous difference on their expectation of achieving their aspirations. A smaller percentage of black and Hispanic students think they can.''
And even several of those who were more sanguine told researchers in follow-up interviews that they had become pessimistic. ''They had a zero-sum perception of the future,'' Dr. Gordon said. ''If someone gains, someone has to lose. The traditional American view of the future is that if one person gains, someone else gains as well.''
If a sense of shrinking horizons afflicts one end of the economic ladder, the people on the other end seem to suffer a kind of vertigo at the huge expanse of choices laid out before them, particularly if they have had an emotional buffeting in their home life. They are taking their time about reaching the traditional demarcations of American adulthood.
They marry later. The average age was 23 for women and 25 for men in 1987; their counterparts in 1970 tended to marry three years earlier. Increasingly, they take five years to complete college. And more of them live on and off with their parents when college is over.
Some of the explanation is economic: in the late 1980's, about a quarter of all college students had student loans, which build up at about $2,500 annually, according to the Department of Education. Housing inflation has pushed all but group rentals beyond the reach of many.
''In the 1950's a high school education bought you a reasonable job,'' said Frank F. Furstenberg Jr., a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania. ''Today that's not the case.'' Also, he said, in an era when women expect to go to work - and may have to - ''there's no question there's been a change in the centrality of marriage as a defining life event.''
But the reasons for hovering on the threshold of maturity seem more than simply economic. For many young people their parents' homes seem emotional as well as economic havens.
''A lot of the choices they are making now they are unmaking,'' said Martha Farnsworth Riche, an economist for American Demographics magazine. ''There's much more stopping out of college. When they unmake a choice'' - schooling, jobs, relationships - ''they go home,'' she said. ''When they choose again, they leave.''
But the sense of aimlessness - whether caused by too many options or too few - is not always translated into cynicism. Surveys of high school seniors and college freshmen by the University of Michigan and the University of California at Los Angeles show more interest in changing society than at any time since the early 1970's. Sociology departments are reporting increased enrollments.
And some choices are being made. Marijuana use, which peaked in the late 1970's, has been going down slowly but steadily. Cocaine use began to drop in 1985. But there is still far more drug use among adolescents and young adults than 20 years ago.
And there is far more sexual activity at younger ages. In 1988, 27 percent of 15-year-old and half of 17-year-old women had had sex, according to the Federal Government's National Survey of Family Growth. One result is ''the decision to marry has clearly become independent of the onset of sexual experience for the great majority of women,'' said Dr. William Pratt of the National Survey.
''There are just fewer societal norms about what ought to be done,'' said Dr. Farley. ''Those stabilizing forces that society once defined as important have disappeared.''
''They are making choices. They will make choices,'' said Ms. Riche. ''But given the changes in the world around them, they can't make definite choices at the same age people did before.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan Gives Its Leader A Long Honeymoon

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WHEN he took office a year ago, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu seemed like the man least likely to succeed. He had no power base, no major record of achievement in government and almost no serious experience at political maneuvering, and he was faced with an electorate irate after more than a year of scandals and unpopular policies.
Today Mr. Kaifu has risen to become one of the most popular Japanese leaders in modern history. Even more startling, he has impressed President Bush and other foreign leaders as a new kind of Japanese politician, ready to play a more assertive role on the world stage and yet more flexible on trade and economic disputes. 
Underneath the surface lies a more complicated reality suggesting that many of the hopes being invested in Mr. Kaifu may be misplaced. Indeed, although the Prime Minister shows increasing confidence in his actions, many politicians say his hold on the Government is precarious and could be overwhelmed by problems that he and others in power are shunting aside.
Japan's difficulties were on display last week as Tokyo struggled to find a response to the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Since Japan is dependent on Mideast oil for nearly 70 percent of its energy needs, it might have been natural to assume that Japan would move swiftly to protect its interests.
Instead, the Government stumbled amid internal policy disagreements, forcing a cancellation of Mr. Kaifu's scheduled visit to the Middle East. A Government spokesman said the Prime Minister decided to stay home to determine what ''concrete measures'' to use against Iraq, aside from economic sanctions. But others made clear that he did not want to be seen undertaking an ''oil buying expedition'' that would anger Iraq and its rivals. Finally, the Government said it would consider sending nonmilitary support to the American-led efforts against Iraq.
Looking to others to show the way has been a theme of Mr. Kaifu's time in office.
 
The paradox of the
Prime Minister's political success is that he has succeeded in spite of his inability to deliver on any promises or to change the policies that caused so much anger a year ago. In what sounds like a zen twist, the Prime Minister is politically strong precisely because he is weak.
''Kaifu does not seem to be viciously in pursuit of power and profit like past leaders,'' Hajime Shinohara, a professor of political science at Seikei University, told one newspaper. ''He also draws sympathy because it seems he is being pushed around.''
The Japanese admire and reward the exercise of power even as they harbor misgivings and nervousness when power becomes too brazen. Mr. Kaifu has discovered that a key to his popularity is that people continue to believe that real power in the Government is wielded by the leaders of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's major factions, including former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, Mr. Kaifu's major patron.
It is the control of these party barons that has prevented Mr. Kaifu from changing the status quo that only a year ago was drawing the wrath of voters. Mr. Takeshita and then his successor, Sousuke Uno, were forced to resign because of voter anger over an unpopular new sales tax and the bribery and influence peddling scandal involving millions of dollars in gifts to politicians.
Mr. Kaifu took office pledging action on several fronts, but shows no sign of being able to revise or rescind the hated tax or to curb the influence of money in politics. But the latest polls show that he has exceeded approval ratings of 60 percent. The Japanese turned to him when they were weary of scandals and looking for stability. They seem to think that the fact he is trying is more important than his inability so far to succeed.
Japanese analysts say Mr. Kaifu has also eased trade tensions with the United States. By promising to make it easier for foreign countries to export more goods to Japan, the Prime Minister has earned a reputation as someone who is taking Japan's trade imbalance with the rest of the world seriously.
President Bush has not hesitated to call on Mr. Kaifu to step up with his money bags and bail out the United States in difficult situations. Tokyo now is a major aid contributor to the Philippines. It is poised to contribute considerable sums to Eastern Europe and, if there can be a political solution, to Cambodia.
But the Prime Minister's aides say three looming issues cast a shadow over his hopes for continued popularity. First, the Middle East situation could put a squeeze on Japan, ending its current high rate of growth. Second, Mr. Kaifu could fail to make promised political reforms. In either event, voters could turn against him. Third, Mr. Kaifu faces a major challenge getting Government approval to open Japan to a small amount of rice imports. Rice farmers and agricultural interests have long had a stranglehold on the ruling party, and Mr. Kaifu could be defeated if he attempts to take them on.
Should Mr. Kaifu stumble, there are plenty of candidates waiting to trample over him. Several senior politicians, such as Shintaro Abe, a former Foreign Minister, and Kiichi Miyazawa, a former Finance Minister, are known to be coveting the top job and ready to pounce. Even Mr. Takeshita is believed to be looking for a comeback. With so many rivals working against Mr. Kaifu, many politicians say he will be lucky to finish his current two-year term in office, which expires in October 1991.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: The Gulf;
Iraq, Though Vulnerable, Has Strong Cards to Play

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
SADDAM HUSSEIN, ruthless and wily though he may be, must be an increasingly worried man.
In Iraq's most audacious move yet, Baghdad announced late last week that thousands of Americans, Britons and other Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait would become human shields, scattered as hostages among potential military and civilian targets.
But a measure of Mr. Hussein's unease was visible in his declaration of a virtual surrender to Iran, an astonishing turnabout in which he gave up all of the disputed lands and his claim to exclusive control of the Shatt al-Arab waterway -the goals for which he waged an eight-year war that cost more than a million casualties and impoverished both nations.
It was that war on which he built his cult of personality as the defender of the Arab nation - with billions of dollars from the oil-rich nations he is now squared off against. 
The peace, immediately heralded by Iran as its greatest victory, would free up about 30 Iraqi divisions and, presumably, secure Iraq's eastern flank as Mr. Hussein turns his attention to the American-led forces assembling in the Saudi desert and the growing international armada steaming into the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea to enforce an economic embargo intended to break his hold on his tiny neighbor and former ally, Kuwait.
Saddam Hussein may feel vulnerable on the battlefield, but his moves against the Western hostages show that he is not without resources and the ruthlessness to use them. Indeed, Mr. Hussein's real strength is that he plays by no rules.
Iraq, with more than a million men under arms and 5,500 main battle tanks, has long been regarded as the most powerful military force in the Arab world. But this is a relative term. After quick initial gains by surprise in the war with Iran, the Iraqis' performance was hardly brilliant. It was only Mr. Hussein's willingness to use poison gas that stopped the Iranian human wave attacks.
The Iraqi President's style is that of a neighborhood bully, but his ability to size up his opponent's staying power is sometimes flawed. In 1980, he wrongly calculated that he could seize what he wanted in a few days from an Iran weakened and militarily demoralized by the Islamic revolution. Instead, his forces got bogged down in eight years of now pointless carnage. He appears to be basing his estimate of American steadfastness on the Reagan Administration's abrupt flight from Lebanon after suicide bombers detonated an explosive-laden truck at a United States Marines barracks near Beirut, killing 241 Americans. But that was a peacekeeping force; the troops now in Saudi Arabia are primed for combat.
As long as he sits tight in Kuwait and stays in power at home, Mr. Hussein has some advantages.
''He probably can't be beaten,'' said a Western diplomat who spent several years in Baghdad at the height of the Iran-Iraq war. ''The West is going to have to go home at some point and in five years' time, if Saddam wants to raise oil prices, all he'll have to do is snap his fingers.
''The man is not a retreater,'' the diplomat added. ''Who can force him out of Kuwait?
Perhaps the Americans can, but at a cost that can't be foreseen. It's not a walkover. The numbers are going to be big.
And whatever happens, he'll be able to bluster, bluster that he was the only one to stand up to the West, the foreigners, the imperialists.'' It is this effort to assume the Arab nationalist mantle of Gamal Abdel Nasser that the Iraqi leader seems to be banking on in the face of the unexpected closing of Arab ranks, led by Egypt, against him. In bombastic speeches, he has not only inveighed against the deeply resented foreigners, but set poor Arabs against rich, portrayed the oil-wealthy emirs as decadent, selfish spendthrifts and - in a touch odd for a leader who espouses an avowedly secular pan-Arab ideology -made a religious appeal to protect Islam's most sacred shrines in Saudi Arabia against the ''infidels.''
His speeches have a visceral appeal to many poor Arabs working in the gulf and to Palestinians in refugee camps, because much of what he says about other Arab rulers is not without truth. Few Arab regimes have real legitimacy; most rule through a combination of inertia and secret police. Of course, Iraq is one of the toughest police states of all, as millions of ill-treated Egyptian workers there can attest, but in a long confrontation Mr. Hussein might be able to win Arab supporters to his cause. In the meantime, he must appease those within his own military embittered by his acquiesence to the Iranians.
There is also the potential for terrorism: Abu Nidal, the renegade Palestinian terrorist, has reportedly moved his base back to Baghdad.
''This is the Middle East,'' said the diplomat who had served in Iraq, reflecting on the dizzying events of the past two weeks. ''For every scenario you can envisage, three more will pop up.''

LENGTH: 1044 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Psychological Counseling From the Company Store

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
AFTER two decades of rapid growth, employee assistance programs, which have helped millions of workers suffering from angst and workplace stress, are experiencing an identity crisis of their own.
In the best of circumstances, the programs offer a ''win-win'' situation. The worker receives professional help, either from in-house counselors or through referral to outside therapists or treatment programs, and is restored as a productive member of the team. The company reaps the benefits of reduced absenteeism and is spared the corrosive conflict of dealing directly with problem workers or their union representatives. 
The attractiveness of this proposition has fed the growth of a small industry that now provides aid to workers in more than 12,000 companies. Reliable numbers are hard to come by, but people in the field estimate that there are 10,000 to 12,000 counselors and other workers providing services to employees, including many who might not otherwise seek help.
Even when employees are referred for outside treatment, the employee assistance programs can help them keep down out-of-pocket costs, supporters say. ''A good E.A.P. is aware of the high costs of treatment and is certainly not going to send an employee to a service he cannot afford or which is not covered by his health insurance plan,'' said Tom Delaney, executive director of the Employee Assistance Professionals Association, Inc., an organization in Arlington, Va., with a membership of 6,300.
According to the association, maintaining an employee assistance program costs approximately $1.50 per month for every employee on a payroll, though only 5 to 10 percent may actually use the services over the course of a year. The sponsoring companies can expect a 5-to-1 return on this investment through savings made possible when a worker responds to counseling and job performance improves.
But some who are active in the field say that the rapid growth of the programs has created potential problems. They point out that states do not require certification of counselors. A few organizations representing employee assistance counselors offer certification of individuals or programs, and counselors may have graduate training in social work, counseling, psychology or administrative skills. But no clearly prescribed curriculum for the new specialty is taught at universities.
''Those in employee assistance have confused rapid growth and acceptance in the workplace as signs of professionalism but they are really entrepreneurs, bureaucrats and counselors,'' said Dr. Paul Roman of the Institute for Behavorial Research at the University of Georgia, an authority on the programs.
He said he is especially dubious of programs run for companies by outside contractors. ''Outside contracting is very attractive at a time of hiring freezes, but when they are set up off-site and the staff is not very visible and may not even know much about E.A.P. skills, which actually happens a lot, how can the human resource manager of a company feel assured that the services his employees are receiving are adequate?''
Employee assistance programs evolved out of efforts in the public and private sectors to deal with occupational problems and absenteeism caused by alcoholism. Following the social upheavals of the 1960's and 1970's, company managers saw both the humane and economic wisdom in offering drug abuse programs and counseling for workers with emotional disturbances. With health insurance costs accelerating over the last decade, employers have found even more incentive to try to hold down costs by offering some kind of relatively inexpensive counseling.
People in the industry recognize that possible conflicts of interest can arise when counselors privy to an employee's secrets are on the employer's payroll.
''Obviously there are circumstances when a counselor learns that a client is an immediate threat to himself or others and a third party has to be notified,'' said Dan Smith, director of employee assistance programs for McDonnell Douglas. The aerospace company is laying off 14,000 to 17,000 workers this year and has seen a sharp rise in activity at its employee assistance program.
It is probably natural for workers to wonder whether the problems they reveal to company counselors are leaked back to their bosses and used against them. Experts say that as companies have responded to pressure from the Federal Government to create drug-free workplaces, suspicions have increased.
 
Maintaining Independence
But Dr. William D. Weitzel, a psychiatrist at the University of Kentucky who has studied the programs for the American Psychiatric Association, said that breaches in confidentiality are rare and more a consequence of unprofessionalism than malice. The American Civil Liberties Union and the American Psychological Association agree with that view.
Some counselors are leery that their independence could be threatened as rising health-care costs tempt companies to try to hold down the number of employees referred to expensive outside programs specializing in mental illness or chemical dependency. To get a tighter grip on their assistance programs, some companies have brought in consultants, or ''gatekeepers,'' to take over the job of employee referrals and to reduce the in-patient options. ''Whether intentional or not, E.A.P. counselors were referring workers and their dependents to the more expensive in-patient facilities where the hotel costs of housing and feeding a patient are more than treatment costs,'' said Lawrence Hicks, president of a consulting firm in Glenview, Ill., that helps companies trim health-care costs. ''Some studies show out-care programs may produce better results,'' he said.
But supporters of the assistance programs say that it is to the counselors' credit when they recognize that treating a problem requires more expertise than exists within the walls of the company.
''The best E.A.P.'s are the greatest thing that ever happened to corporate America and the human beings who work for them,'' said Dr. Gary VandenBos, a psychotherapist and consultant in Washington who has helped companies set up assistance programs. ''The worst ones are utter disasters and nothing but a waste of money.''

HEADLINE: The True Cost of Energy;
Pay It: For Security, the Economy and the Air

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein's plunder of Kuwait only dramatizes something Americans have long known from the bottom of their gas tanks: Oil dependency breeds vulnerability.
One way or another, the Iraq crisis will end. But the vulnerability won't - unless America creates a national energy policy. That's no sanctimonious abstraction; it's a practical need. A sound energy policy would encourage domestic suppliers, insulate the economy against foreign manipulation, protect the environment and raise revenue. Congress could do it all in a stroke, by increasing energy taxes. 
President Bush has followed the Reagan energy policy: reliance on deregulated markets to guide consumers and producers, and the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to offset supply disruptions. These are sensible principles. Deregulation has raised energy prices and cut use. And the reserve has warded off panic buying.
Yet the Reagan-Bush hands-off approach is not enough. Americans account for 2 percent of the world's population but consume an astounding 25 percent of the world's oil. Much of this consumption is wasted because low market prices take insufficient account of real costs.
One is national security. Every extra barrel consumed makes the U.S. that much more vulnerable to oil cartel cutbacks. The price Americans pay for imported oil covers none of the likely costs of future supply interruptions brought on by such dependence. Likewise, energy use fouls air and water and contributes to global warming. Yet consumers pay for none of this damage.
 
The Best Way to Pay
For all these reasons, consumers aren't paying the full costs of energy. The most effective way to do that is higher energy taxes. They would right the balance - and also avoid the need for a lot of micro-managing by Congress. Americans would switch to fuel-efficient cars without elaborate regulations; alternative fuels could become competitive without massive subsidies.
Congress would still have to decide which energy taxes to raise, and by how much. Each tax has a different regional and environmental consequence. Though there are few studies to guide the decisions, a tax that would add between 25 and 50 cents to the price of a gallon of gasoline would make a good start.
Debate over the pros and cons of various options must not overshadow the underlying principle: Americans are paying too little for energy.
 
Fill the Reserve
The Strategic Petroleum Reserve provides another pillar of energy policy. Large buffer stocks can offset temporary supply disruptions - and radically change oil exporters' calculations. These goals would be better served by expanding the reserve to 1 billion barrels from 600 million.
Its operating procedures also need revision. The reserve can be opened only by a Presidential declaration of an emergency. There are promising proposals to open it on an ongoing basis, subject to a fee that would allow Government to replace withdrawn supply at a profit. These proposals deserve serious review, before the next crisis.
 
Revive Nuclear Energy
It's a Federal responsibility also to promote new sources of energy. There is a relatively low-cost, non-polluting form of it, which gives France 70 percent of its electricity, Japan 30 percent but the U.S. only 18 percent: nuclear. One attractive option would be to join with our allies in designing a nuclear reactor so safe that all reasonable unease would be allayed.
The Iraq crisis has generated new oratory about energy independence. A tax that would take national security and the environment into account would mean only a moderate increase in the price of energy. But to achieve energy independence would require a draconian leap that would stifle the economy and cost millions of Americans their jobs. To press for energy independence for its own sake would be economically suicidal.
A wise energy policy must strike a balance between reduced dependence and an induced depression. The starting point is this proposition: Energy taxes must rise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Don't Measure Souter by the Size of His Town;
New Hampshire's Best

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Roy Brooks (Op-Ed, Aug. 1) suggests that among principal qualifications for the Supreme Court are (1) be married, (2) live in a city and (3) be known by name to Justice Thurgood Marshall.
Judge David H. Souter was not born where he now lives. He lived his first 11 years and at least 7 more years in college and law school in and about Boston. Boston, Harvard University and New Hampshire are not peopled exclusively by white, middle-class males. Southern New Hampshire has become a fast-growing extension of the greater Boston area, with its own share of urban problems. Moreover, our rural towns, such as Judge Souter's Weare, have more than their share of poor people. And within these small communities, middle-class, upper-class and poor people get to know and understand one another better than most city people do in their more economically segregated neighborhoods.
As a New Hampshire lawyer, I can assure you that any poll of our bar would produce virtual unanimity, among Republicans and Democrats, males and females, that for his human, as well as his intellectual qualities, Judge Souter is New Hampshire's best candidate for the Supreme Court position; and we are just proud enough to think our best is plenty good.
 
ARTHUR MUDGE
Hanover, N.H., Aug. 2, 1990

HEADLINE: Why Iraq Won't Make Israel Say 'Atom'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Why Israel May Show Its Nuclear Hand'' (Op-Ed, Aug. 6) by Yossi Melman, which concludes that Israel may soon publicly confirm its status as a nuclear weapons state, demonstrates the author's discomfort with Israel's policy of nuclear ambiguity. Periodic comments by Israeli politicians play a role in this policy.
For example, as early as December 1974, President Ephraim Katzir stated: ''It has always been our intention to provide the potential for nuclear weapons development. We now have that potential. We will defend this country with all means at hand. We have to develop more powerful and new arms to protect ourselves.'' 
This policy bestows many of the advantages of both open nuclear weapons possession and renunciation of nuclear arms, with few of the liabilities of either position. A public declaration that Israel possessed nuclear weapons would humiliate its Arab neighbors and further energize their interest in developing nuclear bombs.
Further, a public declaration would revitalize and help legitimize a Soviet role in the Middle East. In addition, it would outrage world opinion and increase Israel's isolation. Most important, Israel could jeopardize the substantial economic and military support that the United States has consistently provided.
Finally, if Israel believes it must shore up the credibility of its nuclear deterrent, there are a number of ways to do so without a public declaration. Another veiled statement by an Israeli official, or perhaps the granting of an interview with Mordechai Vanunu, the former nuclear technician who disclosed details of Israel's nuclear program to London's Sunday Times, would signal to Iraq the potentially devastating consequences of its aggression.
Short of an outright Iraqi attack on Israel that threatens the country's existence, however, there is little reason to expect that Iraq's recent brutality against Kuwait will force Israel into changing its policy of nuclear ambiguity.
 
MITCHELL REISS
McLean, Va., Aug. 8, 1990
 
The writer worked on the National Security Council, 1988-89.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
The Invasion Vacation

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
We didn't want to take this vacation. It was the President's idea. I figured we should just call August on account of invasion, hunker down, and wait for the price of gasoline to reach the foie gras mark. The President would have none of this. ''The American people want to see life go on,'' he said.
This was not as easy as it sounded. As a patriotic gesture, we bought charcoal briquets and went to the middle of nowhere. The middle of nowhere was in the middle of a Middle East mania. News followed us to the outdoor art show and the Farmer's Market. 
The Village Grocery became Democracy Central. First thing in the morning, the bread delivery man, the milk delivery man and the man who runs the place would be clustered around the cash register, trashing King Hussein and tracking troop deployments. ''I think the President is right on the money,'' they said. This is the kind of place where the President is usually right on the money.
The gas station was raucous with gas-line lore, much of it macho and apocryphal. Testosterone filled the air. War will do that. You know the drill: ''Remember in '79 when you punched out that guy who tried to cut in line to put air in his tires, Phil?'' someone says. ''Hell,'' says Phil, ''I never punched him out. I ran over his foot. And it was '73.''
At the mall teen-agers in heavy-metal T-shirts sullenly absorbed current events. ''Saddam Hussein, man,'' they would say, if they could talk. ''He's toast.'' America has rallied round, and it is something to see. There's a local angle, no matter what the locality -American kids in khaki, folks like us held hostage and empty gas tanks. The story is writ large: friends, foes, a big bad guy with the sinister mustache of a James Bond villain. The Iraqis have replaced the Soviets in the evil empire role, much missed since we began playing ''I'm O.K., you're O.K.'' with the Russians. Polls show that Americans are more possessed by this story than by any in years.
People say it's hard to get away from it all because of the magic of cable television, fax machines, computer modems. But this time around it's democracy that's doing us in. Now that election campaigns bear more of a resemblance to MTV than to statesmanship, we've got two ways to reaffirm what this country stands for. One is the jury room, with its miraculous ability to turn 12 bumbling United States citizens into paragons of diplomacy, objectivity and thoughtfulness.
The other is crisis management. Iraq invades Kuwait and - Bingo! -all Americans become experts on the Middle East, dependence on foreign oil, and chemical warfare. It's one of the enduring strengths of this country that the average guy at the corner store believes he has some small influence, and some great responsibility.
''That Iraq fella is going to get what's coming to him,'' said the man waiting in the barbershop to get his short hair cut shorter. ''That's my prediction.''
There's something for everyone here. The word Vietnam, which keeps cropping up in discussions about troop strength and American involvement, speaks to the collective memory of one generation of Americans. The word Hitler, which has been used profligately in discussions of the Iraqi leader, speaks to another. (The public-opinion mavens who've been asking people how Hussein compares to Hitler should be prosecuted for carrying a loaded question.) The angle for kids: Saddam Hussein is Bart Simpson cubed. Bad attitude, dude.
Life goes on, but not on its usual track. Even the President couldn't keep up the illusion of normalcy. He vacates well, but he has to watch appearances. People still remember that he went hunting at the tail end of the Panama invasion.
He told the rest of us to go on with our lives, and then instead of staying put in Kennebunkport, with the phone in his golf cart and his cigarette boat, he took a short trip back to Washington. It was a Daddy vacation. A couple of days in a business suit, a couple of days in a vest with lots of little pockets and hooks and feathers all over it. Takes me back. This all takes me back. Gas shortages, double-digit inflation, trouble in the Middle East - these are the things that shaped my formative years. I thought someday we'd gather around the Weber kettle and pass them along to our children in stories and song. Now they're experiencing them firsthand. All they hear about is the Middle East, and Lyme disease. ''Are we having a war?'' one asked, and in the fashion of my times, I answered, ''Sort of.'' Then we toss a Frisbee around, and wait to hear the news from around the world at the roadside produce stand.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
From Mirage To War

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
A country that emerges from one war without knowing why it came about prepares the way for another war - with the same enemy or his clones.
Now, while memories are fresh, is the best time to figure out why we find ourselves again facing one of the expansionist tyrants who are this country's natural enemies, why we are again so surprised by it all.
This is the historical starting point: Arab leaders and the West have treated the Middle East and its people as objects to fulfill their own power, ambitions and lusts.
The Arab leaders made sure to keep tribal or feudal systems and political or religious despotisms intact. That is how they prevent the Middle East from moving into a fresher world, which could challenge or discard them. 
While much of the world struggled for new political and economic ways, the Arab world has remained ruled entirely by hereditary, military or religious tyrannies and homemade economic monopolies.
With Western support nations like India and Japan moved to freedom from foreign colonialism or domestic imperialism. Elections were held from South Korea to Nicaragua. In the past year, the bells rang in Eastern Europe, bringing hope to all who yearned for freedom's grace.
But in the Middle East, the West looked on benignly as dynastic jailers kept their people in political cellars.
Why? For one reason: The West and the Middle Eastern rulers have floated in a pool of assumed common interest - oil.
National boundaries were usually drawn by Western colonial offices. The economic future of the area was decided by a combination of local rulers, Western ministries and oil companies.
Western ''experts'' said solemnly that Arabs and democracy did not mix - religion and tradition, you know.
Too many Western academic and government specialists, writers and journalists came to believe in a mythological Islamic world, a mirage of tolerance, brotherhood and chivalric rulers.
It was a fantasy world where strangers were fed roasted lamb, and never ever taken hostage. It satisfied the consciences and ambitions and sometimes scratched the erotic itches of foreigners who built their careers around the Middle East. (Reading list: the sensitive, rich books of Bernard Lewis, director of the Annenberg Research Institute of Philadelphia and Princeton University professor, including his latest, ''Race and Slavery in the Middle East.'') But it was a fantasy built on the contemptuous idea that Arabs could not aspire to or practice democracy.
The result of the confluence of Arab-Western oil interests and mythology - and later Moscow's arming of Arab dictators - is that not a single Middle Eastern ruler has been freely chosen by his people, not a one.
They rule by heredity of recent vintage, like the Saudis, by coup, like Saddam, by a no-opposition ''referendum,'' like President Mubarak of Egypt, or by imposition of the British colonial office, like King Hussein of Jordan.
Yesterday's history but it has become today's war. Arab rulers tried to protect themselves by making religious fanaticism or zealotry for the ''Arab nation'' the only political currencies in the Middle East. Torture and death are the price of talking about freedom.
The rulers stoked frenzied nationalism. It helped build Saddam as it did Assad of Syria, the terrorist paymaster who is now our 15-minute ally and one day will turn against us again.
And in Washington our specialists were so wrapped up in their Middle East fantasies that they refused to hear Saddam's threats against us until he stuck his gun in their ear.
The Arab nations are dangerous not because Arabs are born with knives in their mouths but because with our help, only dictators rule. Because they are unchosen, dictators are insecure. Insecure rulers with armies are dangerous by definition.
Time and again the U.S. has found itself at war with one of them; democracy and despotism threaten each other. When was the last time the U.S. found itself at war with a democracy?
But Arab nationalism is not inevitable or unstoppable. The Arab world has never had a chance to hear freedom-loving dissidents or an elected leader who might argue against hatred and Holy War.
We certainly cannot create Arab democracy. But we can support it if it ever begins to appear. Meanwhile, in decency to people who live under any dictatorship, we can throw away our tales of the Arabian nights.
If we do, we may even save ourselves from fighting another war, on the same battleground.

HEADLINE: A Kentucky Home Afloat

BYLINE: By Erik Sandberg-Diment; Erik Sandberg-Diment is a writer who lives in Connecticut.

 BODY:
The dense jungle filling the cove that surrounded our mooring was barely visible in the breaking dawn. An orchestra of birds wrapped their melody around the syncopation of an ancient percolator in the galley as I sat, feet propped on the bow rail, watching the mist lift from the landscape. There was no visible sign of civilization, recalling the shore of some remote Pacific Island until the brightening daybreak revealed the jungle to be tulip trees, sycamores, cedars and maples.
We were in fact lost somewhere on a lake in southern Kentucky. The previous afternoon we had rented a houseboat and set out to explore Lake Cumberland, a crystal-clear 63,000-acre manmade mountain lake almost unknown to anyone beyond the heartland of America. My wife and I and our two children were there (in June) simply because a fishing friend in Iowa had suggested the trip.
Inexperienced at houseboating - although the four of us had vacationed together on a canal boat in England - we had gone through the marina's five-minute ''skippers' training'' program: ''This is the way you choke the engine to start; use only our bathroom tissue in the marine toilet or it will clog and you'll have to pay for repairs; take the key out of the ignition if you use the swimming ladder in back; the emergency channel on the radio is 16, call us if you need help.'' 
Our instructor had then backed our houseboat out of its slip and maneuvered it past another 30 or so houseboats to the mouth of the marina. Turning the wheel over to us, he said, ''Good luck!
If you need to dock, just bring the boat this far, honk twice and we'll come pick you up.'' He stepped into his dinghy and roared back to shore.
''All right, you take the wheel,'' I said to Tanya, our 16-year-old daughter, ''and I'll try to figure out where we're going.''
This had proved easier said than done. Because of its steep shoreline, Lake Cumberland (which is about 80 miles south of Lexington) has almost no houses or other manmade landmarks along its edge. Since no geodetic or navigational charts were available where we rented the boat, our aides consisted of a complimentary Lake Cumberland map from the Regional Information Center, pretty but not very specific, and the slightly more detailed Westmorland fishermmen's version. Both showed the water as blue, the Cumberland foothills as green - equally green no matter what their height - and the few access roads to the lake in black or red. The fishermen's map also indicated submerged building sites, creek channels and cemeteries from the days before the Wolf Creek Dam was built, when the lake bottom had been an agricultural valley - none of these exactly navigational landmarks. Neither map gave any sense of scale for the first-timer on the relatively narrow, serpentine lake.
The one thing obvious from both maps was that Lake Cumberland has an incredibly jagged and serrated shoreline, which explains how a 100-mile-long lake can boast a 1,300-mile-long shore. I passed the maps around and we all agreed that we were in the middle of a big U the lake makes at the conflux of Lily, McFarland and Wolf Creeks - unless we were already much farther along, all the way to Difficulty Creek. Mercifully, no one at that point suggested we were up it without a paddle.
''We have to find a small cove to anchor in before it gets dark,'' I said, employing a navigational inaccuracy, since boats on Lake Cumberland don't come with anchors. The water is simply too deep for an anchor in most spots, often dropping 30 or more feet just 10 feet from shore and reaching soundings of hundreds of feet toward its middle.
Half an hour and a dozen coves later - all but one unoccupied - we finally pulled into a steep-sided valley that we all agreed was perfect and nosed our nameless houseboat, No. 8, up against a shore-bound log. We had two stern lines tied to firmly rooted trees at the approved 45-degree angle, the bow deck gas grill running hot and both kids frolicking in the aquamarine water all in the space of five minutes. Which is how I found myself the following morning fantasizing about Pacific islands while waiting for the mist to rise and the coffee to perk.
Eventually, the rest of the family joined me for breakfast on deck. After some shoreline exploration on foot, although extensive hiking is difficult because of the 45- to 90-degree ascent one must make along almost all of the banks - and some leisurely aquatic activity in water whose average summer surface temperature averages in the low 80's, we set off once more in search of a tiny cove.
Our journey was punctuated by ''There we are - no, that cove!'' and stabs at the map by everyone until Revell, our 10-year-old son, said, ''Hey, there's a launching ramp.''
''True. But it can't be,'' my wife, Susan, pointed out. ''There's absolutely nothing like that anywhere near where we are, according to this map.''
''Let's dock and see if we can find out where we are,'' Revell suggested.
Now I suppose I could comment here on my children's astute powers of observation. The launching ramp was deserted but for two battened-down small boats and an empty telephone booth. But I'll admit that what was really passing through my mind at the moment was that we were cruising along just fine, thank you. Why should I rock the boat? After all, I was getting the hang of maneuvering a 48-foot houseboat, but not yet taking comfort in the thought of actually docking.
At first, the idea of letting totally inexperienced people set off in such a large boat might seem total madness. But, as it so happens, Lake Cumberland is the perfect place for such neophyte ventures. Hugged tightly by the surrounding hills, the surface of the lake is unusually calm and wind free. The number of boats per acre is far less than one, rather than some multiple of 10 as is the case in so many East Coast lakes, so there's little danger of crunching encounters.
Then, too, the houseboats themselves are slow and stable craft. Venturing out on them may well be described as boating for those who get seasick. Except for an occasional rocking set off by the wake of a passing boat, these nautical quarters are as steady as a mountain cabin. With a modicum of care and caution, anyone can handle a houseboat on Lake Cumberland comfortably within a short period of time. (Ours, one of about 200 houseboats operated by a dozen marinas on the lake, had one sleeping cabin and a living space with cooking facilities and, off to one side, double bunks.) We continued up the lake, mooring in a small bay for lunch. Part of the pleasure is not the boating itself, but simply lolling around the deck while at rest.
It was the lolling around part that I had difficulty convincing the rest of the family about. Right after lunch Revell discovered a geode on shore. Tanya hopped over the rail and began searching for her own specimen along the rock-strewn coast, soon followed by Susan on a similar mission.
They weren't great geodes, mind you. The crystals growing in their hollow cavities appeared for the most part to be a poor grade of amethyst. Still, I couldn't be a stick-in-the-mud. I joined in, picking up the smooth round baseball-size sandstone rocks and cracking them open like walnuts against larger rocks. ''The lighter they are, the bigger the hollow.'' ''Look at the crystals in this one!''
Three hours later, we left what in our family was now known as Geode Bay. We headed back out to open water laden down with a cargo of geodes, a tire complete with rim that must have broken free from someone's dock and made an excellent boat bumper, and a ship now finally christened the M.V. Junkyard.
Our vessel's nickname and newly loaded deck notwithstanding, the litter and pollution besetting Lake Cumberland remains surprisingly slight. Two factors, however, could well combine to destroy this idyllic situation within the decade to come. First, boats on the lake are not currently required to have holding tanks. The marine toilets are equipped with macerators. Flush them, and everything in them is simply ground up and discharged into the water.
Secondly, there is a proposal by a local underwear manufacturing company to use the lake as a liquid dump. The plan is to pump industrial waste into the lake via pipeline, the idea being that this inland sea would be large enough to dilute and absorb the effluent without noticeable deterioration in water quality.
What a sad mistake that move would be, I thought as we cruised along the clear surface of what is still, below its now generous expanse, the Cumberland River. Daniel Boone had once canoed this very river as far as French Lick (now Nashville) on one of his long hunts.
That evening we again found a deserted spot to call our own for the night. We moored against a small island - there are not many on the lake, but the ones there are are lovely - about 20 times as long as our boat. Some 30 feet of sheer layered rock face rose above us, twisting stunted lone pines clinging precariously to it by the path ascending its ridge. Scaling its pinnacle was somehow like traversing a magnified bonsai garden.
At one end, the island descended to a flat ledge at water level. This outcropping was covered with large black and yellow butterflies. Tanya and Revell spent the dusk, between grilled hamburgers and a pile of grapes, mixing a sugar solution and feeding the butterflies. And so Butterfly Island was born in our memories.
Another night's mooring turned up fossils, and one afternoon was spent frolicking beneath a cascading waterfall at the headwaters of Indian Creek. As we traveled from mooring to mooring, Tanya and Revell, and even at times the grown-ups, took turns cooling off in the spray tossed up around them as they sat on a supersized inner tube towed behind the houseboat. Farther up the lake, the shoreline featured flatter areas permitting walking and exploring, though the rocks all over are sharp enough so that only the toughest of feet survive unscathed without shoes.
What at first had seemed as if it might be a very uniform, even monotonous lake was offering a new discovery every day, I reflected while stretched out on our upper deck. Lazing there as we explored various creeks and inlets was totally relaxing.
The steady hum and slight vibration of the engine made it feel as if one were on the deck of an ocean liner bound for an endless voyage -or maybe the African Queen. No, not the Queen, there weren't any leeches about. In fact, there weren't any real problems at all on Lake Cumberland. They'd been left behind in our week of bother-free houseboating.
 
CHARTING A COURSE FOR A LAKE TRIP
 
Planning
The best way to start planning for a Lake Cumberland houseboat trip is with a note or call to the Russell County Tourist Commission, Post Office Box 64, Russell Springs, Ky. 42642 (502-866-4333). You will be sent a map of the lake and brochures from the various marinas renting houseboats.
These brochures will require some careful perusing. What is one to make, for instance, of the description ''Sleeps up to 8, but no more than 10 please''? Follow-up calls to confirm prices, availability and what is included in the rental package will be needed. Some outfitters, for instance, include towels and bedding; others do not. Most rentals are for Monday through Friday afternoon; the weekend, including Friday evening and Monday morning, or a full week. The Monday through Friday rates are generally the most cost effective.
 
Boats and Rates
The boats range in size from a basic 48-footer, which may have an ice chest instead of a refrigerator and no hot water, to a deluxe 70-footer with V.C.R., microwave, full air-conditioning, wet bar and hot tub. We opted for the spartan model and thoroughly enjoyed it. The whole family agreed, after inspecting one of the luxury models, that it was more like a private motel than quarters befitting adventure.
Rates vary tremendously depending on time of year and duration of stay. They begin at just over $400 for four days on an economy houseboat and run up to $1,600 for the same period on a floating palace sleeping 10 in several private cabins during the height of the summer season. However, prices are sometimes flexible. This past June, for instance, business was fairly slow, and most of the docks were discounting their rentals. The $595 rental on our boat was reduced to $399 because of a special. Shop around. It pays.
When tallying up costs, be prepared to add another $25 or so a day for gasoline, which is normally not included in the rental. There are also liability waiver options to consider, as when renting a car. Many houseboat renters also take a small fishing boat ($50 a day), a ski boat (around $200 a day) and skis ($100 a day) or a personal watercraft ($150 a day) to add variety to their waterborne activities. We settled for towing a large inner tube.
 
Provisions
Food shopping can be done at stores near the lake - we went to a supermarket in Jamestown. The marinas usually sell some basic supplies. A final word for those wanting to sit on deck, preprandial cocktail in hand, watching the sunset. This part of the country is dry, alcoholically speaking. It will be strictly a bring-your-own party - unless you hook up with one of the local bootleggers, in which event a case of beer will run you $30 to $40 and the brand selection will tend to be on a you-take-what-you-get basis.E. S-D.
