SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 3; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 385 words

HEADLINE: Postings: 15-Story Facelift;
New Windows, Lobby on 33d

 BODY:
Most people familiar with the oddly shaped, ''winged'' structure that straddles the Penn Central Railroad tracks on West 33d Street and 10th Avenue know it as the home of Sky Rink, Manhattan's only public indoor ice-skating rink.
But the 15-story, 1.5 million-square-foot building, which stretches from 33d to 31st Streets, was built for light manufacturing and warehousing companies. It was completed in the late 1960's just as Manhattan's economic base was beginning to lose its brawn as rents became too high for many industrial tenants. Since it took over in 1977, the building's owner, John Hancock Properties of Boston, has signed on office tenants as warehousing and manufacturing companies left. Now the building is undergoing cosmetic surgery to make it even more appealing for office tenants. 
''The first wave of office tenants to come to the building were back-office space users,'' said Timothy Rodgers, senior vice president of John Hancock Properties. ''But we have been successful in attracting tenants like Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover Bank and we want to strengthen the building's front-office use.''
The facelift will include upgrading inside and outside. Der Scutt, the architect in charge of the transformation, said that although a new look was the goal of the renovation, he wanted to do it in a way that would respect the work of the original architects, Davis Brody & Associates.
The building's discolored concrete surface will be repaired and given a new coat of beige paint. New window frames and bronze-tinted windows will be installed. The new main entrance will have stainless steel doors and a canopy of bronze metal panels and colored ceramic tile. Two existing loading docks will be converted to retail space.
Inside, two small lobbies will be combined to make a large one. The new lobby will have marble floors and walls as well as new incandescent lighting. Floors in the building range from 42,000 to more than 100,000 square feet in size. With the departure of Baby Togs, a children's apparel distribution company, there is now approximately 325,200 square feet of space available of which 195,000 square feet is contiguous space on two floors. The asking price for this space is $21 a square foot.
Work on the building is expected to be completed by October.

LENGTH: 2025 words

HEADLINE: Lenders Feel New Pressures To Aid Poor Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Already squeezed by mounting defaults, lower earnings and a savings and loan debacle that has made them shy away from many development proposals, the nation's real estate lenders are now feeling pressure from another source - new Federal rules that require greater attention to the credit needs of minorities and low-income neighborhoods.
The rules, adopted last year, are part of the same law under which Congress budgeted $157 billion to close hundreds of ailing thrift institutions. Although the huge cost of the bailout - some experts say it will grow to $500 billion - has largely overshadowed the law's provisions for community development, they have not escaped the notice of bankers, who are coming under increasing scrutiny by bank regulators.
Under one key provision of the 1989 law, the Federal Reserve and other regulatory agencies began last month a review of the performance of lenders that will lead to public ratings based on the quality of their service to poor neighborhoods.
The impact seems certain to be strongest in New York City, the nation's center of finance. One reason is the large number of major lending institutions in the city. 
Another is the city's huge 10-year program to renovate, build and manage thousands of units of low- and moderate-income housing; dozens of community groups are seeking construction loans and other financial support under that program.
Bank executives are not eager to attribute their community spirit to the dictates of Federal law. But since the requirements were adopted by Congress the lenders have been making many unusual initiatives in low-income neighborhoods, and no one suggests the timing is purely coincidental.
Community development offices are being established, executives recruited from not-for-profit community groups and government agencies, and large pools of money set aside for community development projects.
''It comes at a curious time because all real estate loans are being looked at carefully, but banks are repositioning themselves to beef up community development,'' said Gary Hattem, vice president in charge of a newly established community development group at the Bankers Trust Company.
Among other new programs, Bankers Trust announced last Wednesday that it will make a $500,000 grant to housing groups in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx that manage buildings for the homeless. For Bankers Trust, the commitment is unusual because its more conventional lines of business have almost nothing to do with small-scale real estate lending, but instead encompass a wide range of commercial development, corporate financing and international business.
And by traditional standards, Mr. Hattem is an unusual presence in the starched-collar world of big-city banking. He was hired away in March from the not-for-profit St. Nicholas Neighborhood Preservation Corporation, where he spent 15 years as a community organizer in the blighted sections of the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn.
''The banks are clearly under pressure,'' said Paul Grogan, president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, an organization that arranges private and public financing for low-income housing around the country. ''They are actually competing to lend in poor neighborhoods.''
Behind the flurry of activity is the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989, a 1,000-page law widely referred to by its acronym Firrea (pronounced Fye-REE-ah).
Although its principal impetus was the savings and loan crisis, Congress included the community development provisions after hearing persistent reports of redlining and of inadequate banking services for poor people.
The most potent of the new rules, according to bank executives, is designed to strengthen an existing law, the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which was meant to end discriminatory lending and bank services. The 13-year-old law empowered community groups or local officials to challenge, and in some cases block, bank mergers, the opening of new branches and other ventures by lending institutions that require regulatory approval.
If they have evidence that a lender provides poor or discriminatory service in its own community, the local groups can mount Community Reinvestment Act challenges at regulatory hearings.
The act also created new responsibilities for the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and other regulators. Each was to review the performance of the lenders it supervised, giving them ratings similar to a student's ''A'' to ''F'' grades. The ratings were not disclosed to the public.
What was private under the Community Reinvestment Act will be public under Firrea. Although the regulators conduct their reviews infrequently - at intervals of three to five years for many lenders - the new law requires the results of all future reviews to be made available to community groups, local government officials or anyone else seeking to apply pressure on lenders.
Even if they do not face legal challenges, lenders that receive poor ratings could suffer serious damage to their corporate prestige.
''Banks take a lot of pride in their public standing, and they want their ratings to reflect that,'' said Mr. Hattem of Bankers Trust.
Other provisions of Firrea, aimed more directly at the beleaguered savings and loan industry, are designed to push them into low-income housing projects.
One requires the nation's 12 Federal Home Loan Banks - Federal lending institutions that provide financing to savings and loans - to put a percentage of their net income each year into a pool of money used to offer below-market-rate loans.
The banks have already set aside $78 million from their 1990 profits, and the amount is expected to grow to at least $100 million a year by 1995.
Low-income housing projects across the nation were selected in July for the the first round of loans under the program. In New York, the recipients include groups that are building 186 homes in the South Bronx, rehabilitating a rental apartment building in Albany and working on other forms of low- and moderate-income housing.
Another Firrea rule applies to the Resolution Trust Corporation, the new Federal agency set up to dispose of assets seized from insolvent thrift institutions. The corporation must offer low-income housing groups the opportunity to buy any home it seizes with an appraised value under $67,500 and is authorized by Congress to offer the groups low-interest financing.
But experts say the provision of Firrea that are having the broadest impact on lenders - and could make the biggest long-term difference in lending patterns - is the new rating system, which went into effect this summer. Although industry anaylsts are skeptical, bankers in some cities say they are approaching the new rules with something close to evangelical zeal.
''I like to compare what is going on at banks to churches doing their community outreach,'' said Gary Jewel, vice president and counsel for the First American National Bank of Memphis. He added that the challenge to banks now is not only in making more loans in low-income areas, but also in finding acceptable projects and customers.
''We've got to find developers and contractors that are honest and reputable,'' he said. ''It doesn't mean lowering our standards, just working harder.''
The motivation of lenders is not entirely dictated by Firrea. After the heady development boom of the 80's, which left many counting their defaults and loan losses, some maintain that working with nonprofit groups in low-income neighborhoods now looks like good business.
''These loans can be harder to make, but they are easier to live with,'' said Hugh Loftus, director of community reinvestment for the Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles, which announced last month it would commit $2.4 billion in loans over the next 10 years to projects or businesses in low- and moderate-income areas, with the bulk going to not-for-profit housing groups.
He added that the bank considers working with not-for-profit groups attractive because most are also receiving financing from several other sources, including government agencies. ''That tends to make these very secure transactions,'' Mr. Loftus said.
In the New York area, there are many examples of new community development initiatives since Firrea was enacted.
In a major program, the Chase Manhattan bank this year established a new subsidiary, the Chase Community Development Corporation, and said it would commit $200 million over the next five years to affordable-housing programs and other development projects in poor neighborhoods.
''The quality of the deals is very good, but by normal banking standards these just are not considered traditional types of lending,'' said Mark Willis, an urban economist and president of the Chase subsidiary and a former deputy commissioner of New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
So far, the Chase subsidiary's initiatives have ranged from large to off-beat. It has invested heavily in the projects sponsored by the Local Initiative Support Corporation and has established a mortgage loan program for low- and moderate-income buyers, who need only a 5 percent down payment.
For its West Indian customers, it has set up the ''Su-Su Account'' - a form of Christmas Club savings program under which immigrants from the West Indies, whose culture dictates that they save money collectively, can use money deposited by several people for down payments on real estate.
Foreign banks, whose United States operations are subject to the same rating procedure as domestically owned lenders, have begun to commit money to low-income housing.
In one example, Neighborhood Housing Services, a New York City not-for-profit group, said in July that IJB Schroder Bank and Trust Company, a Japanese concern, had committed $500,000 in loans for its low- and moderate-income housing programs.
Executives at smaller banks in rural communities say that meeting the new requirements of Firrea will require, more than anything else, an increase in record keeping. Because few of the rural lenders serve communities where the lines dividing ethnic neighborhoods or poor and affluent areas are clear, the law is prompting bankers to meet with representatives of the poor to plan lending programs and to keep painstaking records of their lending.
''Most of the bankers I talk to say we are already in compliance,'' said Robert Moyer, president of the Wilber National Bank in Oneonta, N.Y., an upstate city in a rural setting. ''But what is required under Firrea is very specific records on what you have done.''
Lawmakers and political analysts say that one of the influences on Congress when it adopted the new community development provisions was a series of reports on discriminatory lending policies in several large cities.
''What we found was clearly a matter of insufficient enforcement'' of laws banning discrimination under the Community Reinvestment Act, said Charles Finn, director of the banking and community economic development project at the University of Minnesota, which, since 1988, has conducted detailed studies of mortgage lending practices in Atlanta, Detroit and Boston.
The studies, submitted to Congress when it deliberated Firrea, found many examples of unequal lending in white and black neighborhoods. In Atlanta, for example, Mr. Finn said he looked at lending patterns in white and black neighborhoods that had the same income levels, and found that residents of the black neighborhoods were five times less likely to have their application for a home loan approved.
Because of Firrea, and the resulting initiatives by lenders to set up new community development projects, ''there is clearly a formula being constructed on how to conform to the Community Reinvestment Act,'' he said. Nonetheless, he added that he has adopted a ''wait-and-see attitude.''
''The big decisions that you take to the board of directors have been made,'' he said, ''but whether that reaches down to the day-to-day decisions of loan committees remains to be seen.''

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: Teaneck Journal;
After Night of Violence, Storekeepers Are Determined to Stay

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: TEANECK

 BODY:
IF he closes his eyes and allows his mind to wander, John Callas says, he can still hear sheets of glass breaking and crashing to the floor. But more vividly, he remembers the shouts of anger mixed with frustration and fear.
''What happened that night I still have a tough time understanding,'' said Mr. Callas, the owner of the Mediterranean Gourmet Deli on Teaneck Road, ''and though it made me scared, it made me think that people have to be more tolerant of each other, no matter what the circumstances.''
On April 10, a teen-ager was shot and killed by a local police officer who said he suspected that the youth was armed. The following evening, a candlelight vigil in front of police headquarters, on the corner of Teaneck Road and Cedar Lane, turned into a skirmish between local residents, out-of-towners and the police. Before it was over, half a dozen police cruisers were destroyed, and the glass storefronts of some 20 businesses along Teaneck Road had been smashed. Some stores were looted. A dozen people were injured, including youths, police officers and journalists covering the situation. 
''I saw the crowds moving and there was anger in their eyes and then something came crashing through my window,'' Mr. Callas said. ''We called the police and they told us to just leave, to get out, but I wasn't about to abandon what it took me years to build up.''
The passage of four months has led many store owners to reassess their damage, both material and emotional. Many, like Mr. Callas, say the incident has done little to change the way they feel about the community.
''Emotions got out of hand and people got out of hand,'' he said, ''but since that day, people have worked together to make things better. Sometimes good things come out of the bad.''
Tensions were renewed recently when a state grand jury in Trenton chose not to indict Gary Spath, the Teaneck police officer who had shot the youth, Phillip C. Pannell. The State Attorney General has said that a discrepancy in the county Medical Examiner's autopsy report warrants a second grand jury's being convened to re-examine the case.
Echoing the sentiments of many shopkeepers who suffered losses that night, Mr. Callas, who lives in nearby Bogota, said he felt that much of the damage was caused by youths from outside this middle-class Bergen County community of 40,000.
''I get a lot of kids from the high school who come in here all the time, and that night I didn't recognize any faces,'' he said, adding that after the night of violence, a group of local youths came in and apologized for the damage, insisting that outsiders were responsible.
''That took a lot of guts for them to come in here and tell their side, I have to say that,'' said Mr. Callas, who estimated the damage to his store at $12,000.
Jerry Mrkulic, a Bronx resident who owns Jerry's Pizza on the corner of Teaneck Road and Forest Avenue, had to close his business for three days because of the damage and looting. But now, he said, it's ''business as usual.''
''This neighborhood is my second home,'' he said, ''and nothing is ever going to change that. I get along with the people here, I know them they know me and I've never had any trouble.'' Mr. Mrkulic has been doing business in town for three years.
''The night they broke in, there were faces I did not know for the most part,'' he said. ''Had it been people that I knew, it would have hurt me all the more.''
 
'They Told Me to Calm Down'
That night, many shopkeepers said, they were enraged that the police did not respond immediately to their calls for help, but, looking back on the degree of police restraint shown during the incident, many now say that they cannot fault the police.
''When I called the police, they told me to calm down and if I had to, to abandon my place until the crowd left,'' Mr. Mrkulic said. ''I told them, 'How can I leave, the people are crazy out there and what if somebody comes in here to kill me or I hurt somebody in protecting my store?' '' Later, he said, his bitterness turned to empathy. ''I think the cops did the best they could,'' said Mr. Mrkulic, whose damage was assessed at $8,000.
The merchant who operates Martinson's Cleaners on Teaneck Road said, ''Things are back to normal, they are calm and my customers come back.''
''This is a good town and the people are good,'' said the merchant, who identified himself only as Kim. ''I feel bad at what happened, but there has been no trouble before or since. This is a kindly, loving town, and I think this is how it will stay.'' He said a half-dozen large plate-glass windows cost $7,000 to replace.
Most business losses were covered by insurance policies, shopkeepers said.
''What happened, well, it happened but people tend to forget and life goes on as usual, but they never really forget because it's always in the back of their minds,'' said Wilmoth Brooks, manager of the Carvel Ice Cream store on Teaneck Road. ''We were hit and we were boarded up but remained open, and for a couple of weeks it was the talk of nearly everyone who came in here.
''But once the glass was replaced and things looked like normal, the subject changed to other things.'' said Mr. Brooks, who lives in the Bronx.
The store, he added, was broken into twice more within a week after the incident, with damage estimated at $8,000.
Perhaps hardest hit that night was Jeanette Barhydt's Teaneck Road shop, the Film Lab Outlet. In addition to the shattering of windows, there was theft of film stock, video camcorders and rental films and extensive damage of film-processing equipment.
''I lost about $35,000, and that's not including losses of having to be closed for five days,'' said Mrs. Barhydt, who lives in Dumont.
 
Effects of Economy Cited
For some five weeks after the clash, business dropped off dramatically at many stores. Some attribute this to economic problems unrelated to the incident, but others say that lingering memories have had their effect.
''My business is down 25 percent, but I think that such a thing can be said for everyone anywhere because of the economy,'' said Mr. Callas, who says his evening trade particularly still suffers.
One Teaneck Road store manager, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said business had dropped off so much that she might be forced to close. ''Most of my regulars are shopping elsewhere because they're afraid of what happened and that it may happen again,'' she said. ''People who don't know Teaneck think of the Teaneck they saw on the evening news, and they don't want to see anything else. We've got the label, and the label is not easily discarded.''
On the other hand, Mr. Callas, who invested some $200,000 to expand his business a year and a half ago, talks of the help that local people offered.
''After my windows were busted in,'' he said, ''I started getting phone calls from my regular customers that night, asking me if they could come down to help, whether to clean up or just guard the store. People care, and if we all work together to see things through, Teaneck will come through this just fine.''

PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 18, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 202 words

HEADLINE: Recycling Measure: A Pleasant Surprise

 BODY:
I recently returned to New Jersey after an absence of about 10 years. It won't come as a surprise to anyone that I was met with utter amazement every time I told people where I was going, and that I was doing it by choice. ''But why New Jersey? It is so dirty,'' was the general message.
I was proud of our state when I arrived and learned that there was a mandatory recycling measure, and further delighted when I learned from ''Recycling: New Report, New Debate'' (July 15) that participation is much higher than expected.
Senator William Gormley, however, has missed the point of the issue when he expressed doubts about recycling because of the cost. Sure, we should find the most economical way to recycle. Go ahead and put a surcharge on the sale of tires. The point is that recycling and other methods of safe waste disposal are vital to the future of the state.
Let New Jersey pursue recycling and research on other methods of safe waste disposal regardless of the cost. New Jersey has the opportunity to set an example as being the state most committed to cleaning up our environment and redeem our reputation as being filthy in the eyes of the country.
 
ANNE I. FAIRWEATHER
 Ridgefield

PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 12, Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1379 words

HEADLINE: Reappraising the Appraisal Industry

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
''THE party is over,'' said Eugene Albert, a real estate appraiser. ''The binging of the 1980's is finished.'' Mr. Albert was discussing the excesses that characterized the 1980's real estate market and led to a recent law requiring state certification of real estate appraisers.
Mr. Albert, who has been an appraiser for 40 years, heads the Albert & Sterling Appraisal Company, with offices in Tarrytown and Manhattan.
''Many of the bad loans made by the banks in the S.&L. disaster were sanctioned by unscrupulous or untrained appraisers,'' he said. ''Even some bank lending officers here in the county, in their frenzy to make loans, would call my office and say, 'I want an X dollar value of this property, can you give it to me?' Our firm lost business because we wouldn't cooperate, but there were appraisers that did. And that's why state certification is important. It will prevent shoddy appraisal practices.'' 
 
Support From Savings Banks
The New York League of Savings Institutions, a trade group based in Scarsdale and representing 63 savings and loan associations and 20 savings banks statewide, also supports the law. Speaking for the league, its president, Paul A. Schosberg, said that legislation was necessary to promote accuracy and integrity in real estate appraisals and ''to protect lenders and borrowers from inept or fraudulent appraisal practices.''
Mr. Schosberg noted that the Financial Institutions Reform and Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989 required states to set up systems for licensing and certifying real estate appraisers. ''New York's real estate industry is such a vital part of our economy that we should be in the vanguard of reform to insure its integrity,'' he added.
The state certification program,signed into law in May, was a response to the mandate by the Federal Government, Mr. Albert said.
''In essence the Fed said to the states, 'Either you have certification programs signed into law by July 1, or we will do it for you,' and that threat encouraged 39 states to pass legislation.''
But many New York appraisers, Mr. Albert pointed out, wanted stricter rules, higher licensing fees and higher exam fees than the bill provided. Licensing fees are now $200 and exam fees are $50.
''What happened,'' Mr. Albert said, ''was that real estate groups lobbied like mad to retain the right of their members to make appraisals'' even though uncertified.
Those who win certification, which is based on training, experience and the examination, are to be licensed by a new state appraisal board.
 
Appraisals Can Still Be Made
Mr. Albert said, however, that ''licensing will not put unlicensed real estate brokers out of the appraisal business.''
''As long as they don't call themselves certified licensed appraisers, real estate brokers can offer appraisals to clients as a way of drumming up business,'' he said. ''And there's still nothing in the new law to prevent them from making appraisals of houses right on the spot. So it's still a buyer-beware situation.
''But I suspect that in order to protect themselves, banks and trust department heads and lawyers will now only use the services of certified appraisers. And I think certified appraisers will still get business from reputable realtors who want accurate appraisals for buyers or sellers.''
P. Gilbert Mercurio, the executive vice president of the 3,900-member Westchester County Board of Realtors said the licensing law would ultimately help the consumer.
 
'They'll Demand More'
''People will quickly become aware of the high standards required for licensing, and they'll demand more from the appraisers they deal with,'' Mr. Mercurio said.
''Although I understand Mr. Alpert's reaction,'' Mr. Mercurio said, ''he's a respected appraiser, long active in Westchester, and I know he is disappointed that the bill doesn't have stricter licensing standards. But on the other hand, legislation did not automatically grandfather real estate agents or brokers who have been doing appraisals to become certified.
''And given the short time frame that the Legislature had to work in, and the urgency of this bill, quick action was understandable.''
Fredric Streb, president of the Westchester County Society of Real Estate Appraisers, a professional group, agreed with Mr. Mercurio.
 
'They'll Want Only the Certified'
''Once the public realizes that appraisers are now licensed, they'll want to deal only with those who are certified,'' said Mr. Streb, who is also a principal in John Streb & Son, a three-generation firm of realtors with offices in Dobbs Ferry, Tarrytown and Ardsley.
''We're an old-time real estate firm,'' Mr. Streb said, ''and if my son, who just joined the company, wants to make appraisals, I believe he'll have to take courses and study for the exam. That's how the field will be in the future.
''As for myself, I think I'm very well advised to take the exam, too. But I know, right now, a lot of realtors are saying that they're trying to get along without it as long as they can. But banks will demand certification, and eventually unlicensed appraisers will be phased out.''
The Westchester County Society of Real Estate Appraisers, Mr. Streb said, was formed more than 40 years ago as a way to upgrade the professionalism of appraisers.
''Back in 1947, when our organization was formed,'' he said, ''appraisers didn't have to have any formal training. There were very few guidelines for them. We established our own strict standards for those in the profession. Membership in the association was conferred only after a review of qualifications, education andexperience was made by a peer group. Our organization has been working for state licensing for years, and we're very pleased that it's finally happened.''
Licensed or unlicensed, local appraisers are in for hard times, those in the field predict.
 
60 to 70 Appraisals a Week
''We're making only 65 to 70 appraisals a week, which is about half the number of appraisals we handled during the 80's,'' Mr. Albert said. ''Activity in the real estate market in Westchester is almost at an all-time low. Sales are worse than they were in the 1975-1976 period and I think they're heading even lower.
Mr. Albert compared the 1980's to the Roaring Twenties, saying: ''Prices were sky-high, and the banks literally ran after customers, offering all kinds of credit. They were helped by appraisers and what happened was they ended up making lousy loans. The abuses weren't so widespread in New York, but in the Southern and Western states things were very bad.''
Mr. Albert, who is 65, entered Pace University Law School when he was 58.
''I went to law school for four years at night,'' he said, ''not because I wanted to practice law, but I believed a knowledge of the law would give me a clearer picture, when I was making appraisals, of every possible situation - such as in matrimonial disputes,when real estate inevitably comes up for grabs. And knowing the law has been useful in making Internal Revenue Service appraisals and in working with trust departments.''
 
Working Alone or in Big Offices
The trend today for appraisers, he said, is either to work by themselves, or to manage large offices. ''Those are the only two ways, if you want to make a living,'' he said, ''because appraisals require an awful lot of time-consuming, laborious detail work.''
A typical residential appraisal, he said, would be a house in Scarsdale his firm did recently. It ''took two days and the cost is comparatively modest, $275 to $300,'' he said. ''In our Westchester office we have 15 appraisers on staff and six in Manhattan and they are able to handle 10 to 12 jobs at a given time, which they do by gathering a lot of the essential data on several properties at once.''
Some of the procedures used to make an appraisal, Mr. Albert said, involved detailed property and neighborhood inspections that included surveying schools, recreational facilities and transportation availability.
''There are also trips to the town hall to compare prices of similar properties recently sold; title searches, and inspections of Federal flood-control maps,'' Mr. Albert said. ''It's a complex process. There's more involved than most people realize.''

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 19, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2438 words

HEADLINE: Fears That Haunt a Scrubbed America

BYLINE: By DAVID LEAVITT; David Leavitt is the author of two novels, ''The Lost Language of Cranes'' and ''Equal Affections.'' His second collection of stories, ''A Place I've Never Been,'' will be published next month by Viking.

 BODY:
Put yourself, for a moment, inside the mind of Jesse Helms. Imagine a scrubbed, manicured neighborhood, a pocket of decency in the heart of our sinful land. The music is by Wayne Newton, the paintings are by Norman Rockwell, and sex takes place only between married men and women in beds at night.
Then one day a church-reared boy or girl goes to a museum and sees a Robert Mapplethorpe photograph; or goes to a library and checks out a novel by Rita Mae Brown (neither action likely to be undertaken innocently). What does Jesse Helms think happens? Does the photograph or book emit something between a magic fragrance and a sales pitch, luring this high-minded but fallible child into the back alleyways of decadence and sin? The ''artist,'' in this story, is really nothing more than a street-corner beckoner, a wolf in smock and painters' pants, a wolf with a camera or a pen. What he or she creates, under the guise of art, is a ''promotion'' for sexual deviance, a tool for the ''recruitment'' of the young. 
While the scenario I've just described may sound paranoid, even ludicrous, its dissemination has become the primary weapon in the current attack on the National Endowment for the Arts, an attack that, in fact, has little to do with the arts at all, and everything to do with the extreme right wing's determination to terrorize an already ambivalent American population by manipulating its entrenched fears of anything foreign, unfamiliar or explicitly sexual. People can argue as long as they want about the definitions of obscenity and art; in doing so, they become hopelessly sidetracked, trapped in a struggle to resolve unanswerable questions that neatly distracts them from the real crisis at hand, the way a computer can be distracted indefinitely by being asked to calculate the value of pi.
From Robert Mapplethorpe to Holly Hughes, the message is ringing out loud and clear. Gay and lesbian artists who deal frankly with sexuality are being singled out and refused grant money they were awarded by peer panels, as part of a conscious attempt to censor, humiliate and discourage all artists whose work challenges the right wing's rigid notions of ''correct'' sexual behavior. The N.E.A. is simply another target in an effort to legislate sexual demeanor that also encompasses attacks on abortion rights and on laws that protect homosexuals from violence and discrimination.
Consider the language of the infamous clause this year's National Endowment recipients were forced to sign: It binds the artist to guarantee that he or she will not use the grant money for works that include ''depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts, and which, when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific merit.''
 
'Homoeroticism' In Bad Company
 Is it only because I'm gay that when I read that sentence, the word ''homoeroticism '' leaps out at me? Or is it because there is nowhere in the clause a reference to ''heteroeroticism,'' only to the portrayal of ''individuals engaged in sex acts,'' which is of course an entirely different matter? ''Sadomasochism'' and ''the sexual exploitation of children'' can of course be both heterosexual and homosexual, and in any case represent just the sort of vague, fear-mongering terminology the right wing adores. Totally nonsexual photographs of nude children, taken with their parents' approval, have been appropriated by the F.B.I. under the latter heading; who's to say that one of Il Bronzino's cupids - portrayed, in the 16th century, as eroticized, chubby little boys - would not be as well?
By situating the word ''homoeroticism'' next to a taboo extreme of sexual behavior few would be willing to argue in favor of, the authors of the clause make their position glaringly clear: while only selective or extreme heterosexual content is to be forbidden, all homosexual content is to be forbidden. Once again, the fear that children may be molested, abused or lured to ''deviant'' life styles is being exploited as a tool to strong-arm Americans into approving the Moral Majority's effort to control artistic expression.
Behind this language - though unspoken - is the right wing's perpetual insistence that gay men and lesbians try to ''recruit'' young people to homosexuality by disseminating art and writing that ''promotes'' the homosexual life style. Of course, to any gay person who, as a frightened and confused teenager, searched desperately for books or films or television shows that offered even a mention of homosexual experience to latch on to, the idea of gay ''recruitment'' is laughable. It is also profoundly insulting.
 
Artists as Outsiders
 Tennessee Williams, Michelangelo, W. H. Auden, Gertrude Stein -I hardly need to repeat history's long and illustrious list of gay and lesbian writers and artists. If a lot of gay people have felt the urge to produce art over time, it's probably only because our early-perceived status as outsiders in a largely heterosexual world forced us to call into question those assumptions about sexual identity that our straight brothers and sisters could simply take for granted.
Female in a world of men, Jewish in a world of gentiles, black in a world of whites: it's the same difference. It's rare to find an artist who, as a child, wasn't in some way treated as a member of some minority and therefore felt the need to refract the complications of his or her world through the prism of that ''different'' self; to offer untroubled people a troubling perspective; to reveal the strangeness of the ordinary and the ordinariness of the strange.
What distinguishes gay and lesbian artists is that their ''difference'' is located in the realm of sexuality; the assumptions they question are assumptions about sexuality; and therefore the work they create, in a culture that is both sex-phobic and homophobic, becomes particularly susceptible to the charge that it is ''obscene,'' or dangerous for young people. This last notion is especially distressing; while homoerotic art may have the power to awaken subconscious homosexual feelings in individuals who already harbor them, the suggestion that it can brainwash or corrupt chaste minds is almost medievally superstitious.
History offers some scary examples of what happens when a government tries to control a culture. Consider Hitler's now infamous 1937 ''Degenerate Art'' show, in which the works of such painters as Max Beckmann, Marc Chagall and Henri Matisse were jammed chaotically onto the walls of a Munich museum, along with hand-scribbled labels denouncing the artists and implying their links to ''unfit'' members of German society.
I attended a re-creation of that exhibit in Berlin last year; in the next room was another re-creation, of the ''Great Exhibition of German Art'' Hitler had set up as a contrast to the ''Degenerate Art'' show. Here gargantuan sculpted Aryan torsos thrust their muscled arms into the sky, while in paintings happy blond families frolicked on farms. Photographs from the opening of the exhibit show a rare smiling Hitler. A failed watercolorist, he apparently considered the show something of a high point in his career: what was the appropriation of political power in comparison, after all, to the appropriation of culture, not to mention the redemption of his ambition - thwarted by teachers who said he had no talent - to be a painter?
Now, five decades later, when history has redeemed the work of the ''degenerate artists,'' it is frightening to see Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs being appropriated by Cincinnati sheriffs and put on trial; or to see videotapes of the performance artist David Wojnarowicz being incorporated into videos used by right-wing pressure groups to demonstrate N.E.A.-sponsored decadence and obscenity; or to try to imagine the kind of ''art'' a Jesse Helms-run N.E.A. might choose to give its money to.
 
The Side Effects Of Cultural Control
 The National Endowment crisis, however - so far, at least - is not about banning art; it is about denying artists money. And what are the consequences of that going to be? Initially, at least, refusing grant money to these artists will probably result in a sudden wave of interest in their work. In England, the notorious Clause 28, which allows the Government to censor art that ''promotes'' homosexuality, prompted a surge of enthusiasm for gay literature, theater and film. Alan Hollinghurst's brilliant novel ''The Swimming Pool Library'' became a best seller, as did works by such gay American writers as Edmund White and Armistead Maupin; the BBC had a major hit with its four-hour television version of Jeannette Winterson's lesbian novel ''Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit.''
Here in America, meanwhile, where banning has always been a perverse form of publicity (consider Henry Miller), the brouhaha over the Mapplethorpe show in Cincinnati drew huge crowds to that show. And Karen Finley, the performance artist, is much better-known now than she was a month ago, though hardly for the reasons she might wish. Ms. Finley was the only heterosexual among the four performance artists whose grants were retracted.
Such a reaction, however, will probably be only temporary. Soon enough the really terrible side-effects of cultural control will start to manifest themselves. There may be a mass exodus of artists out of America to Europe, where state support of the arts is already much stronger, and where a booming economy has made it possible for governments to welcome foreign artists and writers as well.
Last year I spent five months in Barcelona as a guest of the Catalan Government. During my stay in Barcelona I could hardly keep count of the number of exhibitions (many of them Government-sponsored) of work by American artists and photographers, some quite avant-garde, not to mention the extraordinary publicity those exhibitions received. Jennie Livingston, a film maker who received money a few years ago from the National Endowment to work on ''Paris Is Burning,'' a documentary about the gay culture of Harlem, ended up finishing the film with the help not of the N.E.A., but the BBC. If Europe continues to pick up the slack, the attack on the N.E.A. could result in the depletion of yet another precious American resource: our artists.
The most devastating effect of a Helms-controlled National Endowment, however, is one we won't see until a few years from now, when the furor has died down: the effect on the young novelist who cannot quit his job in order to devote a year to finishing his first novel, and therefore doesn't finish it; or on the young painter who cannot afford supplies, and therefore doesn't paint; or on the young film maker who, fearful of the strictures imposed on her by an N.E.A. run by the Republican Senator from North Carolina, censors her own creative impulses to satisfy such an organization's dubious morality.
I had my N.E.A. grant in 1985, in another time, before the infamous Mapplethorpe exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, before the addition of that notorious clause, before people's grants started being withheld. That year a friend sent me a clipping from the editorial page of The Manchester (N.H.) Union Leader, a vehement attack on the National Endowment that questioned the Government's right to spend taxpayers' money to support artists or writers whose work those taxpayers might find offensive or obscene. To my surprise, it was me who was offered up as an example in the article; do the American people really want their hard-earned dollars going to an author of ''paeans to homosexual love,'' the newspaper asked.
I remember laughing uncomfortably at that phrase, joking that if anything, my stories were paeans to the lack of love - homosexual or heterosexual. Apparently for The Union Leader, any piece of fiction with a gay character in it was necessarily a ''paean.'' Thus, I dismissed the editorial as right-wing nonsense, and went on to finish a novel the financing of which, in the current atmosphere, would certainly have been questioned, and most probably retracted.
 
Art Slowed But Not Stopped
 These days I think a lot about that editorial, and when I do, I wince at my own failure to recognize what it foreboded. Perhaps those of us who depended on the National Endowment, regularly or sporadically, got too comfortable, too complacent, cozying up as we did to a Government that handed out the money and never asked questions. In a chastening editorial in Outweek magazine, the novelist Sarah Schulman has suggested that the current crisis simply puts those few white, upper-middle-class gay and lesbian artists to whom the N.E.A. previously gave its seal of approval in the same position as the vast majority of artists who because of their race or class were never able to benefit from the N.E.A. reward system in the first place.
If the example of Hitler's ''degenerate art'' show teaches us anything, it is that while art can be slowed, it cannot be stopped. But the attack on the National Endowment is not simply about art, just as the ''degenerate art'' show was not simply about art; it is about trying to eradicate or at least suppress anything in American culture that challenges a fundamentalist Christian vision of family happiness that in its portrayal seems eerily similar to Hitler's artists' vision of Aryan farm life. Traditionally the head of state gives the opening address at the annual International AIDS Conference, no matter what country that conference takes place in; George Bush's decision this year to attend a Jesse Helms fund-raiser instead cannot be considered a coincidence.
Fear of change, fear of difference, fear of cultural erosion: all these fears of the extreme right mask, in fact, a deeper fear, a fear of the underground sexual desires every individual harbors (look at Jimmy Swaggart!) and for which homosexuals have traditionally been made into a catch-all symbol.
To say that gay men and lesbians are everywhere is only to say that sexuality is everywhere, that there are no rules other than the ones that we impose. Even in houses where Jesse Helms's picture hangs over the fireplace there are children who will grow up to be gay or lesbian, and some of them may become our greatest artists and writers. The influences that would supposedly seep into and corrupt the healthy American family landscape are in fact an integral part of that landscape already. What the N.E.A.'s opponents really seem to be fighting is the difference in themselves.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 20, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1418 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
FOREIGNERS TRAPPED TILL U.S. LEAVES REGION, IRAQI WARNS; SAYS KUWAIT IS 'ARAB ISSUE'

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 19

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said tonight that he would free foreigners being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait in exchange for a complete military and political pullout by the United States from the Persian Gulf region.
The Iraqi proposal came as diplomats said that some Western citizens were being moved to potential military targets to serve as human shields.
Leaving no doubt that the foreigners would be shields against bombing, Mr. Hussein said ''their presence, along with Iraqi families, at vital targets may prevent military aggression.''
 
Demands a Written U.S. Pledge
The trapped foreigners, more than 10,000, including about 3,000 Americans, could leave, Mr. Hussein said in a message broadcast over Baghdad television, if President Bush gave an unequivocal, written pledge to pull military forces out of the gulf, lifted the economic blockade imposed after the takeover of Kuwait and promised not to attack.
The Iraqi leader said that Mr. Bush's promise should be backed by a United Nations Security Council guarantee that the American forces would withdraw from Saudi Arabia and the gulf on a fixed timetable, as fast as they had been deployed. 
''Averting death and starvation resulting from American policy against Iraq, by preventing some citizens from traveling, is a gain for humanity as a whole,'' Mr. Hussein said in an effort to justify his refusal to let the foreigners leave. Discounted by U.S. He offered no response to international calls for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, terming it an ''Arab issue.''
Aboard the plane carrying Mr. Bush from his vacation home in Maine to Washington, the President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, dismissed the Hussein statement.
''This one doesn't have much relationship to our objective,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''It contains no new relevant proposals and makes no reference to the United Nations and Arab League calls for them to leave Kuwait.''
In Middle East waters, American warships continued to shadow two Iraqi oil tankers while the Administration tried to gain United Nations approval for military action to enforce the international embargo.
On Saturday night, the United Nations Security Council demanded that Iraq free all detained foreigners and gave an implicit warning of military action if they were not freed.
The White House had also been terse on Saturday in response to the Iraqi threat to use hostages as human shields and limit their food. The Iraqi statements were said to be ''totally unacceptable.''
Both today and on Saturday, Mr. Bush declined to respond personally to Mr. Hussein.
In a ''goodwill gesture'' announced moments after the Iraqi leader's statement, Baghdad said that some Westerners from five countries that had not sent troops to join the forces in the gulf - Austria, Finland, Portugal, Sweden and Switzerland - would be allowed to leave.
It was not immediately clear how many of the estimated 570 citizens of the five countries would be freed.
President Hussein made no mention of withdrawing Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait, as has been demanded by Mr. Bush and the United Nations Security Council.
''Arabs would treat this as an Arab issue,'' Mr. Hussein said.
This was not an offer to pull out, particularly since he cited territory disputed in the Western Sahara between Morocco and Polisario guerrillas, and Syria's occupation of much of Lebanon, ''and other issues.'' #9,000 Ordered to Hotels What the Iraqi President described as a call for ''an in-depth dialogue'' came on a day that began with the Iraqi authorities in Kuwait ordering the 9,000 or so Western nationals there to report to three luxury hotels.
''Anyone who does not comply with this call,'' the announcement said, ''they and their governments bear full responsibility for any evil consequences resulting from acts against them by hostile powers.''
Iraqi officials, in a series of announcements on Saturday, said the Western, Japanese and Australian nationals forbidden to leave Iraq and Kuwait - estimated to total nearly 13,000 - would be interned at strategic military and industrial targets in the hope of warding off bombing attacks.
CBS News reported from Baghdad tonight that 35 Americans had taken refuge in American diplomatic quarters there after ''it became obvious that Iraqi authorities intended to round them up and send them out as hostages and human shields at possible U.S. bombing sites.''
The television report quoted an an American Embassy official as saying: ''We're not going to allow our people to be simply herded up like sheep and made to go places against their will without trying to help.''
Referring to the report, the State Department said, ''We can't confirm it and, therefore, we are not commenting.''
 
French, Too, Are Seized
The Iraqi ambassador to France told British television: ''I know for sure that some of your foreign nationals have already been distributed at the strategic sites and industrial sites in Iraq.''
The British Foreign office said that it had been informed by the Iraqi authorities that people who reported to the hotels in Kuwait would be ''transferred to key installations.''
''Those who do not report to the hotels will be rounded up and taken direct to the sites,'' the Foreign Office said the Iraqi officials had told them. This information was in a bulletin read over the BBC's hourly foreign news shortwave broadcasts.
The Foreign Office said that about 40 Britons had been moved out of their hotels in Kuwait to ''unknown destinations.''
British officials added they had reports that British citizens were being held at checkpoints in Kuwait City and that some foreigners had already been moved to strategic sites.
''In addition to British citizens, French, West Germans and Americans have been affected,'' the Foreign Office said.
The French Foreign Ministry protested to Iraq during the day that 26 French citizens had been taken from hotels in Baghdad and that one had been seized in Kuwait. French Navy ships in the gulf were given orders today to use force to carry out the United Nations economic embargo against Iraq.
 
'Keep a Low Profile'
The British Foreign Office told its nationals in Kuwait to stay indoors and ''keep a low profile.''
''We advise any whom the Iraqi authorities attempt to detain or move forcibly not to offer any resistance,'' the Foreign Office added.
In Washington, a State Department spokesman said: ''We've told the Iraqis in the past that we would not order our citizens to comply with such an order. We wouldn't order them around and we don't want the Iraqis to order them around either.
The Iraqi leader warned in his televised message, billed as an address to the families of the trapped foreigners, that ''many of our children and your children will be orphaned if war breaks out and many of our women and your women will become widows. Many of our men and your men will die.''
The later announcement of the ''good-will'' release of the limited number of foreigners, made by the Speaker of Parliament, Saadi Mahdi Saleh, appeared to suggest an effort to weaken the international economic embargo being imposed on Iraq and swap hostages for goods.
More foreigners might be released, Mr. Saleh said, if their countries did not impose ''sanctions on the import of food, medicine and other goods to Iraq.''
The vast majority of foreign workers in Kuwait and Iraq are Arabs - more than a million Egyptians alone - and other third-world nationals, particularly from the Indian subcontinent and the Philippines.
There has been no real attempt to hold these workers - indeed one announcement specifically exempted ''Egyptian brothers'' - and they have been streaming across the Saudi and Jordanian borders, about 100,000 so far, as tired, frightened, sweaty refugees.
More than 13,000 jammed the Jordanian border crossing today. Most had worked at menial jobs, struggling to build a stake for the future and now had lost everything.
The order in Kuwait this morning to report to the Hyatt Regency, Le Meridien and International Hotels specified ''Western foreigners and Australians.'' The largest groups in Kuwait, according to the latest estimates, were roughly 4,000 from Britain, 2,500 Americans, 552 Canadians, followed by substantial numbers of West Germans, French, Italians, Greeks, Swedes, Spaniards and a smattering of nearly all European nations.
Japanese citizens, who reportedly number about 278 in Kuwait and 230 in Iraq have been told they cannot leave.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 20, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
How Vulnerable Is Iraq?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Short of food and dependent on imports for everything from auto parts to chicken parts, Iraq's economy is widely assumed to be exceptionally vulnerable to a trade embargo. If the United States and its allies are prepared to stand up to Baghdad's threats over the weekend to cut off food to foreigners in Iraq - an indication that the embargo is indeed causing worry - the effects of the sanctions are likely to take hold quickly.
But experts are wary of predicting quick results from the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations, even if they can be meticulously enforced.
For while Iraq is a warrior state that has grown accustomed to living well on foreign loans and the proceeds of oil exports, its capacity to adapt to shortages depends as much on psychological factors as on nuts-and-bolts economics. 
 
A Well-Endowed Economy
Few economies are so naturally well endowed as Iraq's. Along with the second-largest oil reserves in the Middle East, after Saudi Arabia's, Iraq is blessed with adequate water and a climate that can sustain a substantial base of agriculture. Its population of 18 million is large enough to provide a market for domestically made industrial goods - but not so large as to crowd the available land.
Since 1970, the Baath Party rulers have heavily invested in roads, irrigation canals and telecommunications. Foreign contractors, mostly Soviet and European, have built plants to make steel, chemicals, cement, electrical equipment, tractors, plastics, textiles, phosphate-based fertilizers, even cigarettes.
The WEFA Group, an economic consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., says all this effort has left Iraq with an output of about $2,500 a person, not much below that of South Korea or Portugal. But the raw numbers mask Iraq's failure to create a diversified, economy capable of meeting the needs of domestic consumers or competing with industrial exports in foreign markets.
An obvious reason for Iraq's lagging economic development is President Saddam Hussein's enormous, well-equipped army, which has first claim on resources. Dorothea el-Mallakh, director of the International Research Center on Energy and Economic Development at the University of Colorado, says the army employs roughly one able-bodied man in four. Perhaps more important, it is a route of rapid social mobility and thus attracts the best and brightest.
 
Just One Export Crop
Heavy industry, until 1988 entirely state owned, grew artificially in a hothouse of direct subsidies and low-cost access to imported parts and materials. Agriculture, buffeted by Government policies that have alternately encouraged and discouraged private farming, has only recently shown signs of vitality.
It should not be surprising, then, that more than 90 percent of Iraq's export revenues and almost half of its national income derive from oil.
Dates are the only crop with a surplus that can be exported. The proclaimed goal of self-sufficiency has remained far out of reach, because Iraqi agriculture is not especially productive, in part because Government food subsidies that were used to buy the support of the urban majority have encouraged rapid growth of consumption.
The United States Agriculture Department calculates that Iraq must import about 60 percent of its food in good harvest years, about 70 percent in bad.
 
Chronic Dependence on Imports
Shipments of food, roughly one-quarter of all imports, cost Iraq $2 billion to $3 billion a year. Almost everything manufactured, from tires to tank shells, comes from abroad, too. Iraq even imports services and has brought in more than a million foreign workers, mostly Egyptians, Palestinians and Pakistanis, who send home about $1 billion a year.
Chronic dependence on imports, a pattern established during the eight-year war of attrition with Iran, which ended with a cease-fire in 1988, has led some outsiders to conclude that a trade embargo could quickly force President Hussein to his knees. Sharif Ghalib, director of Middle East affairs at the Institute for International Finance in Washington, said recent developments had only increased this perception of vulnerability.
A poor grain harvest led Iraq to dip into its grain reserves last year. The reserves were not replenished with imports - most likely, Mr. Ghalib suggests, because Iraq was trying to trim its outlays of foreign currencies.
 
Low Grain Stockpiles
That moderation reflected both the sagging price of oil and a postwar reduction in aid from the Persian Gulf oil states - including Kuwait. As a result, according to Agriculture Department estimates, Iraq had only a two-month supply of wheat, a three-month supply of rice and a two-week supply of corn when it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Kiren Chaudhry, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley, said she believed a fiscal crisis was a primary motive for President Hussein's blunt demands for billions of dollars in protection money from Persian Gulf oil kingdoms, and for the subsequent invasion of Kuwait.
An economic deregulation program, begun late in 1988, tried to stimulate growth and tame the Iraqis' appetite for imports. But the initial effect was to raise food prices, which accelerated the existing inflation rate of 40 percent and sharply reduced urban consumption.
 
Lower Living Standards
Food price controls were subsequently reimposed, and the prices of consumer goods sold by state enterprises were rolled back. But without protection money from gulf countries to supplement oil revenues, living standards remain far below the level that prevailed at the peak of the fighting with Iran.
Now, with an almost empty larder, an overdrawn bank account (the $3 billion to $4 billion Iraq brought back from Kuwait last week will not make much difference for a Government that owes foreign creditors some $70 billion) and a population reeling from austerity, President Hussein might be thought easy prey to the embargo.
But few experts are ready to predict his speedy fall. Paul Jureidini, a vice president of Abbott Associates, a consulting firm in Washington, said Iraq has the internal resources to sustain a living standard far above the level endured for years by, say, the Soviet people during World War II. It is self-sufficient in energy, of course, and transportation and electricity production are thus secure until a lack of spare parts begins to bite.
 
Deflecting Frustration
In the short run, the Hussein regime's staying power turns on its well-oiled machinery for holding the military in line, and ultimately on the public's acceptance of hardship. Ms. Chaudhry, the political scientist, said President Hussein had done well at deflecting frustration over his failure to deliver a promised ''peace dividend'' after the war with Iran ended.
He was successful, she noted, in blaming profiteering merchants for inflated food prices. And she said she expected he would be equally successful in blaming the United States for the current shortages.
A year or two or five from now, the United Nations embargo would surely drive Iraq to a change in policy or a shift in leadership. By the same token, a long siege would surely weaken the resolve of the shaky international coalition trying to defang President Hussein.
The embargo is thus a short-term contest, one in which the United States and its allies appear to hold the best cards, but the winner is far from clear.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: WELFARE ON RISE, REFLECTING SLUMP IN ECONOMY OF U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
In a further sign of weakness in the nation's economy, the number of people receiving food stamps and welfare benefits has jumped sharply this year. At least 44 states have reported increases in enrollment, some ranging up to 50 percent.
''Participation in the food stamp program has grown dramatically in the past 12 months,'' mirroring increases in the welfare caseload, said a report just submitted to Congress by the Agriculture Department, which administers the food stamp program.
Though some factors unrelated to the economy are cited as contributing to the increases, the food stamp rolls are considered a barometer of the nation's economic climate. They often signal economic difficulty in advance of the jobless rate because employed workers may qualify for food stamps when they experience a reduction in wages or working hours. 
The number of people on the food stamp rolls rose by 1.3 million from May 1989 to May 1990, when it topped 20 million for the first time since 1985. The Agriculture Department report said the increase in food stamp recipients was ''strongly correlated'' with growth of the main Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
 
Burden on Governments
The increase in applications is costing the states and the Federal Government billions of dollars. The Federal Government pays more than half the cost of the A.F.D.C. program and most of the cost of the food stamps. State governments also contribute to the programs and adminster them under Federal rules.
New Hampshire reports a 38 percent increase in welfare recipients and a 54 percent increase in food stamp recipients from June 1989 to June 1990. Thomas E. Pryor, the state official who supervises both programs, said in an interview that the increase resulted mainly from a slowdown in the New Hampshire economy, including defense-related industries. ''In many cases,'' he said, ''people have gone from working full time to working part time and have experienced a big decrease in income.''
In the last 12 months, food stamp rolls have increased 16 percent in Texas, 19 percent in Florida, 26 percent in Nevada, 12 percent each in Georgia and Massachusetts, 7 percent each in New York State and California and 21 percent in Connecticut.
Welfare rolls are up 15 percent in Texas, 14 percent in Florida, 15 percent in Nevada, 12 percent in Georgia, 9 percent in Massachusetts, 10 percent in California and 16 percent in Connecticut, state officials said.
''It's hard for people to believe these numbers,'' said Aldona Vaitkus of the State Department of Economic Security in Arizona, where the number of welfare recipients has increased 19 percent in the last year and the number of food stamp recipients is up 22 percent.
 
Faster Than Expected
The food stamp rolls have grown much faster than the Bush Administration expected. Assuming there would be 18.1 million people on the rolls, President Bush originally requested $13.3 billion for food stamps in the current fiscal year. Congress appropriated $14.8 billion. That proved inadequate, and Congress provided $1.2 billion extra in May.
The House has passed an appropriation bill that would provide $18.1 billion for food stamps in the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. The measure is pending in the Senate. Troubled by such increases, Congress directed the Agriculture Department to investigate the causes.
The department report said that ''44 states and the District of Columbia experienced a growth in participation'' in the food stamp program over the last year, while the nation's unemployment rate was relatively stable. But it said, ''Many states are showing signs of economic slowdown that are not reflected in national economic indicators.''
Michigan officials have the most unusual explanation for an increase in welfare caseload: a state ban on Medicaid-financed abortions. F. Charles Peller, a spokesman for the state's Department of Social Services, said the ban had apparently contributed to an increase in births to women with low incomes.
''About a year after the abortion ban took effect in December 1988, we saw a startling increase in the number of A.F.D.C. recipients, which is up 40,000 in the last six months, to a total of 670,000,'' he said.
 
New York Trend Reversed
New York reported a decrease in welfare recipients each year from 1985 to 1989, partly because of a strong economy and partly because of the state's success in preparing welfare mothers for jobs in private industry. But the state reported an increase of slightly more than 1 percent from June 1989 to June of this year, and state officials say the economic slowdown was a factor.
Federal and state officials list several other factors as contributing to the increase in welfare and food stamp rolls. Congress has made numerous incremental expansions of Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for low-income families. As a result, more women come into contact with the welfare system. When pregnant women and new mothers apply for Medicaid, state and local government employees, using computers, routinely check to see if they are eligible for other benefits like food stamps and welfare.
Some states, like Texas, are aggressively trying to make social welfare benefits and services more accessible, with simplified application forms and ''one-stop shopping'' for various services at a single site. Bush Administration officials have enthusiastically promoted this idea.
Jennifer A. Lange, chief of the Florida welfare program, said, ''We are finding people who might not otherwise have applied for A.F.D.C., but who are eligible for it.'' Claudia Langguth, Deputy Commissioner of Human Services in Texas, said her state had reduced its food stamp application form to 2 pages, from 18.
 
Effect of Aliens Discounted
Federal officials say some of the increase in food stamp rolls may be linked to the immigration law under which thousands of illegal aliens have gained legal status since 1987. Immigrant farm workers who gain legal status are allowed to receive food stamps.
But Mrs. Langguth of Texas said, ''We cannot find any impact because of the legalization of aliens.'' She said many aliens were reluctant to apply for welfare and food stamps, even after gaining legal status, because they tended to distrust the government.
Children born to illegal aliens in this country are United States citizens, fully eligible for public assistance. In Florida, Ms. Lange said, ''social workers tell us they are seeing an increase in the number of pregnant women who come to this country from Central America'' so their children will be born here.
Catherine A. Bertini, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Food and Consumer Services, said fraud was not a factor in the recent growth of food stamp rolls. ''The rolls are not up because of ineligible people getting benefits,'' she said in an interview.
The Agriculture Department report said, ''It is possible that social attitudes toward persons receiving government assistance have changed, and that people have become more willing to apply for food stamps.''
Mrs. Langguth endorsed that view. ''For the working poor,'' she said, ''there is definitely less of a stigma attached to use of food stamps, partly because so many people here had no other options when the economy took a downturn in the mid-1980's.''

HEADLINE: New York Real-Estate Slide Hits Biggest Developers

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Some of New York's wealthiest and best-known developers, squeezed by the region's economic retrenchment and a dearth of young, high-salaried tenants, have missed monthly mortgage payments on large apartment complexes and, in at least one case, defaulted on a $100 million mortgage.
The difficulties encountered by some of the region's most prominent master builders - including the LeFrak and Milstein families - have startled many of their colleagues and others who follow the industry.
''You have a lot of major builders who are in trouble,'' said Richard L. Higgins, Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. ''The ripple effect to the development community, the banking community, is not healthy to the economy in general. New York City is real estate. When real estate is in bad shape, that has a tremendous effect on the whole metropolitan area.'' 
 
Widespread Distress in Industry
The financial setbacks are not likely to pose a threat to existing tenants, nor do they suggest that any of the city's established real-estate empires is about to collapse. But the problems at a number of large apartment complexes indicate that the economic slump has begun to strain even the most experienced and resourceful developers.
Real-estate executives and government regulators said the difficulties of such prominent developers reflected widespread distress in the industry, and were likely to contribute to the pace of the general economic decline.
Milstein Properties - a family-owned business that is among the city's largest developers, with more than 10,000 apartments as well as a hotel and a bank - defaulted last month on its mortgage for the Normandie Court, a large rental complex with four towers occupying a full block bounded by East 95th and 96th Streets, and Second and Third Avenues.
The $100 million mortgage was turned over on Aug. 9 to its insurer, the Federal Housing Administration, which has begun negotiations with the owners over reorganizing the debt.
The huge Newport complex in Jersey City, owned by a consortium headed by Samuel J. LeFrak, who is also among New York's largest housing developers, has experienced financial difficulties with its apartment houses, said Alfred A. DelliBovi, Under Secretary of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Newport has not defaulted on its $150 million mortgage, but it is being monitored by the Federal Housing Administration, which insured the mortgage, Mr. DelliBovi said.
 
Other Rental Buildings Watched
''If the wealthiest people in the industry, the Milsteins and the LeFraks, can't make these work, with all their expertise and construction abilities, I despair for rental housing,'' said Arthur William Zeckendorf, vice president of the Zeckendorf Company.
Two other new rental apartment buildings in Manhattan are also being watched by Federal officials because of concern over their financial viability, Mr. DelliBovi said: the Windsor Court, two high-rise towers that occupy the block bounded by East 31st and 32d Streets, and Third and Lexington Avenues, and the Ritz Plaza, a high-rise at 235 West 48th Street. Both carry Federal mortgage insurance.
The Milsteins also own Windsor Court. They missed mortgage payments twice this spring, but are now up to date on their obligations, said James M. Yasser, senior vice president of Milstein Properties. Jason D. Carter is the owner of the Ritz Plaza.
The disclosure of financial setbacks at those projects follows widespread publicity over the revising of Donald J. Trump's debt, and an acknowledgement by Glick Development Affiliates, another prominent real-estate firm, that it had not paid monthly mortgage payments since last November on a new high-rise condominium apartment tower, the Horizon, at 415 East 37th Street.
 
Fewer Young High Spenders
The owners revealed the missed payments in financial statements filed in June with the State Attorney General's office, which oversees cooperatives and condominiums. Jeffrey Glick said on Thursday that the Chase Manhattan Bank had agreed to reorganize the building's financing.
''There is great concern,'' said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, the trade group. ''I would say that everybody has got some trouble, that's how widespread it is. They have trouble either because apartments are not selling or because rental space is not renting.''
Complexes like Normandie Court and Newport, high-rent apartments not in the most fashionable neighborhoods, have been particularly vulnerable, real-estate executives said, because they depend primarily on young, affluent and reasonably adventurous New Yorkers. The retrenchment on Wall Street has led to fewer young executives able to pay $2,500 a month for a two-bedroom apartment.
Whether owners maintain control of troubled buildings will depend largely on the patience of those holding the mortgages, from banks and insurance companies to the Federal Government, and on whether they see any financial opportunities in foreclosing on the properties and trying to sell them in a slumping market.
Many lenders appear willing to be flexible, said Mr. Higgins, the state housing commissioner. ''I don't know a lot of mortgagors who want to manage and operate real estate, especially in this market,'' he said.
Some real-estate professionals say that while certain segments of New York's market are clearly suffering -particularly cooperative or condominium sales and the conversions of existing rental housing to co-ops - the luxury rental housing market has not entirely lost its vitality.
''Demand has remained fairly strong, because people have stopped buying apartments,'' said Andrew J. Singer, a mortgage broker. It is cheaper to rent a luxury apartment than to buy one, Mr. Singer said, and it requires no down payment.
 
Normandie Court's Problems
Federal officials have begun discussing possibly reorganizing the debt at Normandie Court. The mortgage on which Milstein Properties defaulted last month was financed by the State Housing Finance Agency. It covers three of the four 34-story towers, and 1,100 of the complex's 1,500 apartments.
The 11 percent mortgage was negotiated in 1984, when rates were higher than they were in later years, said Mr. Yasser, the Milstein executive. He said the relatively costly financing was one reason for the problems at the Normandie Court, which he said had had operating losses totaling $20 million in the four years since it opened.
The fourth building, also financed through the state, has a separate, variable-rate mortgage and as a result has not been running a deficit, he said.
Twenty percent of the apartments at Normandie Court are set aside for moderate- and middle-income New Yorkers, with the rest renting at market rates. That was one reason it qualified for the below-market state financing. Mr. Yasser said Normandie Court, like other apartment buildings in the program, which is called 80-20, was at a particular disadvantage in the highly competitive luxury rental market because of the lower rental income.
 
Rents Are Flat or Falling
He said the complex also had problems common to high-end rental housing. Turnover is way up, demand has dropped and thus rents are flat or falling. Normandie Court is at 97 percent occupancy, Mr. Yasser said; yet it is losing money because rents are lower than were projected when the project was underwritten and the mortgage interest rate is high.
Mr. DelliBovi, the Federal housing department Under Secretary, made it clear that he hoped the negotiations with the Milsteins to reorganize the complex's financing would succeed, in part because it is economically integrated, with a proportion of moderate- and middle-income tenants.
The LeFraks' 1,500 rental apartments in four towers at Newport, the huge complex of apartments, office buildings and stores in Jersey City, have a similar proportion of moderate- and middle-income tenants. Both Mr. LeFrak and his son, Richard, are out of the country, said officials of their organization, who declined to comment on the financial difficulties at Newport.
Neither the LeFraks nor the owners of the two other New York apartment complexes that are being monitored by the Federal housing agency have defaulted on their mortgages, but many real-estate officials said they would not rule out the possibility.
''We're watching them because we have the insurance,'' Mr. DelliBovi said. ''There are problems with all four of them related to the real-estate market in New York. You can trace the problems of each of these buildings back to that day in October 1987 when Wall Street crashed.''
