LENGTH: 1303 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Oil, Saddam Hussein and the Re-emergence of America as the Superpower

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The obituaries were a bit premature.
There is still one superpower in the world, and it is the United States. More than any other country in the world, its interests, its exposure and its reach are global, as the events of the last two weeks have demonstrated so vividly.
Washington is not the backwater that it seemed to some when the action was all in the streets of Prague or at the Berlin wall.
But as the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, has reveled in reminding everyone this summer weekend, the costs of maintaining such status can be enormous, and not only in terms of national treasure. The lives of thousands of civilian hostages have been put at risk in the Middle East, to say nothing of those of tens of thousands of soldiers, sailors and airmen. Even then, it is not clear that United States arms and diplomacy will achieve President Bush's goals. 
There are inescapable limits on what even superpowers can accomplish, and if they overreach, or fail, doubt and irresolution often follow.
 
U.S. Dependence on Imported Oil
Other harsh realities are easy to forget in the heat of the moment. The dispatch of American military power to the Middle East was made more urgent because the United States has allowed itself to become heavily dependent on foreign oil. The show of force was useful, furthermore, precisely because some people had begun to doubt American will in the post-cold war era.
Still, even in a hot, humid month when much of Washington is on vacation, there is a rush of excitement in the air here. In news bureaus and Pentagon offices, dining rooms and lobbyists' hangouts, the fever is back - the heavy speculation, the avid gossip, the gung-ho, here's-where-it's-happening spirit, that marks the city when it grapples with great events.
''These days, conversations are huddled,'' said Stan Bromley, the manager of the Four Seasons Hotel, where King Hussein of Jordan stayed. ''People are leaning closer together. It's serious business.''
Only a month ago, after the summit conferences in London and in Houston, after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany concluded a deal that the White House knew nothing of, it seemed clear that some of the power the United States has wielded in the postwar era was slipping away. The soon-to-be-united Germany and a stunningly wealthy Japan went their own ways on important questions, with Mr. Bush, making a virtue of a necessity, graciously wishing them well.
In a world suddenly escaped from the shadow of nuclear confrontation between East and West, economic strength was king, diplomats and politicians said, and that made it harder for the United States, militarily strong but struggling with fiscal problems, to exercise political leadership.
 
No One, Universal Power
The crisis in the Persian Gulf has demonstrated that all of that is valid, but only to a limited extent, only in some places on some issues.
''It is most certainly true,'' said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, a leading spokesman for his party on foreign policy issues, ''that there has been a remarkable diffusion of power in the world. No one is the unchallenged boss everywhere, on everything, and no one is likely to hold that position, as we did after the war, very soon again.
''But when action is needed against an aggressor, only the United States has the wherewithal to respond.''
So it is the United States, not Germany or Japan, that has drawn the line in the sand against an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia, with its huge oil reserves that Germany and Japan need more, in fact, than the United States does.
''The realities are back in the forefront,'' a senior European diplomat said. ''The realities are American power and leadership. As the world is now constructed, there is often absolutely no substitute for them.''
Economic power counts for more where no one is challenging the status quo, where the political order is legitimate and longstanding, as in much of Europe and, to a slightly lesser degree, in East Asia. That is decidedly not the case in the Middle East.
 
Where U.S. Is Still Central
''There are a lot of different chessboards now,'' said Michael Mandelbaum of the Council on Foreign Relations and Johns Hopkins University. ''On some of them, like aid to the Soviet Union and Central Europe, we aren't the main player. But on this one, in the struggle for Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, we're supremely important.''
Because oil is the indispensable element for modern industrial civilization, at least for the immediate future, and because 40 percent of it is in the Persian Gulf region, the instability there - as opposed, for example, to the instability in Africa - is deemed worthy of military intervention, as a last resort, by decision-makers in dozens of world capitals.
But in Europe, where each country has different geopolitical, economic and constitutional concerns, institutions are slow to decide, and some, like NATO, are designed to act effectively in only one set of circumstances - an attack within Europe - and not in others.
This time, Germany is hamstrung, constrained by law but even more by the past. Even a suggestion by Mr. Kohl last week that he might send minesweepers to the Persian Gulf produced a political uproar, with a clash between the Chancellor and his Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and a debate as to whether German troops should ever engage in armed conflicts again, even as peacekeepers.
Japan was so perplexed in the early days of the crisis that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had to cancel a long-planned trip to the region because he did not know what to say if asked how Japan proposed to help. Now, after tremendous soul-searching, he is considering sending nonmilitary support personnel to assist American and other military forces - a bold step for Japan, unmatched since World War II, but still something of a token gesture.
 
Thatcher's Decisiveness
The major exception is Britain, able to act fast because it has a unitary Government, with no junior coalition partners, and headed by an extraordinarily decisive woman, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has fought to keep the British-American special relationship alive as others dismissed it as moribund. The old imperial tradition in the zone east of Suez makes things easier for the British, too.
Only the Soviet Union has a military establishment in the same league as that of the United States.
Had the current emergency arisen a decade ago, it would have provided a prime opportunity for Soviet intervention, but Moscow is so preoccupied now with internal questions as to seem uninterested. Mr. Gorbachev is seeking instead to play a peacekeeping role through the United Nations, hoping to gain credibility with some Arab leaders, but he is in no position to move thousands of troops long distances almost overnight.
So the field is clear for Washington this time, at least as long as Mr. Bush can keep the country behind him. There are a few warning lights flashing; like other members of Congress who have been back in their districts this week, Mr. Hamilton reports that his constituents are ambivalent, ''taking a certain pride in our superpower status, but more and more questioning the cost of that unique position, in terms of taxes and of families separated.''
In the longer term, Washington faces a major task in defining exactly where the spheres of vital interest to the United States lie, and building a broad public consensus behind that set of priorities. Failing that, said Robert D. Hormats of Goldman Sachs, formerly a high-ranking official at the State and Treasury Departments, ''we'll be unable to sustain public support when the crises come, we'll have to pull back and we'll lose credibility.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Consults U.N. on Use of Force As Navy Shadows 2 Iraqi Tankers

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
With American warships shadowing two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in Middle East waters, the Bush Administration began a round of urgent diplomacy today in hopes of winning United Nations approval of its use of military power to enforce the international embargo on trade with Iraq, Administration officials said.
But a senior official said the United States was prepared to order the Navy to halt the two tankers in any case, even if it did not succeed in the diplomatic effort.
The two tankers, both outward bound from the Persian Gulf and evidently loaded with Iraqi oil, defied a series of warning shots fired across their bows by American warships on Saturday, the first shots fired by American military forces in the Persian Gulf crisis.
The senior official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States wanted to avoid renewing the friction that developed in the United Nations last week when President Bush acted unilaterally to impose a blockade against Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. But the official said, ''It's not question of if we are going to stop these tankers. It's a question of when.'' 
 
Resolution Being Prepared
Officials from the delegations of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council held at least two meetings today to discuss a resolution that would authorize the use of military power to enforce the worldwide embargo on trade with Iraq that was imposed after the Iraqis' Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.
The United States, which has only a few days before the first of the ships reaches its intended port, is hoping to arrange a Security Council meeting as early as Monday, officials said. Administration officials said Washington has asked Britain to introduce a draft resolution, which the five permament Council members were considering today.
United States Navy ships, part of an international flotilla that is seeking to block the export of Iraqi oil and maritime trade bound for Iraq, were monitoring several other vessels that were believed bound for Iraq with food and other supplies, officials said.
Pentagon officials today said the Navy had stopped a Cypriot freighter traveling under the Sudanese flag from entering the Red Sea port of Aqaba, Jordan, to pick up 550 Sudanese citizens who were trying to leave the area.
Although a senior official said the action ''certainly appeared to be odd under the circumstances,'' other officials said the freighter was carrying a load of chrome and steel bound for Iraq and planned to unload that cargo before picking up the refugees. That would have had the effect of breaching the embargo, the officials said.
Mr. Bush brushed aside questions about the military developments in the Persian Gulf as he flew home tonight from his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., to meet with national security advisers at a White House dinner.
He plans to address a gathering of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Baltimore on Monday and attend Republican Party campaign fund-raisers in Maryland and Rhode Island before returning to Maine. Although this is the second time Mr. Bush has returned to Washington to meet with his aides since he left for vacation on Aug. 10, the White House has tried hard to present the image of business as usual.
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, dismissed a statement by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in which he said he would allow Americans and Britons trapped in Iraq and Kuwait to go free if the United States withdrew its forces from Saudi Arabia and lifted the trade embargo.
''This one doesn't have much relationship to our objective,'' he said. ''It contains no new relevant proposals and makes no reference to the United Nations and Arab League calls for them to leave Kuwait.''
 
The Unspoken Word: Hostages
The Administration has been trying to dampen anxiety about the trapped Americans, and Mr. Fitzwater today said Washington still does not regard the approximately 3,500 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait as hostages.
Although the United States representative to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, did say on Saturday that Iraq ''is going to hold all foreigners hostage,'' Mr. Fitzwater said today, ''They are in the same boat as thousands of others. We would not use that word.''
Mr. Fitzwater, noting that the two Iraqi tankers are ''several days out of port,'' said, ''We intend to enforce the sanctions. But we want to give them every opportunity to turn around and change course.''
But other officials said the United States does not expect the two ships -the Khanaqin and the Baba Gurgur -to stop. An Administration official said one of the ships is headed to Yemen. The other's destination was not known. The Khanaqin was sailing in the Gulf of Oman today, while the Baba Gurgur was farther behind. It was reported this afternoon to be just leaving the Persian Gulf, which is separated from the Gulf of Oman by the Strait of Hormuz. Disagreement at U.N. Representatives of the five permament members of the United Nations Security Council - the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China - met in the morning to to discuss the British proposed resolution, which would put teeth, including an authorization to use military force, into the trade embargo against Iraq.
The initial meeting failed to resolve the issue, a United States official said, and the political counselors of the five nations met tonight to continue the negotiations.
''These have been informal meetings that we hope would lead to a resolution that the permanent five could support at a Security Council meeting, hopefully on Monday, to strengthen the provisions for the enforcement of the embargo,'' one official said. He added, ''That would include military force.''
But the American official said none of the five has yet requested a meeting of the Security Council, hoping to work out their differences over the resolution before doing so.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: U.S. CONSULTS U.N. ON USE OF FORCE AS NAVY SHADOWS 2 IRAQI TANKERS;
Cheney With the Admirals

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, Aug. 19

 BODY:
With tension running high in the Persian Gulf region after Iraqi ships ignored American warning shots, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met here today with the commanders of the United States' naval blockade of Iraq.
After arriving here on a four-day visit to American forces and Arab leaders in the region, the Defense Secretary went immediately to the La Salle, the command ship for American vessels in the Persian Gulf, for a briefing on the Persian Gulf situation by Adm. William Fogarty, the head of the Navy's fleet in the gulf, and Adm. Henry Mauz, who commands all American naval forces in the Middle East. 
Mr. Cheney left the aircraft carrier Eisenhower in the Red Sea this morning and flew to an air base in eastern Saudi Arabia, where he greeted American troops.
The crisis in the gulf deepened on Saturday when the Navy frigate Reid fired six warning shots toward an Iraqi oil tanker, the Khanaqin, in the Gulf of the Oman and the frigate Bradley fired three shots toward a second Iraqi tanker, the Baba Gurgur, in the Persian Gulf. Neither vessel stopped, posing a challenge to Mr. Bush's policy to interdict oil and other material going to and from Iraq.
 
Movement of Ships
The Reid is continuing to shadow the Khanaqin as it moves slowly toward the Arabian Sea. The Bradley is tracking the Baba Gurgur as it moves south in the Persian Gulf. Neither ship is very close to its intended destination so it is not imperative to take immediate action to prevent the delivery of the tankers' cargoes, American officials said.
American officials said that the Heng Chun Hai, a Chinese vessel headed out of the Persian Gulf with fertilizer from Iraq, was boarded by the American cruiser England on Saturday and ordered to return to its port of origin. It is currently at anchor in the gulf, officials said. This is the first report of a ship being boarded as part of the Iraqi blockade.
Meanwhile, there were reports that an Iraqi freighter, the Zein al-Qaws, believed to be carrying food, has eluded the American blockade and arrived at Aqaba, Jordan.
Asked about this on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' Mr. Cheney avoided a direct answer.
''Jordan is not a nation that has been sanctioned by the United Nations,'' he said, ''so traffic into and out of the gulf is not automatically prohibited. Traffic that we can identify as going through Jordan to be trans-shipped through Jordan to Iraq would in fact be subject to the sanctions.''
American officials said that news reports that a ferry for Sudanese refugees from Iraq and Kuwait had been turned away from the Gulf of Aqaba appeared to be a reference to a Cypriot vessel. American officials said on Saturday that the Cypriot vessel was turned away because it appeared to be carrying chemicals destined for Iraq.
 
Instructions for Boarding Teams
Reporters traveling with Mr. Cheney were told that boarding teams have been organized on Navy ships in the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea.
A lieutenant on the cruiser Ticonderoga said that he headed a 13-man boarding team armed with .45-caliber revolvers, shotguns, an automatic rifle and a grenade launcher. The boarding team also has protective gear for use against chemical weapons.
After boarding, the teams are instructed to present yellow plastic cards bearing instructions written in French, Arabic and English warning crew members on the vessel being boarded to ''remain calm'' and to ''avoid confrontation.''
'' Do not interfere with U.S. forces; If fighting starts in your area, drop to the deck with your hands outstretched and remain silent. Follow all instructions,'' the card states.
''You will be taken to a safe place. Report all injuries, so we may treat you, and cooperate, and no harm will come to you,'' the card adds.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordan Asserts U.S. Stopped Refugee Rescue Ship

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Jordan charged today that an American warship in the Red Sea turned back a ship en route to the port of Aqaba to pick up refugees from Kuwait.
Jordan, which has been under pressure from the United States to join other nations in enforcing trade sanctions against Iraq, reacted indignantly to the incident and took the unusual step of summoning Roger Harrison, the United States Ambassador, to the Foreign Ministry and issuing a formal protest.
''Jordan expressed its concern over this move,'' a senior Government official said, ''because this ship had no intention of either moving goods to Iraq or doing anything except the humanitarian task of moving Sudanese nationals.''
In a separate statement, the Government said: ''The action foiled Jordan's efforts in extending humanitarian services for all foreigners crossing into Jordan from Iraq.'' 
 
U.S. Regrets Reported
Jordan said in the statement that Mr. Harrison confirmed the incident and ''expressed his Government's regrets.''
But Patrick Theros, the American Ambassador's deputy, would only say through a spokesman, ''We do not comment on diplomatic exchanges between Jordan and the United States.'' [The Associated Press reported that the Pentagon confirmed that the Scott, a destroyer, had intercepted a Cypriot ferry flying the flag of Sudan as it tried to enter Aqaba.] Jordan identified the vessel as the 12,000-ton Sudanese freighter Dongola and said it had been confronted on Saturday night. The Dongola was carrying a load of cars for Jordan, a Government official said, and was scheduled to board 800 Sudanese, who had been working in Kuwait before the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2. The refugees, the Government said, were to be taken back to the Sudan. [The A.P. quoted Sudanese officials in Khartoum as saying the Sudan planned to lodge a protest in Washington. They also said the Dongola had been carrying 200 tons of cargo, mainly steel.] Talks Are Under Way As the shipping incident was made public, thousands of Arab and Asian refugees from Kuwait and Iraq were flooding across the Iraq-Jordan border, and Jordanian officials said talks were under way between the two nations to slow arrivals in Jordan at least temporarily.
''The border facilities are overloaded,'' an official said, ''and tens of thousands of people are in Aqaba waiting for ships to take them home.''
Jordanian officials estimated that more than 150,000 refugees, including about 200 Westerners, have crossed into Jordan since Kuwait was invaded and American troops began landing in Saudi Arabia to confront Iraq. About 40,000 have arrived in the last four days as the threat of war has grown.
Some of the refugees have been leaving Amman on international airline flights. But many Egyptian and Sudanese laborers with modest incomes have taken cross-country buses to Aqaba, Jordan's only outlet to the sea, with plans to catch inexpensive ferries and boats home.
''There is a very terrible situation in Aqaba,'' a Jordanian official said. ''These people cannot be absorbed. There are not enough services, not enough hotel rooms. Some people are sleeping outside.''
 
Economic Effect Cited
In resisting implementation of sanctions, Jordan argues that cutting off trade with Iraq, its biggest trading partner, would deprive the already troubled Jordanian economy of more than $1 billion a year. Iraq also supplies 90 percent of Jordan's oil.
But Jordan also has strong bonds with Iraq. The Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, has become a close friend of King Hussein of Jordan. The Iraqi leader is cheered at rallies at which the American flag is burned, and newspaper columnists have praised him for standing up for Arab dignity against foreign powers.
The sanctions were one of the key issues in talks between President Bush and King Hussein in their meeting Thursday in Kennebunkport, Me. Mr. Bush said afterward that he was encouraged that Jordan would be joining in the boycott of Iraq. But the King told reporters in Maine that Jordan's position had not been altered.
In what is widely seen by Westerners here as another delaying tactic, a delegation of Jordanian officials is meeting with United Nations officials in New York on Monday ''to discuss details'' of the measures, which have already been put into effect by all other countries in the region.
 
Reduction in Ships to Aqaba
Even without Jordanian action, the United Nations call for sanctions and the American armada have persuaded many ship owners to stop carrying cargo bound for Iraq.
''There has been a tremendous slowdown in the number of ships coming to Aqaba,'' a senior Jordanian official said tonight.
Jordan has been arguing recently that it is inhumane to follow the United States in denying food shipments to Iraq and may violate the United Nations charter.
Today an organization called the General Union of Voluntary Societies placed an advertisement taking up the lower third of the front page of the daily Jordan Times under the heading, ''Milk For the Children of Iraq.'' Half a dozen Government offices were listed as places where contributions could be made.
 
France to Join Embargo
PARIS, Aug. 19 (Special to The New York Times) - France moved closer today to the position adopted by the United States and Britain on the Iraqi crisis when it ordered its naval forces in the Persian Gulf to apply the trade embargo against Iraq ''with firmness.''
French officials refused to say whether French warships were now permitted to use force in cases where ships heading to or from Iraq refuse to stop and be searched. But a Foreign Ministry statement said that to be effective, the United Nations embargo implied ''measures of verification, control and constraint.''
At the United Nations last week, France criticized moves by the United States and Britain to establish a naval blockade of Iraq, arguing that only the Security Council could authorize such an action.
Meanwhile, the French Foreign Ministry confirmed today that 27 French nationals - one in Kuwait and 26 in Baghdad - were among Western civilians who were apparently moved to strategic military or civilian locations inside Iraq on Thursday.

HEADLINE: From State Pricing to Stoop Labor, Soviet System Dooms a Bumper Crop

SERIES: SOVIET FOOD CRISIS: HARVEST OF WASTE - SECOND OF TWO ARTICLES.

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 19

 BODY:
When the first reports from the Soviet grain belt reached Moscow early this summer, it seemed that fate had at last chosen to take pity on the famished economy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Wheat had burst from the soil of Russia, the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan in such profusion that some Government optimists began to speculate about the country becoming self-sufficient in food for the first time in decades.
But Moscow's hope has soured into anxiety, and the anxiety to near despair, as the feckless Soviet agriculture system fumbles the process of putting nature's bounty onto dinner tables across the nation.
In a desperate attempt to prevent the crop from spoiling on the ground, 100,000 troops have been mobilized, factory workers and students exhorted to the fields, states of emergency decreed in many farm districts, directives issued, new incentives enacted -apparently to little avail.
 
Barren Grocery Stores
By mid-August, halfway through the harvest season, the Government reported that the grain was being cut at only three-fourths the rate of last year. The lag in the vegetable harvest was visible in the barren state grocery stores and in astronomical fruit and vegetable prices in farmers' markets. 
Soviet officials say the country's farmers have grown enough this year to exceed the record 237-million-ton harvest of 1978, but there is increasing anxiety that the final total, measured by shipments to market, will fall short of that potential.
The preliminary estimates of the grain wasted from what one Soviet writer called ''this catastrophically rich harvest'' was 40 million tons -roughly equal to the amount of grain the Soviet Union will import this year with its desperately scarce reserves of foreign money.
''This year God gave us a good harvest, and we are unable to gather it!'' wailed Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, his voice verging on hysteria during a televised emergency meeting of his Council of Ministers early this month.
''If we fail, then what purpose are we serving, those of us sitting here and the local authorities?'' asked the Prime Minister, whose position as Mr. Gorbachev's head of government is already precarious.
One failure of farming Communist-style is a communal approach to owning and working the land, an approach that has stifled initiative. Another failure, exposed by this summer's embarrassment of riches, is a command-driven food industry that assures that even when nature does provide, much of its bounty will be spilled on the way from field to consumer.
The losses the Soviets tolerate in normal years - about 15 percent of the grain and 30 percent of the vegetables - ''would be considered disastrous'' in the United States or Canada, said one Western agricultural specialist here.
Moreover, in this time of social disintegration, the built-in weaknesses of the system have been further aggravated by ethnic unrest, the breakdown of discipline and the disruption of old economic arrangements. A system based on commands, the Soviet food industry is learning this summer, only works so long as people obey.
The Soviet food industry leaks at each stage in the trip from collective farm to state-run market, but about half of losses occur on the farm itself, , a result of inadequate machinery and manpower, officials say.
 
Stranded Machinery
The overall slowdown of the Soviet economy has left harvesting combines stranded this year for lack of batteries, spare parts and fuel.
According to Vladlen V. Nikitin, chairman of the State Commission on Foodstuffs, one-fifth of the serviceable harvesters have no drivers - a result of the mass exodus that yearly takes a million people from the impoverished countryside to the slightly less impoverished cities.
The harvest usually depends on crash teams of extra hands mobilized from factories, schools and military bases. In effect, part of the industrial sector takes a holiday so that machinists, bookkeepers and doctors can do stoop labor on the state's farms. This has always been casual labor in the most literal sense of the word. A reporter who dropped in unannounced one morning at the barracks of temporary workers at a grain elevator near Kaluga, in central Russia, found the crew all giggling drunk on watery beer, half an hour before their shift began.
 
Low Enthusiasm
This year the enthusiasm for the harvest campaign is lower than ever. The rubles paid for stoop labor do not buy much any more, and the Communist Party network responsible for mustering the seasonal work force has lost much of its authority.
Vegetable farms, which are especially dependent on seasonal guest workers, report that helpers are showing up at only one-fifth the usual rate.
Once the crop is out of the ground, most of it is to be delivered to the Government in fulfillment of state contracts, for distribution to the bakeries and feedlots and state-run grocery stores.
But another new hitch is that farms are increasingly reluctant to surrender their goods.
One reason is the quirky state-run price system. A collective farmer near Kaluga gave the following example:
The state price on grain last year was so low that the farm lost money on every ton. The state price on milk, however, produced a big profit. The logical conclusion: neglect the state and keep the grain to feed the cows.
 
Bartering for Scarcities
Many farms have simply ignored their contracts and kept the grain either to feed livestock for local consumption, or to barter directly with other regions for such scarcities as building materials, which rubles cannot buy.
At the Chapayev Collective Farm in the village of Vasyurinskaya, near Krasnodar in southern Russia, the management has created a trading subsidiary. The subsidiary takes the farm's surplus and also buys up food from the private garden plots in the area to ship to the far north and far east in exchange for timber, steel and pipe.
''We offer the population fairly high prices so that they do not take their produce to the market but sell it to our trading cooperative,'' explained Grigory P. Onishchuk, the deputy director of the farm.
The farm is also building its own sausage plant and bakery and contemplating a cannery as alternatives to the state.
Some economists welcome this as a healthy sign that farmers are becoming more entrepreneurial. But it also means serious hardship for regions of the country with little to swap, for low-income pensioners who can only afford to shop in state-priced grocery stores, and for industries like poultry and pork that tend to depend heavily on feed requisitioned by the center.
 
Payment in Dollars
To combat local hoarding, the Government announced last year that it would pay farmers for part of their grain in dollars, giving them access to foreign goods. The program has faltered so far because farmers said the dollar prices were too stingy, and because the Government made it extremely difficult to spend the money.
Prospects for an increase in the barter economy are also undercut by the fact that most Soviet farms do not have their own storage sites, relying instead on state grain silos that fill quickly in a bumper year.
Once a farm has gathered its crop and decided to turn it over to the state, the next problem is getting it there.
Few farms have enough trucks to manage a big harvest, and this year there have been numerous reports of harvested grain lying in the fields, rotting in the rain.
In an effort to deliver the crop, farmers assemble mismatched caravans of dump trucks, flatbeds, army trucks and whatever other vehicles can be found.
 
Overloaded Trucks
''The trucks are old, with big cracks in the container,'' said Vladimir B. Khutaryants, director of a grain elevator in Krasnodar. ''The smaller the trucks, the more runs they make every day, the more losses we have. That's not even to speak of the carelessness of the drivers. They are paid by the ton delivered, so they are interested in loading the truck to the brim.''
The next stage of the process, deliveries from the elevators to mills and feedlots, has suffered from a severe shortage of railroad cars, resulting from strikes by nationalists in Azerbaijan and Georgia. Freight cars have also been diverted to coal regions in response to demands by striking miners. Processing is the next choke point. ''It's overwhelming, their ability to grow,'' marvelled Richard Bosio, a Modesto, Calif., businessman scouting potential investments this summer in the Krasnodar area. ''And then it gets to the processing, and it stops there and rots in the truck.''
 
Stuck in the 1930's
The canneries, breweries and slaughterhouses, he said, were all stuck in the 1930's, still heavily dependent on manual processes and not designed to grow.
''Their canning and bottling plants do maybe 3,000 a day,'' he said. ''We do that in minutes. In the United States we're always ahead of our yield. The capacity to grow is a given. Not in Russia.''
Mr. Bosio said the system has so many bottlenecks that the problem must be solved gradually. Installing state-of-the-art equipment at one stage would just mean more produce to clog the next stage. To give a farmer a mechanized tomato picker, for example, without building storage sheds and installing new canning equipment, would just add to the pile of rotting tomatoes.
''There is a lot of used equipment in world,'' he said. ''I kind of think they should be thinking in those terms. The question is, do we bring these people into the 70's? Or do we bring them up to the 21st century and boggle their minds?''

In a desperate attempt to prevent ruin, troops, factory workers and students have been mobilized to work in the fields, including volunteers picking tomatoes in Krasnodar. (Robert D. Tonsing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Los Ojos Journal;
Aiding the Poor Receives Its Reward

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS OJOS, N.M.,

 BODY:
One morning a few weeks ago Maria Varela received a telephone call informing her that after a lifetime of working with the poor, she suddenly had become rich.
It was a surprise notification from the MacArthur Foundation in Chicago that she had received a $305,000 grant. She was told that the money was for her personal use so she could continue her efforts with the corporation she had started to create profitable businesses for the sheep herders, weavers and housewives of the impoverished Chama Valley in northern New Mexico.
''At first I thought it was a hoax,'' Ms. Varela said, ''and so I didn't tell anybody about it. Then I started feeling like a tremendous burden had been taken off my shoulders. My line of work does not exactly pay very well, and it doesn't provide any retirement benefits.'' 
She is to receive the money over five years in quarterly checks. Ms. Varela, along with her husband, who is a construction worker, and their 11-year-old daughter lives in a trailer without running water. She said the first check went to pay bills and the second may as well.
The MacArthur Fellowships, as the grants are known, are distributed every year to support the work of individuals in fields as diverse as medical research and poetry.
In the case of Ms. Varela, 50 years old, the money was a reward for a career of social activism that began in the 1960's when concern for the poor was popular and that has continued through times when such commitment has been less fashionable.
The very practical side of her convictions became apparent in a visit to the enterprises created by Ganados del Valle, Spanish for ''livestock of the valley,'' the economic development corporation she helped create in 1983.
She sounded like a foreman when she discussed floorboards with workers carrying out the renovation of a 1890's building that is to become a general store.
She sounded like an accountant when she detailed the savings gleaned from a solar-powered wool drier.
Walking through the showroom of Tierra Wools, a spinning and weaving cooperative that produces and sells high-quality yarns, clothing and rugs, she sounded like an entrepreneur, talking about the $250,000 in yearly sales and the commercial loan negotiated this year after six years of dependence on money from foundation grants.
Later, recalling the early training she received from the Young Christian Students, a Roman Catholic organization active in social causes, she said, ''I learned then that it is not enough to pray over an injustice or protest it or research it to death, but that you have to take concrete action to solve it.''
For five years during the mid-1960's she worked in the South as an organizer for the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, a civil rights organization. That experience, she said, taught her that ''helping poor people achieve self-reliance is much more important than getting them government money or the advice of experts.''
Some 20 years ago she found her way to this green mountain valley about 100 miles north of Santa Fe where Hispanic families make a meager living on small plots.
A steady flow of foundation grants to finance Ms. Varela's projects seems to support her belief that the projects may serve as a model for other communities. Ms. Varela is convinced she can best influence larger issues by directly affecting just a few dozen lives.
''I feel most productive,'' she said, ''when I think of the people who were so shy and passive and poorly educated when they started here and who are now accomplished weavers or managers.''
She realizes that such an individualized process is slow. ''You have to stick with it for two generations at least to really change a culture,'' she said. ''That's why we have a children's program to start training our future work force and leaders.''
Since she received the MacArthur grant, Ms. Varela worries less about her own future because she expects to put away half the money as a sort of pension.
''I am going to be a community organizer for as long as I can,'' she said, ''then I am going to go retire, preferably somewhere warm by the sea.''

Among her projects is Tierra Wools, a spinning and weaving cooperative producing high-quality yarns, clothing and rugs. (Roberto Suro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Seeking Seats, Republicans Find Ally in Rights Act

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Are Republicans using the civil rights laws to undercut the Democratic Party?
The Democrats say there is no other way to describe the clever, and ironic, politics in which the Republican Party and the Bush Administration have on several occasions aligned themselves with black and Hispanic groups seeking to expand voting rights.
Even Republicans concede the irony in their newly aggressive interest in insuring enforcement of the Voting Rights Act, which was strengthened in 1982 over the strenuous objections of the Reagan Administration.
So why the turnabout to help black and Hispanic voters, who are among the most loyal Democrats?
''I don't think the position of the Republican National Committee on voting rights is necessarily motivated by a completely altruistic feeling toward minorities,'' said Frank Parker of the Lawyers Committee on Civil Rights. 
Some minority members would agree, but are reluctant to turn down help.
 
Master Plan Is Denied
Republicans insist they are not working from the master plan that Democrats perceive, but they acknowledge that doing right by racial minorities also means doing well for Republicans.
What they have come to realize is that in crucial circumstances - from the drawing of new Congressional districts to the debate over primary runoffs, actions that strengthen black or Hispanic power often have the independent consequence of weakening the Democratic Party.
''I think the Administration and the national committee see in the Voting Rights Act a very powerful tool in terms of advancing the Republican cause,'' said a Republican Representative who insisted on anonymity.
 
Examples of Alliances
Here are two examples of why the politics of voting rights has brought together Republicans and traditionally Democratic advocates of increased minority voting strength.
First, voting rights groups are seeking in next year's redistricting to create more constituencies that are heavily minority, thus increasing the likelihood that a minority member would be elected. Republicans realize that such moves would remove minority voters from other districts, where they have been helping to elect white Democrats.
''It makes it a lot easier to elect a white, suburban Republican if he doesn't have any blacks in his district,'' said Charles Schroder, executive director of the Georgia Democratic Party. So the net result could be more black representatives and more Republican representatives.
Second, the elimination of primary runoffs when no candidate gets a majority of the primary vote could help more minority members win Democratic nominations. Republicans believe they would then have a better chance to win the general election, as some whites abandon the minority Democratic candidate.
 
Help With Redistricting
The Republican Party has offered to help minority groups who want to challenge redistricting plans. The plans are drawn up by state legislatures, which are, most often, controlled by Democrats. Among the help that the Republicans are offering is a powerful computer program that allows private groups to draw their own redistricting maps for presentation to the legislatures or courts. Republicans place the value of the computer software at $360,000, although Democrats say $200,000.
The Justice Department also announced that it planned to scrutinize redistricting plans around the country, not just in states where it is required by law, to make sure the plans do not dilute minority voting strength.
The new Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, John R. Dunne, says the Justice Department has become more aggressive in actions under the Voting Rights Act. For instance, last week the department for the first time took a position against primary runoffs. Mr. Dunne filed a brief in support of a challenge to the Georgia law that requires a runoff when no candidate wins a majority in a primary election.
 
Offer of Help in Alabama
In Alabama, Hank Sanders, a Democratic State Senator who is black, said he had been approached by a Republican colleague who wanted to join him in a fight against that state's runoff system. ''I asked him how that would be in the interest of the Republican Party,'' Senator Sanders recalled. ''He indicated it would open things up, having Democratic candidates who are not consensus candidates.''
Mr. Dunne was asked whether his department's more aggresive pursuit of voting rights cases dovetailed with the Republicans' interests.
''I'd like to think it's more coincidental,'' he said. ''I can't believe that any partisan Democrat is going to say, 'Hey, Dunne, don't vigorously enforce the civil rights laws.' ''
If a byproduct of his actions is to beneifit the Republican Party, Mr. Dunne added, that is fine. ''But this is too sensitive a position to let partisan considerations control decisions,'' he said.
 
A Problem for Blacks
Many blacks see a dilemma in this, since they are being asked to team up with an Administration that is sending mixed signals on civil rights.
The same Administration that is offering support on voting rights is threatening to veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990, claiming it would promote racial quotas in business.
''There is always a suspicion because the Reagan Administration had such a terrible record on minority voting rights, and some of the people involved in the new Republican initiative participated in the lack of voting rights enforcement,'' Mr. Parker said. ''But at the same time the civil rights community has had such a paucity of resources that when the Republicans come along and say, 'We'll give you a reapportionment software package with no strings attached,' they're not going to turn it down because of political ideology.''
Why should they? many in the civil rights movement ask. After all, over the years they have worked with Democrats who did not seem to have their interests in mind.
''If I finally decide an idea is a good idea, then I'll take my help from where it comes,'' Senator Sanders said in a telephone interview from Selma, Ala. ''But there's no doubt in my mind that Republicans have decided it's also in their best interest from a political point of view and are pursuing it on that basis.''
But blacks also face a second, and more fundamental, problem. While their representation in elective office still falls short of their numbers in the population, blacks are a crucial constituency in the Democratic Party, and many Democrats warn that if the increase in black representatives ends up decreasing the number of Democrats in Congress, then the interests of blacks nationwide could be hurt.
 
The Question of Influence
Eddie Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization, questioned whether heavily black districts might produce more black officials but less overall influence. ''Are you better off with one district which is guaranteed or with significant influence in four districts?'' he asked.
Republicans have been giving speeches about how the Democrats have not done right by blacks.
Benjamin Ginsberg, counsel to the Republican National Committee, repeatedly cites figures. In the 11 states of the Confederacy, he tells black groups, blacks are 17.4 percent of the voting age population. There are 116 members of Congress from those states, and 4 are black.
''It is no accident that all branches of the legislatures and the governorships were controlled by Democrats during the last redistricting,'' Mr. Ginsberg adds.
Democrats concede that more districts capable of electing blacks need to be created. But they warn voting rights groups against walking away from old friends.
Mr. Schroder, in a telephone interview from Atlanta, said the effort to overturn Georgia's law on runoffs was an ''unholy alliance'' between the American Civil Liberties Union, left-leaning factions among blacks and the Republicans.
''If you crawl in bed with those folks, it's like selling your soul and selling out the progess of the past, and really the progress of the future,'' he said.

Hank Sanders, a Democratic State Senator from Alabama, thinks the Republicans are supporting the act because it is in their best interest from a political point of view. HEADLINE: 100 Groups Form Coalition to Help Blacks

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a diverse group of more than 100 other organizations have formed a coalition to battle social ills among blacks.
The group, the National Association of Black Organizations, grew out of the meeting, which was assembled by the N.A.A.C.P. The meeting, held here over three days, concluded Saturday. 
Coalition members, which include groups as varied as the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives and the Progressive National Baptist Convention, will focus their efforts on problems like teen-age pregnancy and school dropouts.
The executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., Benjamin L. Hooks, said the coalition was intended to enhance the ''continuing struggle of African Americans to gain a fair share of the American Dream.''
The organization's plans call for a communications network to share information, development of a brain trust to research and make recommendations on social and economic concerns affecting blacks and development of strategies to strengthen support for black institutions.
''What we have accomplished here is but a beginning,'' Mr. Hooks said. ''It marks the start of a new approach, where the visible payoff is farther down the road.''
He said the N.A.A.C.P. did not intend to turn from its historical focus, traditionally legislation and litigation. But he said the 81-year-old group realized the need for black organizations to address problems facing blacks.
''We as black people are stepping up to the bat and saying we are taking responsibility for our own destiny,'' Mr. Hooks said.
He said the coalition's nine-member executive committee would meet in two weeks to work out further details.

LENGTH: 557 words

HEADLINE: Keeping the Nations United

 BODY:
Concerted international action: It is essential to secure the safety of the thousands of foreigners trapped in Kuwait and Iraq. It is essential to resolve the Iraq-Kuwait crisis with minimum violence. It is essential to keep Saddam Hussein from obscuring his own aggression with continued fabrications about the nature of American intervention. 
And it is essential to realize a more profound possibility. How well the world cooperates now can set a bold pattern of peacekeeping for the post-cold war world.
Such concerted action starts with the newly united United Nations. Once-empty mechanisms and procedures daily take on life. Cooperation can best be discussed and coordinated through the U.N., which for virtually the first time in its history is functioning as it was designed to.
Yesterday, the Security Council passed a tough resolution on Iraq's manipulative threats toward foreign nationals. Scores of nations have now reported on the effectiveness of U.S. sanctions to date. A three-nation subcommittee of the Security Council began to weigh the need for further steps.
This week in a historic step, the council is convening a meeting of the long-neglected panel designed to coordinate U.N. collective security operations.
There are many contributions that particular nations can make. On the military side, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France, West Germany, Australia, Canada, the Netherlands and Belgium have now sent ships. Three Islamic countries, Egypt, Morocco and Bangladesh, have joined the United States in sending ground troops to defend Saudi Arabia against Saddam Hussein's massed armies; two more, Syria and Pakistan, are poised to follow. But most of these individual contingents operate under separate command authority. Further Security Council action is needed to constitute them into a true international force. In the event of such action, the Soviet Union has also declared its willingness to contribute troops. Japan and West Germany, stronger economically than militarily, can help pay for military deployments. Washington now estimates that it will spend a billion dollars-plus just this month, even without a shooting war. Tokyo, Bonn and others can also contribute by giving financial assistance to countries like Turkey and Jordan that could otherwise become indirect victims of the embargo against Iraq. Oil-producing countries can make a critical contribution, notably to the poor third world, by following the lead of Saudi Arabia and pumping extra oil to replace lost Iraqi and Kuwaiti output. Arms and technology exporting countries could further tighten controls against transfers militarily useful to Iraq. The Soviet Union, China and other arms producers like Brazil and Argentina need to join in tight restrictions on exporting missile technology. And West Germany needs to press its belated crackdown on exporters of chemical weapons plants.
The United States acted hastily last week when it moved unilaterally to block naval traffic to Iraq. A few days' delay matters little in enforcing economic sanctions, which work slowly and cumulatively. As officials now seem to realize, there was certainly no good reason to forfeit consensus.
The wider that global consensus, the better the chance of enforcing the peace without resorting to war - now and in future crises.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Proposal to Execute Drug Kingpins Appeals Strictly to Fear

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's letter defending his amendment to the omnibus crime bill (July 31) is a chilling document from an elected official in a democratic country.
Even if the death penalty for ''drug kingpins'' were taken seriously, as it should not be, few people are ever convicted of at least three major Federal drug crimes. Most drug convictions are for ''five and dime'' street deals made by young unemployed individuals supporting their own habits or needing a quick income source. Our legal system makes a second felony conviction difficult to obtain and uphold. This is a protection for all citizens, given the record of drug trials both past and present.
Ten to 13 years of appeals, retrials and motions cost money: prison space, prosecutorial costs, defense costs and court costs. Does Senator D'Amato assign a dollar value to these? We have a staggering Federal deficit for which the proposed solutions are reductions in Medicare, Medicaid and food supplements for women and children.
Considering the time required for legal appeals, will there be a backlog in death rows, requiring more cell space? Will there be proposals for death camp construction?
I do not want drug kingpins dead; I want them poor. The Senator's proposal increases the risks, scarcity and prices for the commodity, not the demand.
Tax-free cash will pour into the villas-yachts-and-private-plane life style, as few are caught. More violence can be expected to protect high profits. The ''targets'' of the proposals might very well applaud them.
One must surely question the grandstanding that exploits fear into frenzy. This is the road to totalitarianism.
 
MARIAN J. DALE
 Staten Island, Aug. 1, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Saddam's Last Roundup

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The question is no longer ''will there be war?'' between the world and Iraq, but ''what is the best strategy to win the war already begun with the least loss of life?''
The conflicting choices now before Mr. Bush are not secret: two different strategies have been laid out in public by former national security advisers Zbigniew Brzezinski and Henry Kissinger.
Our object should be ''to squeeze but not strangle Iraq,'' says the author of the Carter Doctrine. Zbig holds that we should defend Western access to oil, but not seek to roll back the conquest of Kuwait - to rely on international cooperation to negotiate a compromise with Saddam rather than try to defeat him. 
Henry differs. Our goal should be the removal of Saddam as a threat to the world's economic lifeline, says the author of the Nixon Doctrine. A settlement leaving Saddam with growing military might would be ''only an interlude between aggressions,'' writes Dr. Kissinger; he urges ''a surgical and progressive destruction of Iraq's military assets'' before the world's will dissipates.
I believe the Brzezinski ''squeeze option'' was destroyed in the past few days by the Iraqi decision to hold Western nationals as hostages. Saddam's promised starvation of Western children would squeeze us, not him, to negotiate ''peace in our time.''
But if Mr. Bush moves quickly, we can counter the Iraqi threat to use our nationals as human shields at military installations. He need not be the third consecutive U.S. President to be humbled by kidnappers.
Saddam has already told Westerners trapped in Kuwait to assemble at three hotels to be saved from a threat he will soon cook up. Mr. Bush - with Mrs. Thatcher and as many other leaders as he can induce to join him -should announce that any ''roundup'' or harassment of up to 10,000 non-Communist Western nationals taken in the capture of Kuwait would be considered an act of war triggering potent military retaliation.
Such fair warning has been delayed, I presume, to permit a buildup of our forces in Saudi Arabia. But action is now urgent; we can do little at the moment for the two-score Americans already condemned to target duty in Iraq, but we can use a credible threat to protect thousands of others in Kuwait who - once rounded up for designation as human shields - may be doomed.
Suppose President Bush goes on the air quickly to tell the putative hostages in Kuwait to evade capture as long as they can and to urge loyal Kuwaitis to hide them; and suppose he adds that any attempt at a ''roundup'' will be answered by bombers taking out all Iraqi strategic sites.
In that circumstance, let us consider the options open to Saddam:
Option One: He could ignore the threat and order his troops to hunt down the foreigners, or promise death to any who do not surrender at a given time.
Option Two: Saddam could let the foreign nationals leave as evidence of his desire for peace.
Option Three: He could neither round them up nor let them out; he can say defiantly he will take them prisoner whenever he decides to, but not yet.
He is likely to select the first: to order his army to arrest, alive, every non-Kuwaiti in Kuwait.
The U.S., with whatever supporting cover it can get from the U.N., would then carry out its solemn commitment. We would bomb every key warmaking center in Iraq - nuclear, poison-gas and missile-production installations first - including the tanks assembling on the Saudi border.
In this way, the shooting war would begin as a direct result of Saddam's grab for hostages. His hostage ''roundup'' would pull our trigger; kidnapping on top of invasion would call down the ensuing destruction. The world, and Iraqis, would know why the first nuclear-preventive war was being carried home to its source.
What if he outsmarted us, choosing options two or three? That would prolong the crisis, which is in his interest, but would save the lives of thousands of trapped innocents - not our central purpose, but no small thing.
By waging a decisive, conventional World War 2 1/2, we avert a nuclear World War III. Our national interest is not primarily to protect an oil supply, or to save our way of life from depression, or to make the world safe for sheiks, or even to assert the noble principle of collective resistance to aggression.
What makes an interest ''vital'' is its centrality to life and death. The world interest in bringing down Saddam Hussein is to insure that the means of mass destruction never fall into the hands of a mass murderer.

LENGTH: 2193 words

HEADLINE: It's Kickoff Time For a New Game

SERIES: College Football In Transition; First of a series.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
FACED with legal challenges, shifting alliances and a deteriorating relationship with the National Football League, college football is beginning the most significant season in its 122-year history.
Sweeping winds of change that passed as rumors five years ago have begun to erode conference ties, scatter advertisers' dollars and even sow seeds of a movement for players' rights. They have also presented coaches, athletic directors and players with a challenging mandate: Be successful and raise revenue, but stay within the constraints of an increasingly complex body of rules.
 
'Decade of Change'
''I've never seen a season begin with so many issues,'' said Roy Kramer, the commissioner of the Southeastern Conference. ''Recruiting, financial aid, distribution of revenue, conferences. There's been talk for a long time about changes, but I think we're all convinced that the 1990's will be the decade of change.'' 
College coaches, who have seen salaries and pressures escalate, are caught in the throes of change that will force many to alter the way they have operated for years.
''The status quo is gone,'' said Joe Paterno, who is beginning his 25th year as the Penn State coach. ''The N.F.L. is expanding into college football. Our presidents are demanding reforms and cutbacks. Yet we have to make money for 27 other sports from gate receipts and other revenues; the presidents have no place to get it from except us.
''So coaches are now asking, 'How do I make more money and do it legitimately without exploiting the guys?' That's the dilemma; that's why you're seeing so many changes. The world turns and things change. You better change with them or be left behind.''
 
A Blitz of Problems
As Tennessee and Colorado prepare to kick off Sunday in the season's first game, the problems confronting college football, like an all-out blitz, seem to be coming from every direction.
* Relationship with the pros: The once-cozy arrangement between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the N.F.L. has become combative as the two enterprises vie for a shrinking advertising dollar and fight a tug of war over star college players eager to test the pro market.
* Conference realignment: Traditonal rivalries are ending as schools and conferences enter into hastily arranged marriages of economic convenience. Earlier this month, Arkansas jumped from the Southwest Conference to the Southeastern after determining it would be enriched by the move. That came a few months after Penn State eschewed its traditional independent status to join the Big Ten, where it is expected to begin football competition by 1995.
* Television negotiations: Notre Dame changed the ground rules earlier this year when it went outside the College Football Association, which it helped form, and independently forged its own deal with NBC for an estimated $30 million over five years. This prompted conferences and other independents to look for ways to best enhance their own TV revenue and forgo a more collective approach.
* Advertising: TV advertisers are reassessing the free-spending practices of the 1970's and early 80's, when they poured millions of dollars into college football.
* Players' rights: Players won the right this year to apply for the N.F.L. draft as underclassmen. Encouraged by this progress and surrounded by million-dollar deals, they are using the courts to challenge N.C.A.A. and N.F.L. rules that restrict their ability to test their marketability. Last week, a former Notre Dame player, Braxston Banks, lost his suit against the N.C.A.A. and Notre Dame to have a final year of eligibility restored. Banks forfeited that year when he declared for April's N.F.L. draft. He was one of 20 undergraduates not selected.
Banks said he wanted to draw attention to the N.C.A.A.'s eligibility rules, which he believes are unclear and unfair. ''We want to insure that those who follow will have a better chance and a clearer understanding of what is going on around them and won't have to go through the same thing I've had to endure,'' he said.
 
New Realities, New Problems
Like players, coaches have been forced to deal with new realities and not all of them like it.
''They want to cut back and eliminate and have time restrictions,'' said John Jenkins, the first-year coach at Houston. ''You just wonder whether it's going to come to a head where our school and some of the other major colleges step back and just say: 'Hey, enough of this. We're getting out of the N.C.A.A. How do you like that?' ''
Houston has problems symptomatic of those that prompted Arkansas to leave the Southwest Conference after having generated a fourth of the conference's revenue. Despite having Andre Ware, the Heisman Trophy winner, last season, Houston was not a big gate attraction. The Cougars averaged 28,449 fans per home game. The average attendance last season in the S.W.C. was 37,541, compared with a conference-record 65,445 in the S.E.C, where 6 teams ranked in the top 12 nationally in attendance. ''We've run through the N.C.A.A. record book as if it were a track meet, and yet as far as sellout crowds and what not, it hasn't happened,'' Jenkins said. ''You need to look at the fact (a) we're in a pro town, and (b) the televison. An individual can sit home and watch five or six games without even getting out of his chair, where back in the 1960's and 70's people were driving 100 miles to a ball game, to go see a game.''
Critics point out that college football created the current glut of televised games and that the glut is partly responsible for the downward turn of attendance.
The N.C.A.A. negotiated its first television football package, worth $1.1 million, in 1952, but a restrictive policy limited exposure. In 1982, Oklahoma and Georgia successfully sued the N.C.A.A. on behalf of the C.F.A. and earned the right for all schools to negotiate their own television deals. The Big Ten and Pacific-10 remained outside the C.F.A. and made their own deals. In 1984, the Supreme Court upheld the lower court decision. College football began to fill the airwaves, and attendance for Division I-A has declined ever since. It fell to 41,970 per game last season after reaching a high of 43,689 in 1982.
While few coaches feel that leaving the N.C.A.A. is necessary - or practical - an increasing number of them agree that change is necessary to make the game more attractive and stop further fragmentation.
''We compete now with the N.F.L., the N.B.A. and the N.C.A.A. basketball championships,'' Paterno said. ''Each of those has done a great job of promoting itself, and they've done it with playoffs; they've spiced up their games. We have not. We've relied on bowls to spice up the ends of our season.'' Paterno said that when he began his college coaching career in 1950 many of the N.F.L. owners had deep roots in the college game. ''They had a feel for the college game,'' Paterno recalled. ''Now owning a team is a $140 million investment. We have to find a way to regenerate interest in our game and we're naive if we think the N.F.L. is going to be less of a problem.''
 
Changing Alignments
Penn State sparked widespread talk of shifts in December when it accepted the Big Ten's invitation for membership.
What many find curious about the move is that the overtures to Penn State came from Big Ten presidents at a time when the N.C.A.A. Presidents Commission was calling for more controls over athletic programs and a constricting of big-time athletics. Some coaches complained that Penn State's move, and the subsequent shift by Arkansas, sent the wrong message.
''I'm getting mixed signals,'' said Grant Teaff, the Baylor coach. ''Administrators, faculty representatives, tell us we have to reign in athletes, cut back the number of scholarships and coaching staff. No athletic dorms, no spring practice.
''Then they expand, reach out in the name of finance to bring in this team or that team as part of a league to get a larger share of televison money. It seems as if they want to go in two separate directions.'' But some presidents defended the additions. ''I felt they have an excellent university, which is very similar to most of the other Big Ten institutions in terms of excellent academic programs and variety,'' said Dr. Morton Weir, the chancellor at the University of Illinois. ''It's our kind of institution.
''I didn't think of this as the beginning of a chain reaction. I don't think any of us did.''
 
Wiser Players Seek Fair Share
One clear direction is that the modern-day college football player at most big-time programs is no longer the naive teen-ager oblivious to the huge amount of money his university is making or to six-figure contracts the coach is signing. Banks said that while football and basketball teams at large schools support other programs, football and basketball players lack the freedom of athletes in tennis and golf to compete against professionals without losing eligibility. Baseball and hockey players can enter pro drafts in their respective sports without forfeiting eligibility.
''I think these colleges are afraid that if these so-called star players were to have the freedom to test their marketability openly, the schools would lose a lot of money because they would lose a lot of the key players and a lot of the hype that goes with having key players,'' Banks said.
Richard D. Schultz, the N.C.A.A.'s executive director, has said that he favors removing restrictions on football players to allow underclassmen to put their names in drafts without losing eligibility. But legislation on that issue has not been introduced. Players testing the pro market is just one of the areas that has strained the relationship between the college and pro games. The promise of playing professionally is a magnet that often attracts outstanding players to a particular college program. But with pressure to graduate players, athletic officials have openly begun to point their fingers at pro scouts.
''Our concern was that they take people out of school during their last semester and that prevents them from graduating,'' said Chuck Neinas, the executive director of the College Football Association.
''They're telling young men that they have to visit 16 different professional clubs and then they conduct minicamps during final exam period, So obviously they don't have a chance to graduate. We're suggesting in very strong terms that the N.F.L. should underwrite the educational expense of those underclassmen who do come out early, whether they're drafted or whether they're free agents.''
But the N.F.L., apparently weary of the quasi-minor league function college football performs, has come upwith a plan that may succeed where years of N.C.A.A. reform have failed: getting college football out of the minor league business.
The N.F.L. is underwriting the World League of American Football with the idea that it will serve as a minor league.
Some college administrators secretly welcome a minor league that would finally get their schools out of sports-entertainment business.
''I would be not at all unhappy,'' said Weir, the Illinois chancellor.
''If someone told me tomorrow,'' he said, ''that all around the country we're going to give up major network coverage of football and basketball, and that the billion-dollar contract is going away, I'd say, 'We'll adjust to that.' I believe that the money is creating a problem. We've got to do something about it.''
 
Greener Pastures For Fighting Irish
Two months after Penn State was invited into the Big Ten, Notre Dame struck its own deal with NBC, leaving the 63 other C.F.A. members with a less lucrative ABC package.
Notre Dame's move left C.F.A. members stunned at first, then angered, finally frightened. The Irish had gobbled up an entire network for $7.6 million per year with NBC which will offer live national coverage of all home games beginning in 1991.
''Notre Dame didn't think of itself as a catalyst, or anything like that,'' said the Rev. E. William Beauchamp, the Notre Dame executive vice president.
''We did not look at what we were doing as starting the wave, or realigment. We had the need for academic scholarships that is a major effort of fund raising, this was a good time to do that.''
The Federal Trade Commission, meanwhile, has been investigating whether ABC-TV's agreements with the C.F.A., the Pac-10 and the Big Ten violate Federal antitrust regulations. The two contracts - one with the C.F.A. and another with the Pac-10 and Big Ten - give that network rights to 84 of the 106 Division I-A teams.
For all of the talk of reform and cutbacks, actions suggest that universities who can afford it are building up for an offensive that may last several years. ''Everybody is building indoor practice facilities for football, and bigger sports complexes,'' said Dr. Arnold Weber, the president of Northwestern University. ''We just did that here,'' he said. ''We've resisted the indoor practice facility, but we're building a major aquatics and sports center. So it's absurd to think that things are being contracted.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
ABC Thrives on Its Edge in News

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
An extraordinary thing happened on television this month: the networks' evening newscasts received higher ratings than the average prime-time entertainment show.
Viewers wanted news of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. And more of them wanted their news from ABC than from any other network.
ABC's evening newscast rose 20 percent in the ratings during the week after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Its late-night news program ''Nightline'' jumped 30 percent. 
CBS and NBC also received sharply higher ratings for their news programs, and CNN had its highest-rated week ever. But ABC's upper hand in ratings was matched by an edge in the coverage. Symbolized by Ted Koppel's coup last week in being the first American journalist to report on the crisis from Baghdad, ABC's advantage was conceded even by executives at other news organizations. ''ABC definitely deserves credit for being three laps ahead of everybody else,'' one NBC News executive said.
 
Consistent Ratings Leader
ABC's evening newscast is now established as the consistent ratings leader, having won the competition for 31 consecutive weeks.
''The gulf coverage has absolutely solidified ABC's edge, which really began to emerge as long as three years ago,'' said Robert Karl Manoff, director of the Center for War, Peace and the News Media at New York University. ''By now, there is really no question that they are the leader.''
Still, CBS scored its own coup. Its anchor, Dan Rather, also went to Baghdad last week and provided extensive coverage.
For ABC, however, the ascension of its news division could have long-term economic benefits if viewers' perception continues to grow that ABC is ahead in its news coverage.
''The image of superiority that a news department develops can spread out for months and months,'' said John S. Reidy, a media analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''That usually equates to higher sustained ratings, which is, of course, the real benefit.''
Developing that image has a high price. ABC News said it had spend more than $2 million on its gulf coverage by the end of last week. Those costs come at a time when its parent company, Capital Cities/ABC Inc., has been predicting a possible downturn in profits because of weaker summer ratings, soft advertising sales for its stations and a loss of about $20 million on the baseball package for ESPN, its cable channel.
But the news division may be able to make up more than its share of the extra costs, using the increased ratings to secure higher advertising revenues. Bruce Heim, a vice president at the Bozell advertising agency, noted that the surge in news ratings occurred at the very end of a network advertising-sales cycle, with a new cycle due to begin next month. ''With these numbers late in August, ABC will almost surely be able to exceed its ratings guarantees to advertisers,'' Mr. Heim said.
He added that the network would probably be able to increase its ad rates for its news programs.
The network newscasts moved ahead of prime time in the second week of August. The overall rating average for news was 28.8, compared with 28.1 for prime time. And ABC came out ahead with a news ratings of 10.6. One ratings point equals 921,000 homes with television.
The ratings week that ended Aug. 12 was only the second week in recent history in which the network newscasts attracted bigger ratings than the average prime-time program. The other time this occurred was during the 1988 Republican convention. But viewers then did not have much choice; most entertainment shows were pre-empted.
The competition to place a reporter in Baghdad was a microcosm of the news rivalry. ABC was a day ahead of CBS. Mr. Koppel arrived in Baghdad on Tuesday, and the next day he interviewed the Foreign Minister of Iraq, Tariq Iziz. He also talked with Americans being detained at a hotel, which upset Iraqi officials. By Thursday, the Iraqi Government asked Mr. Koppel to leave Baghdad.
Mr. Rather, meanwhile, almost single-handedly tried to counter ABC's advantage, going to great lengths to report the gulf story from the Middle East. He succeeded in getting into Baghdad on Wednesday, and also had an interview with the Foreign Minister later in the week. As of yesterday, he was still reporting from Baghdad.
But he was second on the scene, and CBS News is now perceived by some people in the industry to be second to ABC News.
NBC News was unable to get anybody into Iraq and was behind ABC in getting a correspondent into Saudi Arabia. Tom Brokaw of NBC arrived in Saudi Arabia one day after Sam Donaldson of ABC.
NBC executives have argued for months that based on the overall quality of its coverage, NBC should not be considered the third-ranked news division, even though it has the lowest newscast ratings and fewest number of news programs on the air. In trailing on the gulf story, that argument lost some credibility.
CNN, which has scored numerous triumphs in breaking news over the last several years, had to acknowledge that both ABC and CBS had the edge in Baghdad as its own attempts to get into Iraq were stymied.
''They did real good,'' said a CNN vice president, Ed Turner.
The change in leadership of network news has never been widely accepted in the television industry, even beyond CBS, largely because ABC has been fighting two entrenched images: CBS's historic superiority in news and ABC News as a newcomer of somewhat questionable pedigree.
For years after he became president of ABC News in 1977, Roone Arledge was criticized for bringing showmanship to news coverage. What he indisputably brought were shows; ABC News added more news programs on which to build identifible anchors and correspondents.
Indeed, one longstanding criticism of ABC News - that the division has been built on high-priced news ''stars'' to the detriment of the basics of good journalism - has been directly contradicted by ABC's success in covering the gulf crisis.
ABC executives noted that Mr. Koppel and Mr. Rather were able to get into Baghdad precisely because they are such high-profile figures.
''People ask about why it's important for an anchor to be at the scene of a story,'' Mr. Arledge said. ''But if you're Ted Koppel dealing with the Foreign Minister of Iran, it does make a difference.''
He added, ''A Ted Koppel gives you more entree than a beat reporter.''
Mr. Arledge said ABC held a built-in advantage over CBS and NBC in that it essentially had two main anchors - Peter Jennings, the evening news anchor, and Mr. Koppel - as well other high-profile names, including Mr. Donaldson, Barbara Walters and Diane Sawyer.
Joanna Bistany, a vice president of ABC News, said Mr. Arledge's strategy of building prominent anchors -even at million-dollar salaries - had been ''validated'' by their use in the gulf coverage.
But ultimately, it is the advertisers who will decide whether the strategy is cost effective.
