LENGTH: 905 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Iraq Crisis Gives Fed New Woes

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The dominant figure in the credit markets these days does not sit in the Federal Reserve's ornate office at the corner of Constitution Avenue and 20th Street in Washington, but in the Iraqi presidential palace in Baghdad.
As a consequence, the short-term course of interest rates will be determined more by international politics than by domestic economics, analysts say. ''The market will be detached from economic fundamentals for as long as the politics are as wacko as they are,'' one government bond trader said last week.
The shift is likely to be acutely felt tomorrow, when the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, gathers with fellow members of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee to set monetary policy and assess the state of the economy. 
 
Unable to Take Action
In the opinion of most credit market analysts, the members of the Fed group have much to discuss, but at least temporarily are prevented from taking action by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
Given the weak state of the economy, it seems clear that if there were no crisis in the Middle East the Fed would pay less attention to the stubbornly high rate of inflation and move to ease monetary policy quickly.
But the possibility that the full inflationary effect of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has not yet been seen preys on credit market participants, who fear that oil prices will move well above the $28.63-a-barrel level reached on Friday.
Fears of inflation and of war have helped push bond yields close to 9 percent since late July, and could raise them higher if the Fed decides to move soon to ease short-term rates, analysts said, effectively negating any benefits that an easing of monetary policy might bring.
 
'No Feel' for Reaction
Underlying every policy move by the Fed ''is an expectation that market interest rates outside of their control will move in conjunction with their movement,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. ''This time, Fed governors cannot have a fair level of confidence that that will happen. And if you have no feel for what the reaction will be, there is no reason to make the move.''
Most analysts agree that eventually the Fed will move to ease policy. But given the highly unsettled market, the central bank will probably choose a highly propitious moment to show its hand.
''The Fed needs the right kind of background to do it,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''If you ease policy in this environment, where the bond market is collapsing and the dollar is sliding, the reaction will be bad. But something like a weak employment report for August might allow them to do it in a credible way.''
The August employment report, the next important announcement on the economy, is expected to be released on Sept. 7.
 
Eventual Move Expected
Despite the inflation threat, the recent sharp upward spike in oil prices and interest rates has raised the odds of a recession and will force the Fed to move eventually, analysts said. ''The Fed is in a tough situation, but they can't afford to stop what they are doing and combat psychological and political events,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''They have to help this economy. That is their job.''
Another forecasting group last week joined the list of those who now expect a recession. In their weekly ''Comments on Credit,'' analysts at Salomon Brothers offered a revised forecast that projects three quarters of negative growth beginning in the fourth quarter of 1990.
''Forecasting recessions over the past eight years has been a losing game,'' Richard B. Berner, a Salomon economist, wrote in the weekly commentary. But, he added, ''the shock of higher oil prices seems likely to be the final straw that tips the U.S. economy into recession.''
 
Modest Revival Forecast
From the fourth quarter of 1990 through the second quarter of 1991, Salomon now expects the gross national product to contract at a 1 percent annual rate and then revive ''modestly'' in the second half of next year.
While the economic outlook seems decidedly bullish for bonds, and current yields are at highly attractive levels, some money managers said that for the time being they intended to remain on the sidelines.
''With as much skittishness as there is in the market, I think bond yields will go as high as 9 1/8 percent,'' said Roberta Olsen, a portfolio manager at the Banc One Asset Management Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. ''That should be the high point unless something unknown happens in the Iraqi situation. And at those levels we see value in bonds.''
Late last week, the Treasury's benchmark 8 3/4 percent bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.93 percent.
Developments in the Middle East and on world petroleum and foreign exchange markets seem likely to dominate trading activity in the fixed-income markets again this week. The economic calendar is light, and will be highlighted on Friday by the release of a revised set of second-quarter growth figures.
Most analysts expect that the numbers will show upward revisions in personal consumption expenditures and net exports. As a consequence, analysts are projecting that the Commerce Department will raise second-quarter growth to 1.5 percent, on an inflation-adjusted basis, up modestly from the preliminary estimate of 1.2 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Renewed Call For Chinese Stock Market

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
After two difficult years of stop-and-go progress, a group of ambitious economic experts has taken another small step toward developing a centralized securities market in China.
The Stock Exchange Executive Council, whose staff is largely young and Western trained, has just completed a white paper that includes a list of specific measures the Government could take to transform a loosely organized collection of securities dealers into a true market system.
If the proposals are accepted, the centralized exchange could be running before year-end. The stock exchange would be the second in a socialist country, after Hungary, and could begin another wave of reform for China's planned economy. 
 
A Lively Debate
How top Government officials will react to the proposals is uncertain, although the debate over the introduction of a securities exchange system has been relatively open and lively in recent months, with many articles in the Government-controlled press advocating the system. Some people here regard that as a moderately positive sign, given that such talk was throttled by political hard-liners after the crushing of the democracy movement last year.
''Any proposal being made now is being entertained,'' said Wang Poming, vice president of the organizing body, the Stock Exchange Executive Council. ''You're hearing some really bold things. We're becoming more optimistic.''
Gao Xiqing, the American-trained general counsel for the executive council, an independent research group, added: ''To some extent, in this area the debate is over the pace of reform, not whether or not it will take place.''
In the eyes of many Western and Chinese economists, the creation of a viable securities market would have the potential for radically altering the way financing is done in China, now handled through a Government monopoly on credit. Ultimately, it could be the start of major changes in the creaking state-controlled economy itself, introducing more efficient ways of allocating capital to businesses and, in turn, forcing businesses to become more efficient.
 
A Place for Savings
It would give individuals an alternative to banks as a place for their savings. This is important, since the level of savings has soared over the last year, in response to the Government's tightening of credit to battle inflation.
But Government banks have not found productive uses for all this money, according to articles in the Chinese press. Investing in a stock market would present greater risks for investors but would also offer them the potential of greater returns.
Around China, interest in establishing a market appears to be keen. A competition has already developed between Shanghai and Shenzhen, the special economic zone bordering Hong Kong, over which will be the first to open a full-fledged exchange. That has lent the idea some additional momentum.
 
White Paper
The white paper, which took nine months to complete, was produced at the request of the People's Bank of China, China's central bank, and the Ministry of Finance. It is the first comprehensive report on China's securities markets, describing the history of these markets and the nascent systems that have developed in recent years. It also suggests a series of steps to broaden the process, including:
* Completing the development of a computerized trading system, known as the Securities Trading Automated Quotation System, or STAQS, which would centralize the fragmented trading structures. Mr. Wang said he hoped this would be on line by the fall.
* Helping the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges open and create regulatory and trading mechanisms.
* Training staff members of securities companies how to trade, process those trades and keep records. Plans have already been made for establishing a training center in Shanghai later this year.
* Changing the system for selling government bonds - the principal security traded on the nascent markets in China - from an allocation system to underwriting by syndicates of securities companies. This would make the market more sensitive to supply- and-demand considerations and increase its liquidity.
 
New Sources of Financing
A centralized stock market would also diversify the sources of financing for corporations. Now, capital is effectively allocated by the Government.
A market would permit more efficient companies to draw capital from individuals and other institutions by issuing securities. It would also give efficient enterprises a means of expanding by acquiring other businesses.
A market also would give the Government a means of building private ownership of state-owned enterprises. That is not being discussed publicly at this point, but state-owned enterprises have become a budgetary albatross for the Government, recording huge losses every year. Selling all or part of them could force the companies to improve their operations and cut unnecessary layers of fat.
''We have an expression,'' said Mr. Wang, referring to a Chinese proverb. ''If you pull one hair, the whole body jumps.'' The point, he said, was that the introduction of private ownership would lead to a chain of events that have the potential for sharply improving the efficiency of Chinese industry.
 
Concept Is Not New
The concept of creating a securities market here is not entirely new. Two big steps were taken in 1986, the heady days when economic reform was being pushed vigorously. Small markets were opened in Shenyang, the capital of Liaoning Province in northeast China, and Shanghai. Then, in April 1988, the Government permitted open trading in its bonds.
The trading, however, has been regional and inefficient. The securities executive council found that the same security is often priced differently in different cities.
One speculator in Shanghai - referred to by the press as ''Millionaire Yang'' - became notorious for discovering price discrepancies and flying into cities where prices were too low. He would buy bonds at one price, fly back to Shanghai and sell the bonds for a tidy profit at a higher price. The Government has tried to squelch such arbitrage by placing limits on investors.
The Securities Exchange Executive Council hopes its proposals will eliminate such bugs in the system, while creating a smooth-running mechanism for pushing China further down the road of market reform.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Novelty in Leipzig: A Paper With No Party Line

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEIPZIG, East Germany

 BODY:
This is the time to be an entrepreneur in Eastern Europe, in newspaper publishing as in any other business. But at East Germany's largest independent weekly, youth and steady nerves are the most important assets.
Jan Peter, the 21-year-old chief editor and co-founder of Leipziger Andere Zeitung, has plenty of both, but at the moment, not enough ads.
''In the beginning, it was much easier,'' he said, recalling how he and his team of journalism students, writers and members of the New Forum democracy movement put out the first issue on Feb. 1, thanks largely to a $12,500 advertisement by the West German Kommerzbank. 
 
Western Competition
''Only a few weeks later, the West German newspapers began moving in,'' Mr. Peter said. ''We figured we had six to seven weeks to get well enough established with readers here so that we wouldn't disappear once the West German papers came in, and we made it. But I think it'd take 20 million marks, not just 20,000, to start a newspaper now.''
The weekly is commonly known as DAZ, an abbreviation for Die Leipziger Andere Zeitung, which translates roughly as ''The Other Newspaper in Leipzig.'' It has a press run of 40,000 in a city of about half a million people, and its staff says every issue sells out at one mark, or 63 cents, a copy. The dozen or so editors work full time, seven days a week.
What makes DAZ unusual is that Mr. Peter insists that he wants it to be independent of all political movements. Though Americans take such journals for granted, most readers in Europe assume that their publications are identified with some political party or ideology.
Mr. Peter's shoestring operation faces stiff competition - not only from established Leipzig daily newspapers formerly tied to the Communist Party and other parties, which have now been bought by West German media concerns, but also from the giant West German daily tabloids Bild Zeitung and Express, which now circulate freely in the East.
 
A Struggling Economy
With the East German economy still struggling with the transition from Communism, this means trouble for an enterprise that depends on advertising revenues. The big state-run businesses in Leipzig are all cutting costs and shedding staff, and a recent issue of DAZ had just one paid quarter-page advertisement, for a motor show sponsored by Renault.
Despite this, the spirit is lively and the mood optimistic in the newspaper's offices, in a cobblestone street of slowly crumbling buildings.
DAZ is serious but light-hearted, and intentionally provocative. One issue in July, for example, featured a front-page article critical of the maneuvering by East German political parties to seek the best vote count for themselves in the all-German elections planned for Dec. 2.
Another article in that issue examined the anti-Communist credentials of one of the most conservative politicians, Hansjoachim Walther, and noted sarcastically that they consisted of one anti-government conversation in the privacy of his home in 1953, when he was 13 years old.
 
'We Wanted to Be Independent'
Mr. Peter, a conscientious objector who once worked in a Leipzig hospital, became involved in the New Forum movement as opposition to East Germany's Communist government built up last year. He was one of five people who put out the movement's newsletter.
''After the Communist leadership fell, it became clear that to put out a real newspaper we couldn't stay within New Forum,'' Mr. Peter said. ''We wanted to be independent, so in December we founded Forum Press as a separate organization, with the intention of printing books and magazines as well as a newspaper.''
Mr. Peter, Peter Frabel, who runs the business side, and Holger Ahrens, the picture editor, invested their savings in the business and made DAZ a corporation in which Mr. Peter owns 40 percent of the shares.
A lanky young man whose speech never slows below rat-a-tat-tat speed, Mr. Peter is clearly driven by his ambition to create an East German newspaper that will resemble nothing else in its approach to the news.
 
Government Permission Needed
''It wasn't clear until the day before the first issue that we'd actually be able to put it out,'' he recalled. ''We had to get official permission to publish from the Media Ministry in Berlin, go up there and get it and then take it back here to Leipzig and show it to the printers before they would agree to publish it.''
The printing presses belong to the competition, the formerly Communist daily Leipziger Volkszeitung; they are the only ones in town.
Wearing a wrinkled lavender Russian student shirt and a pair of green chinos, the young editor did not look like a businessman who expected to get rich anytime soon.
''Because of the bank ad, the first issue was tremendously profitable,'' he said. ''We used the profits to buy Atari computers to do the layout on. At the moment, we're just about covering costs, no more.''
 
Newspaper to Expand
He said DAZ would expand in September to 24 pages from 16, adding more articles to supplement the cultural calendar, movie reviews, historical and political essays and news reports the paper publishes.
''We need more international advertising, maybe from British and American companies that want to do business here,'' Mr. Peter said. ''And we're looking abroad for seed money from foundations or individuals interested in helping build up a really original, independent kind of new journalism here.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1816 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
BUSH VOWS NOT TO BE COWED BY THE TAKING OF 'HOSTAGES'; IRAQ SHIFTS THEM TO TARGETS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 20

 BODY:
As Iraq began moving Americans and other foreigners to military and industrial installations, President Bush declared for the first time today that those trapped in Iraq are indeed hostages. He vowed that ''America will not be intimidated'' by Iraq's efforts to use them as shields against attack.
Government statements from Washington, Paris and London indicated that Iraq had moved at least 203 citizens of those countries, including 12 Americans seized from the Hyatt, International and Hilton hotels in Kuwait.
But it was not known how many more foreigners trapped by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait were being used as what Mr. Bush called ''pawns'' in the war of nerves between President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the Arab-Western alliance ranged against him. #2,500 Americans in Kuwait There are about 2,500 Americans in Kuwait and 530 in Iraq, including 35 who had been in Iraqi hotels and are believed to have been moved elsewhere by the Iraqi authorities, the State Department says. 
''The foreign guests of Iraq have indeed been hosted in various vital and military installations,'' a spokesman for the Iraqi Parliament told the official Iraqi News Agency today, in a dispatch monitored in Washington and relayed to the President's vacation White House here. The Iraqi announcement gave no numbers on the captives.
Iraq reiterated its demand that foreign countries close their embassies in Kuwait by Friday, warning that diplomats there would lose their protected status and become vulnerable to arrest along with other foreigners. #9 Nations Refuse But Mr. Bush and officials of at least nine other nations - Austria, Britain, Denmark, Finland, Italy, Spain, Sweden, the Soviet Union and West Germany - rejected the demand. Mr. Bush called the threat ''unacceptable,'' but did not say what the United States would do if Iraq moved against the diplomats.
Sharpening his denunciation of Iraq in a speech in Baltimore to the annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Mr. Bush warned that he was holding Mr. Hussein responsible for the safety of the trapped Americans.
After two days of withholding comment on the Gulf crisis, Mr. Bush denounced the invasion of Kuwait as ''ruthless,'' and said a country that used ''citizens as pawns'' would face the world's scorn and condemnation. He said he had a message for Iraqi leaders: ''Release all foreigners now. Give them the right to come and go as they wish.''
But as two United Nations officials headed to Baghdad to press for the foreigners' release, Mr. Bush did not back his oratory with any explicit threat of retaliation.
The United States, still working to deploy its full military force in Saudi Arabia, continued to put off taking any military action against the most immediate Iraqi targets, two oil tankers that American warships have been shadowing for two days in the waters around the Arabian Peninsula.
 
Hope of U.N. Action
Washington was still hoping for United Nations approval to force the tankers to stop before they reach their ports this week. But the United Nations Security Council took no decisive action today on a British proposal to put military teeth into the economic sanctions it imposed on Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2.
The United States Navy continued to allow ships with cargos bound for Iraq to enter the Jordanian port of Aqaba on the Red Sea.
In permitting that hole in their economic net around Iraq to remain open, Mr. Bush and his advisers seemed reluctant to take any action that might cause domestic turmoil for King Hussein of Jordan, who has been torn between his avowed allegiance to the nations arrayed against Baghdad and the threat that could be posed by troops in neighboring Iraq.
 
Bush Returns to Maine
Mr. Bush returned to his vacation home in Kennebunkport today after the speech in Baltimore and a fund-raising event in Rhode Island. He brushed off concerns that his continued vacation in Maine and his political swing in the midst of an international crisis were unseemly. ''Life goes on,'' Mr. Bush told a Republican audience in North Kingstown, R.I.
In Baltimore, he delivered a speech replete with patriotic themes and references to American military prowess in past wars. He relied heavily on quotations from historic figures like Theodore Roosevelt and George Washington, offering little in the way of soaring language of his own to rally public support for what he said would be remembered as one of the most important military operations of the 20th century.
Mr. Bush let his voice rise and his fist pound his lecturn as he denounced Presiident Hussein's efforts to use the foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait as a shield against military attack. ''I want there to be no misunderstanding,'' he said. ''I will hold the Government of Iraq responsible for the safety and well-being of American citizens being held against their will.''
Reports from the Middle East have said that Iraq was planning to move some of the thousands of foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait to military and industrial installations in the hope of making a military attack too costly for the United States and other countries.
 
No More Euphemisms
Mr. Bush pointedly dropped the euphemisms his Administration had been using - ''inconvenienced people'' for example - to describe the more than 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The President had been choosing his words carefully to avert the kind of hostage standoff that has so tightly hobbled American action in the Middle East in the past.
''We've been reluctant to use the term 'hostage,' '' Mr. Bush said. ''But when Saddam Hussein specifically offers to trade the freedom of those citizens of many nations he holds against their will in return for concessions, there can be little doubt that whatever these innocent people are called, they are in fact hostages.''
On Sunday, Mr. Hussein said he would let the hostages go if the United States withdrew its military force from Saudi Arabia and lifted the economic embargo. Mr. Bush is hoping the trade sanctions will force the Iraqis to withdraw from Kuwait by cutting off oil sales and imports of food, ammunition, spare parts and others supplies.
Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One, on the trip from Baltimore to Kennebunkport, he said Mr. Hussein's conditions were ''totally unsatisfactory to most countries in the world.''
''We must not delude ourselves,'' Mr. Bush said in Baltimore. ''Iraq's invasion was more than a military attack on tiny Kuwait. It was a ruthless assault on the very essence of international order and civilized ideals. And now, in a further offense against all norms of international behavior, Iraq has imposed restrictions on innocent civilians from many countries. This is unacceptable.''
 
Predicts 'Hard Choices'
Warning that the military deployment to the Persian Gulf would be lengthy and would require ''American planning, patience and, yes, personal sacrifice,'' he said: ''The outcome is not yet decided. Hard choices remain. But of this we are certain: American will not be intimidated. When some ask, where does America stand, our answer is, America stands where it always has, against aggression, against those who would use force to replace the rule of law.''
In the speech to the political fund-raiser in a country club in North Kingstown, the President said: ''It was not with passionate haste, but really with a heavy heart that I had to commit our troops to Saudi Arabia. I took this action not out of some national hunger for conflict, but out of the moral responsibility, shared by so many committed nations around the world, to protect our world from fundamental evil.''
He sought to borrow the religious arguments that Mr. Hussein has evoked in his oratorical attacks on the United States and Saudi Arabia. Addressing Iraqi leaders, Mr. Bush said: ''In moving foreign citizens against their will, you are violating the norms of your own religion. You are going against the age-old Arab tradition of showing kindness and hospitality to visitors.''
He insisted later that he was not deliberately intensifying his attacks on Mr. Hussein by referring to the Americans as hostages for the first time. But he said that he and his advisers had met Sunday night to discuss the issue and that he decided this morning that the conditions the Iraqi leader was setting for their release merited the use of the emotionally charged word.
 
'Definition of Hostages'
''There's a recognition of the fact that now demands are being made for the release of people, and I think that is the definition of hostages,'' he told reporters aboard Air Force One.
In his speech in Baltimore, Mr. Bush made a point of praising the extraordinary Soviet-American cooperation that Administration officials have credited with doing much to smooth the path to forging the international alliance against Mr. Hussein.
He said that by condeming the Iraqi invasion, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ''has shown, if anyone doubted it, that nations which joined to fight aggression in World War II can work together to stop the aggressors of today.''
In Moscow, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze appealed today to the visiting Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Saddoun Hammadi, to free the foreigners in his country and in Kuwait. The official press agency Tass said he had ''expressed satisfaction'' to Mr. Hammadi that Soviet citizens were being allowed to leave Iraq and Kuwait and asked for ''a similar decision in relation to citizens of other states.''
Mr. Bush, who has often sought to compare Mr. Hussein to Hitler, evoked the World War II theme several times in his speech today. ''Half a century ago, the world had a chance to stop a ruthless aggressor and missed it,'' he said. ''I pledge to you: We will not make that mistake again.''
He ended his speech with a partisan attack on Democrats in Congress, with whom he remains locked in a dispute over efforts to cut the Federal budget deficit. Although Congress has been in recess during the current crisis, Mr. Bush suggested that lawmakers had not yet realized that the threat of war in the Middle East would make it difficult to make deep cuts in the fiscal 1991 budget, and that careful planning would be needed for future years so the United States can meet such military challenges.
''Make no mistake,'' he said. ''To prevent aggression, to keep America militarily prepared, I will oppose the defense budget slashers who are out of tune with what America needs to keep freedom secure and safe.''
The President has adamantly refused to cancel his vacation out of fear of appearing to be imprisoned in the White House, as Jimmy Carter seemed to be during the Iranian hostage crisis.
Upon returning to Kennebunkport, he threw himself back into his vacation schedule, roaring off into the Atlantic Ocean aboard his speedboat, Fidelity.

PUB-DATE: August 21, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1412 words

HEADLINE: Export Restrictions Fail to Halt Spread Of Supercomputers

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The growing ease with which it is possible to design and build supercomputers is making it increasingly difficult for the United States and Japan to keep the powerful machines from proliferating. That raises the possibility that more nations may be able to use supercomputers to design advanced weapons systems.
In recent years companies and state-financed development efforts in Britain, Germany, France, Sweden, Bulgaria, India and Brazil have been able to build machines at least as fast as their American and Japanese counterparts in some ways, although they are not yet believed to have the sophisticated software needed to take advantage of the advanced hardware.
In many cases, these computer builders rely on off-the-shelf microprocessor chips widely available in the United States and elsewhere. Not powerful enough to come under the strictures on technology exports, the chips can be strung together to achieve supercomputer-level performance. 
''It used to be that the U.S. was the storehouse for all technology,'' said Michael C. Sekora, a former official of the Defense Intelligence Agency. ''Now advanced technologies are ending up in third world countries. It's no longer simple to control.''
Supercomputers, capable of performing hundreds of millions of mathematical operations a second, are used to solve the most complex scientific and engineering problems. Since Japan entered the market in 1984, the United States and Japan have controlled the market for supercomputers and have been able to restrict the machines by establishing export controls. The machines have been sold, under strict conditions on their use, to some nations, but they have not been exported to Eastern Europe and only in rare instances to the developing world.
A secret agreement between the United States and Japan was negotiated in 1984 to limit supercomputer sales. The two countries plan to hold discussions in Hawaii next month on a variety of topics, including a re-examination of the 1984 agreement, an Energy Department official said. Government officials said new agreements with countries gaining supercomputer competency would be sought.
The agreement has blocked the sale of supercomputers to Israel, largely because Israel has refused to sign the nuclear nonproliferation treaty.
 
Restraints Are Ebbing
But restraints are ebbing because of the increasing power of fingernail-size microprocessor chips that can be easily linked to work in tandem in computers called parallel processors, greatly multiplying their speed.
Such components are now readily available at electronics parts outlets in the United States and are also manufactured in other countries. They are beginning to appear in personal computers and are virtually impossible to control, Commerce Department officials say.
''The genie is out of the bottle,'' said Paul Freedenberg, a specialist on trade and technology who had been an export control official under the Reagan administration. ''There was enormous leverage used by the U.S. to control supercomputer technology over the last decade. That is not going to be exercised by European countries because they don't feel the risk.''
The winding down of the cold war has added fuel to a debate within the United States Government over whether the curbs on technology exports remain valid and whether the restrictions should be shifted from the traditional East-West axis to North-South lines, with a focus on keeping the equipment from Libya, Iraq and much of the third world.
 
'Disconcerting and Bewildering'
''It's a recent phenomenon, and it's a bit disconcerting and bewildering for those of us who have to run the regulatory regime,'' said Dennis E. Kloske, Under Secretary of Commerce for export administration. ''It raises all kinds of questions if we are no longer the sole provider of fire.''
Some arms control experts and weapons specialists dispute whether supercomputers are vital tools for designing advanced weapons systems.
Jack Worlton, a researcher at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, noted that the first thermonuclear weapon was designed in the early 1950's with a computer no more powerful than a modest personal computer widely in use today.
But some arms control experts said technology curbs were useful, making it more difficult for nations without nuclear weapons to develop them.
''I don't think anyone wants Iraq to have a supercomputer,'' said Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, which tracks the spread of nuclear weapons to developing countries. ''We ought to maintain the controls until it is obvious that they have been superseded by developments.''
 
When Hardware Is Widespread
Mr. Milhollin and Mr. Kloske agreed that if supercomputer hardware became so widespread that it could no longer be controlled, governments seeking to control the spread of advanced weapons should focus on the software the powerful machines would need to perform complex weapons-development tasks.
Mr. Worlton was pessimistic about the possibility of controlling software. ''The actual weapons codes are classified,'' he said. ''But they are composed of such components as hydrodynamics, neutron transport and thermodynamics programs. All these things are easily available. I don't think there is any way to control that kind of software.''
In addition to the concerns about weapons proliferation, some computer industry executives say the United States' restraints on supercomputer makers could damage the industry, which relies on exports for 45 percent to 55 percent of its sales.
''You don't want to penalize innovation in the marketplace,'' said Debra Waggoner, senior manager for trade policy at the American Electronics Association. ''Right now the control system penalizes the first to market.'' 66 Million Calculations a Second Among the relatively powerful chips that are popular with computer makers abroad is the Intel Corporation's i860 microprocessor, introduced two years ago. The first version of the chip is capable of performing 66 million mathematical operations a second.
Later this year, Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is planning to introduce a faster version of the i860 that will reach speeds above 100 million math operations a second.
Under United States export regulations, any machine capable of processing more than 100 million mathematical operations a second is considered to be a supercomputer. Computers that have processing speeds above 150 million operations a second may be sold only under a special security plan that requires the buyer and the buyer's government to restrict access to the building that houses the computer and requires detailed audits of the programs run on the machine.
 
A British Manufacturer
The manufacture of high-speed microprocessors is not restricted to the United States and Japan. Inmos Ltd., a British semiconductor maker, offers a microprocessor chip known as the Transputer that is designed specially to be connected in large arrays. A single version of the current model reaches speeds of five million math operations a second, and a model the company is expected to announce shortly will reportedly exceed 100 million operations a second.
A number of United States and foreign companies are now designing high-performance computers that chain together dozens or even hundreds of the i860 and Transputer chips, reaching speeds that compete with the fastest supercomputers made.
Meiko Ltd., the most successful British maker of parallel supercomputers, has now hooked more than 600 Transputer and Intel chips together in a computer capable of processing more than four billion math operations a second. The machine is currently operating at Edinburgh University.
Supercomputer technology is also no longer limited to Western nations. Last year, Bulgaria began shipping a computer known as an array processor that has a peak speed of 576 million math operations a second. And T. J. Rogers, the president of Cypress Semiconductor Inc., a Silicon Valley chip maker, recently returned from a trip to the Soviet Union, where he said he had visited a computer center with a working supercomputer capable of performing more than a billion math operations a second.
The United States companies that make supercomputers include the Cray Research Corporation, based in Minneapolis, the Thinking Machines Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., and the International Business Machines Corporation.

HEADLINE: Buenos Aires Journal;
Where Horatio Alger Heroes Want to Pack It Up

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20

 BODY:
For Yolanda and Alfredo Di Sanso, their 10 years as business owners have been a losing struggle against political instability, runaway inflation, recession and government economic policies that were protectionist one day and free-trade the next.
So they are ready to pack it in and emigrate from Argentina, a one-time promised land.
All they ask is to be able to put their proven entrepreneurial skills to work in a growing country where business does not come to a halt before each change of government and every new president does not mean new rules for the game.
''This has me demoralized,'' said Mr. Di Sanso, 47 years old. ''We've faced a crisis on and off for 10 years.'' 
The Di Sansos are middle-class Argentines, people who built their house with their own hands and their business from scratch.
 
More Think of Leaving
Their kind of Argentines - people who work in small businesses and low-paid professionals - increasingly think of leaving a country that once gave them more opportunity than any other Latin American country could offer.
Conversations with many such people indicate that slowly, over months, they are seeking out connections abroad - in the United States, Europe, Canada, Australia - that could turn into jobs. Their dissatisfaction and declining faith in Argentina do not translate into an avalanche of people at the foreign consulates seeking visas. Instead, they are reflected in the regular departures of small numbers of professional staff members from such places as hospitals, universities and research institutes.
For the very poor and uneducated, living in growing numbers in the shantytowns that ring Buenos Aires and other major cities, emigration is not much of an option. The neighboring countries offer no opportunities for them, and this is too far from the United States to consider illegal immigration by land.
''There's a lot of frustration floating in the air here,'' said Dr. Oscar S. Ledesma at a hospital in the provincial city of Santiago del Estero. ''Any doctor or researcher young enough to start over somewhere else is thinking about leaving.''
 
'Argentine State Is Finished'
Dr. Elsa Segura, who directs a specialized institute in Buenos Aires that belongs to the Ministry of Health, said two biologists and one medical doctor, out of a professional staff of 34, had left the institute in the last eight months to work in the United States. Two others left for private organizations in Argentina.
''The Argentine state is finished,'' she said, referring to the Government's inability to continue adequate financing of education, medical care and scientific research. Professionals on her staff are generally earning less than $400 a month.
The Government of President Carlos Saul Menem, which inherited a collapsed economy, immense debts and a bureaucracy unable to collect taxes or control expenditures when it took power last year, has promised to turn the economy around and join the world trend toward free markets and open trade. Officials have said they hope that selling off money-losing state companies and attracting foreign investment will eventually revive the economy.
But for the Di Sansos and their three children, the rosier future is too far off and too uncertain. They want to emigrate to the United States and complete the Horatio Alger dream that Alfredo has had since his youth.
 
Start as an Errand Boy
For a while, Mr. Di Sanso's dream seemed to be going along pretty well in Argentina. He started his working life as an errand boy for an advertising agency and rose through the ranks.
''I always read those stories from the United States about the boys who began at the bottom and ended up owning the company and thought I could do the same,'' he said.
So he and Mrs. Di Sanso, who is 43, started their own company to design and produce display materials used by stores to sell name-brand products - such things as bright banners to string in supermarkets advertising Coca-Cola or temporary racks to sit on the floor or counters of pharmacies and stores to hold and display cosmetics, razors, cold cream and lingerie.
They typically designed a sample to show a company and then went into production when they had a contract. In one case, he had to invent the machine to produce the display materials, usually made of cardboard or lightweight synthetic materials.
 
Happy Working Day and Night
''It was the happiest time of my life,'' he said. ''Sometimes I worked from 6 A.M. to 10 P.M. and on weekends.''
A labor strike almost crippled their first big product introduction, Mrs. Di Sanso recalled, but the whole family worked day and night to finish the supplies on schedule.
But almost before they were successful, the orders began to fall off. At first, he said, any 10 proposals requested by manufacturers would result in 9 orders for their company. Then it declined steadily to about 4 contracts for every 10. Now, he said, it is a scramble to get one paid order for every 10 proposals he prepares.
The Di Sansos do not have their bags packed yet, but they are trying to find some assurance of similar work in the United States and to sell their machinery and home here. He says they are qualifying for an immigrant visa under the United States visa lottery, talthough they do not have it in hand.
The lottery, called the Berman lottery after Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat who was the chief sponsor of the legislation, was set up by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to increase immigration prospects for people from countries such as Argentina that have supplied few immigrants to the United States. Consular officials here said about 500 immigrant visas would go to qualifying Argentines under the lottery.
''We are in very bad shape,'' Mr. Di Sanso said. ''The factory is not operating most of the time. I have a desperate, permanent search for orders. We have no chance to grow, and what I want is to grow.''

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
At U.S. Request, Security Council Holds Preliminary Talks on Crisis

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Tuesday, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The Security Council gathered informally Monday night for preliminary discussion of American proposals for enforcing the trade embargo against Iraq, diplomats said early today. The talks adjourned without a formal meeting.
Ambassador Crispen Tickell of Britain said there no longer was any urgeny in voting on the resolution, Reuters reported. The United States sought endorsement of sanctions for military action it might take while American vessels shadowed two Iraqi tankers in waters near the gulf. 
One tanker was said to be headed for Yemen and was scheduled to discharge oil there later today. But in the consultations that began on Monday night, Yemen said it would respect the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations, indicating that the tanker would not be allowed to unload its cargo.
 
Use of 'Minimum Force'
The diplomats said the United States, one of the council's five permanent members, presented three papers with proposed language for a Council resolution on the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. The third version included language that would call on all member states that have deployed naval forces in the gulf to use ''minimum force'' to ''insure strict enforcement'' of the economic embargo, they said.
Diplomats said that a paragraph in the third version of the American proposal said that the Security Council ''calls with immediate effect upon all member states which are deploying maritime forces to the area to use such minimum force as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to verify the cargoes and destinations of all inward and outward maritime shipping and to insure strict enforcement'' of related measures under the trade embargo against Iraq.
The representative of Cuba, which currently holds one of the 10 rotating seats on the Council, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, repeatedly denounced the American proposal for a resolution, which he described as illegal and unnecessary.
The Yemen diplomat, Abdallah al Ashtal, told reporters that his country would implement the trade embargo on Iraq. He did not say how his country would accomplish this.
The consultations, which were urgently requested on Monday by the United States, came as a surprise to many of the Council's 15 members.
 
Unexpected Meeting
When the representatives of the Council's five permanent members met earlier Monday to discuss the terms of such a resolution, Sir Crispin Tickell, Britain's representative, had said, ''We are working on something, but we are not going to do anything else today.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 13, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
U.S. Citizens Being Moved Just Some of Those at Risk

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The 47 Americans in Iraq and occupied Kuwait who have been picked up and transferred to unknown locations are among a far larger group of foreigners, numbering in the hundreds, taken from hotels and residences and apparently placed in strategic military and industrial installations.
A total of 123 British citizens, the largest number of any nationality so far, were detained in Kuwait over the weekend. A British Foreign Office spokesman in London said 48 were relocated into two civilian buildings in Kuwait, which he declined to identify, while the rest had been stationed in unknown areas.
Some Britons and Americans have taken refuge in their respective embassies in Kuwait. 
 
British Aide Is Exercised
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government has promised to join the United States in enforcing the blockade against Iraq with naval power. The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, today strongly protested Iraq's roundup of foreigners. ''We have taken every opportunity over the weekend, in public and private, to point out to the Iraqis that this behavior is illegal and repulsive,'' he said at a news conference in London.
Mr. Hurd also said that Britain would not comply with Iraq's demand that all embassies in Kuwait be closed by Aug. 24. ''We are not accepting that instruction,'' he said. Britain will try to keep officials in Kuwait as long as possible in order to keep in touch with its citizens there and give what help they can, he said, adding, ''I say as long as possible. I don't know how long that will be.'' A total of 4,500 British citizens are trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
Announcing that six more French nationals were taken from a hotel in Kuwait on Sunday, Paris today rejected Baghdad's demand that it close its embassy in Kuwait and dismissed President Saddam Hussein's offer to release foreign hostages in exchange for a lifting of the trade embargo. Yesterday, the French Government disclosed that 27 of its citizens - 26 in Iraq and one in Kuwait - had been taken to undisclosed locations by Iraqi authorities last Thursday. A total of 560 French citizens - 290 in Iraq and 270 in Kuwait - are now trapped.
 
Many Arabs Getting Out
More than a million foreigners are in the two countries, although thousands of people, mostly Egyptians and other Arabs, have been managing to cross the Iraqi and Kuwaiti borders every day.
While other Western countries, including Denmark, Italy and West Germany, have said that they would not obey Iraq's order to close their embassies in Kuwait, third-world countries and Japan have generally been more cautious in their responses.
In a sign of the difficulty that Japanese foreign policy officials are having over how to respond to the Persian Gulf crisis, a Foreign Ministry official today said it would take a week or more to decide on how to support the military embargo against Iraq. Last week, the Foreign Ministry had indicated that Japan would send nonmilitary personnel soon.
A Japanese official said there was concern that a more active role by Japan could threaten the safety of its 500 citizens currently in Kuwait and Iraq.
 
Caution in Manila
The Philippines, which has 93,000 citizens in Iraq and Kuwait, has hesitated to allow the use of American military bases there in Operation Desert Shield, the American operation intended to protect Saudi Arabia. Manila has also sought partial exemption from the sanctions mandated by the United Nations. In part, Philippine officials say, this is to get food to Filipinos unable to leave the two countries.
More than 150,000 Indian citizens remain in Iraq and Kuwait, Inder Kumar Gujral, India's Foreign Minister, visited Baghdad on Sunday and is planning to travel to Kuwait. The Indian Government would not discuss what Mr. Gujral said in Baghdad. His mission is said to be the freeing of Indians.
President Hussein has offered to release citizens from nations that do not take sides in the conflict, such as the estimated 1,300 citizens from Indonesia, Austria, Switzerland, Sweden, Finland and Portugal.
Hundreds of Soviet citizens have also been freed in recent days, for which the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, thanked a visiting Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister in Moscow today.
 
Moscow Keeping Options Open
Mr. Shevardnadze also said after the meeting that parts of the conditional offer by President Hussein to release trapped Westerners deserved attention and that Soviet experts were considering it.
''We are studying all the details and parts of the Iraqi President's speech,'' Mr. Shevardnadze told the Soviet press agency Tass after three hours of talks with Deputy Prime Minister Saadun Hammadi of Iraq. ''Later, we shall respond in an appropriate manner.''
On Sunday, President Hussein offered to free Westerners held in Iraq if foreign countries withdrew their forces from the Persian Gulf and abandoned economic sanctions adopted against Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait.
Mr. Shevardnadze described his talks with Mr. Hammadi, held at Iraq's request, as useful and necessary.

PUB-DATE: August 21, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 816 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Libya Denounces Iraq's Decision to Take Westerners as Hostages

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, today condemned Iraq's decision to make hostages of Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait and said that he would dispatch Libyan troops to the Persian Gulf if the United Nations requested them as part of a blockade against Iraq.
''I am against bargaining using civilians, workers or hostages; this is a fixed position,'' Colonel Qaddafi told reporters gathered under a marquee at a military barracks in Tripoli.
The reporters were brought here for the day aboard Libyan planes dispatched by Colonel Qaddafi to several points in the Middle East and Europe, suggesting that the 47-year-old Libyan leader has been frustrated in not being able to make his voice heard in the crisis over Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. 
About 70 reporters flew in from Paris, Cairo, Malta and Tunis, and were taken by bus to the Bab-Alazaizia barracks, one of the Libyan targets attacked by United States warplanes on April 15, 1986, in retaliation for terrorist attacks that the United States accused Libya of supporting. .
 
No Alignment Indicated
Seated under a green-and-white striped marquee about 100 yards from the shattered shell of the house that he had been using at the time of the American attack, Colonel Qaddafi appeared at pains not to align himself too clearly with either side in the gulf crisis. While criticizing the United States, Britain and other allied nations for dispatching forces to the area and halting shipments bound for Iraq without a formal United Nations vote in favor of a blockade, he renewed his criticism of Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.
''I'm not here trying to defend Iraq's occupation of Kuwait by means of force, because that is something condemned by the Arab League charter,'' he said in remarks in Arabic that were translated into English.
The vigor with which Colonel Qaddafi once attacked the United States appeared muted, and his positions on the current crisis appeared intended to present him as a peacemaker.
 
'Colonial Ambitions' Cited
That seemed particularly evident in his remarks about the moves made by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to make hostages of Americans and other Westerners. In answer to an American reporter's question, Colonel Qaddafi said that he had tried to telephone Mr. Hussein in recent days, but that the calls had not gone through because ''the United States and its allies'' had jammed the telephone lines. ''I tried, but I failed,'' he said, switching briefly to English.
When asked what he would tell Mr. Hussein if he got through, Colonel Qaddafi replied: ''Should there be direct contact with Iraq, surely I should talk to Saddam, but there is no contact. I've already said I'm against using civilians in such cases.''
Iraq, he said, had ''put the matter on a golden platter,'' for the United States and its Western allies, which he said had long harbored ''colonial ambitions'' in the Middle East, while the United States' dispatch of troops to the area had ''given Iraq justification'' for its actions.
 
Peace Plan Failed
The Libyan leader said the United States' actions were ''a clear violation'' of the United Nations Charter because military action in support of the economic sanctions voted by the Security Council would be legitimate only if the Council followed up with a new resolution under Article 42 of the Charter, giving United Nations sanction to a blockade. While he did not say directly that Libya would support an Article 42 resolution, Colonel Qaddafi implied that it would when he said that Libya, if requested by the Security Council, would provide troops for a United Nations force.
At an earlier stage of the crisis, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization put forward a peace plan, under which Iraq would have been expected to withdraw from Kuwait in return for which Kuwait would have ceded two strategic islands in the Gulf to Baghdad and have paid Iraq large sums to settle an oil dispute between the two nations. Diplomats here said the plan also provided for elelctions under Arab supervision for a new Kuwait Government.
The plan died when an Arab summit meeting convened in Cairo by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt voted 12 to 3 to condemn the Iraqi invasion and to dispatch a joint Arab military force to Saudi Arabia. Libya joined the P.L.O. and Jordan in voting against.
Before reporters left the heavily defended barracks, officials gave them a tour of the shattered house nearby, in which an adopted daughter of the Libyan leader died during the bombing attack. The house has been preserved as a dusty museum, and the closest that the visit came to the old anti-American sentiment was in painted signs lying in the courtyard, one of which read, ''America Go to Hell!'' Inside was a display of wreckage from a downed F-111 fighter used in the raid, including the shattered flying helmet of one of the two crewmen who died.

PUB-DATE: August 21, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1193 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Few From Left or Right Protest Bush's Big Stick

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
So far, the critics of American military involvement in Saudi Arabia have been few and relatively soft-spoken, pending further developments in the confrontation with Iraq, notably its duration.
Only a few people and a handful of peace and anti-nuclear groups have voiced firm opposition. ''We were quick, too quick, to move to a military solution,'' said Nick Carter, executive director of SANE/Freeze, one of the largest peace groups, claiming 150,000 members.
Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General who has long been a critic of American military interventions, also opposed the military moves. ''I think it's a serious mistake for the United States to place its military in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf,'' he said. ''We can't police the world.'' 
But over the last few days, even as military transport planes continued to lift off United States runways bound for Saudi Arabia, few American politicians, officials or commentators were sharply critical of President Bush's decision. And polls showed broad support among the public.
 
Conservatives Worried
Some of the strongest reservations come from conservatives who question the President's tactics or whether he should make such a large military commitment to aiding the royal families of Kuwait or Saudi Arabia.
Patrick J. Buchanan, the syndicated columnist who was Ronald Reagan's director of communications, said Mr. Bush had acted brilliantly in diplomatic terms, but added, ''I'm concerned with the extent of rhetorical commitment he's making.'' In his column on Saturday, he wrote of Mr. Bush's statement comparing Iraq to Nazi Germany. ''By using the Hitler analogy, Bush is virtually ruling out any negotiated settlement,'' he wrote.
And Charles Oliver, assistant editor of Reason, a monthly libertarian magazine, expressed little fondness for the Kuwaiti leader displaced by the Iraqi invasion. ''I don't see the point of intervening because the emir may be a nicer thug than Saddam Hussein,'' he said.
Many Democrats said they backed American involvement in the gulf but thought more effort should be made to enlist the support of other nations.
 
Getting Caught Alone
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said he was worried that the United States seemed to be paying less and less attention to operating under the umbrella of the United Nations. At first, he noted, President Bush referred to the United Nations Charter and international law in responding to Saudi Arabia's request for help against an Iraqi invasion.
Then came the naval blockade of Iraqi ports. ''And for reasons I can't understand we haven't wanted to get U.N. sanction,'' the Senator said. ''Something has faltered.'' He added, ''The Americans would be mad to be caught alone.''
Coretta Scott King said the danger faced by Americans stranded in Kuwait and Iraq would be reduced by a stronger commitment to United Nations sanctions. ''With this commitment, a little patience and restraint could go a long way to resolving this crisis without endangering the lives of American hostages and soldiers,'' said Mrs. King, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Even many people once vocal in their opposition to United States military involvement overseas, whether in Vietnam or Grenada, expressed at least general support for Administration actions, while speculating that criticism would quickly mount if the confrontation became a long stalemate.
 
Defense, Not Offense
The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., the former Yale University chaplain who rose to national prominence as an organizer of Vietnam War protests, said he supported the President's troop decision, as long as the force remained defensive and multilateral. ''Deterrence, yes,'' he said. ''Intervention, no.'' Deterrence, he went on, was bolstering Saudi Arabia; intervention was trying to push Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
''The world is still a dangerous and savage place,'' Mr. Coffin added, ''and we need actions to contain it. But they need to be the proper kind of actions.''
George S. McGovern, the Democratic candidate for President in 1972 who had opposed the Vietnam War, said, ''I support President Bush's decision to take a stand in Saudi Arabia.'' The former South Dakota Senator, who now travels on the international lecture circuit and owns a hotel in Stratford, Conn., added: ''I hope we keep the diplomatic option open. No really important problem facing the U.S. today would be resolved by war in the Middle East.''
Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President who headed the Democratic Presidential ticket in 1984, said he also ''basically supports'' United States actions so far but thinks the Administration should use the United Nations more energetically.
 
Spin Into Recession
''The more isolated Saddam Hussein becomes,'' Mr. Mondale said, ''and the more this becomes a world effort and not just a Western effort, the better.''
The Rev. Jesse Jackson endorsed the troop deployments but warned, ''The longer we stay there, sand has a way of sinking.''
He said the United States created considerable Middle Eastern animosity with its selective involvement, stepping in to deter an invasion of Saudi Arabia's oilfields while remaining silent about Israeli occupations of Lebanon and the West Bank.
''Our interests should be higher than just energy,'' he said. ''They should be humanity and self-determination as well.''
The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But he said the situation should have been an excellent opportunity to support the United Nations ''rather than mobilizing armed forces and considering hasty, impetuous military action.''
Dr. Lowery also cited petroleum as the driving force behind the confrontation. ''I do not think that we ought to be on the brink of war over the issue of oil,'' he said. ''And that's what this is about, not the rights of Kuwaitis.''
In a recent New York Times Poll, 76 percent of Americans approved of the trade embargo against Iraq, and 66 percent approved of sending troops to Saudi Arabia. But 40 percent said the Administration was too quick to send in the military and only 48 percent felt the Government had tried hard enough to reach a diplomatic solution. The telephone poll of 670 people was conducted Aug. 9 and 10 and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Deborah Huber, a 21-year-old housewife in Wichita, Kan., was among those in the poll with doubts. ''This is really hitting home for us,'' she said in a subsequent interview. ''My husband's brother, David, is being shipped over on the 24th this month. It's a very personal issue. We would disapprove no matter what country was involved. It's their war.''
Dennis Morganbesser, a 35-year-old New York City sanitation worker, said the troop deployment actually worsened the situation. ''By sending troops over,'' he said, ''it's like it's being blown out of proportion. They're a bunch of fanatics over there.''
He added, ''We should stay in the back and then move in, not go to the forefront right away like we always seem to do.''
